Speaker: NA
Text: Monday, 15 June 2009

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Mr Harry Jenkins)

Speaker: NA
Text: took the chair at 12 pm and read prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: MAIN COMMITTEE

Speaker: NA
Text: Private Members' Motions

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: In accordance with

Speaker: NA
Text: standing order 41(h), and the recommenda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of the whips adopted by the House on 3

Speaker: NA
Text: June 2009, I present copies of the terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: motions for which notice has been given by

Speaker: NA
Text: the members for Murray, Maranoa and Blair.

Speaker: NA
Text: These matters will be considered in the Main

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee later today.

Speaker: NA
Text: EMPLOYMENT AND WORKPLACE

Speaker: NA
Text: RELATIONS AMENDMENT BILL 2009

Speaker: NA
Text: Message from the Governor-General re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ported informing the House of assent to the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMITTEES

Speaker: NA
Text: Membership

Speaker: Mrs ELLIOT
Text: Richmond-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Ageing) (12.01 pm)-by leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That members be discharged and appointed as

Speaker: NA
Text: members of certain committees in accordance

Speaker: NA
Text: with the list which has been placed on the table.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the list is a lengthy one, I do not propose to

Speaker: NA
Text: read the list to the House. Details will be recorded

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Votes and Proceedings.

Speaker: NA
Text: SOCIAL SECURITY AND OTHER

Speaker: NA
Text: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: (PENSION REFORM AND OTHER 2009

Speaker: NA
Text: BUDGET MEASURES) BILL 2009

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill and explanatory memorandum-by

Speaker: NA
Text: leave-presented by Ms Macklin.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Text: Jagajaga-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Families, Housing, Community Services and

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous Affairs) (12.03 pm)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill implements key elements of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's secure and sustainable pension

Speaker: NA
Text: reform package announced in the 2009

Speaker: NA
Text: budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: This reform package addresses the ade-

Speaker: NA
Text: quacy of the pension, makes its operation

Speaker: NA
Text: simpler and more responsive to pensioner

Speaker: NA
Text: needs, and secures its long-term sustainabil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity.

Speaker: NA
Text: It prepares Australia to meet future chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenges, including the ageing population,

Speaker: NA
Text: through amendments to social security, fam-

Speaker: NA
Text: Assent

Speaker: NA
Text: ily assistance, veterans' affairs and aged-care

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition to providing significant in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creases in pensions, the reforms will make

Speaker: NA
Text: the pension system simpler, fairer and more

Speaker: NA
Text: flexible.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's 3.3 million age pensioners,

Speaker: NA
Text: disability pensioners, carers, wife and widow

Speaker: NA
Text: B pensioners, bereavement allowance, spe-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial needs pension and veteran income sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port recipients will benefit from increases in

Speaker: NA
Text: their pension payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: The pension reform measures in this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: implement the reforms to social security and

Speaker: NA
Text: aged-care laws. A further bill, to be intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced at a later date, will deliver the pension

Speaker: NA
Text: reform measures for veterans and their de-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendants.

Speaker: NA
Text: Most of the pension reforms, including the

Speaker: NA
Text: important pension increases, will be intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced from 20 September 2009. Other meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures will commence on the dates as speci-

Speaker: NA
Text: fied.

Speaker: NA
Text: Increased pension payments

Speaker: NA
Text: From 20 September 2009, the secure and

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainable pension reforms will deliver total

Speaker: NA
Text: increases of $32.49 a week for singles who

Speaker: NA
Text: receive the maximum rate of pension, and

Speaker: NA
Text: $10.14 a week combined for couples on the

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum rate.

Speaker: NA
Text: These increases are on top of regular in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dexation due in September. The total in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease will comprise a rise in the base rate

Speaker: NA
Text: for single pensioners and a new, and in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased, pension supplement for all pension-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers. This increase brings the single rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: pension up to two-thirds of the combined

Speaker: NA
Text: couple rate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The maximum base rate of the pension

Speaker: NA
Text: payable to single people will be increased by

Speaker: NA
Text: $30 a week. In addition, singles will receive

Speaker: NA
Text: an increase of $2.49 a week in the new pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion supplement, bringing their total increase

Speaker: NA
Text: to $32.49 a week. The $10.14 a week in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease for couples combined will be pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided through the new pension supplement.

Speaker: NA
Text: These increases are on top of all existing

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions and allowances.

Speaker: NA
Text: Following these reforms, the new total

Speaker: NA
Text: weekly pension plus supplement will be an

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated $336.68 for singles and $507.50

Speaker: NA
Text: for couples combined. This amounts to

Speaker: NA
Text: $17,507.36 a year for singles, and

Speaker: NA
Text: $26,390.00 for couples combined. The actual

Speaker: NA
Text: figures to apply from 20 September will de-

Speaker: NA
Text: pend on indexation. Actual cost of living

Speaker: NA
Text: increases and wages figures are not yet

Speaker: NA
Text: available.

Speaker: NA
Text: New indexation and benchmarking

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: New indexation arrangements will be in-

Speaker: NA
Text: troduced to better reflect cost of living in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creases for pensioners. As part of the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's reform package, a new pensioner

Speaker: NA
Text: and beneficiary living cost index will be cal-

Speaker: NA
Text: culated by the Australian Bureau of Statis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tics. This new index will measure increases

Speaker: NA
Text: in the living costs faced by pensioner and

Speaker: NA
Text: beneficiary households, which can be differ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent to those faced by other households.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new living cost index will be more re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsive to changes experienced by pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner households where the living costs may

Speaker: NA
Text: have moved faster than the rate of changes

Speaker: NA
Text: measured by the consumer price index for

Speaker: NA
Text: the living costs of all households. From 20

Speaker: NA
Text: September 2009, the maximum base rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant social security and veterans pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions will be adjusted in line with either the

Speaker: NA
Text: the consumer price index or the new pensioner

Speaker: NA
Text: and beneficiary living cost index, whichever

Speaker: NA
Text: is the higher.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pension rates will also continue to be

Speaker: NA
Text: benchmarked to male total average weekly

Speaker: NA
Text: earnings.

Speaker: NA
Text: From 20 March 2010, a new pension

Speaker: NA
Text: benchmark for the maximum combined cou-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple rate of pension will be introduced. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: be 41.76 per cent of the annualised amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of male total average weekly earnings.

Speaker: NA
Text: For a person being paid a single rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: pension, the maximum rate payable to that

Speaker: NA
Text: person will be set at 66.33 per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum rate payable to a combined cou-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple. Therefore, the new benchmark for the

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum single rate of pension will be 27.7

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of male total average weekly earn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings, an increase of more than 10 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: from the current 25 per cent benchmark.

Speaker: NA
Text: Current arrangements will continue to ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: ply for parenting payment (single) and for

Speaker: NA
Text: the disability support pension paid to people

Speaker: NA
Text: under age 21 without children.

Speaker: NA
Text: New pension and seniors supplements

Speaker: NA
Text: The range of supplementary payments and

Speaker: NA
Text: allowances currently paid to pensioners will

Speaker: NA
Text: be simplified and made more flexible

Speaker: NA
Text: through the introduction of a new pension

Speaker: NA
Text: supplement.

Speaker: NA
Text: This will help make pension payments

Speaker: NA
Text: easier to understand. Following the reforms,

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners will receive two main payments:

Speaker: NA
Text: the base pension and the pension supple-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: This new pension supplement incorporates

Speaker: NA
Text: the value of the existing GST supplement,

Speaker: NA
Text: pharmaceutical allowance, utilities allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance and telephone allowance (at the higher

Speaker: NA
Text: internet rate). Increases of $2.49 a week for

Speaker: NA
Text: singles and $10.14 a week for couples com-

Speaker: NA
Text: bined will be paid on top of the value of ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: isting allowances.

Speaker: NA
Text: The pension supplement will be indexed

Speaker: NA
Text: in March and September each year in line

Speaker: NA
Text: with increases in the consumer price index.

Speaker: NA
Text: will be available only to people resident in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia or temporarily overseas.

Speaker: NA
Text: The pension supplement for a single pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner will be around two-thirds, 66.33 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, of the pension supplement for a couple

Speaker: NA
Text: combined. This mirrors the new single to

Speaker: NA
Text: couple ratio established for pension rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: At 20 September 2009, it is estimated the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension supplement will be worth up to

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,462.70 a year for singles (or $28.13 a

Speaker: NA
Text: week) and $2,199.60 a year for couples (or

Speaker: NA
Text: $42.30 a week). This is an estimate as the

Speaker: NA
Text: actual indexation increase is not yet known.

Speaker: NA
Text: The pension supplement will be included

Speaker: NA
Text: in the pension payment rate and subject to

Speaker: NA
Text: income and assets testing. This means that,

Speaker: NA
Text: once the base pension rate is reduced to nil,

Speaker: NA
Text: the pension supplement will decrease until it

Speaker: NA
Text: reaches a minimum payment of an estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: $790.40 a year for singles (or $15.20 a week)

Speaker: NA
Text: and $1,190.80 a year for couples (or $22.90 a

Speaker: NA
Text: week). The payment a person receives will

Speaker: NA
Text: not fall below the minimum amount of the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension supplement until the person's in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come or assets reach a level that would oth-

Speaker: NA
Text: erwise reduce their payment to nil.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new pension supplement will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners with more flexibility in managing

Speaker: NA
Text: their own budgets.

Speaker: NA
Text: From 20 September 2009, the pension

Speaker: NA
Text: supplement will be paid fortnightly, along

Speaker: NA
Text: with the base pension. From July 2010, pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioners will have the choice of receiving

Speaker: NA
Text: around half of the pension supplement in

Speaker: NA
Text: quarterly instalments. This flexible part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the pension supplement will be equal to the

Speaker: NA
Text: minimum payment of pension supplement.

Speaker: NA
Text: Self-funded retirees will also benefit from

Speaker: NA
Text: these reforms. A new seniors supplement for

Speaker: NA
Text: holders of a Commonwealth seniors health

Speaker: NA
Text: card will be introduced from 20 September

Speaker: NA
Text: It 2009. The seniors supplement will replace

Speaker: NA
Text: the seniors concession allowance and tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: phone allowance (at the higher internet rate)

Speaker: NA
Text: for eligible recipients. The seniors supple-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will continue to be available as a quar-

Speaker: NA
Text: terly payment and will be paid at the same

Speaker: NA
Text: rate as the minimum amount of the pension

Speaker: NA
Text: supplement. The seniors supplement for a

Speaker: NA
Text: single person will be 66.33 per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: seniors supplement for a couple combined.

Speaker: NA
Text: In September 2009, the seniors supplement

Speaker: NA
Text: will be an estimated $790.40 a year for sin-

Speaker: NA
Text: gles and $1,190.80 a year for couples.

Speaker: NA
Text: Increases in the pension supplement

Speaker: NA
Text: minimum amount for couples combined and

Speaker: NA
Text: for singles will flow through to increases in

Speaker: NA
Text: the seniors supplement. This will mean pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioners cannot receive less supplement than

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible self-funded retirees.

Speaker: NA
Text: Change to the pension income test

Speaker: NA
Text: As part of the secure and sustainable pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion reform package, the pension income test

Speaker: NA
Text: will be tightened. This will help ensure the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension system is sustainable in the longer

Speaker: NA
Text: term, and that increases can be targeted to

Speaker: NA
Text: those most in need. These changes apply to

Speaker: NA
Text: recipients of social security age pension, dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ability support pension, wife pension, carer

Speaker: NA
Text: payment, widow B pension, bereavement

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance and special needs pension. This

Speaker: NA
Text: change does not apply to recipients of par-

Speaker: NA
Text: enting payment (single).

Speaker: NA
Text: From 20 September 2009, the pension in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come test taper rate will increase from 40c

Speaker: NA
Text: 50c for each dollar of income over the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come test free area. Under the new rules,

Speaker: NA
Text: where a pensioner has ordinary income over

Speaker: NA
Text: the income test free area, their rate of pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion will reduce by 50c for each dollar of

Speaker: NA
Text: income above the free area. In the case of a

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioner couple, their combined pension

Speaker: NA
Text: will reduce by 50c for each dollar of income

Speaker: NA
Text: (combined) over the income test free area.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pensions paid to each partner will reduce by

Speaker: NA
Text: 25c for each dollar of income (couple, com-

Speaker: NA
Text: bined) over the income test free area.

Speaker: NA
Text: To bring the pension income test into line

Speaker: NA
Text: with other means-tested payments, including

Speaker: NA
Text: allowances and family assistance, the addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional income test ‘free area' for dependent

Speaker: NA
Text: children will be removed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Transitional arrangements will be put in

Speaker: NA
Text: place to protect existing pensioners who

Speaker: NA
Text: would otherwise have faced a payment re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction because of the changes to the income

Speaker: NA
Text: test. The transitional safety net will ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that current payment rates for part-rate pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioners are maintained in real terms, with

Speaker: NA
Text: indexation in line with increases in the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer price index, and that they benefit from

Speaker: NA
Text: an increase of $10.14 per week for singles or

Speaker: NA
Text: couples combined. They will continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: receive these existing entitlements, including

Speaker: NA
Text: the increase, until they are better off under

Speaker: NA
Text: the new pension rules, including the new 50c

Speaker: NA
Text: income test withdrawal rate.

Speaker: NA
Text: New ‘work bonus'

Speaker: NA
Text: Some pensioners choose to take up paid

Speaker: NA
Text: work to supplement their pension. A new

Speaker: NA
Text: work bonus will be introduced to help age

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners keep more of the money they earn

Speaker: NA
Text: from work. The work bonus will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: concessional treatment of employment in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come under the income test for pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: over age pension age.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under these new rules, employment in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come will be assessed fortnightly for pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: to sioners over age pension age. Only half of all

Speaker: NA
Text: employment income (up to a maximum of

Speaker: NA
Text: $500 a fortnight) will be assessed in the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come test.

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, a single age pensioner who

Speaker: NA
Text: works part time with a fortnightly income of

Speaker: NA
Text: $500 will have only half of their income, or

Speaker: NA
Text: $250, from this job assessed under the pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion income test. This means that the pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner will be up to $125 per fortnight better

Speaker: NA
Text: off just as a result of the new work bonus,

Speaker: NA
Text: even after taking into account the tightening

Speaker: NA
Text: of pension income test rules.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further amendments in the bill are made

Speaker: NA
Text: to close the Pension Bonus Scheme. The in-

Speaker: NA
Text: troduction of the scheme in July 1998 was

Speaker: NA
Text: intended to encourage older Australians who

Speaker: NA
Text: would otherwise retire and claim age pension

Speaker: NA
Text: to remain in the workforce and defer claim-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the payment. The Harmer pension review

Speaker: NA
Text: found the scheme is not meeting its objective

Speaker: NA
Text: of encouraging workforce participation

Speaker: NA
Text: among older Australians. As a result, it will

Speaker: NA
Text: be closed to new entrants from 20 September

Speaker: NA
Text: 2009. Existing members of the scheme will

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to remain in the scheme and claim a

Speaker: NA
Text: pension and their bonus when they finish

Speaker: NA
Text: working.

Speaker: NA
Text: Age pension age

Speaker: NA
Text: As part of these reforms, and to improve

Speaker: NA
Text: the longer term sustainability of the pension

Speaker: NA
Text: system, the qualifying age for age pension

Speaker: NA
Text: will increase for both men and women from

Speaker: NA
Text: 65 to 67 years. This will be done on a grad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ual basis, with the qualifying age for age

Speaker: NA
Text: pension increasing by six months every two

Speaker: NA
Text: years, commencing on 1 July 2017 and will

Speaker: NA
Text: be fully implemented on 1 July 2023. Phas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the change in over this period will allow

Speaker: NA
Text: affected individuals time to plan for their

Speaker: NA
Text: retirement.

Speaker: NA
Text: The change will ensure age pension age is

Speaker: NA
Text: adjusted to reflect the significant improve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in life expectancy that have occurred

Speaker: NA
Text: since the age pension was first introduced in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1909. It will allow the government to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spond to the long-term cost of our demo-

Speaker: NA
Text: graphic challenges. This change will not im-

Speaker: NA
Text: pact on current age pensioners, and will only their fees.

Speaker: NA
Text: affect people born on or after 1 July 1952.

Speaker: NA
Text: The phase-in of the increased age mirrors the

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of increase of the pension age for

Speaker: NA
Text: women, which is currently increasing and

Speaker: NA
Text: will reach 65 years on 1 July 2013.

Speaker: NA
Text: The pension age for veterans will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing as a result of these changes. The

Speaker: NA
Text: male veteran age will remain at 60 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pension age for female veterans is currently

Speaker: NA
Text: 58½ years and is gradually increasing to

Speaker: NA
Text: align with male veteran pension age of 60 by

Speaker: NA
Text: 2013. However, the pension age for nonvet-

Speaker: NA
Text: erans under the Veterans' Entitlements Act

Speaker: NA
Text: will increase in the same manner as the

Speaker: NA
Text: qualifying age for age pension under the So-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial Security Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: More flexible advance arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: Existing arrangements for advance pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments will be improved, to give pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: greater access to advances of certain social

Speaker: NA
Text: security payments. Advance payments are

Speaker: NA
Text: lump sum prepayments of a pensioner's enti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tlements, which are repaid in instalments

Speaker: NA
Text: from future pension payments. The im-

Speaker: NA
Text: provements will increase the maximum al-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowable advance from $500 to around $1,000

Speaker: NA
Text: for singles and $1,500 for couples combined.

Speaker: NA
Text: The actual maximum advance amounts will

Speaker: NA
Text: be linked to movements in social security

Speaker: NA
Text: pension rates. They will also enable pension-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers to access more than one advance in any

Speaker: NA
Text: 12-month period. The changes will modern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ise the advance payment system to better

Speaker: NA
Text: reflect the needs of pensioners, helping them

Speaker: NA
Text: meet large or unexpected expenses.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pension reform implications for aged care

Speaker: NA
Text: As our population ages, it is vital that we

Speaker: NA
Text: support a strong residential aged-care sector

Speaker: NA
Text: that provides appropriate care for frail older

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. It is also important that those

Speaker: NA
Text: older Australians who reside in aged-care

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities have some money left after paying

Speaker: NA
Text: The government has decided to share the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension increase between aged-care provid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers and pensioners. This ensures that pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioners in aged-care homes are able to bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fit from the pension increase, while at the

Speaker: NA
Text: same time recognising that care providers

Speaker: NA
Text: also need additional funding to contribute to

Speaker: NA
Text: the costs of services such as nursing care,

Speaker: NA
Text: food and cleaning.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of the pension increase for singles, $10.09

Speaker: NA
Text: per week will flow to the pensioner and

Speaker: NA
Text: $22.40 per week will flow to the residential

Speaker: NA
Text: aged care provider through an increase to the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic daily fee.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the daily fee charged to self-funded re-

Speaker: NA
Text: tirees is linked to the amount of the age pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion, an increase in the age pension would

Speaker: NA
Text: normally mean the fees faced by self-funded

Speaker: NA
Text: retirees would increase.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government recognises that a sudden

Speaker: NA
Text: cost increase for existing self-funded retiree

Speaker: NA
Text: residents would be an unfair burden, and has

Speaker: NA
Text: decided that those self-funded retirees in

Speaker: NA
Text: residential aged care on 19 September 2009

Speaker: NA
Text: will have their existing fee levels protected

Speaker: NA
Text: until they leave. Those who enter aged care

Speaker: NA
Text: after this date will have any cost increase

Speaker: NA
Text: phased in over four years.

Speaker: NA
Text: The arrangements for self-funded retirees

Speaker: NA
Text: will also apply to part-rate pensioners who

Speaker: NA
Text: do not benefit from the pension increase.

Speaker: NA
Text: During this period, aged-care providers

Speaker: NA
Text: will be compensated by the government,

Speaker: NA
Text: through a new top-up supplement, for any

Speaker: NA
Text: difference between the actual fee paid by

Speaker: NA
Text: these new part-rate pensioners who may not

Speaker: NA
Text: receive the full pension increase and by self-

Speaker: NA
Text: funded retirees and the new standard basic

Speaker: NA
Text: daily fee-that is, the difference between the

Speaker: NA
Text: phased rate and the standard rate.

Speaker: NA
Text: A combination of increased fees paid by

Speaker: NA
Text: residents and the new top-up supplement

Speaker: NA
Text: represents an increase of $713.2 million over

Speaker: NA
Text: four years for the aged-care sector. This will

Speaker: NA
Text: be available to meet the rising costs that

Speaker: NA
Text: aged-care providers face. At the same time,

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners will have extra money to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: their out-of-pocket expenses.

Speaker: NA
Text: Changes to family payment indexation

Speaker: NA
Text: The government is taking important steps

Speaker: NA
Text: to reform family payments to make them

Speaker: NA
Text: more sustainable for the long term. As part of

Speaker: NA
Text: these changes, from 1 July 2009 under provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions of this bill, the maximum rates of fam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ily tax benefit part A will only be indexed in

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with movements in the consumer

Speaker: NA
Text: price index. For rates of payment for chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren under 16 years, current benchmarks to

Speaker: NA
Text: the combined pensioner couple rate (which

Speaker: NA
Text: enable benchmarking to male total average

Speaker: NA
Text: weekly earnings) will be removed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The removal of the link to earnings en-

Speaker: NA
Text: sures that government expenditure on family

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance is more sustainable in the long

Speaker: NA
Text: term. The indexation of maximum payment

Speaker: NA
Text: rates in accordance with movements in the

Speaker: NA
Text: consumer price index will continue to main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain the real value of assistance for families

Speaker: NA
Text: on low and moderate incomes. In a tight fis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal environment, savings from reduced ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: penditure on family tax benefit can be di-

Speaker: NA
Text: rected to funding other priorities, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: secure and sustainable pension reforms. Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's spending on family payments is gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: erous by international standards. The most

Speaker: NA
Text: recent analysis shows our spending on cash

Speaker: NA
Text: family benefits was equal third highest in the

Speaker: NA
Text: OECD, at 2.2 per cent of GDP, well above

Speaker: NA
Text: the average of 1.3 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: The indexation date for the maternity im-

Speaker: NA
Text: munisation allowance will be changed from

Speaker: NA
Text: twice a year to once a year. In line with other

Speaker: NA
Text: family payments, the maternity immunisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion allowance will now be indexed on 1

Speaker: NA
Text: July. The first annual indexation will occur

Speaker: NA
Text: on 1 July 2010.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other measures

Speaker: NA
Text: Recipients of social security and veterans

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlements payments, who receive pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments under certain Western Australian pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grams, will have these amounts excluded

Speaker: NA
Text: from the income test for the purposes of cal-

Speaker: NA
Text: culating their rate of payment. The Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian programs are the Cost of Living

Speaker: NA
Text: Rebate Scheme and the Country Age Pension

Speaker: NA
Text: Fuel Card. The income test concession will

Speaker: NA
Text: start on 1 July 2009 and end on 30 June

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill also includes amendments relat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to the adjusted taxable income test for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth seniors health card,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether issued under the Social Security Act

Speaker: NA
Text: or the Veterans' Entitlements Act. The

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments will include in adjusted taxable

Speaker: NA
Text: income any reportable superannuation con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tributions, including income salary sacrificed

Speaker: NA
Text: to superannuation. These amendments are

Speaker: NA
Text: relocated from the Social Security and Veter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ans' Entitlements Amendment (Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Seniors Health Card) Bill 2009, cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rently before the parliament, but which will

Speaker: NA
Text: be withdrawn. The measure is consistent

Speaker: NA
Text: with changes that have been legislated in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of a range of pension and allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: income tests, and arrangements that have

Speaker: NA
Text: the existed for the age pension for some time.

Speaker: NA
Text: To better support pensioners who are

Speaker: NA
Text: studying to improve their qualifications, the

Speaker: NA
Text: portability conditions for full-time students

Speaker: NA
Text: on Austudy and youth allowance will be ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tended to other income support payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: This will apply to a person receiving disabil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity support pension, parenting payment, carer

Speaker: NA
Text: payment, widow B pension, wife pension,

Speaker: NA
Text: partner allowance or widow allowance. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: person is in full-time study and continues to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet the qualification conditions for their

Speaker: NA
Text: payment, they will be entitled to go overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: for more than 13 weeks to study as part of

Speaker: NA
Text: their full-time Australian course.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will also amend schedule 2 to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans' Entitlements Act to include a new

Speaker: NA
Text: operational area. This will give Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Force members allotted for duty in the new

Speaker: NA
Text: operational area during the relevant dates

Speaker: NA
Text: access to pensions and benefits available

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: Conclusion

Speaker: NA
Text: This government has acted to introduce

Speaker: NA
Text: long-overdue reforms to significantly im-

Speaker: NA
Text: prove the adequacy of the pension and to

Speaker: NA
Text: make the pension system simpler and fairer.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reforms to provide long-term security and

Speaker: NA
Text: certainty, and to ensure that, over time, the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension system remains both adequate and

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainable.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reforms which tackle the reality of the

Speaker: NA
Text: ageing population and the challenges this

Speaker: NA
Text: presents.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reforms to adapt to changing circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances, while maintaining the system's en-

Speaker: NA
Text: during strength.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reforms to guarantee an adequate and

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainable standard of living for the aged,

Speaker: NA
Text: carers, veterans and people with disability

Speaker: NA
Text: who rely on the pension to survive.

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Forrest) ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: journed.

Speaker: NA
Text: INTERNATIONAL MONETARY

Speaker: NA
Text: AGREEMENTS AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: (FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE) BILL 2009

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 4 June, on motion

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Bowen:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr NEUMANN
Text: Blair) (12.27 pm)-

Speaker: NA
Text: When I left off my speech on the Interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Monetary Agreements Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Financial Assistance) Bill 2009 a week or so

Speaker: NA
Text: ago, I was saying that our relationship with

Speaker: NA
Text: Indonesia is of crucial importance to Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia's economic development and prosperity.

Speaker: NA
Text: In our region we are a neighbour to Indone-

Speaker: NA
Text: sia. They partner with us in all kinds of ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: eas, not just in sport and culture but also in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of tackling the challenges of climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change and education. There are 15,000 stu-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents from Indonesia alone studying here in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. That brings close to A$500 million

Speaker: NA
Text: into our economy each year. That is an

Speaker: NA
Text: enormous amount of money, contributed by

Speaker: NA
Text: Indonesian families to this economy, helping

Speaker: NA
Text: our prosperity, our economic development

Speaker: NA
Text: and our wealth in this country. So the impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance of our relationship with Indonesia can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not be underestimated.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have committed $462 million over the

Speaker: NA
Text: 2008-09 year in official assistance to Indone-

Speaker: NA
Text: sia. There have been many visits by senior

Speaker: NA
Text: cabinet ministers, including the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, to Indonesia and other parts of South-

Speaker: NA
Text: East Asia to show how important our rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions with the region are. Lest it be said that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are doing something unusual in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: partnering with the World Bank and other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries to provide this sort of facility-

Speaker: NA
Text: US$1 billion to Indonesia as a standby

Speaker: NA
Text: loan-and lest it be said that charity begins

Speaker: NA
Text: at home and somehow we should not be do-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing this, I say it is extremely important to

Speaker: NA
Text: show that we are a good neighbour to Indo-

Speaker: NA
Text: nesia and to build on the many ties that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have with Indonesia.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1989 the Australia-Indonesia Institute

Speaker: NA
Text: was established by the Australian govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Its aim was to develop relations be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween Australia and Indonesia and to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: mote greater mutual understanding and ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: panded areas of contact, and we have had

Speaker: NA
Text: Indonesian students under the program

Speaker: NA
Text: studying here in Australia, for example. Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, you and I had the privilege of being

Speaker: NA
Text: there on the 20th anniversary when the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian ambassador hosted the conference.

Speaker: NA
Text: The goodwill, the amity and the friendship

Speaker: NA
Text: that was there between Australia and Indone-

Speaker: NA
Text: sia was quite evident and we must do every-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing we possibly can to continue to improve

Speaker: NA
Text: the relationship.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our bilateral economic and trade relation-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship with Indonesia is extremely important.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indonesia was Australia's 13th largest mer-

Speaker: NA
Text: chandising trading partner in 2007, the 11th

Speaker: NA
Text: largest export market and the 11th largest

Speaker: NA
Text: source of imports. Our main merchandising

Speaker: NA
Text: exports to Indonesia are, of course, wheat,

Speaker: NA
Text: crude petroleum, live animals, aluminium

Speaker: NA
Text: and sugar. Our major imports from Indonesia

Speaker: NA
Text: are crude petroleum, gas pumps, non-

Speaker: NA
Text: monetary gold and simply worked wood. So

Speaker: NA
Text: it is important for us to acknowledge how

Speaker: NA
Text: vital Indonesia's relationship is with Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia. Our two-way merchandise trade totalled

Speaker: NA
Text: $8.8 billion in 2007. Exports were valued at

Speaker: NA
Text: $3.9 billion and imports at $4.8 billion. Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia was Indonesia's eighth largest export

Speaker: NA
Text: destination and ninth largest source of im-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports. So the relationship in terms of goods

Speaker: NA
Text: important, providing assistance to Indonesia

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that the impacts of the global fi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nancial crisis and the global recession are

Speaker: NA
Text: lessened on that country. Our two-way ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices trade in Indonesia exceeded $1.6 bil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion in 2007. We are providing assistance in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of education related travel and per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonal travel. Our major imports from Indone-

Speaker: NA
Text: sia in terms of services were personal travel

Speaker: NA
Text: and transportation as well. So our relation-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship with Indonesia is simply vital for our

Speaker: NA
Text: economic security as well as our prosperity.

Speaker: NA
Text: But what we are doing in terms of assis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance for education is simply vital also. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the education sector strategic planning has

Speaker: NA
Text: been undertaken by Indonesia. The Indone-

Speaker: NA
Text: sian people set a goal to ensure that all Indo-

Speaker: NA
Text: nesian children receive a minimum nine-year

Speaker: NA
Text: primary and junior secondary education.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is so important in increasing the pros-

Speaker: NA
Text: perity and productivity of the Indonesian

Speaker: NA
Text: people and ensuring that Indonesian children

Speaker: NA
Text: have a better chance in life. We are partner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing with Indonesia in our Australia-Indonesia

Speaker: NA
Text: Basic Education Program. That has an aspi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ration to ensure that there are 2,000

Speaker: NA
Text: schools-1,500 general and 500 madrasa

Speaker: NA
Text: schools-constructed to create 330,000 new

Speaker: NA
Text: junior secondary school places for 13to 15-

Speaker: NA
Text: year-old Indonesian children. We are financ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing through that program Indonesian schools

Speaker: NA
Text: and constructing them in consultation with

Speaker: NA
Text: local communities. It is important from the

Speaker: NA
Text: point of view of giving those children a

Speaker: NA
Text: chance in life. I have been to rural Central

Speaker: NA
Text: Kalimantan and to see the delight on the

Speaker: NA
Text: children's faces when they have new facili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties there is simply a wonderful experience to

Speaker: NA
Text: enjoy, and to realise that our dollars sent to

Speaker: NA
Text: this place and the work that we do in Indone-

Speaker: NA
Text: sia are very important in creating a great deal

Speaker: NA
Text: of goodwill towards Australia as well is most

Speaker: NA
Text: rewarding.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our partnership with Indonesia just does

Speaker: NA
Text: is not go to lending money and helping in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of education. It also goes to tackling

Speaker: NA
Text: the challenge of climate change. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged with Indonesia in the Kalimantan

Speaker: NA
Text: forest in a climate partnership. Our govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments have announced that we will help In-

Speaker: NA
Text: donesia in this regard. That was done at

Speaker: NA
Text: APEC in 2007 by the previous government.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have committed $30 million to the part-

Speaker: NA
Text: nership and we hope to attract an additional

Speaker: NA
Text: $70 million over time with other partners.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are trying to work with other partners to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the Peatland Project in Central

Speaker: NA
Text: Kalimantan is also dealt with in such a way

Speaker: NA
Text: as to conserve the environment there and the

Speaker: NA
Text: wetlands because they are just so important

Speaker: NA
Text: for orangutans and other fauna and flora. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are partnering with the World Wide Fund for

Speaker: NA
Text: Nature and the BOS Foundation as well as

Speaker: NA
Text: universities in rural Kalimantan. The largest

Speaker: NA
Text: source of greenhouse gas emissions in Indo-

Speaker: NA
Text: nesia is deforestation, estimated at 80 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of national greenhouse gas emissions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our partnership, the Indonesia-Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: Forest Carbon Partnership, is key to ensuring

Speaker: NA
Text: that we can tackle this problem and deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: this issue in a global way.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we are doing with Indonesia does

Speaker: NA
Text: not go just to education or climate change or

Speaker: NA
Text: cultural and interfaith assistance; we are also

Speaker: NA
Text: helping Indonesia in many ways, and not just

Speaker: NA
Text: in our trade but in other ways as well. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: partnering with them for national security,

Speaker: NA
Text: confronting the problem of people-

Speaker: NA
Text: smuggling and dealing with them through

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Federal Police, who have a pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence in Indonesia, tackling the problems of

Speaker: NA
Text: terrorism. We have seen over 200 terrorists

Speaker: NA
Text: prosecuted and convicted by the Indonesians,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the government's initiatives are to be

Speaker: NA
Text: commended with respect to tackling the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem of terrorism. We have seen that in

Speaker: NA
Text: Bali and we have seen it on so many other

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions. Our own embassy has been at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tacked over there in Jakarta in Indonesia.

Speaker: NA
Text: So our relationship with Indonesia is cru-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial for our economic development, our na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional security and in terms of being a good

Speaker: NA
Text: neighbour. In these circumstances this loan,

Speaker: NA
Text: which I note has bipartisan support, should

Speaker: NA
Text: be carried out and we can show just what

Speaker: NA
Text: good neighbours we are with Indonesia. We

Speaker: NA
Text: should also promote the kind of assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: that is crucial to cultural, sporting activities

Speaker: NA
Text: and other help. The legislation before the

Speaker: NA
Text: House does have bipartisan support. I note

Speaker: NA
Text: the comments made by the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: North Sydney in respect of this matter. He

Speaker: NA
Text: was quite equivocal and quite critical of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government in many ways in relation to this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation, but, despite his criticism of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Rudd Labor government, the coalition will

Speaker: NA
Text: support this legislation, and I commend it to

Speaker: NA
Text: the House.

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Text: Prospect-Minister for Fi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nancial Services, Superannuation and Corpo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rate Law and Minister for Human Services)

Speaker: NA
Text: (12.36 pm)-in reply-I thank all honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members who have contributed to this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate. The purpose of the International

Speaker: NA
Text: Monetary Agreements Amendment (Finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial Assistance) Bill 2009 is to amend the

Speaker: NA
Text: International Monetary Agreements Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1947-the IMA Act-to extend the current

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions that enable the Treasurer to lend

Speaker: NA
Text: money or enter into a currency swap with a

Speaker: NA
Text: country in support of an International Mone-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary Fund program. The amendments extend

Speaker: NA
Text: the current arrangements to include support

Speaker: NA
Text: for the World Bank and the Asian Develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Bank. The amendments will enable

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to provide a standby loan to Indo-

Speaker: NA
Text: nesia if needed, as well as to enter into a loan

Speaker: NA
Text: or currency swap with other countries to

Speaker: NA
Text: support World Bank or ADB programs in the

Speaker: NA
Text: future should the need arise. Consistent with

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1998 International Monetary Agreements

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill, this bill will allow Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia to continue to play its part in international

Speaker: NA
Text: cooperation efforts. It is in Australia's na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional interest to support stability and eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic recovery, particularly in our region, an

Speaker: NA
Text: issue on which there is an established history

Speaker: NA
Text: of bipartisanship.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill also extends the same conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: currently contained in the IMA Act that ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: ply to IMF programs. That is to say, there

Speaker: NA
Text: must be a request by the World Bank or the

Speaker: NA
Text: ADB for Australia's assistance. The agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment must allow Australia to require repay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment if the World Bank or ADB program is

Speaker: NA
Text: suspended or prematurely terminated. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer must be satisfied that the other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries or international organisations in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved will also be providing support to the

Speaker: NA
Text: recipient country as part of the World Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: or ADB program.

Speaker: NA
Text: Consistent with the IMA Act the bill will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to require public release and tabling

Speaker: NA
Text: in each house of parliament of a national

Speaker: NA
Text: interest statement relating to an agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: entered into by Australia under the bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Statements will include a description of the

Speaker: NA
Text: nature and terms of the agreement and set

Speaker: NA
Text: out why it is in the national interest, having

Speaker: NA
Text: regard in particular to foreign policy, trade

Speaker: NA
Text: and economic interests.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian government is tackling the

Speaker: NA
Text: financial crisis both at home and in coopera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion with others internationally. This bill will debt.

Speaker: NA
Text: enable Australia to contribute to World Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: and ADB financial assistance programs

Speaker: NA
Text: should the need arise. Provisions contained

Speaker: NA
Text: in the bill will ensure Australia is able to

Speaker: NA
Text: spond quickly to requests to participate in

Speaker: NA
Text: international cooperation efforts during times

Speaker: NA
Text: of crisis and that this assistance is in Austrapromises

Speaker: NA
Text: lia's national interest. I commend the bill to

Speaker: NA
Text: the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Message from the Governor-General rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ommending appropriation announced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Text: Prospect-Minister for Fi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nancial Services, Superannuation and Corpo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rate Law and Minister for Human Services)

Speaker: NA
Text: (12.39 pm)-by leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: (EXTENDED MEDICARE SAFETY

Speaker: NA
Text: NET) BILL 2009

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion

Speaker: NA
Text: by Ms Roxon:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: Dickson) (12.40 pm)-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Health Insurance Amendment (Extended

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare Safety Net) Bill 2009 represents

Speaker: NA
Text: yet another Labor attack on health care for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. The measures contained in this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill will put a cap on payments under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare safety net for a variety of medical

Speaker: NA
Text: services, putting those treatments out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: reach of a great many Australians and impos-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing yet another burden on ordinary Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians at a time when they can least afford it

Speaker: NA
Text: because of this government's reckless spend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, which is pushing this nation into record

Speaker: NA
Text: The government will make savings of

Speaker: NA
Text: $450 million over four years as a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: rethis measure. This bill comes just days after

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister and his Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health and Ageing shredded the solemn

Speaker: NA
Text: that they made over a lengthy pe-

Speaker: NA
Text: riod of time not to change private health in-

Speaker: NA
Text: surance rebate regimes, which encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians to take out health insurance and

Speaker: NA
Text: in doing so relieve some of the pressure on

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation's public healthcare system. Not

Speaker: NA
Text: content with that attack on one of the funda-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentals that have given Australia one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: best health systems in the world, the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment is now intent on bringing more pain

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australians requiring various medical

Speaker: NA
Text: treatments-in the main to elderly Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians needing cataract surgery and young

Speaker: NA
Text: couples either having children or needing

Speaker: NA
Text: help to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: Health featured heavily in this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's campaign for office with a lengthy

Speaker: NA
Text: list of the things that it would or would not

Speaker: NA
Text: do. Before the House now is a bill that does

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly what this government said it would

Speaker: NA
Text: not do. This bill represents yet another bro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ken promise on health from this government

Speaker: NA
Text: and Australians are now starting to realise

Speaker: NA
Text: that Mr Rudd would clearly say anything at

Speaker: NA
Text: all or do anything at all in his pursuit of

Speaker: NA
Text: power. Let us look at what the health minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter was saying with regard to the Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net in the run-up to the last election.

Speaker: NA
Text: Here is what she said to the Meet the Press

Speaker: NA
Text: program in September 2007:

Speaker: NA
Text: We are setting out a comprehensive plan and the

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net is part of that plan that we are commitones

Speaker: NA
Text: ted to and we will be running on for the election.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today we see what the minister's commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments mean. Let us look back again to Sep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tember 2007 and to one of those now infa-

Speaker: NA
Text: mous joint media releases from now Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Rudd and Minister Roxon:

Speaker: NA
Text: A Rudd Labor government will retain the Medi-

Speaker: NA
Text: care safety net as Australian working families-

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me repeat that: as Australian working

Speaker: NA
Text: families-

Speaker: NA
Text: have come to rely on it for help with their family

Speaker: NA
Text: budgets.

Speaker: NA
Text: The document goes on:

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Labor will not put more pressure on fam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ily budgets by taking that assistance away.

Speaker: NA
Text: One can only wonder what working families

Speaker: NA
Text: think right now. There has been no other pe-

Speaker: NA
Text: riod in recent times when working families

Speaker: NA
Text: have been under more pressure than they are

Speaker: NA
Text: right now. One million Australians earning

Speaker: NA
Text: less than $26,000 a year have private health

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance. This health minister says they will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be hurt by her attack on insurance re-

Speaker: NA
Text: bates. Wait until premiums rise by more than

Speaker: NA
Text: would have been necessary and let us see if

Speaker: NA
Text: they are not hurt then. She also says that the

Speaker: NA
Text: measures in these bills which cap payments

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Medicare safety net will not hurt.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tell that to Australia's senior citizens and

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners, one of the groups most impacted

Speaker: NA
Text: by this government action.

Speaker: NA
Text: The extended Medicare safety net was in-

Speaker: NA
Text: troduced by the former coalition government

Speaker: NA
Text: in 2004 to protect Australians from high out-

Speaker: NA
Text: of-pocket expenses for medical services pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided out of hospital. About one million Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians each year receive payments under

Speaker: NA
Text: the safety net to help them with their large

Speaker: NA
Text: medical bills-among them, no doubt, many

Speaker: NA
Text: working families, many senior Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: and pensioners and many young people start-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing or seeking to start a family. They are the

Speaker: NA
Text: who will be hit hardest by the caps the

Speaker: NA
Text: government now seeks to put on the Medi-

Speaker: NA
Text: care safety net.

Speaker: NA
Text: Caps are to be put on: all obstetric ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices; some pregnancy related ultrasounds;

Speaker: NA
Text: all assisted reproductive technology, includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing IVF; varicose vein treatment; and cata-

Speaker: NA
Text: ract surgery. Cataract surgery gets hit twice

Speaker: NA
Text: by this government-in these measures and

Speaker: NA
Text: elsewhere in the government's budget. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: unbelievable. Now the government blames

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors for the need to impose these changes

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Medicare safety net and Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: who incur high medical costs and benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: from it. ‘Doctors are taking advantage of the

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net; doctors are charging excessive

Speaker: NA
Text: fees' has become the somewhat repetitive

Speaker: NA
Text: refrain. Of course, it has nothing to do with

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's debt splurge that now re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quires them to find every cent of saving they

Speaker: NA
Text: can in this budget to fund the $300 billion of

Speaker: NA
Text: debt this nation will be saddled with in a few

Speaker: NA
Text: short years. Senior Australians needing cata-

Speaker: NA
Text: ract surgery must pay for this government's

Speaker: NA
Text: reckless behaviour, so too must young cou-

Speaker: NA
Text: ples seeking to start a family.

Speaker: NA
Text: These changes pose very important ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. Did the government really think

Speaker: NA
Text: through what these changes would mean?

Speaker: NA
Text: Are they sure of what they are doing here?

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us have a look at cataract surgery. Under

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill a cap is going to be placed on one

Speaker: NA
Text: cataract procedure, but this will combine

Speaker: NA
Text: with other budget measures to bring about

Speaker: NA
Text: significant changes. The government will

Speaker: NA
Text: halve the MBS rebates for this medical pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cedure from around $600 to around $300.

Speaker: NA
Text: Patients, many of them senior Australians-

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners and retirees-will have to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: hundreds of dollars out of their own pocket

Speaker: NA
Text: and for some procedures only a small part

Speaker: NA
Text: will now be recoverable from the safety net.

Speaker: NA
Text: Around 120,000 or more Australians un-

Speaker: NA
Text: dergo surgery each year, with 200,000 cata-

Speaker: NA
Text: ract operations. The majority of cataract op-

Speaker: NA
Text: erations-70 per cent-are done in the pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate system, with only 30 per cent done in

Speaker: NA
Text: public hospitals. There are substantial wait-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing lists for treatment in the public system.

Speaker: NA
Text: The effect of this would seem to be to drive

Speaker: NA
Text: patients to the already congested public

Speaker: NA
Text: health system. That is at the core of so many

Speaker: NA
Text: of the government's ill thought out decisions

Speaker: NA
Text: in health. At the last election they promised

Speaker: NA
Text: they would fix public hospitals by mid-2009

Speaker: NA
Text: and now, if we reflect on the 18 months since

Speaker: NA
Text: they made that announcement, every deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion they have taken in health will put only

Speaker: NA
Text: more pressure on the public health system.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Combined Pensioners and Superan-

Speaker: NA
Text: nuants Association of New South Wales has

Speaker: NA
Text: described these changes as ‘disastrous'. The

Speaker: NA
Text: association says that the costs will prove im-

Speaker: NA
Text: possible for pensioners and other low-

Speaker: NA
Text: income earners to meet and they will not

Speaker: NA
Text: receive what is an essential medical service.

Speaker: NA
Text: They believe services in regional and rural

Speaker: NA
Text: areas could be cut altogether. Noted eye sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: geon Dr Bill Glasson agrees. He has restored

Speaker: NA
Text: the sight of thousands of people in rural and

Speaker: NA
Text: remote areas of Australia. It is worth hearing

Speaker: NA
Text: what he has to say about what this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is doing. He told the ABC:

Speaker: NA
Text: The impact really is going to be on the battlers

Speaker: NA
Text: across Australia, particularly those in rural

Speaker: NA
Text: regional Australia, particularly Indigenous and it's

Speaker: NA
Text: just going to make things tougher and tougher.

Speaker: NA
Text: They've given the pensioners $30 on one hand

Speaker: NA
Text: and effectively taking $300 with the other hand-

Speaker: NA
Text: it is a very short-sighted decision and all this is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to do is drive more and more people out

Speaker: NA
Text: onto the public waiting list.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what this minister and the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister-this government that promised to

Speaker: NA
Text: fix health-are doing to the battlers, to the

Speaker: NA
Text: working families and to the pensioners of our

Speaker: NA
Text: country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Seventy per cent of people aged in their

Speaker: NA
Text: 80s will suffer cataracts. Surgery that re-

Speaker: NA
Text: stores vision has other beneficial outcomes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, if people who are ageing have

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty with their sight they are likely to

Speaker: NA
Text: have falls, fractures, hospitalisation and

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment for other outcomes of poor vision.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government is going to block those

Speaker: NA
Text: people from having this life-saving, and life-

Speaker: NA
Text: changing in many cases, surgery. It is incon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceivable that this government could believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that this is a measure that ultimately will re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sult in savings.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Society of Ophthalmologists has de-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed the government's action as a ‘huge

Speaker: NA
Text: blow' to patients. It says it will put the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of private cataract surgery beyond the reach

Speaker: NA
Text: of average Australians. Remember, 70 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of all current cataract surgery is carried

Speaker: NA
Text: out in the private sector. What does that say

Speaker: NA
Text: for the public sector from here? More pa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tients waiting longer. Ophthalmology already

Speaker: NA
Text: has the longest waiting times of any special-

Speaker: NA
Text: ist surgery. That is the result of this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's broken promises. This is hardly what

Speaker: NA
Text: you would call fixing health. There are the

Speaker: NA
Text: broken promises and then there is the hypoc-

Speaker: NA
Text: risy.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill is going to cap payments to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian couples who need help in starting a

Speaker: NA
Text: family. Assisted reproductive technology and

Speaker: NA
Text: and IVF will be hit hard. More than 40,000 peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple accessed IVF services last year with the

Speaker: NA
Text: support of the Medicare safety net. It is esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mated that 11,000 babies were born in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country as a result. Medical sources also es-

Speaker: NA
Text: timate that one in six couples will have fertil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity problems of some sort and need assis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance to start a family.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not need to speak against this meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure. I will let members of the Rudd cabinet

Speaker: NA
Text: do that. Their hypocrisy in putting this meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure forward is astounding. Only three years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago none other than the Deputy Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter was extremely vocal in her support for

Speaker: NA
Text: IVF. Now she sits on the sidelines, it seems,

Speaker: NA
Text: in silence as this measure is pushed through

Speaker: NA
Text: by her own government. Julia Gillard pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented petitions to this parliament in support

Speaker: NA
Text: of IVF treatment. At that time she spoke out

Speaker: NA
Text: against mooted changes to Medicare and

Speaker: NA
Text: said, ‘Labor opposes any cutbacks to Medi-

Speaker: NA
Text: care funding of IVF.' Let me repeat that for

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefit of the House and for all Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians listening to this debate: ‘Labor opposes

Speaker: NA
Text: any cutbacks to Medicare funding of IVF.'

Speaker: NA
Text: What a cruel hoax that was, Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. What a disgrace that you are now

Speaker: NA
Text: part of a government which is ripping apart

Speaker: NA
Text: the support to those people who are most in

Speaker: NA
Text: need. The Deputy Prime Minister also said

Speaker: NA
Text: only three short years ago:

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a cruel thing to do to Australian women

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly older Australian women, whose only

Speaker: NA
Text: hope of falling pregnant is through the IVF proc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ess.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was the Deputy Prime Minister's view,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was reflected by many who are now in

Speaker: NA
Text: government when they were on the back

Speaker: NA
Text: bench of the Labor opposition. Clearly, they

Speaker: NA
Text: have done a complete about-face. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: what makes the government such a joke

Speaker: NA
Text: when they talk about their commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: fixing health. Everything they have done

Speaker: NA
Text: over the last 18 months in the health program

Speaker: NA
Text: has put only extra pressure on an already

Speaker: NA
Text: overstretched system.

Speaker: NA
Text: No fewer than four Labor members pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented petitions to this House four years ago,

Speaker: NA
Text: among them Ministers Emerson and Burke,

Speaker: NA
Text: and perhaps even the current Treasurer, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Swan, joined the campaign in favour of IVF.

Speaker: NA
Text: Where are these people now? That is not my

Speaker: NA
Text: question but the question of thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: people who feel betrayed by this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, thousands of Australians who feel

Speaker: NA
Text: ripped off by this government. This clearly is

Speaker: NA
Text: a policy driven by Treasury, not by Health. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is a policy driven by Treasury and Finance,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it cannot have any basis in good health

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes. It cannot be the basis for this gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's decision to rip away support for

Speaker: NA
Text: needy Australians, the people who rely on

Speaker: NA
Text: that safety net.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have met, spoken and corresponded with

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of Australians in relation to their

Speaker: NA
Text: experience on IVF. I want to bring to the

Speaker: NA
Text: attention of the House one compelling case. I

Speaker: NA
Text: read from a Friends of QFG Newsletter

Speaker: NA
Text: which was presented to me by one of my

Speaker: NA
Text: constituents. For the benefit of the House, I

Speaker: NA
Text: will read some excerpts from a letter to the

Speaker: NA
Text: editor of that particular newsletter:

Speaker: NA
Text: Brian and I had been married for about 7 years

Speaker: NA
Text: and although he had been ready for children from

Speaker: NA
Text: day 1 I was now finally ready. It was June 1998

Speaker: NA
Text: … I was only 27. We tried with no success and

Speaker: NA
Text: parBrian had a sperm test with his GP that came

Speaker: NA
Text: back perfect. I then went to my GP and was told

Speaker: NA
Text: to relax and have a holiday “you're young” don't

Speaker: NA
Text: worry about it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The letter goes on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: We managed to get in to see Dr Bob Watson in

Speaker: NA
Text: February 2004. He asked an enormous amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: questions and sent both Brian and I off for more

Speaker: NA
Text: dreaded blood tests that seemed to never end, this

Speaker: NA
Text: was the start of attempting to overcome my fear

Speaker: NA
Text: of needles …

Speaker: NA
Text: Well we rocked up refreshed and eager to get this

Speaker: NA
Text: over with even though we were told that IUIs

Speaker: NA
Text: probably wouldn't work for us but it's worth giv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing it a go. Two attempts at that was more than

Speaker: NA
Text: enough for me, bring on the big guns that should

Speaker: NA
Text: work. Off to Wickham Terrace to meet with Gail

Speaker: NA
Text: for the details about IVF and all the drugs.

Speaker: NA
Text: We started out the first of what was to be all 8

Speaker: NA
Text: stimulated IVF cycles on 11 June 2004, the first

Speaker: NA
Text: FSH injection (125 units) was on our 13th wed-

Speaker: NA
Text: ding anniversary 29 June 2004. That first cycle,

Speaker: NA
Text: although in hindsight one of the worst, was good

Speaker: NA
Text: because we really didn't know what we were

Speaker: NA
Text: doing or what to expect. I knew that the chance of

Speaker: NA
Text: success on the first go was slim but I was very

Speaker: NA
Text: positive and when it failed before I even had my

Speaker: NA
Text: blood test I fell in a heap. I just sat on the bath-

Speaker: NA
Text: room floor and cried.

Speaker: NA
Text: Brian and I picked ourselves up from that cycle

Speaker: NA
Text: and thought if we went back quickly that would

Speaker: NA
Text: be the best way to cope. The second cycle started

Speaker: NA
Text: in September we got 9 eggs (due to 600 units of

Speaker: NA
Text: FSH) but none fertilized …

Speaker: NA
Text: November 2004 was to be our third cycle … This

Speaker: NA
Text: cycle also was the first time we used ICSI, we

Speaker: NA
Text: couldn't have coped with another cycle with no

Speaker: NA
Text: transfer so we hoped this was the answer … By

Speaker: NA
Text: this stage we had never had any embryos good

Speaker: NA
Text: enough to freeze so we had 3 transferred, but

Speaker: NA
Text: again it wasn't to be.

Speaker: NA
Text: I changed jobs because the stress at work was too

Speaker: NA
Text: much and we thought that this would help, well it

Speaker: NA
Text: didn't. It was easier though as I decided it was

Speaker: NA
Text: easier not to tell my workmates. This was one

Speaker: NA
Text: place I could go and not think about IVF, it was

Speaker: NA
Text: great. I also joined the Friends of QFG commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee, I felt they had helped me so much that if I

Speaker: NA
Text: could help one person the way they had helped

Speaker: NA
Text: me it would be great.

Speaker: NA
Text: We started our fourth cycle in April 2005. This

Speaker: NA
Text: failed and to top it all off I got a nasty infection.

Speaker: NA
Text: Still not willing to give up, our 5th cycle began in

Speaker: NA
Text: June 2005, Bob did the pickup, we got 14 eggs,

Speaker: NA
Text: that was the most so far and 9 fertilised, surely it

Speaker: NA
Text: would work this time, Dr Kilvert transferred 2 of

Speaker: NA
Text: our precious embryos and I still didn't make it to

Speaker: NA
Text: a blood test.

Speaker: NA
Text: The sixth cycle this was the worst EVER. I got 13

Speaker: NA
Text: eggs and 10 fertilised. Bob said they were the

Speaker: NA
Text: worst quality yet, but we had 3 transferred.

Speaker: NA
Text: This lady goes on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: full Maybe 7 was the cycle for us, a new year a new

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude. Three were transferred this time, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: works, ICSI, hatching, embryo glue and more

Speaker: NA
Text: drugs Cardiprin, Prednisone and HCG injections

Speaker: NA
Text: after transfer. We went on holidays and relaxed, it

Speaker: NA
Text: had to work this time. We made it to the blood

Speaker: NA
Text: test, but it wasn't to be. A week later I was so sick

Speaker: NA
Text: I had stopped the prednisone the same as I had on

Speaker: NA
Text: previous cycles but this time it was a higher dose

Speaker: NA
Text: and my body could not deal with it. Brian touched

Speaker: NA
Text: me on the arm and I sobbed because my skin hurt

Speaker: NA
Text: intensely …

Speaker: NA
Text: I had begun to have severe pain on day 2 of my

Speaker: NA
Text: cycle the previous September, so I asked Bob

Speaker: NA
Text: what he could do about this and he scheduled

Speaker: NA
Text: laparoscopy etc on 10 March 2006, this only dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: covered mild endo.

Speaker: NA
Text: Brian and I were starting to get quite down about

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole IVF thing by now, so I decided we

Speaker: NA
Text: would try everything.

Speaker: NA
Text: This lady goes on to say, ‘We tried boot

Speaker: NA
Text: camp,' and:

Speaker: NA
Text: … walking group 2 nights per week. Bob had

Speaker: NA
Text: suggested that losing a bit of weight might help

Speaker: NA
Text: … I also saw a Dietician …

Speaker: NA
Text: This lady continues, ‘I wanted to see this

Speaker: NA
Text: particular doctor and was referred by the

Speaker: NA
Text: specialist.' She goes on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: (the immunologist) phoned me on day 2 of what

Speaker: NA
Text: was to be our 8th cycle (8 has always been my

Speaker: NA
Text: favourite and lucky number). He told me to take

Speaker: NA
Text: Cardiprin, Caltrate, Folate and Vitamin E and get

Speaker: NA
Text: some tests done the next day. The test took 13

Speaker: NA
Text: vials of blood. The cycle went well … and I had

Speaker: NA
Text: the transfer on Good Friday, then came the

Speaker: NA
Text: dreaded 2 week wait with the added bonus of

Speaker: NA
Text: Fragmin injections daily from day 3 after transfer

Speaker: NA
Text: and 2 lots of HCG top ups. I made it to the blood

Speaker: NA
Text: test on the Friday of the Labour day long week-

Speaker: NA
Text: end. I felt good, but the test came back negative

Speaker: NA
Text: … Bob convinced us to talk to one of the scien-

Speaker: NA
Text: tists and then come and see him as he wanted to

Speaker: NA
Text: discuss “donor eggs” with us again. At the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: the appointment Brian mentioned that the dreaded

Speaker: NA
Text: period had not arrived yet, so Bob sent me for

Speaker: NA
Text: another blood test the next morning. It came back

Speaker: NA
Text: positive, Bob thought maybe it was ectopic so I

Speaker: NA
Text: went back 2 days later, it had doubled and then

Speaker: NA
Text: again the next week it had more than doubled

Speaker: NA
Text: each day. Then finally a scan and the look on

Speaker: NA
Text: Bob's face when he saw the heartbeat was price-

Speaker: NA
Text: less. Brian and I couldn't believe it. We were

Speaker: NA
Text: pregnant. Many scans later I was finally an ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: stetrics patient, I never thought I would see that

Speaker: NA
Text: day … 18 weeks and Brian found out what we

Speaker: NA
Text: were having, I didn't want to know it as I had

Speaker: NA
Text: always from the transfer felt I was meant to have

Speaker: NA
Text: a girl. 24, 28, 30, 32, 34, 36 week scans finally

Speaker: NA
Text: whether I wanted to know or not it was obvious

Speaker: NA
Text: we were having a girl. It still felt like the

Speaker: NA
Text: wait, the Fragmin was coming to an end, for a

Speaker: NA
Text: needle phobic like me it was about time, 8 months

Speaker: NA
Text: of injections every day. Yuck. The Cardiprin fin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ished on week 37 and Emily Charlotte was born

Speaker: NA
Text: at 1.46pm. 22 December 2006 (my Dad's birth-

Speaker: NA
Text: day) at five pound 10 ounces by caesarean. Bob

Speaker: NA
Text: declared she was perfect and Brian and I could

Speaker: NA
Text: finally breathe a sigh of relief, she was here.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have met some fabulous people throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: our journey, people who truly understand just

Speaker: NA
Text: what you're going through. Our thanks go out to

Speaker: NA
Text: all of them …

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a little bit more to the letter, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: will finish there. That was by two amazing

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians, two people who represent the

Speaker: NA
Text: stories of so many thousands. It is very tough

Speaker: NA
Text: to read for any of us who have been involved

Speaker: NA
Text: in this debate. It is an emotional debate be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause people's lives, their futures and their

Speaker: NA
Text: perspectives on life are changed as a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: this particular cruel outcome by this gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment.

Speaker: NA
Text: No contributor to this debate could sit op-

Speaker: NA
Text: posite and say honestly to the parliament this

Speaker: NA
Text: is a good health outcome. That is why the

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Prime Minister, when she was Dep-

Speaker: NA
Text: uty Leader of the Labor Party in opposition,

Speaker: NA
Text: stood up and rallied against any proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: changes. She railed against those changes

Speaker: NA
Text: because she knew that support should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: taken away from families who needed that

Speaker: NA
Text: support at their most desperate hour and de-

Speaker: NA
Text: served to have that continuing support. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is a government that, of course, has gone into

Speaker: NA
Text: incredible debt-that is not a political state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment; it is a fact. The economic certainty is

Speaker: NA
Text: not there at the moment; it has changed sig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificantly over the last 12 or 18 months, at

Speaker: NA
Text: the same time that the government has spent

Speaker: NA
Text: $42 billion-not one of those dollars in

Speaker: NA
Text: health. Why would it continue with these

Speaker: NA
Text: cruel cuts when it knows that it has the ca-

Speaker: NA
Text: pacity in other areas to allocate the money to

Speaker: NA
Text: save these people the extra stress? The story

Speaker: NA
Text: 2 week that I just read out completely and ade-

Speaker: NA
Text: quately represents the feelings of many of

Speaker: NA
Text: these people who have gone through IVF to

Speaker: NA
Text: create a family, to make their mark on the

Speaker: NA
Text: world, to bring a child into the world. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is no better reason for our existence than to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring new life into this world. This govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's cruel attack on the ability of families

Speaker: NA
Text: to be able to access that support really should

Speaker: NA
Text: stand condemned.

Speaker: NA
Text: I say to the government: the coalition will

Speaker: NA
Text: offer bipartisan support in trying to find

Speaker: NA
Text: other savings to offset this measure if the

Speaker: NA
Text: government sees fit to reverse it. We will

Speaker: NA
Text: work in a bipartisan way to see that this sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port is kept for those thousands of Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians who deserve this support from their

Speaker: NA
Text: government. We will work with the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to make sure that we relieve the burden

Speaker: NA
Text: that is now being put on these families at a

Speaker: NA
Text: time when they need anything but more bur-

Speaker: NA
Text: den. The story that I just read is compelling

Speaker: NA
Text: because it describes in some detail the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: credible pressure that these families-in

Speaker: NA
Text: some cases for years and years and years-

Speaker: NA
Text: and, in particular, the women involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: these processes endure. Why on earth we as

Speaker: NA
Text: a parliament and this government would put

Speaker: NA
Text: extra pressure on those families in a time of

Speaker: NA
Text: most need is completely beyond any reason-

Speaker: NA
Text: able voice as part of this debate. We say to

Speaker: NA
Text: the government: ‘Please reconsider your po-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition. Reconsider your position in light of

Speaker: NA
Text: the comments made by the Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister when she was sitting in opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: as Deputy Leader of the Labor Party.' None

Speaker: NA
Text: of the facts have changed in relation to this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate from the time that the Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister made her comments to this debate

Speaker: NA
Text: today. None of the facts have changed when

Speaker: NA
Text: petitions by the thousands were presented to

Speaker: NA
Text: this parliament by other members who now

Speaker: NA
Text: sit on the front bench of the government.

Speaker: NA
Text: None of the facts have changed which would

Speaker: NA
Text: lend any credibility to a change in the posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and the arrival at what the government

Speaker: NA
Text: now proposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the position of the coalition. We

Speaker: NA
Text: offer support to the government to see a

Speaker: NA
Text: more rational outcome. We want to make

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that these families who have incredible

Speaker: NA
Text: pressures on them already have some of that

Speaker: NA
Text: pressure relieved, not more put on them.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is our call on the government, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: is what we will continue to fight for on be-

Speaker: NA
Text: half of so many Australians over the coming

Speaker: NA
Text: period of this debate.
