Speaker: Ms HALL
Text: Shortland) (1.04 pm)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Insurance Amendment (Extended

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare Safety Net) Bill 2009 amends the

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Insurance Act 1973 to enable the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Health and Ageing to determine

Speaker: NA
Text: the maximum benefit payable under the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tended Medicare safety net-I will refer to it

Speaker: NA
Text: from here on in as the EMSN-for each

Speaker: NA
Text: Medical Benefits Schedule, MBS, item. The

Speaker: NA
Text: bill creates a mechanism by which the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment can responsibly manage the expen-

Speaker: NA
Text: diture on the EMSN. I need to state very

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly at the commencement of my contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bution to this debate: this legislation does

Speaker: NA
Text: remove any item from the MBS; all items

Speaker: NA
Text: remain on the schedule. What it does is put a

Speaker: NA
Text: cap on the MBS item which is determined in

Speaker: NA
Text: line with the median cost or charge that is

Speaker: NA
Text: made by specialists. Median cost means that

Speaker: NA
Text: that is the midpoint in the cost schedule.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are some specialists who are charging

Speaker: NA
Text: rather exorbitant fees, but I will come to that

Speaker: NA
Text: later in my contribution to the debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I have already mentioned, the EMSN

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit cap will apply to benefits for MBS

Speaker: NA
Text: items, which will be payable in addition to

Speaker: NA
Text: the standard Medicare rebate once a patient

Speaker: NA
Text: reaches the EMSN threshold. Each patient

Speaker: NA
Text: will be eligible to receive up to the EMSN

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit cap each time they receive a service.

Speaker: NA
Text: There will be no limit on service; each time

Speaker: NA
Text: they will be able to receive that benefit. Once

Speaker: NA
Text: an individual or a member of a registered

Speaker: NA
Text: family reaches the applicable out-of-pocket

Speaker: NA
Text: EMSN threshold, the person is entitled to an

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in the Medicare benefit equal to 80

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of their out-of-pocket expenses for

Speaker: NA
Text: that claim for the rest of the calendar year. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am sure that members on both sides of this

Speaker: NA
Text: House are acquainted with constituents

Speaker: NA
Text: within their electorates who fall into this

Speaker: NA
Text: category.

Speaker: NA
Text: The increased amount of the Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit payable under the EMSN is com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monly referred to as EMSN benefit. A differ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent level of EMSN benefit cap can apply to

Speaker: NA
Text: different EMSN items. The EMSN benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: cap would be a dollar value. For example, an

Speaker: NA
Text: EMSN benefit cap of $100 may apply to one

Speaker: NA
Text: item and for a different item it may be $500.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are three things that I have sought to

Speaker: NA
Text: establish here: (1) no item is excluded from

Speaker: NA
Text: the MBS (2) the caps can vary according to

Speaker: NA
Text: the item number and (3) those people who

Speaker: NA
Text: reach the EMSN threshold will continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: receive a refund equal to 80 per cent of their

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: Currently there is no limit on the amount

Speaker: NA
Text: not of benefit payable under the EMSN and a

Speaker: NA
Text: person will receive 80 per cent of out-of-

Speaker: NA
Text: pocket expenses for services, which means

Speaker: NA
Text: that, if a doctor chooses to charge an exorbi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant fee, that patient will still receive an

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent refund. One patient may go to a doc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor who charges $500 for an item on the

Speaker: NA
Text: MBS and another patient may go to one who

Speaker: NA
Text: charges $2,000 for the same service. This

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation provides for the fact that some

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors are charging three or four times what

Speaker: NA
Text: other doctors charge for the same item num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber. Taking a midpoint from the example I

Speaker: NA
Text: just gave, the median figure would be

Speaker: NA
Text: This legislation enables the minister to de-

Speaker: NA
Text: termine the cap on the EMSN benefit, which

Speaker: NA
Text: will be set out in the legislative instruments.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will cover 15 obstetric items, which

Speaker: NA
Text: will generate a saving of $451.6 million over

Speaker: NA
Text: four years. As has been mentioned in the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate so far, these savings were part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 2009-10 budget. The implementation date for

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill is 1 January next year.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the shadow minister for health and

Speaker: NA
Text: ageing rightly pointed out, one area that will

Speaker: NA
Text: be impacted is IVF. As a member of this par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament, I am very supportive of IVF. As-

Speaker: NA
Text: sisted reproduction has helped many people,

Speaker: NA
Text: including people I know-family and

Speaker: NA
Text: friends-to have that much sought after

Speaker: NA
Text: child. This legislation in no way seeks to

Speaker: NA
Text: stop that. The shadow minister gave an ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ample in relation to a woman who underwent

Speaker: NA
Text: eight cycles. She will still be able to undergo

Speaker: NA
Text: eight cycles under this legislation. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: no limit on the number of cycles a person

Speaker: NA
Text: may undergo. If members on the other side

Speaker: NA
Text: of this House are going to argue that the

Speaker: NA
Text: islation limits the number of cycles, they are

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresenting the legislation. I emphasise

Speaker: NA
Text: yet again: what it does is put a cap on par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular MBS services.

Speaker: NA
Text: The extended Medicare safety net service

Speaker: NA
Text: will continue for all Australians and for all

Speaker: NA
Text: services currently covered. The safety net

Speaker: NA
Text: threshold has not been changed from the

Speaker: NA
Text: $555.70 for Commonwealth concession card

Speaker: NA
Text: 80 holders and $1,111.60 for all others in each

Speaker: NA
Text: calendar year. It is indexed each year, and

Speaker: NA
Text: will continue to be indexed each year, in line

Speaker: NA
Text: with the consumer price index. The govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is not seeking and will not seek to

Speaker: NA
Text: means test access to the EMSN. It seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: me that a lot of the speakers on this debate

Speaker: NA
Text: from the other side of the House have sought

Speaker: NA
Text: to scare people in the community. I find that

Speaker: NA
Text: the approach of the opposition in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: this has been less than optimal.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another matter was brought up by the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Dickson that I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: touch on. He referred to ophthalmic sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: geons. Yes, that is one area upon which a cap

Speaker: NA
Text: will be placed, but he also referred to how

Speaker: NA
Text: that would impact on Indigenous Australians,

Speaker: NA
Text: linking it into private health insurance. I sus-

Speaker: NA
Text: pect that the member for Dickson should

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake a little research into how many

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous Australians will actually be af-

Speaker: NA
Text: fected by this. The answer would be: next to

Speaker: NA
Text: none. To come into this House and use that

Speaker: NA
Text: as part of his argument shows that he has

Speaker: NA
Text: very limited knowledge of health and very

Speaker: NA
Text: little knowledge particularly of Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: health and the needs of Indigenous Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians. I would like him to consult with ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: perts in this area, people who work on a day-

Speaker: NA
Text: to-day basis with Indigenous Australians, to

Speaker: NA
Text: put some facts to the fiction he has been put-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting forward in the parliament today.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government chose to put this measure

Speaker: NA
Text: in place, to cap benefits at a level which cov-

Speaker: NA
Text: leg- ers average payments. Reasonable amounts

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be affected. If a person visits a doc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor who charges a reasonable amount, an

Speaker: NA
Text: average fee, they will receive a refund of 80

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent. There is no cycle limit and no items

Speaker: NA
Text: are being removed. Another thing the opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion were touting is that it is going to affect

Speaker: NA
Text: cancer patients, but cancer patients will not

Speaker: NA
Text: be affected.

Speaker: NA
Text: This measure has been well researched.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government commissioned a review to

Speaker: NA
Text: which evidence was given. The opposite side

Speaker: NA
Text: are saying that those in greatest financial

Speaker: NA
Text: need will miss out on the benefits. It is the

Speaker: NA
Text: patients with higher incomes who are claim-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing higher out-of-pocket expenses. The re-

Speaker: NA
Text: view found that for every EMSN benefit dol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar paid to patients 78c went to meeting the

Speaker: NA
Text: doctor's higher fee rather than to reducing

Speaker: NA
Text: the patient's out-of-pocket expenses. I put

Speaker: NA
Text: very strongly to this parliament that the

Speaker: NA
Text: EMSN is about making services that Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians need more affordable, to enable them to

Speaker: NA
Text: purchase services, to undertake IVF or to

Speaker: NA
Text: have a cataract operation. I would strongly

Speaker: NA
Text: argue that, if 78c of each benefit dollar goes

Speaker: NA
Text: to meeting the doctor's higher fees rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than to reducing the patient's out-of-pocket

Speaker: NA
Text: expenses, this scheme is not working in the

Speaker: NA
Text: way it was meant to. Putting the cap in place

Speaker: NA
Text: will ensure that patients benefit rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors. As I mentioned earlier, those who

Speaker: NA
Text: have benefited most from the more afford-

Speaker: NA
Text: able services have tended to be wealthier and

Speaker: NA
Text: in a better position to access some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: more expensive services in the first place.

Speaker: NA
Text: The EMSN did create some problems for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Howard government, who raised the

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net expenditure threshold so that they

Speaker: NA
Text: could reduce the number of people who

Speaker: NA
Text: would qualify for the EMSN and they did

Speaker: NA
Text: that to rein in the cost. We are not doing that;

Speaker: NA
Text: in this legislation, we are putting in place a

Speaker: NA
Text: cap designed to come into play at the aver-

Speaker: NA
Text: age fee point.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not support what those on the other

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the parliament have been saying-

Speaker: NA
Text: that this is about stopping women or families

Speaker: NA
Text: receiving IVF assistance; rather, it is about

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring that they see doctors who charge an

Speaker: NA
Text: average fee. They will still get 80 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the EMSN. This is only about the high end,

Speaker: NA
Text: about doctors who charge exorbitant fees.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are doctors involved in IVF who earn

Speaker: NA
Text: incomes in excess of $4 million a year-

Speaker: NA
Text: rather a large salary. We support women con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinuing to receive funding for an unlimited

Speaker: NA
Text: number of cycles and we support all items

Speaker: NA
Text: remaining on the MBS, but we do not sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port paying 80 per cent when doctors charge

Speaker: NA
Text: exorbitant fees.

Speaker: NA
Text: I support the legislation and I encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: those on the other side of the House to look

Speaker: NA
Text: at what the legislation does, rather than put-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting out a smear and fear campaign, as they

Speaker: NA
Text: always do. I encourage them to provide the

Speaker: NA
Text: correct information to their constituents, tell-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing women or pensioners who visit them,

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘Yes, you can still get 80 per cent of your fee

Speaker: NA
Text: back, but you must go to a specialist who

Speaker: NA
Text: will charge a median fee and not an exorbi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant fee.'

Speaker: Mr MORRISON
Text: Cook) (1.22 pm)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Insurance Amendment (Extended

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare Safety Net) Bill 2009 is a cruel

Speaker: NA
Text: bill. It is a heartless bill. Contrary to what

Speaker: NA
Text: has just been suggested in this House, it has

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing to do with people having any restric-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion placed on them as to how many IVFs

Speaker: NA
Text: they can undertake. This bill will put up the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost by between $1,500 and $2,000 a cycle

Speaker: NA
Text: for those who are looking to use assisted re-

Speaker: NA
Text: productive technologies. That is what the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of this bill will be and, for many Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians, that will mean the end of the road of

Speaker: NA
Text: their dream to have children. It is a heartless

Speaker: NA
Text: bill and it is a cruel bill, and to sit here in this

Speaker: NA
Text: place and listen to the suggestions put for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward by those on the other side that this is all

Speaker: NA
Text: about overcharging doctors and there not

Speaker: NA
Text: being caps on how many times you can do it

Speaker: NA
Text: says one thing to me: they just do not get it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those opposite really do not understand

Speaker: NA
Text: what the impact of this bill will be on people

Speaker: NA
Text: who are desperate to have children.

Speaker: NA
Text: Infertility is not a choice. It is not some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing you wish for. It is not something that

Speaker: NA
Text: you elect. It happens to you, like many

Speaker: NA
Text: things in life happen to you. Just under one

Speaker: NA
Text: in six couples of reproductive age in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country have a fertility problem. IVF is re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsible for some 11,000 births each year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Around 40,000 treatments were provided in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2008. Around one child today in a classroom

Speaker: NA
Text: of 25 is in that classroom because of IVF and

Speaker: NA
Text: other related treatments. Forty per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: fertility problems relate to men, 40 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: to women and 20 per cent are of non-specific

Speaker: NA
Text: cause, which is one of the hardest things to

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with when you just do not know why.

Speaker: NA
Text: IVF and related assisted reproductive treat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments are the only hope for people afflicted

Speaker: NA
Text: with infertility. I make reference to a state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment made by Sandra Dill, the Chief Execu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive of Access Australia, which is the group

Speaker: NA
Text: that supports, represents and provides assis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance to those who are going through this

Speaker: NA
Text: horrendous ordeal. She says:

Speaker: NA
Text: IVF is the last chance for many to have a child

Speaker: NA
Text: their own and the Medicare Safety Net has en-

Speaker: NA
Text: sured that every Australian has that opportunity.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's decision has taken away many

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians last chance to have a baby.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a cause which sits very close to my

Speaker: NA
Text: heart. I have taken the unusual step today of

Speaker: NA
Text: returning from leave. My wife gave birth to a

Speaker: NA
Text: child last Thursday-our second child, Lily

Speaker: NA
Text: Alice. Our first child, Abbey Rose, was born

Speaker: NA
Text: on the 7th of the 7th of the 7th-14 years

Speaker: NA
Text: from when my wife and I began assisted re-

Speaker: NA
Text: productive treatments, which consisted of 10

Speaker: NA
Text: IVF cycles. It was a horrendous ordeal. My

Speaker: NA
Text: wife had very difficult surgery and we were

Speaker: NA
Text: finally able to conceive a child without the

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimate assistance of IVF. Everything we

Speaker: NA
Text: learned along the road-every day, every

Speaker: NA
Text: lesson, every treatment and every piece of

Speaker: NA
Text: advice-was critical to our path and to the

Speaker: NA
Text: process of having children.

Speaker: NA
Text: The desire to have children is the most

Speaker: NA
Text: positive, life-affirming instinct we as human

Speaker: NA
Text: beings have. The desire does not go away

Speaker: NA
Text: when you are told that you cannot have chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren or that you will have difficulty having

Speaker: NA
Text: them. The feeling of loss at every failed at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tempt is indescribable. Others, removed from

Speaker: NA
Text: the emotional hell, rationalise the failure of

Speaker: NA
Text: embryos failing to take, while parents and

Speaker: NA
Text: want-to-be parents grieve the loss of chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren. We console ourselves with the thought

Speaker: NA
Text: that one day we will be reunited with our

Speaker: NA
Text: unborn child beyond this life. Added to this

Speaker: NA
Text: physical and emotional torment is the pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that it places on extremely fragile rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionships working through these very diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cult issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: Most families understand the sacrifice in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved in having children. They understand

Speaker: NA
Text: that as they have those children and see them

Speaker: NA
Text: growing up in their homes. It means many

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to our lives-many welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: changes, I must add. But one of the reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: we as parents can deal with those sacrifices

Speaker: NA
Text: of is that it is accompanied by the sheer joy of

Speaker: NA
Text: parenthood-and there is nothing to match it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some people go through fertility treatment

Speaker: NA
Text: over extended periods of time. You would

Speaker: NA
Text: have heard the member for Dickson recount

Speaker: NA
Text: an incredibly moving story, which I am so

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased had a happy ending even though so

Speaker: NA
Text: many of these stories do not. For those going

Speaker: NA
Text: through the hell of fertility treatment over an

Speaker: NA
Text: extended period of time, their first experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence of parenthood is only sacrifice. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: all that many will ever know; the joy of par-

Speaker: NA
Text: enthood never comes. The pain of these ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: periences is not altered by your level of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come. It does not change how you feel and

Speaker: NA
Text: what goes on inside you. Regardless of how

Speaker: NA
Text: much or how little you have, you do what-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever it takes to make this work. You make

Speaker: NA
Text: the sacrifices. You take out the extended loan

Speaker: NA
Text: or the second mortgage. You do whatever

Speaker: NA
Text: you need to do to try to realise that dream.

Speaker: NA
Text: For families going through this very dark

Speaker: NA
Text: chapter of their lives, it is all consuming.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reason I am pointing this out is that I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not believe that those in the government

Speaker: NA
Text: have got a full handle on the depth of this

Speaker: NA
Text: issue or a real appreciation of the pain that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are going to inflict on their fellow Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians as a result of this measure. When you

Speaker: NA
Text: go through this, everything comes into ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. You are challenged spiritually, emotion-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally, physically and financially. You question

Speaker: NA
Text: everything-God, each other, your priorities,

Speaker: NA
Text: your future. Nothing escapes scrutiny when

Speaker: NA
Text: you are going through this treatment and this

Speaker: NA
Text: ordeal. Along this road you will find the

Speaker: NA
Text: wreckage of shattered lives, marriages and

Speaker: NA
Text: families. But when you do this you know the

Speaker: NA
Text: risks you take, because you are so committed

Speaker: NA
Text: to and so passionate about the fact that one

Speaker: NA
Text: day you might be able to realise that dream

Speaker: NA
Text: of bringing a child into the world, which I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe is a very pure dream.

Speaker: NA
Text: Against this background, the government

Speaker: NA
Text: has introduced this bill and has moved, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous speaker said, to cap payments under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Medicare safety net for IVF and related

Speaker: NA
Text: fertility treatments. The bill also imposes

Speaker: NA
Text: caps on a range of other services-including

Speaker: NA
Text: obstetric services, pregnancy related ultra-

Speaker: NA
Text: sounds and cataract surgery. I will not touch

Speaker: NA
Text: on these; the shadow minister has already

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned these. The saving that is expected

Speaker: NA
Text: to be gained from this measure is $475 mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion. Just to put that in context, that is less

Speaker: NA
Text: than two per cent of what the Labor govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment borrowed and gave away in cash pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. So what we are seeing right here be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore us in this bill is one of the many costs

Speaker: NA
Text: the spending that this government has en-

Speaker: NA
Text: gaged in.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I mentioned at the start of my remarks,

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost for couples is estimated to rise from

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,600 or thereabouts-and for many it is far

Speaker: NA
Text: more than that-in out-of-pocket expenses to

Speaker: NA
Text: around $3,000 to $3,500. So when the previ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous speaker, the member for Shortland,

Speaker: NA
Text: makes the assertion that this measure will not

Speaker: NA
Text: end the dream of Australians seeking to have

Speaker: NA
Text: children she clearly does not understand

Speaker: NA
Text: what the consequences of the cap will be.

Speaker: NA
Text: The cost will go up significantly. It will more

Speaker: NA
Text: than double for some families and some cou-

Speaker: NA
Text: ples-for many couples, I expect.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think Labor are in complete denial when

Speaker: NA
Text: it comes to this measure. I think they are

Speaker: NA
Text: looking to run and hide. I think they want

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation to move through this parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment as quickly as possible because they are,

Speaker: NA
Text: frankly, ashamed and embarrassed about it.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have taken a position on this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: which is in complete contradiction to what is

Speaker: NA
Text: outlined in this bill, so they sit here in denial

Speaker: NA
Text: and put forward these arguments, but,

Speaker: NA
Text: frankly, they should sit silent because this is

Speaker: NA
Text: an indefensible measure, particularly as it

Speaker: NA
Text: relates to IVF and related procedures. The

Speaker: NA
Text: pressure on these couples is hard enough-

Speaker: NA
Text: and I have given some of my own insight

Speaker: NA
Text: into that-without the added anguish of hav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to find that extra money. It is bad

Speaker: NA
Text: enough. It is hard enough. The relationships

Speaker: NA
Text: are already under enough stress. Having

Speaker: NA
Text: watched my wife go through these proce-

Speaker: NA
Text: dures many, many times and seen the health

Speaker: NA
Text: impacts on her as she dealt with them, to

Speaker: NA
Text: know that she then would have to also en-

Speaker: NA
Text: dure additional financial stress would be

Speaker: NA
Text: simply too much to bear. It will be too much

Speaker: NA
Text: to bear for many, and they will just say, ‘I

Speaker: NA
Text: can't go on.'

Speaker: NA
Text: I know what it is like to have reached that

Speaker: NA
Text: point: after 10, we actually did reach that

Speaker: NA
Text: of point. At some other time, we thought, we

Speaker: NA
Text: might go forward again. Thanks be to God,

Speaker: NA
Text: we had the situation where, after the surgery

Speaker: NA
Text: and some years later, things happened. But

Speaker: NA
Text: that is not a normal story; that is actually

Speaker: NA
Text: quite a miraculous story. That is why we re-

Speaker: NA
Text: fer to our little girl, Abbey Rose, as our

Speaker: NA
Text: miracle child. It does not always work out

Speaker: NA
Text: like that-in fact, it rarely does. So I ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: government to be kind enough to listen. A

Speaker: NA
Text: week or so ago I recounted the story of Jenny

Speaker: NA
Text: and me in the Sunday Telegraph and I have

Speaker: NA
Text: had an enormous response from people go-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing through the same situation. I want to read

Speaker: NA
Text: out some of those responses. One said:

Speaker: NA
Text: My husband and I are currently going through

Speaker: NA
Text: IVF and it is not an easy path. Even with gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment subsidies, it is expensive. I can't believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government is going to implement

Speaker: NA
Text: changes which will make it even more difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: for couples who are already going through great

Speaker: NA
Text: emotion in their lives.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unless you've experienced the grief of infertility

Speaker: NA
Text: and miscarriage, I doubt that anyone would be

Speaker: NA
Text: quite aware of the impact it can have on a per-

Speaker: NA
Text: son's day-to-day life. The grief is ongoing,

Speaker: NA
Text: mourning because of a failed cycle, utter devasta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion at yet another miscarriage. Yes, some people

Speaker: NA
Text: go on to live fulfilling lives without children, but

Speaker: NA
Text: for my husband and I this is not an option we

Speaker: NA
Text: want to consider without first exhausting all pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible options, including IVF first.

Speaker: NA
Text: I strongly encourage those affected by Mr Rudd's

Speaker: NA
Text: heartless decision to keep fighting this as it is

Speaker: NA
Text: only way that we can even try to stop this very

Speaker: NA
Text: cruel funding cut.

Speaker: NA
Text: Again in 2008, another said:

Speaker: NA
Text: My husband and I had four unsuccessful IVF

Speaker: NA
Text: attempts. This year is now a recovery year, emo-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionally and financially, and we had all intentions

Speaker: NA
Text: of starting up again in 2010. This now looks to be

Speaker: NA
Text: unlikely due to the new changes the government

Speaker: NA
Text: will be putting in place. Unless we win Lotto, the

Speaker: NA
Text: government has forced us to accept the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: we could well remain childless forever. Not an

Speaker: NA
Text: easy realisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are not my words. These are the words

Speaker: NA
Text: of those who are affected by this measure,

Speaker: NA
Text: and their voices should be heard. Another

Speaker: NA
Text: said:

Speaker: NA
Text: I think a lot of people do not realise that, even

Speaker: NA
Text: with the existing rebates, IVF is not free. Far

Speaker: NA
Text: from it, in fact. Not to mention all the in-between

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments, tests and exploratory procedures

Speaker: NA
Text: that seem to come with the territory. And no-one

Speaker: NA
Text: ever thinks that they will need to go to IVF once,

Speaker: NA
Text: let alone four or 10 times, so how can you prop-

Speaker: NA
Text: erly save or prepare for that expense when every-

Speaker: NA
Text: one including the doctors, nurses, friends, fami-

Speaker: NA
Text: lies tells you to never give up, the next cycle just

Speaker: NA
Text: might be the one that works. How can you simply

Speaker: NA
Text: give up and walk away from that hope or possi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility?

Speaker: NA
Text: I wonder if Kevin Rudd or Wayne Swan would

Speaker: NA
Text: have made the same decision if any of their own

Speaker: NA
Text: children or friends needed fertility treatment.

Speaker: NA
Text: And again:

Speaker: NA
Text: We are the unlucky ones: 13 cycles, one with a

Speaker: NA
Text: miscarriage of eight weeks, nearly $80,000

Speaker: NA
Text: poorer. I would have kept going too. We bor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rowed money on three credit cards then finally

Speaker: NA
Text: had to extend our mortgage because we could not

Speaker: NA
Text: keep up with the payments. It would have been

Speaker: NA
Text: worth every single penny if we had conceived

Speaker: NA
Text: successfully.

Speaker: NA
Text: And another:

Speaker: NA
Text: I think the Rudd government did a good beat-up

Speaker: NA
Text: of IVF in the months coming into the budget with

Speaker: NA
Text: false facts that were made to look like IVF com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies were profiting and the community was

Speaker: NA
Text: the paying 80 per cent of the IVF when in fact they

Speaker: NA
Text: only pay for a quarter of the total bill. Partly as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of this beat-up, the general community are

Speaker: NA
Text: indifferent to the cause. The cost that is included

Speaker: NA
Text: in the statements to the media only included the

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare part of the cost of IVF and not the day

Speaker: NA
Text: surgery, fertility specialist, appointments, non-

Speaker: NA
Text: refundable tests like the SSA, which we had done.

Speaker: NA
Text: This test cost approximately $800 alone, but

Speaker: NA
Text: made us realise we had a problem and contributed

Speaker: NA
Text: to us changing some vitamins, succeeding in our

Speaker: NA
Text: second ISCI.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are the stories of those who deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: this problem every day, and they understand

Speaker: NA
Text: what the impact of this bill is.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those who practise in the area also under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand that it will put increased pressure on

Speaker: NA
Text: the actual medical procedures themselves,

Speaker: NA
Text: because those who are going through these

Speaker: NA
Text: procedures will not want to risk the loss of

Speaker: NA
Text: an opportunity of going through a further

Speaker: NA
Text: cycle for financial reasons and they will ask

Speaker: NA
Text: to have additional eggs put back in. That

Speaker: NA
Text: increases the risk to a mother and increases

Speaker: NA
Text: the risk to both children in a multiple birth.

Speaker: NA
Text: This has not come from the opposition; this

Speaker: NA
Text: has come from medical practitioners in the

Speaker: NA
Text: area. I know, as a parent now but as one who

Speaker: NA
Text: went through this process, that these are the

Speaker: NA
Text: things that go through your head. These are

Speaker: NA
Text: the issues that you have to try to resolve. You

Speaker: NA
Text: do not want to have to take that extra risk.

Speaker: NA
Text: You do not want to have to go through that

Speaker: NA
Text: process again if you can avoid it. But you

Speaker: NA
Text: also have to try to maximise your chances of

Speaker: NA
Text: success-and if you do not have that next

Speaker: NA
Text: chance, then you will take greater risks.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think what makes this measure even

Speaker: NA
Text: more disgraceful is the hypocrisy of the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment in bringing it forward. In 2005, the

Speaker: NA
Text: then shadow health minister, now the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor completely opposes any cutbacks to Medi-

Speaker: NA
Text: care funding of IVF. Labor will be launching a

Speaker: NA
Text: petition against the changes to Medicare funded

Speaker: NA
Text: IVF by the Howard government, tomorrow in

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then, in a doorstop interview in 2005, she

Speaker: NA
Text: said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Tony Abbott and John Howard before the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, were wandering around saying the best thing

Speaker: NA
Text: about Medicare is that it's an uncapped scheme, a

Speaker: NA
Text: patient-driven scheme. The Prime Minister went

Speaker: NA
Text: so far as to say that's fundamental. Well, what

Speaker: NA
Text: was fundamental before the election is expend-

Speaker: NA
Text: able after the election with this plan to cap Medi-

Speaker: NA
Text: care funding for IVF.

Speaker: NA
Text: John Howard and Tony Abbott should listen to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian community, to the Labor Party and

Speaker: NA
Text: to women within their own ranks, and back down

Speaker: NA
Text: today on this proposed very cruel cutback. And at

Speaker: NA
Text: the same time they should rule out capping Medi-

Speaker: NA
Text: care for other things that Minister Abbott deems

Speaker: NA
Text: non-essential.

Speaker: NA
Text: Frankly, the Deputy Prime Minister and the

Speaker: NA
Text: government should take their own advice,

Speaker: NA
Text: because on that occasion the government did

Speaker: NA
Text: listen and did change their policy. They lis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tened and they understood. They became

Speaker: NA
Text: sympathetic and understood the challenges

Speaker: NA
Text: that were faced by couples in this situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: They showed a heart and reversed the meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure.

Speaker: NA
Text: That measure is in this parliament today,

Speaker: NA
Text: brought forward by those who gave that ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice to the previous government. I can think

Speaker: NA
Text: of no more bitter hypocrisy than that. But it

Speaker: NA
Text: went further, because not only did they say

Speaker: NA
Text: those things in the press; they took up peti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. They collected, in total, 1,759 signa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tures, including those in a petition lodged by

Speaker: NA
Text: the previous speaker, the member for Short-

Speaker: NA
Text: land. I am interested to know whether she is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to write to the 240 citizens who signed

Speaker: NA
Text: her petition to oppose cuts to Medicare fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for IVF and tell them that her govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment are now going to do exactly what she

Speaker: NA
Text: was trying to get their support to stop the

Speaker: NA
Text: then government from doing. Is she going to

Speaker: NA
Text: write to those 240 citizens? Is the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister going to write to the more

Speaker: NA
Text: than 1,300 citizens whose signatures she col-

Speaker: NA
Text: lected and apologise to them for her act of

Speaker: NA
Text: hypocrisy in being supportive of this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: coming before the House? She would not

Speaker: NA
Text: even answer questions, when put to her in

Speaker: NA
Text: this House, about whether she supported this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill, given the fact that she had collected

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 1,300 signatures opposing the

Speaker: NA
Text: measures that she in fact has brought before

Speaker: NA
Text: the House. There were also petitions from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer, from the Minister for Agricul-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture, Fisheries and Forestry, from the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Small Business, Independent Contrac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors and the Service Economy, and from

Speaker: NA
Text: other members. The government said one

Speaker: NA
Text: thing and are doing another. Either they were

Speaker: NA
Text: being deceitful and disingenuous at that time

Speaker: NA
Text: or they are being heartless today. They can

Speaker: NA
Text: take their pick, but either is abominable. Ei-

Speaker: NA
Text: ther should bring them to the table, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow minister was saying before, to talk to

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposition about how these things can be

Speaker: NA
Text: avoided.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government's budget is dripping with

Speaker: NA
Text: spending, yet they put through a cut like this

Speaker: NA
Text: which will deny a person the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: become a parent. For that, I think they need

Speaker: NA
Text: to take a good, hard look at themselves in the

Speaker: NA
Text: mirror. There are savings that can be found

Speaker: NA
Text: in this budget. In my shadow portfolio alone,

Speaker: NA
Text: the first home saver accounts have underper-

Speaker: NA
Text: formed by 96 per cent. Even if we just

Speaker: NA
Text: capped the scheme at 10 per cent of what its

Speaker: NA
Text: projected take-up was going to be, the sav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings over the next three years would be $700

Speaker: NA
Text: million. The Minister for Housing did not

Speaker: NA
Text: bring to the table one dollar of savings in

Speaker: NA
Text: housing portfolio that could have avoided the

Speaker: NA
Text: government bringing forward this measure.

Speaker: NA
Text: She did not do that, and it was left to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Health and Ageing to find sav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings. I must say that on other matters I have

Speaker: NA
Text: found the Minister for Health and Ageing to

Speaker: NA
Text: be very encouraging, particularly in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to epidermolysis bullosa and the support

Speaker: NA
Text: given in the budget to children suffering

Speaker: NA
Text: from that condition. I welcome that and I

Speaker: NA
Text: applaud and commend the minister for tak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing what I think is a very compassionate po-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition. It cost $16 million and she was very

Speaker: NA
Text: supportive of our representations on the mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter. I encourage her now to speak to her col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leagues and encourage them to be compas-

Speaker: NA
Text: sionate on this matter. When in opposition,

Speaker: NA
Text: the government opposed the very thing they

Speaker: NA
Text: have brought forward in this House. They

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot justify it on the basis that they have

Speaker: NA
Text: lost control of their budget. They should get

Speaker: NA
Text: control of their budget. They should avoid

Speaker: NA
Text: the inclination to bring in such heartless and

Speaker: NA
Text: hypocritical measures. Most importantly,

Speaker: NA
Text: they must listen to the people who are af-

Speaker: NA
Text: fected and they must come to the table and

Speaker: NA
Text: change this measure immediately.

Speaker: Mr NEUMANN
Text: Blair) (1.42 pm)-I rise

Speaker: NA
Text: to speak in support of the Health Insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Extended Medicare Safety Net)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 2009. First, I want to congratulate the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Cook and his wife on the birth of

Speaker: NA
Text: their second child. I have two daughters my-

Speaker: NA
Text: self. Fortunately, we did not have any diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: culties with my wife, Carolyn, falling preg-

Speaker: NA
Text: nant. My daughters are now 18 and 19. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are the love of our lives and we rejoice in

Speaker: NA
Text: their development spiritually, educationally,

Speaker: NA
Text: socially and intellectually. It is wonderful to

Speaker: NA
Text: have children. They are a great blessing and

Speaker: NA
Text: heritage. Those of us of the Christian faith

Speaker: NA
Text: accept that scriptural injunction.

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to this bill, I say to the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Cook that the trouble is that there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: the great deal of inconsistency between what the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition are saying and what they did in

Speaker: NA
Text: practice when they were in power. The truth

Speaker: NA
Text: is that in my area alone they effectively de-

Speaker: NA
Text: funded health and hospital services. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the reality. We have one GP for every 1,609

Speaker: NA
Text: people in my area, the Ipswich and West

Speaker: NA
Text: Moreton area in South-East Queensland.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even the former Minister for Health and

Speaker: NA
Text: Ageing, the member for Warringah, admitted

Speaker: NA
Text: before the last election in October 2007 that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: had got it absolutely correct in saying that

Speaker: NA
Text: the previous coalition government, under

Speaker: NA
Text: John Howard, had actually defunded health

Speaker: NA
Text: and hospitals in this country and that the

Speaker: NA
Text: states had had to take up the slack. The

Speaker: NA
Text: much-maligned state Labor governments had

Speaker: NA
Text: to take up the slack because the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition government failed to fund health

Speaker: NA
Text: and hospital services. They capped the num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of doctors in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor has increased the number of train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing places for doctors. We have put $1.1 bil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion into that to increase the number of train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing places and to encourage more people to

Speaker: NA
Text: go into medicine and the allied health profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions. We want to encourage nurses to go

Speaker: NA
Text: back into the system-into health and aged-

Speaker: NA
Text: care services. We want to try to get them

Speaker: NA
Text: working in regional and remote areas. One of

Speaker: NA
Text: the first things that the Rudd government did

Speaker: NA
Text: was to put in more money for elective sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: gery. About $1.6 billion was put in, in accor-

Speaker: NA
Text: dance with agreements with the states. The

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Dickson said that there was little

Speaker: NA
Text: or no money put into health by the Rudd

Speaker: NA
Text: government under our Nation Building and

Speaker: NA
Text: Jobs Plan. I looked around on budget night

Speaker: NA
Text: and saw him in the chamber when the Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer was talking about what the Rudd Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government were doing to fund our health

Speaker: NA
Text: and hospital system. The Treasurer said:

Speaker: NA
Text: … Australians deserve a world-class health and

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital system.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what we are providing. We are spend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a lot of money not only locally in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate but also nationally. What we are

Speaker: NA
Text: doing under the legislation that is before the

Speaker: NA
Text: House today is in accordance with the report

Speaker: NA
Text: that was delivered on this matter. What gets

Speaker: NA
Text: me is that those on that side of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: think they have a monopoly on family val-

Speaker: NA
Text: ues, on compassion, on heart and on care.

Speaker: NA
Text: But they do not. This legislation that is be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore the chamber is not about us being

Speaker: NA
Text: against women and men who struggle to

Speaker: NA
Text: have a child. It is not about that at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: gratulate the member for Cook for having

Speaker: NA
Text: two children and contributing. From what he

Speaker: NA
Text: had to say, you could tell the love, the affir-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation, the care, the wonder of birth and

Speaker: NA
Text: how fantastic it is that he and his wife have

Speaker: NA
Text: had children. We are not about punishing

Speaker: NA
Text: people in these circumstances. In fact, the

Speaker: NA
Text: inconsistency here is that in 1996, 1997,

Speaker: NA
Text: 2004 those opposite actually agreed with the

Speaker: NA
Text: idea of having caps on Medicare. Do not

Speaker: NA
Text: come into this place and say that by putting

Speaker: NA
Text: caps on funding we are heartless, cruel, mean

Speaker: NA
Text: and nasty. It is simply not true. Through most

Speaker: NA
Text: of the time of the Howard coalition govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment it supported the idea of having caps.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before the introduction of the safety net in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2004 there was a limit on the amount of gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment contribution for Medicare ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices-that is, the Medicare schedule fee-

Speaker: NA
Text: but I did not hear the member for Dickson or

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Cook say that. That was the

Speaker: NA
Text: policy of the Howard coalition government.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what it took for most of its tenure in

Speaker: NA
Text: office.

Speaker: NA
Text: The truth is that we are doing what we

Speaker: NA
Text: need to do to save $450 million to better

Speaker: NA
Text: fund our health system, our hospital system,

Speaker: NA
Text: our roads, our schools and other sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: things. That is what we are doing. We are not

Speaker: NA
Text: about punishing people who cannot have

Speaker: NA
Text: children. It is simply untrue for the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Cook to come in here and say and imply

Speaker: NA
Text: that. What we are doing here is in response

Speaker: NA
Text: to a report that we had commissioned. Under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Health Legislation Amendment (Medi-

Speaker: NA
Text: care) Act 2004 the Minister for Health and

Speaker: NA
Text: Ageing tabled a report entitled the Extended

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare safety net review report 2009 and it

Speaker: NA
Text: looked at the effectiveness, the operation and

Speaker: NA
Text: the implications of the safety net with respect

Speaker: NA
Text: to a variety of different things. The report

Speaker: NA
Text: was carried out by the Centre for Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Economics Research and Evaluation at the

Speaker: NA
Text: I conUniversity of Technology in Sydney. That

Speaker: NA
Text: report said a number of things, and I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that the report's existence and its recommen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dations seem to have washed over the oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition entirely.

Speaker: NA
Text: The report was very clear. What we are

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to do here is stop doctors charging

Speaker: NA
Text: excessive amounts by effectively taking ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vantage of the safety net. That is what the

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors are doing. We want to make sure the

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net is sustainable. The report recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mended and noted a number of things which

Speaker: NA
Text: are very important to note. The report noted

Speaker: NA
Text: that the safety net had helped patients that

Speaker: NA
Text: had very high costs and reduced the out-of-

Speaker: NA
Text: pocket expenses for some patients with can-

Speaker: NA
Text: cer. Nonetheless, the review showed that

Speaker: NA
Text: there were some real concerns in obstetrics

Speaker: NA
Text: and assisted reproductive technologies, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluding IVF and other Medicare services.

Speaker: NA
Text: The report noted that 50 per cent of safety

Speaker: NA
Text: net benefits were paid to obstetrics and as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sisted reproductive technologies, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare benefits had more than doubled for

Speaker: NA
Text: both of those groups since the safety net had

Speaker: NA
Text: been introduced.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reported noted that between 2003 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 2008-and the Minister for Health and Age-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing has reported this in her speech-the fees

Speaker: NA
Text: charged for obstetricians for in-house hospi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal services went down by six per cent. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, the fees for those obstetricians outside

Speaker: NA
Text: of hospital, in private practice, and who

Speaker: NA
Text: charge people like the member for Cook and

Speaker: NA
Text: his wife, had increased by 267 per cent. How

Speaker: NA
Text: can it be possible to justify increases of that

Speaker: NA
Text: nature? Similarly, the fees charged for as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sisted reproductive technology services fell

Speaker: NA
Text: by nine per cent for in-house hospital ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices while the fees charged for out-of-

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital services increased by 62 per cent. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is very clear that some doctors were taking

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage of the safety net. It is crystal

Speaker: NA
Text: The figures say very clearly that it is the

Speaker: NA
Text: case.

Speaker: NA
Text: What are we going to do about it? Are we

Speaker: NA
Text: going to have a sustainable safety net? The

Speaker: NA
Text: unlimited nature of the benefits available

Speaker: NA
Text: through the safety net has led some doctors

Speaker: NA
Text: to take advantage. The truth is they knew

Speaker: NA
Text: that the majority of their expenses were be-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing paid for by the taxpayers. That is what it

Speaker: NA
Text: was all about. Lest anyone says that some-

Speaker: NA
Text: how we are opposed to the safety net and

Speaker: NA
Text: that somehow we are making massive

Speaker: NA
Text: changes that will adversely affect Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians, I just point out that the government is

Speaker: NA
Text: supportive of the safety net. The truth is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the safety net operates in this way. Once an

Speaker: NA
Text: annual threshold has been met, Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: pays 80 per cent of any future out-of-pocket

Speaker: NA
Text: expenses for all out-of-hospital services for

Speaker: NA
Text: the remainder of that calendar year. In 2009,

Speaker: NA
Text: the annual threshold for concession card

Speaker: NA
Text: holders and people who receive family tax

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit part A is $555.70. For singles and

Speaker: NA
Text: families the threshold is $1,111.60. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: indexed every year. The bill before the

Speaker: NA
Text: House allows the minister for health to de-

Speaker: NA
Text: termine by legislative instrument the maxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mum increase in benefit payable under the

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net for specified items. These are

Speaker: NA
Text: items that are specified in the Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: Benefit Schedule. If it is not specified it does

Speaker: NA
Text: not apply. The total out-of-pocket costs in-

Speaker: NA
Text: curred by a person for services will still

Speaker: NA
Text: count towards the safety net threshold

Speaker: NA
Text: amount. Once a person has reached that

Speaker: NA
Text: threshold, they will continue to be eligible to

Speaker: NA
Text: receive the benefits, equal to 80 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: their out-of-pocket expenses, for those items

Speaker: NA
Text: that are not specified by legislative instru-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what is happening. We are actually

Speaker: NA
Text: putting a cap on certain things. We are doing

Speaker: NA
Text: it to maintain the integrity and sustainability

Speaker: NA
Text: of the system. In 2008, expenditure on the

Speaker: NA
Text: clear. safety net was $414 million, 30 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: more than in 2007. Why is that? The truth is

Speaker: NA
Text: that doctors are charging too much. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the reality. And, if we do not do something, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is going to get out of control in such a way

Speaker: NA
Text: that the whole future operational sustainabil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity of the safety net will be adversely af-

Speaker: NA
Text: fected. The government is not means-testing

Speaker: NA
Text: access to the safety net; the government is

Speaker: NA
Text: maintaining the safety net. The truth is that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are trying to get the health costs charged

Speaker: NA
Text: by doctors back under control.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are doing a lot of things when it comes

Speaker: NA
Text: to health and hospital services. In my elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate, we are bringing in a GP superclinic.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have announced that, and negotiations on

Speaker: NA
Text: that are currently underway. We are trying

Speaker: NA
Text: our best to ensure that we get more doctors

Speaker: NA
Text: in the local area. Before I was elected to this

Speaker: NA
Text: place, I was on a health community council

Speaker: NA
Text: for a long time, and we struggled to get more

Speaker: NA
Text: local doctors to the area-and Ipswich is a

Speaker: NA
Text: fast-growing area. It is growing at about four

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent per annum. It is the fastest-growing

Speaker: NA
Text: area in Queensland at the moment. We need

Speaker: NA
Text: more and more doctors and so we are seeing

Speaker: NA
Text: a lot more overseas-trained doctors in the

Speaker: NA
Text: local area. But we need to get more local

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors. We need to train more doctors and

Speaker: NA
Text: we need to spend more money locally. So the

Speaker: NA
Text: $450 million we are saving here will go a

Speaker: NA
Text: long way towards helping my community

Speaker: NA
Text: and helping the communities in the 150 elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torates represented in this place.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unlike what the member for Dickson said,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Rudd government is working with the

Speaker: NA
Text: states to improve the health and hospital sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem in this country. Through COAG we are

Speaker: NA
Text: putting $64 billion over five years into the

Speaker: NA
Text: public hospital system in this country. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: an increase of $20 billion, nearly 50 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: over the previous Australian healthcare

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement and it is an indictment of the pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vious government for letting the health and

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital system run down. That is the reality

Speaker: NA
Text: of health and hospital systems in this country

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Howard coalition government. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are also improving participation in the health

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce as well as increasing access to

Speaker: NA
Text: health care.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the things that I think the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has done very well is the change we are

Speaker: NA
Text: making in relation to maternity services. The

Speaker: NA
Text: 2009-10 budget included a great provision

Speaker: NA
Text: which was warmly welcomed in my elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate, and that is funding of $120.5 million for

Speaker: NA
Text: maternity services. It is a reform package

Speaker: NA
Text: that will allow women greater choice. One of

Speaker: NA
Text: the most precious things a woman can ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: perience in life is, of course, the birth of her

Speaker: NA
Text: child. My wife tells me that she will never

Speaker: NA
Text: forget the birth of our child, and I will never

Speaker: NA
Text: forget holding my eldest daughter in my

Speaker: NA
Text: arms. It is a wonderful experience. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: not about to punish women and families in

Speaker: NA
Text: this regard by this legislation. We are giving

Speaker: NA
Text: women the option of a home birth or having

Speaker: NA
Text: their child in a hospital. That is their choice.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need to increase freedom of choice for

Speaker: NA
Text: women when it comes to the birth of their

Speaker: NA
Text: children. It is a precious and wonderful ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: perience.

Speaker: NA
Text: So the Rudd government, through our last

Speaker: NA
Text: budget, are improving the options and oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunities for women. In this country we have a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong record in providing high-quality ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: ternity services, and I know the women in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate, including those in the mater-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity coalition groups I have met who have

Speaker: NA
Text: been arguing for such a long time that we

Speaker: NA
Text: need to improve maternity services and im-

Speaker: NA
Text: prove the options for women, warmly wel-

Speaker: NA
Text: come this funding. Cas MCCullough, who is

Speaker: NA
Text: very well known locally and a very well

Speaker: NA
Text: known advocate for home births, has been

Speaker: NA
Text: arguing for this for a long time. I warmly

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome this funding. I support the legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that is before the House and, once again,

Speaker: NA
Text: I congratulate the member for Cook and his

Speaker: NA
Text: wife on the birth of their second child.

Speaker: Mrs HULL
Text: Riverina) (1.56 pm)-It

Speaker: NA
Text: would have been kind of the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Blair to have taken just a little bit longer! But

Speaker: NA
Text: as I am now on my feet I will take the oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to speak-for the three minutes before

Speaker: NA
Text: the debate is interrupted-on the issues be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore us with this Health Insurance Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment (Extended Medicare Safety Net) Bill

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Ms AE

Speaker: NA
Text: Burke)-The member need not rush; you

Speaker: NA
Text: can speak when the debate is resumed if you

Speaker: NA
Text: want.

Speaker: Mrs HULL
Text: I am enormously concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: about some of the services that are being

Speaker: NA
Text: capped through this legislation. The concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: that I have revolve primarily around obstetric

Speaker: NA
Text: services, assisted reproductive technology

Speaker: NA
Text: and types of cataract surgery that will be

Speaker: NA
Text: capped under this bill. I would also like to go

Speaker: NA
Text: further and speak about the concerns that I

Speaker: NA
Text: have that are not directly related to this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: but are yet to come into this House, particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly to do with cataract surgery. While only

Speaker: NA
Text: one type of cataract surgery is affected by

Speaker: NA
Text: this particular bill, there are significant issues

Speaker: NA
Text: yet to come that are associated with cataract

Speaker: NA
Text: surgery in general. In particular, there is the

Speaker: NA
Text: decision to reduce by half the payment to

Speaker: NA
Text: ophthalmologists for cataract surgery. It is an

Speaker: NA
Text: issue that ophthalmologists will have to start

Speaker: NA
Text: to contend with.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the years, it seems that ophthal-

Speaker: NA
Text: mologists and cataract surgeons have had

Speaker: NA
Text: their payments cut significantly. The sched-

Speaker: NA
Text: ule fee for cataract surgery in the early 1980s

Speaker: NA
Text: was around $800. In 1996 the then govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment cut that fee by around 30 per cent. Now

Speaker: NA
Text: this government wants to cut that fee in half

Speaker: NA
Text: again. In late 2009, I believe, the fee for

Speaker: NA
Text: cataract surgery will be cut by at least half,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that will bring the fee for doing cataract

Speaker: NA
Text: surgery back to half of what it was over 25

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago in real dollar terms. That is still to

Text: MEMBER FOR HIGGINS

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition) (2.00 pm)-On indulgence,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, today is a momentous day in the

Speaker: NA
Text: history of our parliament and in the history

Speaker: NA
Text: of our country. The member for Higgins, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hon. Peter Costello, has announced that he

Speaker: NA
Text: will renom-

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: he will not renomi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nate for preselection as the member for Hig-

Speaker: NA
Text: gins. I am pleased the members opposite are

Speaker: NA
Text: so readily amused, because for 11½ years

Speaker: NA
Text: this country had the great gift of a Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: who took our nation from having $96 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: of debt to having no debt at all. He took our

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Other Chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: The Hon Maxine MCKew MP

Speaker: NA
Text: The Hon Gary Gray AO MP

Text: The Hon Dr Craig Emerson MP

Text: Senator the Hon Kim Carr The Hon Julia Gillard MP (Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search)

Text: The Hon Dr Craig Emerson MP Senator the Hon Kim Carr

Speaker: NA
Text: The Hon Richard Marles MP

Speaker: NA
Text: The Hon Peter Garrett AM MP Senator the Hon Penny Wong

Speaker: NA
Text: The Hon Dr Mike Kelly AM MP

Speaker: NA
Text: The Hon Robert MCClelland MP Senator the Hon Penny Wong

Speaker: NA
Text: The Hon Brendan O'Connor MP Senator the Hon Penny Wong

Text: are shown in bold type. As a general rule, there is

Text: there is a Department of Climate Change in the

Text: Affairs in the Defence portfolio. The title of a
