Text: the title of a minister in all cases.

Speaker: NA
Text: nation from a stage where it was putting

Speaker: NA
Text: heavier and heavier burdens on the shoulders

Speaker: NA
Text: of children and grandchildren yet to come, to

Speaker: NA
Text: one where it was putting money away in the

Speaker: NA
Text: bank in the Future Fund to relieve them of

Speaker: NA
Text: that burden. It was a period of unparalleled

Speaker: NA
Text: prosperity and unparalleled economic

Speaker: NA
Text: growth. And it could not have happened-it

Speaker: NA
Text: would never have happened-without the

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution of the member for Higgins.

Speaker: NA
Text: If I may, in this brief moment-

Speaker: NA
Text: recognising that there will be many other

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions to acknowledge the contribution of

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Higgins at greater length and

Speaker: NA
Text: to do him greater justice-I ask you to cast

Speaker: NA
Text: your minds back to his maiden speech in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1990, when he said:

Speaker: NA
Text: When we talk of creating a fairer and more com-

Speaker: NA
Text: passionate society, what do we mean? Over dec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ades arguments have raged over which system of

Speaker: NA
Text: government best creates such a society. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: have argued that a society where government

Speaker: NA
Text: controls industry and controls and directs the

Speaker: NA
Text: production and distribution of goods is a society

Speaker: NA
Text: that is inherently more compassionate and fair.

Speaker: NA
Text: Others have argued the converse. In this century

Speaker: NA
Text: the argument has raged between those who be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that by enhancing government power it, the

Speaker: NA
Text: government, can deliver fairness and compassion

Speaker: NA
Text: to its citizens and others who have maintained

Speaker: NA
Text: that in the interests of fairness the power of

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment itself must be curtailed and the compas-

Speaker: NA
Text: sionate resources of our citizens released.

Speaker: NA
Text: Peter Costello, for all his years in this par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament-20 years-has stood on the side of

Speaker: NA
Text: freedom and of enterprise. He has served our

Speaker: NA
Text: nation well. We salute him and we thank him

Speaker: NA
Text: for his service.

Speaker: Mr RUDD
Text: Griffith-Prime Minister)

Speaker: NA
Text: (2.03 pm)- Mr Speaker, if I may I will add

Speaker: NA
Text: to those remarks, on indulgence. I am ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vised that the member for Higgins has indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated that he will not be seeking re-election

Speaker: NA
Text: at the next federal election, nor will he be

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking preselection for the seat of Hig-

Speaker: NA
Text: gins-a seat, of course, which we still hold

Speaker: NA
Text: out hopes of winning one day for the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party! It was a joke, Malcolm; it was a joke!

Speaker: NA
Text: Can I say something about what is an im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant milestone in any member of parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's career. We enter this place with aspi-

Speaker: NA
Text: rations and hopes, and all the expectations of

Speaker: NA
Text: our families, our communities and ourselves

Speaker: NA
Text: that we bring here. It is an important day

Speaker: NA
Text: when you are elected to this place. Each of

Speaker: NA
Text: us can cast our minds back to when we first

Speaker: NA
Text: stood in the House of Representatives and

Speaker: NA
Text: the enormous pride which we felt in being

Speaker: NA
Text: elected and so representing our political

Speaker: NA
Text: party and our community.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is another equally important day,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that is when we choose to exit this place,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it should be marked appropriately as

Speaker: NA
Text: well, in terms of the contributions that have

Speaker: NA
Text: been made to public life. And this is one

Speaker: NA
Text: such day in the career of a member of this

Speaker: NA
Text: place-and a most notable member at that,

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Higgins. To have been a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of this parliament for 20 years is, of

Speaker: NA
Text: itself, a significant achievement. For that, in

Speaker: NA
Text: itself, the member should be commended-

Speaker: NA
Text: for having represented his constituency for

Speaker: NA
Text: such an extended period of time. Secondly,

Speaker: NA
Text: for having been Treasurer of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: govwealth for virtually 12 years is, of itself, a

Speaker: NA
Text: further credit to the individual member's

Speaker: NA
Text: talents and abilities. He would not have been

Speaker: NA
Text: put in that position by his political party, nor

Speaker: NA
Text: nominated by my predecessor Mr Howard,

Speaker: NA
Text: had confidence not been expressed in him by

Speaker: NA
Text: his party and by the leadership of his party in

Speaker: NA
Text: his considerable intellectual skills and the

Speaker: NA
Text: policy skills which he brings to the public

Speaker: NA
Text: policy debate in Australia. And for that he

Speaker: NA
Text: should be commended as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: On top of that I will add some remarks

Speaker: NA
Text: about his contribution to Australia's place in

Speaker: NA
Text: our international economic engagements

Speaker: NA
Text: through the IMF and beyond. The Treasurer,

Speaker: NA
Text: as he was then- Mr Costello, the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Higgins-was Australia's representative

Speaker: NA
Text: on the IMF and, through his occupancy of

Speaker: NA
Text: that position, other international financial

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions for which Australia has represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation. I would make two particular points

Speaker: NA
Text: about the IMF. One is that in the delibera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions following the Asian financial crisis in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1997-98, the decision at that stage to estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lish the G20 finance ministers meeting was

Speaker: NA
Text: something in which the member for Hig-

Speaker: NA
Text: gins-the Treasurer as he was at the time-

Speaker: NA
Text: played a role.

Speaker: NA
Text: The establishment of the G20 finance

Speaker: NA
Text: ministers meeting from that time on, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: events of the last 12 months in turn, provided

Speaker: NA
Text: a platform through which we, together with

Speaker: NA
Text: other governments, were able to elevate it to

Speaker: NA
Text: a heads of government meeting. That is now

Speaker: NA
Text: the G20 summit, which served this nation

Speaker: NA
Text: well in the meeting held in Washington at the

Speaker: NA
Text: end of last year and in London most recently,

Speaker: NA
Text: and will again, prospectively, in Pittsburgh

Speaker: NA
Text: this September. It has been an important ve-

Speaker: NA
Text: hicle for global economic governance. It had

Speaker: NA
Text: its foundations in the fact that we did have a

Speaker: NA
Text: body established at the finance ministers and

Speaker: NA
Text: treasurers level across 20 of the world's lead-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing economies back then. In those delibera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions at the time, the Treasurer, as he was

Speaker: NA
Text: then, the member for Higgins, played a sig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificant role.

Speaker: NA
Text: The further point I would make in that re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spect is that off the back of the Asian finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial crisis at the time, significant decisions

Speaker: NA
Text: were made here to intervene and support

Speaker: NA
Text: various of our neighbouring economies that

Speaker: NA
Text: were experiencing difficulties-from mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ory, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Republic of

Speaker: NA
Text: Korea. Decisions were taken by the then

Speaker: NA
Text: government, led by the Treasurer, as he was

Speaker: NA
Text: then, to provide significant offers of financial

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance to assist those economies through

Speaker: NA
Text: that difficult time. These were correct deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions in the national interest. They were cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rect decisions as good neighbours of these

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. And they were correct decisions, I

Speaker: NA
Text: would remind the House, which are not for-

Speaker: NA
Text: gotten today. The fact that we have good re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lations with the countries which I have just

Speaker: NA
Text: listed is in part anchored by decisions taken

Speaker: NA
Text: back then, and I would like to make appro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priate recognition of that in the House today.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will make one final point about the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portance of family in a place like this. The

Speaker: NA
Text: nearly 20 years that the member for Higgins

Speaker: NA
Text: has been in this House-as other members

Speaker: NA
Text: who have been here for an extended period

Speaker: NA
Text: of time will understand-has obviously been

Speaker: NA
Text: an extraordinary burden for his wife, his

Speaker: NA
Text: partner, as well as his children to bear. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is a burden which those of us who have been

Speaker: NA
Text: here for some time fully recognise and un-

Speaker: NA
Text: derstand.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would say to the member for Higgins, on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of his confreres and great mates here

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Australian Labor Party, that we wish

Speaker: NA
Text: him well and we wish his family well, after

Speaker: NA
Text: what has been a quite extraordinary career in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian public life.

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: Higgins) (2.09 pm)-

Speaker: NA
Text: On indulgence, Mr Speaker, may I say I did

Speaker: NA
Text: not think I would ever see the day where

Speaker: NA
Text: both sides of this parliament would say nice

Speaker: NA
Text: things about me! It is just possible that both

Speaker: NA
Text: sides of the dispatch box are happy with the

Speaker: NA
Text: announcement that I have made. I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: thank both the Leader of the Liberal Party,

Speaker: NA
Text: Malcolm Turnbull, and the Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Rudd, for their very kind words.

Speaker: NA
Text: Woody Allen was once asked what he

Speaker: NA
Text: hoped to hear people say at his funeral, and

Speaker: NA
Text: he said, ‘As I'm lying there at my funeral I

Speaker: NA
Text: would hope to hear somebody say, “Look,

Speaker: NA
Text: he's still moving!”' It is a very nice thing to

Speaker: NA
Text: come here, not being quite departed, and

Speaker: NA
Text: hear the kinds of speeches one usually only

Speaker: NA
Text: hears as eulogies. In fact, I might come back

Speaker: NA
Text: tomorrow for a little more, I am enjoying it

Speaker: NA
Text: so much!

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister, rightly, I think, talked

Speaker: NA
Text: about Australia's role in the formation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: G20. The G20 would not have happened

Speaker: NA
Text: without Australia. It brought together the

Speaker: NA
Text: developed world and the developing world,

Speaker: NA
Text: and Australia as neither-we came in as an

Speaker: NA
Text: honest broker because we stood in Asia's

Speaker: NA
Text: hour of need as the only country, along with

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan, that came to the rescue of those crisis

Speaker: NA
Text: affected economies. I do not need to say that,

Speaker: NA
Text: from our perspective, a seat at the table

Speaker: NA
Text: which represents 90 per cent of global GDP

Speaker: NA
Text: is a very, very important diplomatic position

Speaker: NA
Text: for us and for our country. It has moved up a

Speaker: NA
Text: notch now with the leader's summit. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: the role that it played when it was convened

Speaker: NA
Text: by President Bush and also by Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter Gordon Brown shows just how important

Speaker: NA
Text: it is. I do think that this is something Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia must never let go of. There will be others

Speaker: NA
Text: that will try and refashion a G-something

Speaker: NA
Text: else-a G8, a G7, a G13, a G14. Bear in

Speaker: NA
Text: mind the G20 is a forum where Australia can

Speaker: NA
Text: play a role, and it always has. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: chaired it; we have hosted it here in Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia. It will be integral, I think, to the shape

Speaker: NA
Text: the future global economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I thank the Leader of the Opposition for

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioning our achievements in the eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic sphere. Of course, those on the other

Speaker: NA
Text: side will not want to refer to them as much,

Speaker: NA
Text: for obvious reasons, but I will make one

Speaker: NA
Text: point. It is a point I have actually made in the

Speaker: NA
Text: new chapter of the forthcoming paperback

Speaker: NA
Text: edition of my book. I do not know if I men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned that the hardback copy has sold out,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we are publishing a paperback edition

Speaker: NA
Text: with a new chapter. The point I have made is

Speaker: NA
Text: that the strength of Australia's position in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of its debt-to-GDP ratio has nothing to

Speaker: NA
Text: do with the journey in the last year but eve-

Speaker: NA
Text: rything to do with the starting point. If we

Speaker: NA
Text: had not had a starting point of a net negative

Speaker: NA
Text: debt-that is, an asset position-then our

Speaker: NA
Text: debt position would be ending up where the

Speaker: NA
Text: Europeans, the Americans and the British

Speaker: NA
Text: are. It was the strength of the starting point

Speaker: NA
Text: that gave Australia ammunition that could be

Speaker: NA
Text: unloaded and unlocked in the current situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Every now and then it is worth paying

Speaker: NA
Text: credit to the people who put in place impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant reforms before your time. None of us

Speaker: NA
Text: come to politics in the year zero. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: always something that has gone on before. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have always paid credit, because I think they

Speaker: NA
Text: were right, to Hawke and Keating for the

Speaker: NA
Text: liberalisation of the financial markets and the

Speaker: NA
Text: cutting of tariffs, and there are things that we

Speaker: NA
Text: could also be given credit for, I think, by the

Speaker: NA
Text: current government. It will make Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: stronger if we do that.

Speaker: NA
Text: In that maiden speech that I gave so many

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago I said these words: ‘I believe in the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament.' And I do, and, although it was

Speaker: NA
Text: my privilege to be a minister for a very long

Speaker: NA
Text: period of time, the parliament is still impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant. There is no person in this place that is

Speaker: NA
Text: not important. Everybody had something that

Speaker: NA
Text: got them here and got them elected and eve-

Speaker: NA
Text: of rybody has a view that has to be listened to.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are lucky to have a parliament. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: why I very consciously decided after the

Speaker: NA
Text: election that I would stay in the parliament-

Speaker: NA
Text: because the parliament is an institution that

Speaker: NA
Text: should be preserved and valued, not just the

Speaker: NA
Text: ministry. It has been my privilege to be in

Speaker: NA
Text: this parliament for 20 years-what I consider

Speaker: NA
Text: the best years of my life.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also want to say I think Australia's best

Speaker: NA
Text: years can still be in front of it. This is still a

Speaker: NA
Text: young country with wonderful opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: and, properly governed, there are greater

Speaker: NA
Text: things in store for us.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister was very generous in

Speaker: NA
Text: his words. I thank him for those words. On

Speaker: NA
Text: this occasion he did not come the raw prawn;

Speaker: NA
Text: he gave a fair suck of the sauce bottle! And I

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciate the statement that he gave.

Speaker: NA
Text: Family means everything to me. You can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not imagine the strength that a strong family

Speaker: NA
Text: gives a person. I thank my family and my

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues, my branch members and my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate committee for everything they

Speaker: NA
Text: have given me. It has been an honour and a

Speaker: NA
Text: privilege to serve in this parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: Interest Rates

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: 2.15 pm)-My ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is to the Prime Minister. I refer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank's claim that its recent

Speaker: NA
Text: rate rise was caused by an increase in its own

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term wholesale borrowing costs. Given

Speaker: NA
Text: the increase in long-term rates is directly

Speaker: NA
Text: related to the massive explosion in govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment debt, doesn't the Prime Minister accept

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is his reckless spending and debt binge

Speaker: NA
Text: which is pushing up interest rates?

Speaker: Mr RUDD
Text: I thank the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition for his question. Let's go to the

Speaker: NA
Text: facts of what the Commonwealth Bank actu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally said. They said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The cheaper funding we had … prior to the

Speaker: NA
Text: crisis is rolling off and is being replaced by

Speaker: NA
Text: more expensive source of funding.

Speaker: NA
Text: The cost of raising funds from offshore whole-

Speaker: NA
Text: sale markets was still 12 times higher than it was

Speaker: NA
Text: before the credit crisis.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is: offshore.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hockey interjecting-

Speaker: Mr RUDD
Text: Let me go to the issue of

Speaker: NA
Text: offshore wholesale markets. Firstly, the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of bank finance, as the member for North

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney would be aware, is set in offshore

Speaker: NA
Text: global markets. Presently, in offshore bond

Speaker: NA
Text: markets we have something like $84 trillion

Speaker: NA
Text: on issue. The fraction of that which the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian bond market, the Australian debt mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ket, issues is 0.001. That is fact 1. Let us just

Speaker: NA
Text: put that into some context.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, the honourable member asks

Speaker: NA
Text: about the impact of Australian government

Speaker: NA
Text: actions in relation to rates. Can I say that one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the principal decisions taken by the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment, for which we were criticised by

Speaker: NA
Text: many of those opposite, was the decision to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide a guarantee on interbank lending in

Speaker: NA
Text: the wholesale finance market to banks.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would draw the honourable member's at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tention to the following. On 12 December

Speaker: NA
Text: 2008 the CBA issued guaranteed bonds at a

Speaker: NA
Text: total price, including the 70 basis point guar-

Speaker: NA
Text: antee price, of 160 basis points above the

Speaker: NA
Text: bank bill swap rate. As of 14 April 2009-

Speaker: NA
Text: that is, after the government's guarantee

Speaker: NA
Text: came into operation-the spread on the CBA

Speaker: NA
Text: issue was down to 123 basis points. In fact, if

Speaker: NA
Text: you look more broadly at the impact on

Speaker: NA
Text: money market spreads as a consequence of

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's direct intervention in the

Speaker: NA
Text: marketplace to support banks with the inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: bank guarantee, it runs as follows: following

Speaker: NA
Text: the collapse of Lehman Brothers the spread

Speaker: NA
Text: increased to 142 basis points; after the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment introduced the guarantees credit

Speaker: NA
Text: spreads had fallen to 80 basis points by the

Speaker: NA
Text: end of November, to 75 basis points by the

Speaker: NA
Text: this end of December, to 34 basis points by the

Speaker: NA
Text: end of March and to 21 basis points by the

Speaker: NA
Text: end of May. I would suggest that the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member reflects on that in terms of the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis of his question as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other thing I would draw to the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member's attention is the relevance

Speaker: NA
Text: of the government's actions in the market-

Speaker: NA
Text: place to support the interbank guarantee in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of the banks actual take-up of this

Speaker: NA
Text: guarantee in their international borrowing.

Speaker: NA
Text: And I would draw the honourable member's

Speaker: NA
Text: attention to the fact that, in the crisis period

Speaker: NA
Text: of October-November last year, interbank

Speaker: NA
Text: lending effectively collapsed to virtually

Speaker: NA
Text: zero. In fact, the total raisings by Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: banks in November last year were $0.14 bil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion-that is, practically zero. After we in-

Speaker: NA
Text: troduced the guarantee-which came into

Speaker: NA
Text: operation, from recollection, Treasurer, in

Speaker: NA
Text: early December-we had those raisings in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease to $23 billion, $28 billion, $19 billion,

Speaker: NA
Text: $8 billion et cetera.

Speaker: NA
Text: But here is the critical point for the benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: of the honourable member who has asked the

Speaker: NA
Text: question: the extent to which the banks have

Speaker: NA
Text: relied upon the guarantee for their actual

Speaker: NA
Text: raisings. In December last year 98 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the overall raisings by the banks were under-

Speaker: NA
Text: pinned by the government guarantee; in Feb-

Speaker: NA
Text: ruary it was 93 per cent, in March it was 86

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent, in April it was 65 per cent and in

Speaker: NA
Text: May it was 53 per cent. In terms of the nor-

Speaker: NA
Text: malisation of credit markets-that is, assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing banks to raise money offshore-from

Speaker: NA
Text: where we had collapsed to zero in November

Speaker: NA
Text: last year, we have had a restoration to these

Speaker: NA
Text: levels of raisings. Most critically, more then

Speaker: NA
Text: half since then-and, in the early months,

Speaker: NA
Text: practically all-have depended upon the

Speaker: NA
Text: government guarantee, producing the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: traction in spreads that I referred to before.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, I would suggest to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member as to the basis of his question:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Australia's public bond issue represents a

Speaker: NA
Text: fraction of 0.001 of the total bond issue

Speaker: NA
Text: which is alive globally-and it is the global

Speaker: NA
Text: bond market that shapes the offshore finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial markets which determine credit price (2)

Speaker: NA
Text: spreads have changed and (3) banks have

Speaker: NA
Text: relied upon the actions of this government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, I ask the honourable member who

Speaker: NA
Text: has asked this question about interest rates

Speaker: NA
Text: simply reflect on where interest rates stood

Speaker: NA
Text: under the previous government as opposed to

Speaker: NA
Text: where they stand under this government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the previous government we had 10

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rates rises in a row-a total rise of

Speaker: NA
Text: 250 basis points, costing an average family

Speaker: NA
Text: more than $400 per month-and interest

Speaker: NA
Text: rates were at their highest point in a decade.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what we inherited. I would contrast

Speaker: NA
Text: that with those opposite in the following

Speaker: NA
Text: way: since the government have been in of-

Speaker: NA
Text: fice families have benefited from six interest

Speaker: NA
Text: rate cuts-a total of 425 basis points-and

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rates are now at their lowest point in

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 50 years, which will save the av-

Speaker: NA
Text: erage family with a $300,000 mortgage

Speaker: NA
Text: around $750 a month, or $9,000 a year. So I

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest to the honourable member that he

Speaker: NA
Text: look at some basic comparisons. Let us look

Speaker: NA
Text: at where the CBA rate stood when the Liber-

Speaker: NA
Text: als left office-at 8.55 per cent. Where does

Speaker: NA
Text: it stand today? At 5.74 per cent. That repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sents a fundamental difference between in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terest rates as the existed under the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: government and where they exist today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, I would suggest to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentlemen that, when he poses questions

Speaker: NA
Text: like this, he reflect upon (a) interest rate per-

Speaker: NA
Text: formance under the previous government

Speaker: NA
Text: relative to what is occurring now (b) how

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rates and the cost of capital are actu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally shaped by offshore credit markets, as

Speaker: NA
Text: underpinned in the correct rendering of the

Speaker: NA
Text: statement by the CBA and (c) the impact that

Speaker: NA
Text: the government guarantee has had on spreads

Speaker: NA
Text: and on the actual uptake of interbank lending

Speaker: NA
Text: courtesy of the government's provision of

Speaker: NA
Text: that guarantee, which was much criticised.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will conclude by saying this: as those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite talk about the impact of the 10 basis

Speaker: NA
Text: point rise by the Commonwealth Bank of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, on which point the Treasurer and I

Speaker: NA
Text: to and others have reflected the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental disappointment, those opposite,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Leader of the Opposition in particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar, should reflect carefully on what he had to

Speaker: NA
Text: say when there was a 25 basis point rise not

Speaker: NA
Text: all that long ago. When interest rates went up

Speaker: NA
Text: in August 2006 by 25 basis points the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition said at the time, ‘I think

Speaker: NA
Text: the interest rate hike has been overdrama-

Speaker: NA
Text: tised.' Furthermore, on the question of inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: est rates, the Leader of the Opposition has

Speaker: NA
Text: also said much more recently-I think as

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow Treasurer:

Speaker: NA
Text: Banks are free to price their products as they

Speaker: NA
Text: wish. After all, they are in the business of making

Speaker: NA
Text: profits and, all things being equal, they will

Speaker: NA
Text: charge as much for every product they have on

Speaker: NA
Text: offer as the market will allow them.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is obviously the philosophy-the free

Speaker: NA
Text: market fundamentalist philosophy-

Speaker: NA
Text: represented by the Leader of the Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: He says that that is what occurs out there in

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rate markets. I would suggest that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition reflect carefully (a)

Speaker: NA
Text: on what he has said about how interest rate

Speaker: NA
Text: markets operate (b) on the relative perform-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance of interest rate pricing and cost under

Speaker: NA
Text: the government of which he was a part for

Speaker: NA
Text: such a long period of time as compared to

Speaker: NA
Text: what applies now and (c) how actual prices

Speaker: NA
Text: are set.

Speaker: NA
Text: DISTINGUISHED VISITORS

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: 2.24 pm)-I inform the

Speaker: NA
Text: House that we have present in the gallery

Speaker: NA
Text: this afternoon the Minister for Foreign Af-

Speaker: NA
Text: fairs and Cooperation of the government of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Republic of Rwanda, the Hon. Mrs

Speaker: NA
Text: Rosemary Museminali and also the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Foreign Affairs of the government of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Republic of Kenya, the Hon. Moses Wetan-

Speaker: NA
Text: gula. On behalf of the House I extend to both

Speaker: NA
Text: of you a very warm welcome.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members-Hear, hear!

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: Economy

Speaker: Mr CHEESEMAN
Text: 2.24 pm)-My ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is to the Prime Minister. Will the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister update the House on the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's nation building for recovery program

Speaker: NA
Text: to drive Australia out of the worst global

Speaker: NA
Text: cession in 75 years?

Speaker: Mr RUDD
Text: I thank the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for this question. The government

Speaker: NA
Text: has embarked on a course of action based on

Speaker: NA
Text: early and decisive action to support jobs and

Speaker: NA
Text: to cushion our economy from the worst im-

Speaker: NA
Text: pacts of the global recession.

Speaker: NA
Text: I refer the attention of the House to what

Speaker: NA
Text: we had produced in the last week in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: the most recent consumer sentiment index,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was up 12 per cent in June. This is the

Speaker: NA
Text: largest increase in 22 years. Consumer sen-

Speaker: NA
Text: timent is now up 20 per cent since the an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nouncement of the government's first eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic stimulus package in October and, fur-

Speaker: NA
Text: thermore, the consumer sentiment index is

Speaker: NA
Text: now at its highest level since January 2008.

Speaker: NA
Text: That covers consumer sentiment, but then, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, we have business confidence, which

Speaker: NA
Text: has also risen. Business confidence for May

Speaker: NA
Text: showed the sharpest rise that we have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: since 1989. It has now reached its highest

Speaker: NA
Text: level since February 2008. Furthermore, we

Speaker: NA
Text: saw other positive economic data in the

Speaker: NA
Text: housing sector, with housing finance grow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing by 3.5 per cent in April. First home buy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers in particular represent an increased pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: portion of that total amount, indicating that

Speaker: NA
Text: people are responding positively to the treb-

Speaker: NA
Text: ling of the first home owners boost.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was asked by the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: about the economic recovery-that is, our

Speaker: NA
Text: efforts to support an economic recovery in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and to lift Australia from the global

Speaker: NA
Text: economic recession. The data suggests that

Speaker: NA
Text: as of now-while there are still many diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: culties lying ahead-Australia is performing

Speaker: NA
Text: better than most other countries during this

Speaker: NA
Text: global recession, the worst in three-quarters

Speaker: NA
Text: of a century. Firstly, on the matter of eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic growth, if you look at the data itself,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has the fastest growth in the

Speaker: NA
Text: OECD. In the March quarter we saw the fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: relowing growth in some other economies:

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan, negative 3.8 per cent; the UK, nega-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive 1.9 per cent; the US, negative 1.5 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent; Canada, negative 1.4 per cent; France,

Speaker: NA
Text: negative 1.2 per cent; Germany, negative 3.8

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent; Italy, negative 2.6 per cent; and

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia grew in the March quarter by 0.4

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent. Against those measures the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian economy is performing relatively well.

Speaker: NA
Text: On unemployment, Australia on the most

Speaker: NA
Text: recent data has the second lowest unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment of the major advanced economies:

Speaker: NA
Text: in the UK it is 7.1 per cent; the US, 9.4 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent; Canada, 8.4 per cent; France, 9.1 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent; Germany, 8.2 per cent; Italy, 6.9 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent; in Australia it is 5.7 per cent-still too

Speaker: NA
Text: high-and in Japan it is 5 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: On debt, Australia has the lowest net debt

Speaker: NA
Text: of the major advanced economies. To again

Speaker: NA
Text: go through the numbers: Japan, 103 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of GDP; the UK, 56.8 per cent; the US, 61.7

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent; Canada, 26.2 per cent; France, 65.2

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent; Germany, 70.9 per cent; Italy, 111.9

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent; and the major economies have an

Speaker: NA
Text: average of 70.4 per cent of GDP. Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: debt is currently forecast to be 4.6 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: 2009-10 rising to 13.8 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the matters of deficits, Australia has a

Speaker: NA
Text: lower budget deficit than the average of the

Speaker: NA
Text: major advanced economies in 2009. The fig-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures are: Japan, minus 9.9 per cent; the UK,

Speaker: NA
Text: 9.8 per cent; the US, 13.6 per cent; France,

Speaker: NA
Text: 6.2 per cent; Germany, 4.7 per cent; Italy, 5.5

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent; and their average is 10.4 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Canada is at minus 3.4 per cent and Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: is at minus 4.9 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: down?

Speaker: Mr RUDD
Text: The member for Sturt is ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: viously not keen on hearing this data. But it

Speaker: NA
Text: is important that the House reflect on the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that every one of the major advanced

Speaker: NA
Text: economies has fallen into recession and Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia has not. I say to those opposite that,

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore, when it comes to economic

Speaker: NA
Text: growth, Australia is the fastest among the

Speaker: NA
Text: major advanced economies and with unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment we have the second lowest of the

Speaker: NA
Text: major advanced economies. On top of that

Speaker: NA
Text: our net debt is the lowest of the major ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vanced economies and our deficit is the low-

Speaker: NA
Text: est of the average of the major advanced

Speaker: NA
Text: economies. These are the data which repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent the impact not just of government policy

Speaker: NA
Text: action but also of the decisive contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: by individuals in the Australian economy as

Speaker: NA
Text: well-the men and women of business and

Speaker: NA
Text: small business in particular.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have some 35,000 construction pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: jects currently underway across the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are important projects for the nation. I

Speaker: NA
Text: notice in this respect that there is a debate

Speaker: NA
Text: within the Australian community about the

Speaker: NA
Text: future of the nation's construction sector. The

Speaker: NA
Text: building and construction sector is critical

Speaker: NA
Text: for the economy. While this sector is full of

Speaker: NA
Text: hardworking and law-abiding people helping

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to build towards recovery, there are

Speaker: NA
Text: also plainly problems. There has been a his-

Speaker: NA
Text: in tory of violence and threats of violence in

Speaker: NA
Text: parts of this sector and these cannot be ig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nored and nor will they be ignored. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: a determination within the Australian gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment to get this right. We will honour our

Speaker: NA
Text: election commitments and have indeed a

Speaker: NA
Text: tough cop on the beat. We will honour this

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment in a fair and responsible way

Speaker: NA
Text: for the sector, for the economy and also,

Speaker: NA
Text: most importantly, to support economic re-

Speaker: NA
Text: covery.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are not out of the woods yet. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: much work to be done. The government's

Speaker: NA
Text: strategy is to lift the economy up through

Speaker: NA
Text: nation building for recovery. I would again

Speaker: NA
Text: contrast that with the strategy embraced by

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite, which is to continue to talk

Speaker: NA
Text: the economy down.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Text: 2.30 pm)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: is to the Treasurer. I refer to the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's claim that its massive debt burden is

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for job creation and has nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: at all to do with rising interest rates. Will the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer now release all Treasury modelling

Speaker: NA
Text: that is used to justify his claims that this

Speaker: NA
Text: huge taxpayer debt is supporting jobs?

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: I thank the shadow Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: for his question. He is acutely embarrassed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the jobs performance of our stimulus

Speaker: NA
Text: package. It is playing a vital role in support-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing employment in the Australian economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Both he and the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: were acutely embarrassed when the national

Speaker: NA
Text: accounts figures came out the week before

Speaker: NA
Text: last, because what they showed was that it

Speaker: NA
Text: was our stimulus that was promoting growth,

Speaker: NA
Text: employment and business in the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: NA
Text: When you listen to the shadow Treasurer,

Speaker: NA
Text: you would think that there was some alterna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive. We have this dishonest campaign about

Speaker: NA
Text: deficits and borrowing when the truth is that

Speaker: NA
Text: we know that they would borrow not one

Speaker: NA
Text: cent less than us and that they would not pay

Speaker: NA
Text: it back one day earlier. We know that. Last

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunday week, there was an embarrassing

Speaker: NA
Text: performance by the shadow Treasurer with

Speaker: NA
Text: Laurie Oakes. Laurie Oakes asked him this:

Speaker: NA
Text: But, if you'd been in government, you also would

Speaker: NA
Text: have lost $210 billion from your forward esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mates wouldn't you? So, do you concede that you

Speaker: NA
Text: would have had to borrow that amount if you

Speaker: NA
Text: were in government?

Speaker: NA
Text: The shadow Treasurer replied:

Speaker: NA
Text: No way Laurie, no way.

Speaker: NA
Text: What a completely ridiculous claim: ‘There's

Speaker: NA
Text: no global recession; it has no impact on the

Speaker: NA
Text: revenues. No way, Laurie; no loss of revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: at all.' Laurie Oakes went on to ask him this

Speaker: NA
Text: very obvious question:

Speaker: NA
Text: So you'd be spending $210 billion less over that

Speaker: NA
Text: period?

Speaker: NA
Text: The shadow Treasurer replied:

Speaker: NA
Text: No, no, not at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: of order on relevance. The question very

Speaker: NA
Text: specifically asked whether the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: would release the Treasury modelling that

Speaker: NA
Text: they use to justify their job creation claims.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even the Treasurer must recognise that his

Speaker: NA
Text: answer is ranging a long way from the ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that he was asked.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Manager of Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition Business will resume his seat. The pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: amble of the question related to debt levels,

Speaker: NA
Text: job creation and interest rates.

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: Exactly. And it relates to the

Speaker: NA
Text: level of borrowings that this government has

Speaker: NA
Text: had to make responsibly to support our

Speaker: NA
Text: economy and to support employment in the

Speaker: NA
Text: middle of a global recession. Mr Oakes said:

Speaker: NA
Text: So you'd be spending $210 billion less over that

Speaker: NA
Text: period?

Speaker: NA
Text: Hockey said:

Speaker: NA
Text: No, no, not at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: So there would be no global recession, they

Speaker: NA
Text: would have less deficit and debt and they

Speaker: NA
Text: would be able to do that without spending a

Speaker: NA
Text: cent less. Talk about a magic pudding!

Speaker: NA
Text: The truth is that we have had to borrow

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibly to cover the revenue collapse

Speaker: NA
Text: brought on in this country-imposed on this

Speaker: NA
Text: country-by a global recession and to sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port employment to give us the outcomes

Speaker: NA
Text: that we got in the national accounts the week

Speaker: NA
Text: before last and to give us the consumer con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fidence figures that the Prime Minister was

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about before.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hockey- Mr Speaker, I rise on a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order on relevance. I just asked the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer to release the basis of his claims.

Speaker: NA
Text: Just release it; he uses it all the time. Just

Speaker: NA
Text: release it.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for North

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney will resume his seat. As I suggested

Speaker: NA
Text: to the member for Sturt, the Treasurer is re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponding to the question.

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: What we saw in the embar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rassment on Laurie Oakes's program is that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no alternative policy. None of

Speaker: NA
Text: them-not one of the entire frontbench-has

Speaker: NA
Text: an alternative policy. All they have is a dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: honest scare campaign about deficit and

Speaker: NA
Text: debt. It is about time that they came clean

Speaker: NA
Text: and admitted that if they were in government

Speaker: NA
Text: they would have to borrow as much as the

Speaker: NA
Text: government has had to borrow to support

Speaker: NA
Text: employment in the Australian economy. But

Speaker: NA
Text: they are so opportunistic. They are so con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned with their own political futures that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are not concerned with the national in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terest. We published for everybody to see in

Speaker: NA
Text: our budget all of our figures; all of our esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mates. Because they are inconvenient for

Speaker: NA
Text: their fake political position, they cannot wear

Speaker: NA
Text: them.

Speaker: NA
Text: On this side of the House, we are proud of

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget that we brought down. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: proud of the role that it is playing in supportbeen

Speaker: NA
Text: ing employment. There are 200,000 more

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians in employment as a consequence

Speaker: NA
Text: of our budget. That is 200,000-plus people in

Speaker: NA
Text: employment who would not have been in

Speaker: NA
Text: employment if it had not been for our

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. That is their embarrassment; that is

Speaker: NA
Text: what they cannot admit to. That is why their

Speaker: NA
Text: dishonest campaign is there for everybody to

Speaker: NA
Text: see.

Speaker: NA
Text: Building the Education Revolution

Speaker: NA
Text: Program

Speaker: Ms BIRD
Text: 2.36 pm)-My question is to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Education, Minister for Em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment and Workplace Relations and Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister for Social Inclusion. Will the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister update the House on recent

Speaker: NA
Text: media reports about the Building the Educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Revolution program?

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: I thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Cunningham for her question. I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: she would be very delighted that jobs in her

Speaker: NA
Text: local economy are being supported through

Speaker: NA
Text: the economic stimulus plan. There are over

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,133 projects in her electorate, and 87 of

Speaker: NA
Text: these projects are at 61 of her local schools

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Building the Education Revolution

Speaker: NA
Text: program. This contribution in Cunningham is

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the biggest school modernisation pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram the nation has ever seen. Over the next

Speaker: NA
Text: 12 months there will be 23,000 projects in

Speaker: NA
Text: about 9,500 schools around the country-a

Speaker: NA
Text: huge national effort to support jobs today

Speaker: NA
Text: whilst we build the infrastructure we need

Speaker: NA
Text: for tomorrow.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, you and others in the House

Speaker: NA
Text: may have seen some recent publicity about

Speaker: NA
Text: the guidelines for the Building the Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Revolution and some claims relating to ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: penditure in particular schools. Can I make

Speaker: NA
Text: this position very clear for the House: the

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines for the Building the Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Revolution are clear; they are available pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: licly on the website; and they have certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: absorbed by school communities who

Speaker: NA
Text: want to benefit their schools under this pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram. In particular, the Building the Educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Revolution guidelines have required

Speaker: NA
Text: that, wherever it is possible, local tradespeo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple are engaged for the work. Preference

Speaker: NA
Text: must also be given to businesses that have

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrated a commitment to adding or

Speaker: NA
Text: retaining trainees and apprentices. The

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines also state that, wherever possible,

Speaker: NA
Text: new buildings and refurbishments should

Speaker: NA
Text: incorporate sustainable building principles

Speaker: NA
Text: and be designed to maximise energy effi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciency. The guidelines are also clear that, for

Speaker: NA
Text: planned amalgamations, the indicative fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing allocation for the school to be merged

Speaker: NA
Text: can be combined and used for capital or re-

Speaker: NA
Text: furbishments in the new school. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: working cooperatively with state and terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory authorities and with the independent and

Speaker: NA
Text: Catholic school systems to deliver this huge

Speaker: NA
Text: modernisation program.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: The opposition are cat-

Speaker: NA
Text: calling about this because they do not sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port and have never supported this invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in schools. Mr Speaker, you may have

Speaker: NA

Text: was alleged that funding was being handed

Speaker: NA
Text: to schools slated for closure or amalgama-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Text: I hear the shadow min-

Text: that in just a moment, and he will be very

Speaker: NA
Text: here-

Speaker: NA
Text: minister for education, caring nothing about

Text: My answer is as it was the

Speaker: NA
Text: last time the honourable member raised this

Speaker: NA
Text: question because that is the advice I have

Speaker: NA
Text: received from my office. Furthermore, can I

Speaker: NA
Text: say to the honourable member that, since this

Speaker: NA
Text: particular vehicle was provided by the indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: vidual concerned, the declaration on pecuni-

Speaker: NA
Text: ary interest was made. The ute was valued at

Speaker: NA
Text: around $5,000; it was put in my pecuniary

Speaker: NA
Text: interest statement on 3 July 2007, as is re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired by the Commonwealth parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: Furthermore, I would say to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member that, in terms of representations that

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made by various members in this

Speaker: NA
Text: place, I am also advised that in addition to

Speaker: NA
Text: the car dealer from Sydney who spoke to me,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kaplan, from Hunter Holden in Sydney,

Speaker: NA
Text: OzCar which I referred to the other day in answer to

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member's question, there

Speaker: NA
Text: have also been representations to the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment from the member for Riverina, the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Dunkley, the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Murray and, of course, the member for Daw-

Speaker: NA
Text: son as well. It is entirely normal for repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentations to be made to OzCar because this

Speaker: NA
Text: is the sort of thing that members of parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment are required to do if they are asked to

Speaker: NA
Text: actually get out there and support the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reason this particular facility existed

Speaker: NA
Text: was that we were approached as a govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment by the industry at the end of 2008 about

Speaker: NA
Text: the collapse in normal supplies of motor ve-

Speaker: NA
Text: hicle finance. As a consequence of that, the

Speaker: NA
Text: government took the view that a co-

Speaker: NA
Text: investment vehicle, a special-purpose vehi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cle, between ourselves and the banks was an

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate way to step into the marketplace

Speaker: NA
Text: and to provide, therefore, an alternative

Speaker: NA
Text: source of finance. We have also been advised

Speaker: NA
Text: that, had we not done so, the impact that

Speaker: NA
Text: would have had in terms of confidence

Speaker: NA
Text: across the industry would have been signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant. Therefore, I would say this has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: worthwhile measure on the part of the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment, and any member of this place, if

Speaker: NA
Text: they are approached by a business seeking to

Speaker: NA
Text: access a government program, would be en-

Speaker: NA
Text: tirely entitled to make representations.

Speaker: NA
Text: go back to the honourable member's ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion: the advice that I received from my of-

Speaker: NA
Text: fice remains current on the matter which the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member raises.

Speaker: NA
Text: Economy

Speaker: Mr RAGUSE
Text: 2.48 pm)-My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Treasurer. Will the Treasurer outline

Speaker: NA
Text: the House the estimated cost to the economy

Speaker: NA
Text: and the budget of not acting to support up to

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: I thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Forde for his very important question. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: the case that the No. 1 priority of the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment is jobs-to support Australian jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: in the face of this most savage global reces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion. Of course, the economic stimulus that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have put in place is expected to reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: the forecast peak in the unemployment rate

Speaker: NA
Text: by 1½ percentage points and it will support

Speaker: NA
Text: up to 210,000 more jobs over the period

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead. That is something the government is

Speaker: NA
Text: very proud of. It is important for us to invest

Speaker: NA
Text: in nation-building infrastructure, to support

Speaker: NA
Text: employment and to support business given

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that there is a withdrawal of private

Speaker: NA
Text: investment and given the collapse in the

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of trade-the dramatic reduction in

Speaker: NA
Text: national income. All of those reasons make it

Speaker: NA
Text: very important that our stimulus, through

Speaker: NA
Text: phase 1, phase 2 and phase 3, continues. That

Speaker: NA
Text: means we do need to borrow responsibly to

Speaker: NA
Text: support employment and to support Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian businesses. The fact that 210,000 Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian families with breadwinners benefit from

Speaker: NA
Text: that is very important. We should not under-

Speaker: NA
Text: estimate the cost to the economy if the un-

Speaker: NA
Text: employment rate were to go up even higher.

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasury estimate that, without economic

Speaker: NA
Text: stimulus, total employee incomes over the

Speaker: NA
Text: next decade would be around $100 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: lower. As a result, budget revenues from less

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax alone would be about $23 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: lower. Of course, spending on unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: But to ment benefits would be about $4 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: higher over the next four years and of course

Speaker: NA
Text: the number of long-term unemployed would

Speaker: NA
Text: be higher. All of those things come at a tre-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendous cost to the economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: But, in this discussion about stimulus and

Speaker: NA
Text: what it does, we should also focus on the

Speaker: NA
Text: to human cost of unemployment-what cost is

Speaker: NA
Text: passed on to the economy through the break-

Speaker: NA
Text: up of families and through the impact on

Speaker: NA
Text: local communities. Every job lost is one too

Speaker: NA
Text: many, which is why the government is so

Speaker: NA
Text: determined to put in place its economic

Speaker: NA
Text: stimulus to support employment and to sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port businesses. We have heard in the House,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly from the Deputy Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier, just how important the investment is

Speaker: NA
Text: in schools and just how important the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestment is in social housing, in clean energy

Speaker: NA
Text: and so on-to support employment while at

Speaker: NA
Text: the same time leaving a lasting legacy for the

Speaker: NA
Text: country. This government is absolutely de-

Speaker: NA
Text: termined to be on the front foot, to put in

Speaker: NA
Text: place positive plans for the future so that it

Speaker: NA
Text: can support employment and make our

Speaker: NA
Text: economy and country a far better place.

Speaker: NA
Text: Economy

Speaker: Mr BRADBURY
Text: 2.52 pm)-My ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is to the Minister for Finance and De-

Speaker: NA
Text: regulation. How have the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: stimulus measures helped to support the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian economy and why is it important for

Speaker: NA
Text: these measures to receive broad support from

Speaker: NA
Text: all parts of the community?

Speaker: Mr TANNER
Text: I think the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Lindsay for his question. Could I also wish

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Higgins well on his depar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture. It is always a sad day when parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: loses a dedicated Essendon supporter, al-

Speaker: NA
Text: though the Minister for Trade may not agree

Speaker: NA
Text: with that, and I wish him well. The govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has put in place an economic strategy

Speaker: NA
Text: built around stimulating economic activity in

Speaker: NA
Text: various sections of the economy in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: take up the slack being left by the global

Speaker: NA
Text: contraction that is hitting the entire world.

Speaker: NA
Text: doing so, we are sustaining approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: 210,000 jobs and countless businesses that

Speaker: NA
Text: otherwise would go under as a result of the

Speaker: NA
Text: global recession. That stimulus is going

Speaker: NA
Text: through payments as to maintenance of

Speaker: NA
Text: school buildings, construction of new school

Speaker: NA
Text: buildings, construction of new homes and

Speaker: NA
Text: construction of new road, rail and other pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: jects. That stimulus strategy has received

Speaker: NA
Text: widespread support throughout the commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity including from most sections of the

Speaker: NA
Text: business community. But, sadly, that support

Speaker: NA
Text: has not been universal. It is particularly dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: appointing that the opposition not only has

Speaker: NA
Text: refused to support the government's eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic stimulus strategy but has continued to

Speaker: NA
Text: snipe at it in an even more hysterical and

Speaker: NA
Text: unfounded way.

Speaker: NA
Text: But last Friday the shadow Treasurer, the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for North Sydney, broke his own

Speaker: NA
Text: previous world record for silliness when he

Speaker: NA
Text: blamed the Commonwealth Bank's increase

Speaker: NA
Text: of 0.1 per cent in its interest rates on the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's stimulus package. I note that

Speaker: NA
Text: this was coming from a former cabinet min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister from a party that when in government

Speaker: NA
Text: promised to keep interest rates at record lows

Speaker: NA
Text: and then delivered 10 interest rate increases

Speaker: NA
Text: in a row. I note also that a respected econom-

Speaker: NA
Text: ics commentator and member of the press

Speaker: NA
Text: gallery described these claims as ‘bizarre

Speaker: NA
Text: garbage'. I think that is a very apt description

Speaker: NA
Text: of the accusation that the shadow Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: made.

Speaker: NA
Text: The factor that has been driving the sepa-

Speaker: NA
Text: ration of market interest rates from official

Speaker: NA
Text: Reserve Bank of Australia interest rates over

Speaker: NA
Text: the past 12 months or so is universally ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledged as the turbulence on interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional financial markets, on global financial

Speaker: NA
Text: markets. That is certainly the reason that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank has advanced for the

Speaker: NA
Text: position that it has taken with respect to its

Speaker: NA
Text: market interest rates: the higher cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: In wholesale funding flowing through from

Speaker: NA
Text: international financial markets into market

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rates in Australia. In effect, the posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion being taken by the shadow Treasurer and

Speaker: NA
Text: being endorsed implicitly by the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition today says that projected

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian government borrowing, the vast

Speaker: NA
Text: bulk of which has yet to occur, is pushing up

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rates in global financial markets and

Speaker: NA
Text: that is crowding out private sector activity in

Speaker: NA
Text: global financial markets. Any examination of

Speaker: NA
Text: the facts will demonstrate that this cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: the case because the Australian proportion of

Speaker: NA
Text: total global government borrowing is ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tremely small, as the Prime Minister outlined

Speaker: NA
Text: before, and Australia has the lowest pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: jected debt profile of all of the major devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: oped economies in the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is interesting to note, if you want to fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: low their arguments and if you want to fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: low through the logic of some of their state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments, and also it is always worth referring

Speaker: NA
Text: back to what the opposition said a little while

Speaker: NA
Text: ago. In effect, what they are saying at the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment is that the government is borrowing

Speaker: NA
Text: in order to finance stimulus payments and

Speaker: NA
Text: that that borrowing is crowding out the abil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity of Australia's banks to finance lending

Speaker: NA
Text: and as a result they have to push up interest

Speaker: NA
Text: rates. It is not that long ago that an opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion member stood here telling us that those

Speaker: NA
Text: same payments were not going to be spent.

Speaker: NA
Text: They were going to be saved. They were go-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to end up with the banks. They were go-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to end up in people's bank accounts. So

Speaker: NA
Text: somehow or other the banks are losing

Speaker: NA
Text: money as a result of borrowing for the stimu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lus payments which are ending up with the

Speaker: NA
Text: banks, according to the position of the oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition. The same person has also said that,

Speaker: NA
Text: should the opposition be elected and were it

Speaker: NA
Text: in office tomorrow, it would maintain the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's stimulus strategy. With Laurie

Speaker: NA
Text: Oakes eight days ago, when asked about this

Speaker: NA
Text: issue, the shadow Treasurer, the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: North Sydney, said that it was hard to un-

Speaker: NA
Text: scramble the egg and that the opposition,

Speaker: NA
Text: were it to become the government tomorrow,

Speaker: NA
Text: would maintain the government's stimulus

Speaker: NA
Text: strategy. The shadow Treasurer has a habit,

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunately, of saying whatever pops into

Speaker: NA
Text: his head irrespective of substance, rigour and

Speaker: NA
Text: any kind of content.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hockey-What am I thinking now?

Speaker: NA
Text: What am I thinking now, Lindsay?

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Gillard-‘When's Malcolm Turnbull

Speaker: NA
Text: retiring?'-that's what you're thinking.

Speaker: Mr TANNER
Text: That is right. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: two people who are very glad you are going,

Speaker: NA
Text: Peter, and they are both on that side. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: same interview with Laurie Oakes eight days

Speaker: NA
Text: ago, the member for North Sydney accused

Speaker: NA
Text: the government of ‘spending record levels on

Speaker: NA
Text: advertising'. I thought I had entered a paral-

Speaker: NA
Text: lel universe on that Sunday morning. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: early in the morning and I was a bit con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned about my state of mind. I thought I

Speaker: NA
Text: had better check the facts. The facts are

Speaker: NA
Text: these: in calendar 2007 total spending on

Speaker: NA
Text: government campaign advertising, $254 mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion; in the 2008 calendar year total spending

Speaker: NA
Text: on government campaign advertising, $87

Speaker: NA
Text: million-in other words, barely a third of the

Speaker: NA
Text: record level set by the former government of

Speaker: NA
Text: which the shadow Treasurer was a member.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, I would like to draw the

Speaker: NA
Text: House's attention to the shadow Treasurer's

Speaker: NA
Text: solution to the problem that he believes is

Speaker: NA
Text: there with government spending and borrow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing crowding out the private sector. He says,

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘The government should spend less money.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Now, there is a slight problem with that.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is something of a problem as those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite have yet to nominate a single sav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings proposal in 18 months-not one. They

Speaker: NA
Text: say they would continue with the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's stimulus payments were they in office

Speaker: NA
Text: tomorrow. They continue to block govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment savings initiatives in the Senate and, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, they keep dropping out expensive

Speaker: NA
Text: new promises on top of that. So for them, as

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposition, to suggest that the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment should be spending less money would

Speaker: NA
Text: be slightly more credible were they to actu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally act in opposition in the same way as we

Speaker: NA
Text: did and put forward savings proposals, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, the Treasurer and I did in

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition prior to the 2007 election. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: time that the opposition put the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer out of his misery. I used to think it

Speaker: NA
Text: was crook that they had a shadow Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: who nicked other people's lines. I have now

Speaker: NA
Text: worked out there is one thing even worse.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is someone who makes up his own.

Text: Building the Education Revolution

Speaker: NA
Text: Program

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Education. I refer the minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter to the Hastings Public School in New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales, which was granted $400,000

Text: for a covered outdoor learning area under the

Text: six years-what action will the minister take

Text: to stamp out waste and mismanagement in

Speaker: NA
Text: the schools stimulus debacle?

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: I thank the shadow min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister for his question, because it proves yet

Speaker: NA
Text: again how little the Liberal Party cares about

Speaker: NA
Text: education in this country. On the specific

Speaker: NA
Text: school that he raises, I will of course investiIf

Text: gate the details of this matter, but can I say

Text: this: the track record of the Liberal Party in

Text: raising accurate claims in this House is a

Text: very poor one indeed. Given that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: already had questions from the Liberal oppo-

Text: sition which, when investigated, turned out

Text: to be completely incorrect, I will not accept

Speaker: NA
Text: any fact asserted by the shadow minister

Text: without having it thoroughly checked. So we

Speaker: NA
Text: will undertake those checks.

Speaker: NA
Text: The shadow minister might think it is

Speaker: NA
Text: smart, as a representative of the Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: Party, to go around the country insulting

Speaker: NA
Text: school communities on the work that is hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pening in their schools. The Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition might think it is smart to vote

Speaker: NA
Text: against $14.7 billion going into local schools

Speaker: NA
Text: and all of the support for local jobs that that

Speaker: NA
Text: provides. But, if they ever got out of their

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal Party bubble and went to a school

Speaker: NA
Text: and spoke to some real human beings about

Speaker: NA
Text: what is happening in their school, they

Speaker: NA
Text: would find a sense of delight about the pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibilities for better quality education that this

Speaker: NA
Text: program brings. I personally have visited

Speaker: NA
Text: schools. I have addressed principals forums

Speaker: NA
Text: where we have talked through Building the

Speaker: NA
Text: Education Revolution and where principals,

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers, parents and, indeed, students them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves have been delighted about the possi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility that it brings to their school and the

Speaker: NA
Text: support that it brings to their local commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity.

Speaker: NA
Text: Here we are in the parliament and what

Speaker: NA
Text: we hear constantly from the opposition is

Speaker: NA
Text: carping, moaning and criticism, just like we

Speaker: NA
Text: are hearing now. What we never hear from

Speaker: NA
Text: the shadow minister for education is an edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation policy-not once, not ever.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: der under the standing orders: the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: was asked a very specific question about

Speaker: NA
Text: profiteering. She is now engaging in rhetoric.

Speaker: NA
Text: she does not know the answer off the top

Speaker: NA
Text: of her head, she should simply sit down.

Text: Order! The Deputy

Speaker: NA

Text: for government schools? If the Liberal Party

Text: and numeracy? If the Liberal Party were

Text: 3.05 pm)-My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport,

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional Development and Local Govern-

Text: ment. Will the minister please update the

Text: House on the rollout of the government's

Text: record investment in regional infrastructure

Text: representatives?

Text: I thank the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Page for her question. More than $21

Speaker: NA
Text: billion of the $35 billion we have set aside

Text: for transport infrastructure will be spent in

Speaker: NA
Text: regional and rural Australia. The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Page will certainly be pleased-I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: quite so sure about the member for Cow-

Text: per-that I have announced today that de-

Text: tailed engineering work will start this week

Text: on the $618 million Kempsey bypass. That

Text: will enable construction work to commence

Text: at the beginning of next year, creating some

Text: jobs, in Kempsey on the North Coast of New

Text: South Wales. I am asked about how the in-

Text: representatives have had a say about this

Text: project-which they could not get around to

Text: due. This is a direct piece of self-criticism

Text: from the National Party representatives, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: literacy cluding the member for Cowper.

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional representatives have also had a

Speaker: NA
Text: bit to say. The Vice-President of the National
