Text: Farmers Federation has said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Transport infrastructure investment, including

Speaker: NA
Text: road and port funding, is welcomed.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said that in a statement that the NFF put

Speaker: NA
Text: out supporting this government's record

Speaker: NA
Text: funding in regional Australia. I am asked

Speaker: NA
Text: about other representatives and what they

Speaker: NA
Text: had to say about our budget proposals and

Speaker: NA
Text: the record investment which is supporting

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs today and building the infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australia needs for tomorrow.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note that the Leader of the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party was speaking at a New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: Nationals conference in Wagga Wagga last

Speaker: NA
Text: Friday. He is also the shadow minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: transport and I thought he might have a bit to

Speaker: NA
Text: say at that conference. Members will recall

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendment moved to the Nation Build-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Program legislation, when the parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: sat a couple of weeks ago, that would stop

Speaker: NA
Text: funding of black spots in regional communi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties. Remember that amendment which the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition moved so that you could not have

Speaker: NA
Text: black spot funding on the national network?

Speaker: NA
Text: They all went to the photo opportunities in

Speaker: NA
Text: their electorates applauding the funding, yet

Speaker: NA
Text: they had voted against it being permitted

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Nation Building Program. I

Speaker: NA
Text: thought the Leader of the National Party

Speaker: NA
Text: might have a bit to say about how the oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition are taking on the government over this

Speaker: NA
Text: outrageous measure that they say the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment has put in. I had a look at the speech

Speaker: NA
Text: and there are 2,600 words in it but transport

Speaker: NA
Text: is not mentioned, not even once. There is not

Speaker: NA
Text: one word from the shadow minister about

Speaker: NA
Text: transport. There is nothing about nation

Speaker: NA
Text: building or about infrastructure. He had

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing at all to say.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the National Party was in

Speaker: NA
Text: Wagga Wagga at the conference and he

Speaker: NA
Text: would have known-and there would have

Speaker: NA
Text: been people from Wagga Wagga there, too,

Speaker: NA
Text: who would have known-that we are dupli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cating the Hume Highway by 2012, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are bringing forward record spending on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Hume Highway. I had a look at what was

Speaker: NA
Text: in the speech of the Leader of the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party and he said a very interesting thing. He

Speaker: NA
Text: said:

Speaker: NA
Text: We are increasingly seen as the party of regional tomorrow.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, grounded in the regions and taking

Speaker: NA
Text: forward regional expertise and ideas for consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration in Canberra and Macquarie Street.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is an interesting perspective given that,

Speaker: NA
Text: when I was elected here in 1996 there were

Speaker: NA
Text: 18 Nationals in the parliament and now there

Speaker: NA
Text: are nine. Yet they argue that they are moving

Speaker: NA
Text: forward and are increasingly seen as the

Speaker: NA
Text: party of regional Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Oakeshott interjecting-

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: I notice the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Lyne having a good chuckle at the idea

Speaker: NA
Text: that the National Party are the party of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gional Australia and that they are moving

Speaker: NA
Text: forward in Macquarie Street and in Canberra.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the National Party has become

Speaker: NA
Text: the Comical Ali of the Parliament. Remem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber Comical Ali as the US troops came into

Speaker: NA
Text: Baghdad? He said, ‘It's okay, nothing's hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pening. It's okay, we're going well.' Comical

Speaker: NA
Text: Ali had this to say about the Americans, ‘We

Speaker: NA
Text: have destroyed their shovels. We have driven

Speaker: NA
Text: them back.' Well, those opposite want to de-

Speaker: NA
Text: stroy the shovels of the government, those

Speaker: NA
Text: nation-building shovels that are being util-

Speaker: NA
Text: ised throughout the country to build roads, to

Speaker: NA
Text: build rail and to build ports. Those opposite,

Speaker: NA
Text: in spite of their best efforts to stop the na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion-building agenda of this government, will

Speaker: NA
Text: not succeed.

Speaker: NA
Text: I must say that the Leader of the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party perhaps listened to the leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition who said, on 20 May when he was

Speaker: NA
Text: in Adelaide, about the government's nation-

Speaker: NA
Text: building agenda and I quote:

Speaker: NA
Text: … everything will have to be reviewed. There's

Speaker: NA
Text: no question about that.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we see is those opposite drawing into

Speaker: NA
Text: question the nation-building agenda that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government has. The government will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: deterred. It will continue to support programs

Speaker: NA
Text: which support jobs today and which build

Speaker: NA
Text: the infrastructure that Australia needs for

Speaker: NA
Text: Building the Education Revolution

Speaker: NA
Text: Program

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Education. Does the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: agree with the Prime Minister's comments

Speaker: NA
Text: on 3 February about the school stimulus

Speaker: NA
Text: package when he said, ‘This government will

Speaker: NA
Text: adopt a zero tolerance approach to any state

Speaker: NA
Text: government, whatever its political complex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ion, to any substitution of effort,' and, if so,

Speaker: NA
Text: what action will the government take against

Speaker: NA
Text: the South Australian government, which cut

Speaker: NA
Text: funding by 12 per cent for capital works pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grams in schools in its 2009-10 budget?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: I call the Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: Thank you very much,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, and once again, because we do

Speaker: NA
Text: not have accurate questions from the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: minister for education, I will check what he

Speaker: NA
Text: has asserted, because we know from former

Speaker: NA
Text: question times that assertions made by the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition about Building the Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Revolution and about the government's edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation policies generally turn out to be com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely spurious when investigated.

Speaker: NA
Text: What I can say to the shadow minister-

Speaker: NA
Text: and he may or may not be interested because

Speaker: NA
Text: the degree of seriousness with which he

Speaker: NA
Text: takes his education work is always some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing to be doubted-is that the government

Speaker: NA
Text: is absolutely determined that the Building

Speaker: NA
Text: the Education Revolution program is an ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dition to investment that would have hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pened in any event as a result of state budg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ets. We work constantly with our state and

Speaker: NA
Text: territory colleagues to deliver that program.

Speaker: NA
Text: The sanctions that can be applied under the

Speaker: NA
Text: agreements that surround the Building the

Speaker: NA
Text: Education Revolution program are serious

Speaker: NA
Text: ones and they are understood by our state

Speaker: NA
Text: and territory colleagues.

Speaker: NA
Text: Can I reiterate: for a man who earlier in

Speaker: NA
Text: question time was yelling at me, ‘What about

Speaker: NA
Text: Gepps Cross school?' only to be humiliated

Speaker: NA
Text: when his claim was found to be ridiculous-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Julie Bishop- Mr Speaker, I rise on a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. The question was specifically

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to the cut of 12 per cent to the

Speaker: NA
Text: capital works program in the South Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian budget. I would ask the Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister to answer what action-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! The Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister is responding to the question.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: I certainly will investi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gate the claims made. But, given the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition has risen to her feet

Speaker: NA
Text: to once again indicate an interest in educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, I will take the opportunity to remind

Speaker: NA
Text: House that, when she was minister for edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation, we did have a problem with funding

Speaker: NA
Text: going to schools that were closing. I remind

Speaker: NA
Text: the Deputy Leader of the Opposition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Investing in Our Schools Program grant she

Speaker: NA
Text: made to the Bowral Rudolf Steiner School in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2007, when it closed in 2007. There is the

Speaker: NA
Text: grant that she made to the Marist College

Speaker: NA
Text: Rosalie School in 2008, when it closed in

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Julie Bishop- Mr Speaker, I-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! The Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister will resume her seat and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Leader of the Opposition will resume

Speaker: NA
Text: her seat.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Julie Bishop interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! The Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition will resume her

Speaker: NA
Text: seat! The Deputy Prime Minister will refer

Speaker: NA
Text: her remarks to the question before us.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: As I understand the

Speaker: NA
Text: question before us, questions are being raised

Speaker: NA
Text: about the government's education programs.

Speaker: NA
Text: The simple point I was making is that some

Speaker: NA
Text: of these criticisms lie ill in the mouths of

Speaker: NA
Text: people whose administration-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: order. I am happy to repeat the question if

Speaker: NA
Text: the Deputy Prime Minister seems to have

Speaker: NA
Text: forgotten it. It was not a general question. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was about states skimming-12 per cent by

Speaker: NA
Text: the state government in South Australia-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: need to repeat the question. The Manager of

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition Business will resume his seat.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: Can I reiterate that, ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: viously, Building the Education Revolution

Speaker: NA
Text: is an economic stimulus package. It is to go

Speaker: NA
Text: on top of other expenditures. I will investi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gate the claims made, but I make this very

Speaker: NA
Text: simple point: for an opposition that opposed

Speaker: NA
Text: the this program lock, stock and barrel, under

Speaker: NA
Text: whose administration not one school would

Speaker: NA
Text: get one cent, it seems to me pretty interesting

Speaker: NA
Text: that they come in here day after day with

Speaker: NA
Text: claims that, when investigated, turn out to be

Speaker: NA
Text: fabricated. On the track record of the opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion when it was in government and the track

Speaker: NA
Text: record of those who held the education port-

Speaker: NA
Text: folio, let us just contemplate for a moment

Speaker: NA
Text: what, if any, lasting reforms people will be

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about from the Howard era. Can't

Speaker: NA
Text: think of one? Well, there would be a good

Speaker: NA
Text: reason for that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Solar Energy

Speaker: Mr BEVIS
Text: 3.17 pm)-My question is to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for the Environment, Heritage

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Arts. How will the new solar credits

Speaker: NA
Text: continue the government's unprecedented

Speaker: NA
Text: support for the solar panel industry? How

Speaker: NA
Text: does this approach compare with previous

Speaker: NA
Text: approaches in delivering value for money in

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental and water programs?

Speaker: Mr GARRETT
Text: I thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Brisbane for his question. The fact is that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is more government support for the

Speaker: NA
Text: solar industry and there are more solar panels

Speaker: NA
Text: going onto Australian rooftops under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Rudd government than at any previous time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The pre-election commitment of $150 mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion for five years was to fund 15,000 solar

Speaker: NA
Text: rebates; we now have funded more than

Speaker: NA
Text: 80,000 solar rebates from the time we came

Speaker: NA
Text: to government. That exceeds our election

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment some fourfold. Over 60,000

Speaker: NA
Text: installations are in the pipeline and that

Speaker: NA
Text: means that the industry has at least 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months work, according to current rates, to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue putting solar panels on people's

Speaker: NA
Text: roofs.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the coalition's entire 12 years in

Speaker: NA
Text: office, the solar rebate program supported

Speaker: NA
Text: around 10,500 installations of solar panels.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is 10,000 panels over 12 years versus

Speaker: NA
Text: 80,000 in just 18 months. I am reminded of

Speaker: NA
Text: that song What a Difference a Day Makes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of you will know the melody.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr GARRETT
Text: I will not sing it here,

Speaker: NA
Text: although I know you would like me to. What

Speaker: NA
Text: a difference a day makes not only for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition, given the an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nouncement by the member for Higgins;

Speaker: NA
Text: what a difference 18 months makes in the

Speaker: NA
Text: term of a government. Now, with solar cred-

Speaker: NA
Text: its operating through the renewable energy

Speaker: NA
Text: target, there is long-term certainty for the

Speaker: NA
Text: solar industry to go and to grow and to invest

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond budget cycles. There will be an up-

Speaker: NA
Text: front capital cost subsidy to all households

Speaker: NA
Text: and no means test. Households, the local fish

Speaker: NA
Text: and chip shop, farmers, community groups,

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses and families are all in the market

Speaker: NA
Text: for solar credits. The member for Flinders,

Speaker: NA
Text: who I notice is absent today, said last week

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to the Leader of the Opposition:

Speaker: NA
Text: Malcolm Turnbull was the guy who introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: the $8,000 rebate. He knew it was going to be

Speaker: NA
Text: successful. He wanted it to be successful and that

Speaker: NA
Text: is why he actually introduced it as an uncapped

Speaker: NA
Text: rebate.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said, ‘Look, if this is successful, that's a good

Speaker: NA
Text: problem we'll have to deal with not a bad prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem.'

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to advise the House of the real story.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the now Leader of the Opposition did

Speaker: NA
Text: increase solar rebates in 2007, he said that he

Speaker: NA
Text: expected the program to be unpopular. I refer

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Daily Telegraph of 12 May 2007,

Speaker: NA
Text: which reported:

Speaker: NA
Text: Environment Minister Malcolm Turnbull doesn't

Speaker: NA
Text: need a state-wide survey showing him solar en-

Speaker: NA
Text: ergy is unpopular. He already knows. The Satur-

Speaker: NA
Text: day Daily Telegraph can reveal the reason the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government didn't make its $150 million

Speaker: NA
Text: solar rebate any bigger was because there was not

Speaker: NA
Text: enough demand for solar panels. ‘If demand ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceeds our expectations then obviously we'll re-

Speaker: NA
Text: view the scheme,' he said. ‘To date shortage of

Speaker: NA
Text: money has not been an issue. Solar panels are still

Speaker: NA
Text: pretty expensive.'

Speaker: NA
Text: So we have the member for Flinders saying

Speaker: NA
Text: that the opposition wrote a blank cheque for

Speaker: NA
Text: solar rebates because Mr Turnbull knew it

Speaker: NA
Text: was going to be successful. But, in 2007, the

Speaker: NA
Text: now Leader of the Opposition was back-

Speaker: NA
Text: grounding the Daily Telegraph and saying

Speaker: NA
Text: that his expectations would be that the rebate

Speaker: NA
Text: would be unpopular. This is an absolute

Speaker: NA
Text: sham. But we should not be surprised by the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was asked how this compares with pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vious approaches to deliver value-on envi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ronmental values, on programs, on water

Speaker: NA
Text: programs and the like. At the same time as

Speaker: NA
Text: very few solar panels were going onto the

Speaker: NA
Text: roofs of Australian homes under the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: government when the Leader of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion was the minister for the environment, he

Speaker: NA
Text: had responsibility for water policy as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: What was that water policy? It was water

Speaker: NA
Text: policy dreamt up on the back of an envelope:

Speaker: NA
Text: a commitment to spend money, not a single

Speaker: NA
Text: delivery of water back into the Murray-

Speaker: NA
Text: Darling Basin system, with no consultation

Speaker: NA
Text: with Treasury, no consultation with the now-

Speaker: NA
Text: departing member for Higgins, no consulta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion with farmers organisations-in other

Speaker: NA
Text: words, just doing it on the run.

Speaker: NA
Text: It should not surprise us because, well

Speaker: NA
Text: fore the last election, we know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition was focusing on

Speaker: NA
Text: another aspect of water policy. This was the

Speaker: NA
Text: advice that the Leader of the Opposition re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived from his department to spend some $2

Speaker: NA
Text: million on investigating cloud-seeding tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nologies. There we were two days into the

Speaker: NA
Text: election campaign, with the substantial mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters of policy to be determined, including

Speaker: NA
Text: what the government was then going to bring

Speaker: NA
Text: to the people by way of climate change pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy and the like, and we had the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Wentworth writing to the Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: saying, ‘Can we have $10 million to spend

Speaker: NA
Text: on the project?'

Speaker: NA
Text: I should point out that a year earlier the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Wentworth, the now Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition, had written to a scientific

Speaker: NA
Text: expert telling him that cloud seeding simply

Speaker: NA
Text: did not work. He used the expression that the

Speaker: NA
Text: results were ‘inconclusive at best'. Here we

Speaker: NA
Text: had a reckless spending exercise, against the

Speaker: NA
Text: advice of the minister's department, whilst at

Speaker: NA
Text: the same time there were no policies for re-

Speaker: NA
Text: newable energy, no policies for green jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: and no policies for increasing the capacity of

Speaker: NA
Text: the solar industry to do what it had to do.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now we have the opposition leader support-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, it is said, the government's targets on

Speaker: NA
Text: climate change, but with coalition members

Speaker: NA
Text: in his own party saying right out loud that

Speaker: NA
Text: they oppose the scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: I say to the Leader of the Opposition: the

Speaker: NA
Text: confusion that is rampant within your ranks

Speaker: NA
Text: over climate change is an absolute dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: grace-with business needing certainty, with

Speaker: NA
Text: green jobs ready to be put into place-and at

Speaker: NA
Text: this point in time we have an opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: leader who is opposed to the stimulus pack-

Speaker: NA
Text: age and who opposed the energy efficient

Speaker: NA
Text: homes plan. This is a plan which will see an

Speaker: NA
Text: extraordinary number of homes-some three

Speaker: NA
Text: million Australian households-get ceiling

Speaker: NA
Text: insulation in their roofs, reducing the costs of

Speaker: NA
Text: beenergy, reducing greenhouse gas emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: and producing jobs and green jobs at the

Speaker: NA
Text: same time. It is time that the opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: leader focused on the real policy initiatives,

Speaker: NA
Text: recognised the importance of providing cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainty for the Australian public in dealing

Speaker: NA
Text: with climate change and looked at these sig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificant issues and at the commitment that

Speaker: NA
Text: this government has to solar panels.

Speaker: NA
Text: National School Pride Program

Speaker: Mr HAASE
Text: 3.23 pm)-My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed to the Minister for Education. Will

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister explain why her National School

Speaker: NA
Text: Pride program prohibits schools from install-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing air conditioning in existing classrooms

Speaker: NA
Text: that have none and why, as a consequence,

Speaker: NA
Text: children in dozens of schools across my elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate of Kalgoorlie will continue to swelter

Speaker: NA
Text: or be sent home on all-too-frequent hot days?

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: I thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: his question, which I am very happy to an-

Speaker: NA
Text: swer. I suggest that perhaps he needs to have

Speaker: NA
Text: a discussion with his shadow minister, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause what his shadow minister said in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last question is that he is concerned that state

Speaker: NA
Text: governments are not maintaining effort on

Speaker: NA
Text: education capital and equipment, whereas

Speaker: NA
Text: the member has raised a question with me

Speaker: NA
Text: which would seem to suggest the only source

Speaker: NA
Text: of funding available to schools for things

Speaker: NA
Text: air conditioning is Building the Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Revolution. Building the Education Revolu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is for specific purposes. Amongst the

Speaker: NA
Text: specific purposes is the construction of new

Speaker: NA
Text: buildings and those buildings can be air con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditioned. Of course, on general repairs for

Speaker: NA
Text: schools and the air conditioning of class-

Speaker: NA
Text: rooms, that is something that state govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments attend to for state schools. So he may

Speaker: NA
Text: want to raise his question with the state Lib-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral government-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Sturt will leave the chamber for one hour

Speaker: NA
Text: under 94(a).

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Sturt then left the cham-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: What the guidelines

Speaker: NA
Text: provide-and the guidelines are very clear-

Speaker: NA
Text: is for newly constructed buildings under

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary Schools for the 21st Century as part

Speaker: NA
Text: of Building the Education Revolution. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, appropriate climate control, whether

Speaker: NA
Text: it be air conditioning or heating, can be in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stalled. National School Pride program

Speaker: NA
Text: money can go to small-scale repairs and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to shadecloth and some of the other

Speaker: NA
Text: important things in schools. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: air conditioning; that is true. As the member

Speaker: NA
Text: would be aware, a substantial consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: with the insertion of air conditioning in

Speaker: NA
Text: schools is the ongoing costs of running the

Speaker: NA
Text: air conditioning. He would know, from the

Speaker: NA
Text: climate he comes from, that the capital cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of putting in the air conditioning is one

Speaker: NA
Text: thing; the year-on-year power cost is another.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have obviously said to state govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments, as we have gone about this task, that

Speaker: NA
Text: our economic stimulus is extra to the things

Speaker: NA
Text: that they ordinarily do. One of the things

Speaker: NA
Text: they ordinarily do is work out how to reno-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate classrooms for climate control, includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing an understanding of what the ongoing

Speaker: NA
Text: like recurrent costs of that would be. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: said to state governments that, with major

Speaker: NA
Text: constructs under Primary Schools for the

Speaker: NA
Text: 21st Century, appropriate climate control

Speaker: NA
Text: will be part of the fit-out, as will the things

Speaker: NA
Text: required to make buildings functional, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluding in some cases interactive white-

Speaker: NA
Text: boards and the like. Those things are all part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the program.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can understand that the member is dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: gruntled about the circumstances in his elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate for some of the children who attend

Speaker: NA
Text: school in his electorate. On the question of

Speaker: NA
Text: air conditioning for current school facilities,

Speaker: NA
Text: he should feel very free to direct that to the

Speaker: NA
Text: state minister for education in his state of

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Climate Change

Speaker: Mr DANBY
Text: 3.27 pm)-My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Defence Personnel, Mate-

Speaker: NA
Text: riel and Science and the Minister Assisting

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Climate Change. Will the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister outline to the House the work that

Speaker: NA
Text: has been done over the last decade to set up

Speaker: NA
Text: an emissions trading scheme and implement

Speaker: NA
Text: an expanded renewable energy target? How

Speaker: NA
Text: has this work assisted the government to take

Speaker: NA
Text: real action on climate change and how is this

Speaker: NA
Text: not going to action being received?

Speaker: Mr COMBET
Text: Thank you to the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Melbourne Ports. As a former con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stituent of his, I can attest to the fact that he

Speaker: NA
Text: has a serious interest in the issue of climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change. We all have a responsibility-

Speaker: NA
Text: including the opposition-to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people and to future generations to act on

Speaker: NA
Text: climate change. For the government's part,

Speaker: NA
Text: the government accepts the consensus view

Speaker: NA
Text: of scientists. Importantly, the Fourth assess-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment report of the Intergovernmental Panel

Speaker: NA
Text: that on Climate Change states that warming is

Speaker: NA
Text: unequivocal and human activities are respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible for most of the observed warming over

Speaker: NA
Text: the last 50 years. That is a consequence of

Speaker: NA
Text: the work of over 1,200 scientists from over

Speaker: NA
Text: 130 countries that has been subject to peer

Speaker: NA
Text: review, contained and represented in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fourth assessment report of the IPCC. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government also accepts that if we fail to

Speaker: NA
Text: now we will cause irreparable damage to our

Speaker: NA
Text: environment, economy and way of life. The

Speaker: NA
Text: fact is that Australia is a hot and dry contiAct.

Speaker: NA
Text: nent and failure to act will have an adverse

Speaker: NA
Text: effect on our ecosystems and our economy,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly on industries such as agriculture

Speaker: NA
Text: and tourism.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further delay in acting against climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change means the cost of adjustment will be

Speaker: NA
Text: greater and other countries will get ahead of

Speaker: NA
Text: us in creating the low-pollution jobs of the

Speaker: NA
Text: future. And that is why the government has

Speaker: NA
Text: established targets and developed the Carbon

Speaker: NA
Text: Pollution Reduction Scheme to go about

Speaker: NA
Text: achieving them. But in the face of all this

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence the coalition continue to ignore the

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge of climate change and insist on

Speaker: NA
Text: delay-even after 12 years in government

Speaker: NA
Text: characterised by inaction on this issue in

Speaker: NA
Text: face of numerous reports and commitments

Speaker: NA
Text: given during their period in government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Just to give an overview of some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: work and the advice that the coalition com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioned and ignored: in 1999 there were

Speaker: NA
Text: no fewer than six reports to the Howard gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment, all of which were ignored. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Greenhouse Office discussion

Speaker: NA
Text: paper series on emissions trading was issued

Speaker: NA
Text: during that year and included a discussion

Speaker: NA
Text: paper on establishing the boundaries of a

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme, a discussion paper on issuing per-

Speaker: NA
Text: mits, a discussion paper on how crediting

Speaker: NA
Text: carbon pollution could occur, a discussion

Speaker: NA
Text: paper on designing the carbon-trading mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ket, a discussion paper on the greenhouse

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge and a further report of the Green-

Speaker: NA
Text: house Energy Group on planning for manda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory targets for the uptake of renewable en-

Speaker: NA
Text: ergy in power supplies, followed in the year

Speaker: NA
Text: 2000 by a further report of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Greenhouse Office on encouraging early

Speaker: NA
Text: greenhouse abatement mechanisms.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 2002 there was a further report from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Greenhouse Office on greenhouse gas emis-

Speaker: NA
Text: act sions. In 2003 there was a report on renew-

Speaker: NA
Text: able opportunities and a review of the opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the Renewable Energy (Electricity)

Speaker: NA
Text: In 2007, of course, there was the Sher-

Speaker: NA
Text: gold report, from the Prime Minister's task

Speaker: NA
Text: group at that time, on emissions trading,

Speaker: NA
Text: which led to the Howard government indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cating that it would commit to an emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: trading scheme. But in the face of all that,

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing was done. The advice was ignored.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reports were shelved.

Speaker: NA
Text: During 2008, by contrast, the Rudd gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment received the Garnaut Climate

Speaker: NA
Text: Change Review report. A green paper on the

Speaker: NA
Text: development of the Carbon Pollution Reduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Scheme was developed. A white paper

Speaker: NA
Text: was issued in December 2008 and there were

Speaker: NA
Text: numerous industry consultations. In 2009,

Speaker: NA
Text: the draft CPRS legislation was released, nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: the merous Senate inquiries have been held and

Speaker: NA
Text: now the draft Renewable Energy (Electric-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity) Amendment Bill has been released. On

Speaker: NA
Text: that point, the government intends imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: menting its policy by virtue of that legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to achieve 20 per cent of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: electricity supply being delivered by renew-

Speaker: NA
Text: able sources by the year 2020. That is ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pected to drive $19 billion worth of invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in renewable energy activity.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are great institutional changes.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are extremely important and in the face

Speaker: NA
Text: of them the coalition has abrogated its re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility to support them. However, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Turnbull, the Leader of the Opposition, has

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated what is the coalition's policy. He

Speaker: NA
Text: made this remark on 9 July 2008:

Speaker: NA
Text: … the Howard Government's policy last year was

Speaker: NA
Text: that we would establish an emissions trading

Speaker: NA
Text: tem not later than 2012.

Speaker: NA
Text: And importantly, in the light of the excuses

Speaker: NA
Text: for delay that have been articulated by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal Party in recent times, Mr Turnbull,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: It was not conditional on international action …

Speaker: NA
Text: Commitment to an emissions trading system

Speaker: NA
Text: was to be pursued by the coalition. More

Speaker: NA
Text: recently, the Leader of the Opposition has

Speaker: NA
Text: confirmed that there will be an emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: trading scheme in this country. The trouble is

Speaker: NA
Text: that the coalition and the Leader of the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position cannot deliver on these issues and

Speaker: NA
Text: all we have heard are excuses for delay. The

Speaker: NA
Text: reason that there are excuses for delay is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposition is deeply divided. And you do

Speaker: NA
Text: not have to take my point of view on it; there

Speaker: NA
Text: is plenty of evidence from members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition. Take this quote from Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Eric Abetz:

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt that weeds-

Speaker: NA
Text: That was ‘weeds'-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose … a challenge much clearer, more present

Speaker: NA
Text: and possibly more serious than the unclear chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenge which climate change may or may not pose

Speaker: NA
Text: to our biodiversity …

Speaker: NA
Text: And there are many other instances where

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the opposition have indicated a

Speaker: NA
Text: completely contrary view to that of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition on the issue of

Speaker: NA
Text: emissions trading and scepticism about the

Speaker: NA
Text: science. And that is the reason for the divi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion on that side of politics and the reason

Speaker: NA
Text: that all they posit are excuses for delay. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government has brought forward the Carbon

Speaker: NA
Text: Pollution Reduction Scheme. It has passed

Speaker: NA
Text: through this House. We will be bringing for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward legislation to establish a fourfold in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease in the renewable energy target. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have established ambitious carbon pollution

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction targets, we have signed the Kyoto

Speaker: NA
Text: Protocol and we will take action. It is time

Speaker: NA
Text: that the opposition exercised responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: sys- on behalf of the Australian community on

Speaker: NA
Text: this question.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Julie Bishop-As the minister read

Speaker: NA
Text: every single word of his answer, I ask that he

Speaker: NA
Text: table the document from which he was read-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Was the minister quot-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing from a document?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Combet-Yes.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Was the document con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fidential?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Combet-Yes.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: I rise on a point of order. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the light of the minister's maiden answer

Speaker: NA
Text: being confidential, could he disclose the au-

Speaker: NA
Text: thor?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Connor will leave the chamber for one

Speaker: NA
Text: hour under the provisions of standing order

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for O'Connor then left the

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber.

Speaker: NA
Text: North West Queensland Mineral Province

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Text: 3.37 pm)-My question

Speaker: NA
Text: without notice is to the honourable Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Resources and Energy. The minister

Speaker: NA
Text: would be aware of his own role as the Lone

Speaker: NA
Text: Ranger riding to the rescue of the $15 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: North West Queensland Mineral Province

Speaker: NA
Text: about to be scalped by electricity demand

Speaker: NA
Text: growth outstripping supply in 2012, the cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rent cost of inefficient small power genera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion rendering our mineral production non-

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive, no growth capacity in the north-

Speaker: NA
Text: west grid and CPR charges. In light of this,

Speaker: NA
Text: could the minister ensure-

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Text: It is a bit important, you

Speaker: NA
Text: know. It really is a little bit important.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennedy has the call. I am trying to hear

Speaker: NA
Text: him.

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Text: I was wondering whether

Speaker: NA
Text: I did, Mr Speaker. In light of this could the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister ensure that (a) he arrives in time,

Speaker: NA
Text: he brings sufficient electricity with him and

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) his proposed clean energy corridor, for

Speaker: NA
Text: which his grid connection has provided the

Speaker: NA
Text: catalyst, will provide the silver bullet for

Speaker: NA
Text: Xstrata, BHP, Rio Tinto and Gutnick's Leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: end Mining with some 15,000 permanent

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs flowing from the Pentland biofuels pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ject and the proposed mineral expansions?

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, if not, would he not agree that even

Speaker: NA
Text: Tonto might decide that he and the infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure minister, Albanese, are palefaces?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Just for the record, the

Speaker: NA
Text: last part of the question is out of order.

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Text: I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: know where the Lone Ranger and Tonto are

Speaker: NA
Text: today, but I can assure the House they long

Speaker: NA
Text: gave up trying to corral the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennedy. More seriously, this question is a

Speaker: NA
Text: very serious question. It goes to the potential

Speaker: NA
Text: development of the North West Mineral

Speaker: NA
Text: Province in Queensland. This province has

Speaker: NA
Text: long been held back by the lack of an ade-

Speaker: NA
Text: quate supply of energy at a reasonable cost.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Kennedy has raised the

Speaker: NA
Text: question of the possible development of the

Speaker: NA
Text: North West Mineral Province in the context

Speaker: NA
Text: of a key part of the government's recent

Speaker: NA
Text: budget strategy going to the establishment of

Speaker: NA
Text: a real government commitment to clean en-

Speaker: NA
Text: ergy in Australia. I welcome his support for

Speaker: NA
Text: that government initiative, because it goes to

Speaker: NA
Text: our requirement to invest in not only carbon

Speaker: NA
Text: capture and storage but also renewable en-

Speaker: NA
Text: ergy in Australia. That is because we are not

Speaker: NA
Text: interested in trying to pick winners; we are

Speaker: NA
Text: about trying to create a framework that en-

Speaker: NA
Text: courages investment in all sources of poten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial energy in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: That takes me, firstly, to the question of

Speaker: NA
Text: carbon capture and storage and a commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of $2.4 billion to cleaning up coal in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, reducing emissions. CCS is vital

Speaker: NA
Text: to our future, because 82 per cent of Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) lia's electricity comes from coal-fired power

Speaker: NA
Text: stations. I was pleased to see carbon capture

Speaker: NA
Text: and storage in a commercial operation, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sleipner petroleum field, when I recently

Speaker: NA
Text: visited Norway. CCS is currently in place

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the world and it is our responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility, not only as a coal-dependent energy

Speaker: NA
Text: nation but also as a major coal exporter, to

Speaker: NA
Text: actually get this technology right. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: also say that, if we achieve later this year the

Speaker: NA
Text: Gorgon gas investment of $30 billion to $50

Speaker: NA
Text: billion, something that the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: and I are working on at the moment, you will

Speaker: NA
Text: see the largest carbon capture and storage

Speaker: NA
Text: operation in the world here, on Barrow Is-

Speaker: NA
Text: land in Western Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member has also raised the need to

Speaker: NA
Text: focus on renewables. We are about investing

Speaker: NA
Text: real money-the biggest investment by an

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian government-in the renewables

Speaker: NA
Text: sector in Australia. That builds on our deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mination to put in place a measured carbon

Speaker: NA
Text: pollution reduction scheme with a renewable

Speaker: NA
Text: energy target of 20 per cent by 2020. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstration program of $1.6 billion in

Speaker: NA
Text: solar technologies is not just about solar PV;

Speaker: NA
Text: it is also about seriously investigating

Speaker: NA
Text: whether or not solar thermal could supply

Speaker: NA
Text: real, baseload, secure energy in Australia-

Speaker: NA
Text: important not only to Australia but also to

Speaker: NA
Text: the global community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not content with just focusing on carbon

Speaker: NA
Text: capture and storage and solar, we are also

Speaker: NA
Text: going to encourage the exploration and de-

Speaker: NA
Text: velopment of other demonstration activities,

Speaker: NA
Text: such as geothermal and wave power. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: about us ensuring as a nation that, when it

Speaker: NA
Text: comes to the issue of energy security, as we

Speaker: NA
Text: move to a low-emission economy, we not

Speaker: NA
Text: only guarantee our own future but also put in

Speaker: NA
Text: place technology options of great interest

Speaker: NA
Text: and need to the global community at large.

Speaker: NA
Text: So I say to the member for Kennedy: I ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: press my appreciation for your support of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's clean energy strategy. I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: the Lone Ranger; I have a huge posse behind

Speaker: NA
Text: me and absolute support of our clean energy

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstration program. Perhaps more im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portantly, he, like me, understands and ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: preciates that without a commitment to clean

Speaker: NA
Text: energy we will never have a capacity to de-

Speaker: NA
Text: velop the North West Mineral Province,

Speaker: NA
Text: which has the potential to be as important as

Speaker: NA
Text: north-west Western Australia. I thank him for

Speaker: NA
Text: his question.

Speaker: NA
Text: Swine Influenza

Speaker: Mr SYMON
Text: 3.43 pm)-My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Will

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister advise the House on the latest

Speaker: NA
Text: swine flu developments in Australia and in-

Speaker: NA
Text: ternationally and on the government's re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponse to date?

Speaker: Ms ROXON
Text: I thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Deakin for his question. Obviously amongst

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian members there is a particular inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: est, but it is a matter of importance for the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole country. Members of the House may

Speaker: NA
Text: be aware that last Friday the World Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Organisation declared the H1N1 influenza

Speaker: NA
Text: strain a pandemic, the first global pandemic

Speaker: NA
Text: for 40 years. The World Health Organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion's phase 6 is characterised by community

Speaker: NA
Text: level outbreaks in at least one country in a

Speaker: NA
Text: different World Health Organisation region

Speaker: NA
Text: from the source country-in this case, Mex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ico. It indicates that there is sustained hu-

Speaker: NA
Text: man-to-human community level transmis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion.

Speaker: NA
Text: The WHO's decision to declare the first

Speaker: NA
Text: pandemic of the 21st century indicates that it

Speaker: NA
Text: is no longer possible to contain the virus in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular geographical area. There are now

Speaker: NA
Text: nearly 30,000 cases of human swine influ-

Speaker: NA
Text: enza around the world, with 74 countries

Speaker: NA
Text: affected. The World Health Organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: considers that this pandemic, at least in its

Speaker: NA
Text: early stages, will be of moderate severity.

Speaker: NA
Text: Around the world, and as we are seeing here

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia, the overwhelming majority of

Speaker: NA
Text: patients experience mild symptoms and will

Speaker: NA
Text: make a rapid and full recovery. This of

Speaker: NA
Text: course is an important factor to be weighed

Speaker: NA
Text: in the public health advice that is being pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided to the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, as we also know, the disease has

Speaker: NA
Text: a hard edge with potentially severe compli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations for people with underlying health

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions such as morbid obesity, respira-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory conditions and chronic disease and, like

Speaker: NA
Text: the regular flu, for pregnant women. Increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly the world's focus, like our focus, is

Speaker: NA
Text: moving to identifying and treating those

Speaker: NA
Text: most at risk of severe complications. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: need to report to the House that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: heard the first reports in the media, as yet

Speaker: NA
Text: unconfirmed, of the first death in the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom, which would be the first death

Speaker: NA
Text: outside the Americas, underscoring the point

Speaker: NA
Text: that this disease can have severe conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quences, although it is expected to be mild to

Speaker: NA
Text: moderate in most.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has about six per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world's confirmed cases. Here in Australia as

Speaker: NA
Text: at 12 noon today there were 1,762 confirmed

Speaker: NA
Text: cases-1,210 in Victoria, 191 in New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales, 116 in Queensland, 63 in South Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, 66 in Western Australia, 32 in Tasma-

Speaker: NA
Text: nia, 53 in the ACT and 31 in the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory. There are 10 people currently in

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital, three of whom are in intensive care.

Speaker: NA
Text: The hospitalised have generally been those

Speaker: NA
Text: people with existing conditions or complica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions such as morbid obesity and respiratory

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions. A number of schools and child-

Speaker: NA
Text: care centres are closed around the country,

Speaker: NA
Text: a particularly in those states other than Victoria

Speaker: NA
Text: that are still in the ‘contain' phase.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's current approach to swine flu

Speaker: NA
Text: is consistent with the World Health Organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sation's recommendation that countries

Speaker: NA
Text: should now focus on treating those who are

Speaker: NA
Text: ill, providing guidance to people to protect

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves, closely monitoring the disease

Speaker: NA
Text: and adjusting the response to local condi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. This is what is already occurring in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and underpins the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: public health advice to the community. In

Speaker: NA
Text: particular, this is consistent with what is oc-

Speaker: NA
Text: curring in Victoria, with that state on a modi-

Speaker: NA
Text: fied ‘sustain' alert level. I need to advise the

Speaker: NA
Text: House that we continue to give ongoing con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration to the appropriateness of Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia's national alert level. The rest of the

Speaker: NA
Text: try remains at ‘contain', where efforts are

Speaker: NA
Text: continuing with a focus on slowing the

Speaker: NA
Text: spread of the disease, which is why we are

Speaker: NA
Text: still seeing school closures in states other

Speaker: NA
Text: than Victoria. Of course, this is something

Speaker: NA
Text: that will continue to be reviewed day by day

Speaker: NA
Text: and hour by hour on the advice of the Chief

Speaker: NA
Text: Medical Officer as well as the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Protection Committee and the Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Pandemic Emergency Committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do need to flag that, as the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: cases in Australia steadily increases, the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment, in conjunction with the states and

Speaker: NA
Text: territories, will give further consideration to

Speaker: NA
Text: moving to a consistent alert level across Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia and to modifying our response to take

Speaker: NA
Text: account of the increasing number of cases in

Speaker: NA
Text: our community and the moderate severity to

Speaker: NA
Text: date. In particular, we will continue to care-

Speaker: NA
Text: fully monitor the extent of community

Speaker: NA
Text: transmission-that is, cases with no known

Speaker: NA
Text: contact with other confirmed cases. From the

Speaker: NA
Text: data over the weekend the majority of cases

Speaker: NA
Text: outside Victoria can still be traced back to

Speaker: NA
Text: known contacts with other confirmed cases.

Speaker: NA
Text: But this is changing, and we will continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: monitor it closely over the coming days.

Speaker: NA
Text: I take this opportunity to remind Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians that the World Health Organisation and

Speaker: NA
Text: the government do not recommend the clo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sure of any borders or travel restrictions dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the pandemic. But the community must

Speaker: NA
Text: be aware that Australians travelling abroad

Speaker: NA
Text: are required to adhere not only to the laws of

Speaker: NA
Text: other countries but also to their health and

Speaker: NA
Text: quarantine arrangements. The Smartraveller

Speaker: NA
Text: website provides advice to this effect for

Speaker: NA
Text: those who are considering travel overseas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although Australians are being encour-

Speaker: NA
Text: aged to continue to undertake normal day-to-

Speaker: NA
Text: day activities, I know this is going to be dif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ficult for some people, particularly as the

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences of voluntary exclusion from

Speaker: NA
Text: school and school closures have an impact

Speaker: NA
Text: counon family life. These school measures are

Speaker: NA
Text: being maintained in states in the ‘contain'

Speaker: NA
Text: phase as an agreed, effective way to slow the

Speaker: NA
Text: spread of the disease in the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to take the opportunity to again

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the public, and parents in particular,

Speaker: NA
Text: for their forbearance in this difficult period,

Speaker: NA
Text: which we know can cause family inconven-

Speaker: NA
Text: ience. I would also like to take the opportu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity to again thank doctors and other health

Speaker: NA
Text: officials for their ongoing efforts and atten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in a pandemic which is going to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue to add a significant burden to their al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ready demanding roles.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nation Building and Jobs Plan

Speaker: Mr BRIGGS
Text: 3.49 pm)-My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer explain

Speaker: NA
Text: why a $900 cash-splash cheque from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Reserve Bank to Mrs Gloria Hartridge has

Speaker: NA
Text: bounced, resulting in a $9 dishonour fee to

Speaker: NA
Text: this hardworking mother? Treasurer, has the

Speaker: NA
Text: government run out of money?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Albanese- Mr Speaker, I rise on a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order under the standing orders.

Speaker: NA
Text: Have they run out of questions?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. There have been a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: questions that, on literal interpretation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: standing orders, have been outside the stand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing orders.

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: I am happy to look at the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: tails, as usual. Whether what the member

Speaker: NA
Text: says is true or not, I do not know, but I am

Speaker: NA
Text: happy to-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Julie Bishop interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: Well, that would be a

Speaker: NA
Text: change, wouldn't it! That would be a dra-

Speaker: NA
Text: matic change from what we have been seeing

Speaker: NA
Text: in the House over a long period of time. This

Speaker: NA
Text: crew opposite will go to enormous lengths to

Speaker: NA
Text: try and discredit the importance of economic

Speaker: NA
Text: stimulus and what it has done to support em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment and business in the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. They will go to any lengths-they

Speaker: NA
Text: will say anything, they will do anything and

Speaker: NA
Text: they will distort anything-to try and cast

Speaker: NA
Text: some doubt on the effectiveness of economic

Speaker: NA
Text: stimulus, which has been of such benefit to

Speaker: NA
Text: so many people in this community who have

Speaker: NA
Text: been employed and so many businesses out

Speaker: NA
Text: there who really need customers coming

Speaker: NA
Text: through the door. But they simply do not get

Speaker: NA
Text: it. I am happy to follow up the details, but it

Speaker: NA
Text: does not in any way absolve any of those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite from their irresponsibility in voting

Speaker: NA
Text: against what has been absolutely critical for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian economy in our time of need.

Speaker: NA
Text: FIFA World Cup Bid

Speaker: Mr CRAIG THOMSON
Text: 3.51 pm)-My

Speaker: NA
Text: question is to the Minister for Early Child-

Speaker: NA
Text: hood Education, Childcare and Youth and

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Sport. Will the minister update

Speaker: NA
Text: the House on Australia's bid for the 2018-22

Speaker: NA
Text: FIFA World Cup?

Speaker: Ms KATE ELLIS
Text: I thank the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for his question and I would of course be

Speaker: NA
Text: delighted to update the House on the exciting

Speaker: NA
Text: developments with the official launch of the

Speaker: NA
Text: World Cup bid yesterday. Before doing that I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to take the opportunity to place

Speaker: NA
Text: on the parliamentary record the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: government's congratulations to Football

Speaker: NA
Text: Federation Australia, to Pim Verbeek, to cap-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain Lucas Neill and of course to the phe-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomenal Socceroos on their recent historic

Speaker: NA
Text: qualification for the 2010 FIFA World Cup. I

Speaker: NA
Text: know that the whole parliament will join in

Speaker: NA
Text: adding their congratulations. This achieve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment should not be underestimated. It is after

Speaker: NA
Text: all only the third time that Australia has

Speaker: NA
Text: qualified to compete with the best of the best

Speaker: NA
Text: on the world stage in this sport. But it is also

Speaker: NA
Text: the first time that we have been able to go

Speaker: NA
Text: back-to-back, and the manner in which we

Speaker: NA
Text: did it was without conceding a single goal

Speaker: NA
Text: and we qualified with two games remaining,

Speaker: NA
Text: all of which make it a truly remarkable

Speaker: NA
Text: achievement.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Socceroos have shown that Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: has become a major player on the world

Speaker: NA
Text: stage when it comes to football. This was

Speaker: NA
Text: also demonstrated yesterday with the official

Speaker: NA
Text: launch of our FIFA World Cup bid. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: that the official launch of our bid was at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tended by members from both sides of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House and quite literally brought football

Speaker: NA
Text: into the parliament. When the bid was

Speaker: NA
Text: launched by the Prime Minister yesterday,

Speaker: NA
Text: the message that Australia sent to the world

Speaker: NA
Text: was clear: Australia is ready and we want the

Speaker: NA
Text: world to come and play on our home turf. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to particularly note the contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that the Leader of the Opposition made

Speaker: NA
Text: yesterday when he stated that the bid had

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘the unequivocal support' of both sides of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House and that the opposition and the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment will be ‘side by side, joined at the

Speaker: NA
Text: hip, as dual strikers' to bring the World Cup

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australia. I think it is important that we

Speaker: NA
Text: note that, on these major international ven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tures, this parliament does work together

Speaker: NA
Text: very productively because we know that bi-

Speaker: NA
Text: partisanship is crucial to the success of the

Speaker: NA
Text: prized goal.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also know that, beyond politics, the

Speaker: NA
Text: involvement and the inclusion of the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity is crucial. We need to show the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: world that as a community we are united

Speaker: NA
Text: behind this bid, and the community will be

Speaker: NA
Text: included with a strong role to play

Speaker: NA
Text: tle going forward. Chairman Frank Lowy

Speaker: NA
Text: announced yesterday that we want the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity to play their role as thousands of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dividual ambassadors. Already, one Face-

Speaker: NA
Text: book site that is dedicated to supporting Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's bid to host the 2018-22 World Cup

Speaker: NA
Text: now has over 80,000 people registered as

Speaker: NA
Text: members. In fact, just prior to

Speaker: NA
Text: received an email from the Subiaco Junior

Speaker: NA
Text: Soccer Club under-15s, who were offering to

Speaker: NA
Text: be-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Julie Bishop-A wonderful team.

Speaker: Ms KATE ELLIS
Text: I am sure they are a

Speaker: NA
Text: wonderful team. In fact they are travelling

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas to compete in Sweden later this

Speaker: NA
Text: year. They have offered to act as ambassa-

Speaker: NA
Text: dors for Australia's bid on the world stage.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is an offer that we will certainly take

Speaker: NA
Text: them up on. I would like to call on all Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians to get involved and log onto the

Speaker: NA
Text: newly launched website, www.australia2018-

Speaker: NA
Text: 2022.com.au, to register their support for our

Speaker: NA
Text: bid and to get behind the campaign to show

Speaker: NA
Text: to the entire world that there is no better

Speaker: NA
Text: place on the planet to hold the World Cup

Speaker: NA
Text: than right here in Australia, because there is

Speaker: NA
Text: no doubt that there is a lot of hard work that

Speaker: NA
Text: lies before us from this point on.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also know that there are significant

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits in terms of infrastructure and job

Speaker: NA
Text: creation and of course massive benefits in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of tourism potential. So we as a gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment will continue to work very hard to

Speaker: NA
Text: support Frank Lowy, Ben Buckley and Foot-

Speaker: NA
Text: ball Federation Australia. We will work on a

Speaker: NA
Text: coordinated approach across government but

Speaker: NA
Text: we will also be working in very strong part-

Speaker: NA
Text: nership with all of the states and territories,

Speaker: NA
Text: which have signed up to supporting the bid

Speaker: NA
Text: through COAG. Australia will be making its

Speaker: NA
Text: first presentation before FIFA later this year,

Speaker: NA
Text: in December, before submitting the formal

Speaker: NA
Text: bid in May of next year, with a decision be-

Speaker: NA
Text: in the bating made in December next year.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that the competition is very tight

Speaker: NA
Text: but we also know that when it comes to host-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing major sporting events there is nobody in

Speaker: NA
Text: the world that does it better than Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Together we will work on a united and inclu-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive bid to show to the whole world that Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia will put on the best World Cup the

Speaker: NA
Text: question time I world has ever seen.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Rudd- Mr Speaker, I ask that further

Speaker: NA
Text: questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

Speaker: NA
Text: Program

Text: Lalor-Minister for Edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation, Minister for Employment and Work-

Speaker: NA
Text: place Relations and Minister for Social In-

Speaker: NA
Text: clusion) (3.57 pm)- Mr Speaker, I seek the

Speaker: NA
Text: indulgence of the chair to add to an answer.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The minister may pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceed.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: I seek to add to an an-

Speaker: NA
Text: swer asked of me by the shadow minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: education, when he was in the parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier, which related to the Hastings Public

Speaker: NA
Text: School. The assertion in the member's ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion was that somehow the cost for a covered

Speaker: NA
Text: outdoor learning area had increased tenfold

Speaker: NA
Text: in just six years. Can I clarify the matter as

Speaker: NA
Text: follows: the Hastings Public School in New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales has certainly received $400,000

Speaker: NA
Text: for the construction of a covered outdoor

Speaker: NA
Text: learning area. This is a significant building

Speaker: NA
Text: with a solid roof. It also includes an amphi-

Speaker: NA
Text: theatre, seating and a sound system to facili-

Speaker: NA
Text: tate school assemblies and performances and

Speaker: NA
Text: science and art work spaces.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not know whether the member was

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking to assert that in 2003 the Hastings

Speaker: NA
Text: Public School had received $40,000 for some

Speaker: NA
Text: shadecloth. I do not have a record of that.

Speaker: NA
Text: What I think is quite likely to have happened

Speaker: NA
Text: is that the shadow minister has become con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fused between the Hastings Public School in

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales and Hastings Primary

Speaker: NA
Text: School in Victoria. If he has become con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fused on that basis let me take the opportu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity to explain to him that they are two dif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferent schools in two different states.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Hastings Public School in New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales, which is so ably represented in this

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament by the member for Lyne, also

Speaker: NA
Text: received funding of $2.6 million for new

Speaker: NA
Text: classroom construction. I understand from

Speaker: NA
Text: him that he is very well aware of the views

Speaker: NA
Text: of the school. They are delighted with the

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for the covered outdoor learning

Speaker: NA
Text: area. The principal has also informed me that

Speaker: NA
Text: he is a semifinalist in The Einstein Factor,

Speaker: NA
Text: with the topic of Franklin Roosevelt-

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: I know that wishing a

Speaker: NA
Text: principal well is just too much for the oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition to do; it is too hard!

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Julie Bishop- Mr Speaker, I rise on a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order on relevance. This is going far

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond just the indulgence of adding to an

Speaker: NA
Text: answer to a question. The Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister is getting on to areas that are totally

Speaker: NA
Text: irrelevant to any question asked of her in

Speaker: NA
Text: question time and she should be sat down.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Deputy Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition will resume her seat. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Prime Minister is adding to an an-

Speaker: NA
Text: swer.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: I know that it is beyond

Speaker: NA
Text: the charity of heart of the opposition to wish

Speaker: NA
Text: a school principal well in The Einstein Fac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor, but I most certainly do, and I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that members of the government and the In-

Speaker: NA
Text: dependents do, including the local member

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite. I am sure that, in studying Franklin

Text: Roosevelt for The Einstein Factor competi-

Text: tion, the principal's grasp on economics is

Text: now far clearer than that of the Liberal oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS

Speaker: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR
Text: Gorton-

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Home Affairs) (4.00 pm)- Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, I wish to make a personal explana-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Does the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR
Text: Yes.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Please proceed.

Speaker: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR
Text: The

Speaker: NA
Text: Daily Telegraph yesterday alleged that a staff

Speaker: NA
Text: member of my electorate office had placed

Speaker: NA
Text: his APH address on his private blog and that

Speaker: NA
Text: his private blog was linked to a pornographic

Speaker: NA
Text: blog. The staff member in question did inad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vertently place his APH address on his blog,

Speaker: NA
Text: for which he has been counselled.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Truss- Mr Speaker, I rise on a point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order. This part of the program of the par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament is designed for members to explain

Speaker: NA
Text: where they have been personally misrepre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented, not their staff.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: I will listen to the min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister and for the way in which this relates to

Speaker: NA
Text: him.

Speaker: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR
Text: The APH

Speaker: NA
Text: address has been removed from his blog.

Speaker: NA
Text: However-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Julie Bishop-How does this relate to

Speaker: NA
Text: you?

Speaker: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR
Text: Because

Speaker: NA
Text: the heading of the article is ‘Minister embar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rassed'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Julie Bishop-Well, aren't you?

Speaker: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR
Text: You are

Speaker: NA
Text: embarrassing; that is what you are.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! The minister

Speaker: NA
Text: will resume his seat. Those on my left will

Speaker: NA
Text: cease interjecting. The minister has the call.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, it is untrue that his private blog

Speaker: NA
Text: was linked to a pornographic site. The site

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to in the article is called Awkward-

Speaker: NA
Text: FamilyPhotos and it is currently linked to

Speaker: NA
Text: many public sites, including, would you be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve it, the Daily Telegraph site. On 19 May,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Daily Telegraph website described the

Speaker: NA
Text: site as ‘taking the world by storm, allowing

Speaker: NA
Text: readers to post cringe-worthy family por-

Speaker: NA
Text: traits, along with witty captions and head-

Speaker: NA
Text: lines'. I table the Daily Telegraph website

Speaker: NA
Text: page that links to the site in question. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: confident that this now clears up any misun-

Speaker: NA
Text: derstanding by the Daily Telegraph and the

Speaker: NA
Text: journalist involved.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Julie Bishop-That was an abuse of

Speaker: NA
Text: the processes of the parliament.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: An abuse of the proc-

Speaker: NA
Text: esses of the parliament is to sit there and insuspects.

Speaker: NA
Text: terject. I indicate that perhaps that might

Speaker: NA
Text: have been wide of the mark, but, given that

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister is a portfolio minister in the

Speaker: NA
Text: torney-General's Department, it may have

Speaker: NA
Text: assisted to clarify those matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS

Speaker: NA
Text: Piracy and Armed Robbery at Sea

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: Grayndler-Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional De-

Speaker: NA
Text: velopment and Local Government) (4.03

Speaker: NA
Text: pm)-by leave-On 12 June 2009 in a joint

Speaker: NA
Text: media release with the foreign minister, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hon. Stephen Smith MP, I announced that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has strengthened its commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: international efforts to combat piracy off the

Speaker: NA
Text: Horn of Africa. Australia will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: $500,000, as well as skills and expertise, to

Speaker: NA
Text: the joint European Commission/United Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions Office of Drugs and Crime (UNODC)

Speaker: NA
Text: Counter Piracy Program to assist Kenyan

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities in receiving and processing ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: prehended piracy suspects.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia will provide an official through

Speaker: NA
Text: the Office of the Inspector of Transport Se-

Speaker: NA
Text: curity and the Australian Federal Police to

Speaker: NA
Text: work with the UNODC in the Nairobi office

Speaker: NA
Text: in Kenya in dealing with piracy in the region.

Speaker: NA
Text: The international community, and particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly the UNODC, recognises that, if an ef-

Speaker: NA
Text: fective deterrent is to be created in the prose-

Speaker: NA
Text: cution of suspected pirates, there needs to be

Speaker: NA
Text: a capacity for the legal processing to occur

Speaker: NA
Text: within the north-east African region. The

Speaker: NA
Text: official will work with local authorities in

Speaker: NA
Text: Kenya in dealing with apprehended piracy

Speaker: NA
Text: This is one of a range of measures under-

Speaker: NA
Text: taken by the Australian government to com-

Speaker: NA
Text: Atbat the growing international problem of pi-

Speaker: NA
Text: racy. International Maritime Bureau figures

Speaker: NA
Text: show that more than 100 ships were attacked

Speaker: NA
Text: and 42 hijacked in the Gulf of Aden and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Somalia region in 2008. There have been

Speaker: NA
Text: around 60 attacks and 25 successful hijack-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings this year. Piracy is an issue that impacts

Speaker: NA
Text: on the entire international community, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: attack on the Italian cruise ship MSC Melody

Speaker: NA
Text: in April demonstrated. With over 1,500 pas-

Speaker: NA
Text: sengers and crew, including 74 Australians,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Melody was attacked by pirates in a

Speaker: NA
Text: speedboat at least 600 miles from the Somali

Speaker: NA
Text: coast-a practical demonstration that this

Speaker: NA
Text: issue is a global one that affects every coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try.

Speaker: NA
Text: The threat of piracy needs to be taken se-

Speaker: NA
Text: riously, especially by countries such as Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, which relies almost exclusively on

Speaker: NA
Text: international shipping for our exports and

Speaker: NA
Text: imports. With 99 percent of our exports by

Speaker: NA
Text: volume being transported by sea, a safe and

Speaker: NA
Text: secure maritime industry is paramount-to

Speaker: NA
Text: our economy, to our maritime industry and to

Speaker: NA
Text: the safety of many Australians who travel

Speaker: NA
Text: through international waters each year.

Speaker: NA
Text: In May this year, the government an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced that Australia would contribute Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Defence Force resources to interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional anti-piracy efforts off the Horn of

Speaker: NA
Text: rica. Our contribution includes the tasking of

Speaker: NA
Text: our Navy Anzac-class frigate and RAAF

Speaker: NA
Text: AP3C Orion patrol aircraft, which are al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ready contributing to counterterrorism activi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties in the region. Flexible employment of

Speaker: NA
Text: our assets across several coalition task forces locations.

Speaker: NA
Text: allows the ADF to contribute in an agile way

Speaker: NA
Text: to the highest priority activity. It is broadly

Speaker: NA
Text: recognised that the best long-term solution to

Speaker: NA
Text: the problem of piracy is to restore peace and

Speaker: NA
Text: stability in the Horn of Africa.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the international conference on Soma-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia in Brussels on 22-23 April this year, the

Speaker: NA
Text: government committed $2 million in security

Speaker: NA
Text: and humanitarian assistance to support inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national efforts to restore peace to Somalia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The United Nations estimates that over half

Speaker: NA
Text: the population of Somalia is in need of hu-

Speaker: NA
Text: manitarian assistance and that one in six So-

Speaker: NA
Text: mali children under five is acutely malnour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ished.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia will contribute $1.5 million to

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Nations Humanitarian Appeal,

Speaker: NA
Text: which will go towards security protection for

Speaker: NA
Text: humanitarian workers in Somalia to support

Speaker: NA
Text: vital health services for women and children,

Speaker: NA
Text: and $500,000 to the African Union Mission

Speaker: NA
Text: in Somalia, which is aiming to help Soma-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia's transitional government stabilise the

Speaker: NA
Text: country through strengthening financial sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tems and further medical assistance. Since

Speaker: NA
Text: 2005-06, the Australian government has con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tributed $9 million of humanitarian assis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance to Somalia and assistance has also been

Speaker: NA
Text: provided to neighbouring countries dealing

Speaker: NA
Text: with Somalian refugees.

Speaker: NA
Text: In December 2008, the Office of Transport

Speaker: NA
Text: Security issued Maritime Security Notice

Speaker: NA
Text: (2/08) on ‘Security Regulated Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Ships: Protective security arrangements for

Speaker: NA
Text: transiting through high-risk shipping lanes'

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australian shipowners in response to the

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in acts of piracy and armed robbery

Speaker: NA
Text: Af- in shipping lanes and waters surrounding the

Speaker: NA
Text: Gulf of Aden and the Somalian coast. The

Speaker: NA
Text: notice emphasised the importance for regu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lated Australian ships to apply robust and

Speaker: NA
Text: layered protective security measures when

Speaker: NA
Text: transiting through shipping lanes in high-risk

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Maritime Safety Authority

Speaker: NA
Text: Marine Notice (10/2009) on ‘Piracy and

Speaker: NA
Text: armed robbery against ships in the Somali

Speaker: NA
Text: Basin and the Western Indian Ocean' of June

Speaker: NA
Text: 2009 advises the Australian shipping indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try to implement International Maritime Or-

Speaker: NA
Text: ganisation preventative measures to deter

Speaker: NA
Text: and suppress acts of piracy and armed rob-

Speaker: NA
Text: bery against ships.

Speaker: NA
Text: In February 2009, I asked the Inspector of

Speaker: NA
Text: Transport Security, Mr Mick Palmer, a for-

Speaker: NA
Text: mer head of the Australian Federal Police, to

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake a comprehensive inquiry into

Speaker: NA
Text: maritime piracy and armed robbery at sea as

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the impact of piracy and armed robbery

Speaker: NA
Text: at sea on Australian registered and interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional trading ships and on Australian mari-

Speaker: NA
Text: time trade more generally. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: government want to make sure that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: an appropriate security framework to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with these threats.

Speaker: NA
Text: As part of the inquiry process, the inspec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor and key members of his team have liaised

Speaker: NA
Text: with a range of senior stakeholders, includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the UNODC, Interpol, the International

Speaker: NA
Text: Maritime Organisation, the International

Speaker: NA
Text: Maritime Bureau, as well as military, indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try and diplomatic stakeholders, to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that his inquiry complements wider interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional efforts.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was a result of the conduct of his in-

Speaker: NA
Text: quiry that the opportunity for Australia to

Speaker: NA
Text: make a contribution to the UNODC Counter

Speaker: NA
Text: Piracy Program came to light. The inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: will assist the Australian government in de-

Speaker: NA
Text: termining whether any changes are required

Speaker: NA
Text: to our domestic security framework. Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Palmer is due to report in the second half of

Speaker: NA
