Text: Within our own region, the Malacca strait

Speaker: NA
Text: has for many years been a focus for pirate

Speaker: NA
Text: and criminal activities. This narrow strait

Speaker: NA
Text: contains thousands of islets, and is an outlet

Speaker: NA
Text: for many rivers, making it an ideal location

Speaker: NA
Text: for pirates to hide and evade capture. It is an

Speaker: NA
Text: important passageway between China and

Speaker: NA
Text: India and is on the route between Europe, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Suez Canal, the Persian Gulf and the busy

Speaker: NA
Text: ports of Singapore, Hong Kong, Taiwan,

Speaker: NA
Text: Pusan and Tokyo. Indonesia, Malaysia, Sin-

Speaker: NA
Text: gapore and Thailand have formed the Ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: lacca Straits Security Joint Working Group in

Speaker: NA
Text: response to the problem. This issue was dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussed at the APEC meeting of transport

Speaker: NA
Text: ministers that I attended in Manila, the Phil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ippines, two months ago. Under the initia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive, the maritime forces of the four countries

Speaker: NA
Text: coordinate sea patrols of the area. Overall,

Speaker: NA
Text: there has been a significant reduction in at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tacks in this important maritime area.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, the Palmer inquiry, the

Speaker: NA
Text: ADF commitment to anti-piracy efforts and

Speaker: NA
Text: the contribution of financial support and

Speaker: NA
Text: skills and expertise to the UNODC demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strate Australia's commitment to work with

Speaker: NA
Text: effective international forums such as the

Speaker: NA
Text: International Maritime Organisation and the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations to deal with the threat of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: ternational piracy off the Horn of Africa.

Speaker: NA
Text: I met with the head of the International

Speaker: NA
Text: Maritime Organisation, Admiral Mitropou-

Speaker: NA
Text: los, at the IMO headquarters in London on 1

Speaker: NA
Text: April this year. At that meeting, he made a

Speaker: NA
Text: request for Australia's direct participation in

Speaker: NA
Text: these activities. I am pleased that the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment have been able to deliver in these

Speaker: NA
Text: small but important measures to make sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that, once again, we are taking our place as

Speaker: NA
Text: good international citizens when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: international maritime issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to acknowledge the presence in the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament today of the Minister for Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs for Kenya, Moses Wetang'ula, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister of Foreign Affairs and Co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operation of the Republic of Rwanda, Mrs

Speaker: NA
Text: Rosemary Museminali. Both of these minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters have expressed their support and grati-

Speaker: NA
Text: tude for Australia making this commitment.

Speaker: NA
Text: This threat of piracy directly affects the

Speaker: NA
Text: lives of Australians travelling through this

Speaker: NA
Text: region and our economic interests that are

Speaker: NA
Text: reliant on the safety and security of interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional shipping.

Speaker: NA
Text: I ask leave of the House to move a motion

Speaker: NA
Text: to enable the Leader of the Nationals to

Speaker: NA
Text: speak for 10 minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That so much of standing and sessional orders

Speaker: NA
Text: be suspended as would prevent Mr Truss (Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Nationals) speaking in reply to the ministe-

Speaker: NA
Text: rial statement for a period not exceeding 10 min-

Speaker: NA
Text: utes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Text: Wide Bay-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Nationals) (4.07 pm)-This ministerial

Speaker: NA
Text: statement from the Minister for Infrastruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture, Transport, Regional Development and

Speaker: NA
Text: Local Government is fundamentally just a

Speaker: NA
Text: repeat of a press release made on 12 June.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister's leaving the chamber demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strates that he is also not too interested in any

Speaker: NA
Text: kind of response to his statement and is,

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore, taking a further step in devaluing

Speaker: NA
Text: the importance of ministerial statements to

Speaker: NA
Text: the chamber. This statement is about a grant

Speaker: NA
Text: of $500,000. Many important things happen

Speaker: NA
Text: in the parliament and many important things

Speaker: NA
Text: happen in our country, and it is appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: that there be ministerial statements to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with these issues; but, when the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: does not even think it is necessary to remain

Speaker: NA
Text: in the chamber to listen to the reply to his

Speaker: NA
Text: statement, it is quite clear that he does not

Speaker: NA
Text: give this matter very high priority.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is disappointing because the issue of

Speaker: NA
Text: piracy on the high seas is an important issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whether this government's contribution will

Speaker: NA
Text: make a significant difference to the level of

Speaker: NA
Text: piracy around the world remains to be seen,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the issue of piracy itself is an important

Speaker: NA
Text: one and deserving of parliamentary debating

Speaker: NA
Text: time. It is a dangerous threat to global mari-

Speaker: NA
Text: time security. It threatens the livelihood of

Speaker: NA
Text: ship-borne commerce, which is the backbone

Speaker: NA
Text: of world trade. The overwhelming majority,

Speaker: NA
Text: by volume, of Australia's trade is carried by

Speaker: NA
Text: ships and, therefore, it is important to us as

Speaker: NA
Text: nation that shipping trade be safe and secure.

Speaker: NA
Text: The risk of piracy means that ships are some-

Speaker: NA
Text: times forced to take longer routes around

Speaker: NA
Text: dangerous zones and it certainly slows down

Speaker: NA
Text: the delivery and reliability of delivery of sea

Speaker: NA
Text: carried goods.

Speaker: NA
Text: The activities of pirates in the Gulf of

Speaker: NA
Text: Aden are of considerable concern threaten-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, as they do, Australia's merchant trade

Speaker: NA
Text: and threatening Australian sailors and tour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ists passing through the gulf and the Suez

Speaker: NA
Text: Canal. The Suez Canal is, of course, an im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant funnel for international trade. A very

Speaker: NA
Text: large proportion of maritime traffic moves

Speaker: NA
Text: through that canal and therefore ships mov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing up the Gulf of Aden are particularly vul-

Speaker: NA
Text: nerable to attack from pirates. It is perhaps a

Speaker: NA
Text: commentary on the audacity of some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: piracy activity that is occurring at the present

Speaker: NA
Text: time that it is happening under the nose of a

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable naval presence and despite the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that the presence of these pirates from

Speaker: NA
Text: Somalia is well known to the maritime

Speaker: NA
Text: community. The very presence of these pi-

Speaker: NA
Text: rates, particularly those coming from some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the countries in Africa where there is an

Speaker: NA
Text: acute shortage of food and other supplies, is

Speaker: NA
Text: a particular irony because the pirate activities

Speaker: NA
Text: threaten the delivery of food and aid to some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the poorest countries in Africa. This was

Speaker: NA
Text: illustrated with the seizure of the Maersk

Speaker: NA
Text: Alabama in April this year. That ship was

Speaker: NA
Text: carrying 5,000 metric tonnes of relief sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: plies for Somalia, Kenya and Uganda. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: who felt that intercepting this trade was in

Speaker: NA
Text: some way acceptable behaviour were not

Speaker: NA
Text: thinking of the impact on their fellow citi-

Speaker: NA
Text: zens in Somalia and other impoverished

Speaker: NA
Text: people in Kenya and Uganda.

Speaker: NA
Text: I understand that Somali pirates received

Speaker: NA
Text: over US$150 million in ransom in the 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months prior to November 2008. Pirates op-

Speaker: NA
Text: erating from Somalia have attacked more

Speaker: NA
Text: than 100 vessels in waters off the African

Speaker: NA
Text: a coast in the past year, including cruise liners,

Speaker: NA
Text: a fully laden supertanker and a ship laden

Speaker: NA
Text: with Russian tanks. As the minister pointed

Speaker: NA
Text: out, much is already being done by the inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national community to address this scourge.

Speaker: NA
Text: According to public reports, the European

Speaker: NA
Text: Union has a task force of six warships and

Speaker: NA
Text: three surveillance aircraft from eight coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries patrolling one million square kilometres

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Indian Ocean and the Gulf of Aden.

Speaker: NA
Text: The United States is making a contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: with its Fifth Fleet based in Bahrain. India,

Speaker: NA
Text: Russia, Malaysia and others are also provid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing warships. Australia, too, is making its

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution. The recent successful assis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance provided by HMAS Sydney and

Speaker: NA
Text: HMAS Ballarat in protecting MV Dubai

Speaker: NA
Text: Princess south of Yemen from an attack by

Speaker: NA
Text: pirates is an example. The deployment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Anzac frigate with the assistance of the

Speaker: NA
Text: RAAF AP3C Orion maritime aircraft is a

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome contribution to this international

Speaker: NA
Text: effort. This effort will have to continue, as

Speaker: NA
Text: the success of the international task force is

Speaker: NA
Text: driving the activities of the pirates further

Speaker: NA
Text: south, increasing the threat to sea lanes and

Speaker: NA
Text: expanding the area of ocean that will need to

Speaker: NA
Text: be patrolled.

Speaker: NA
Text: A policy of effective interdiction provided

Speaker: NA
Text: by a substantial and robust international na-

Speaker: NA
Text: val presence in the waters east of Africa is

Speaker: NA
Text: essential part of the strategy to deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: threat of Somalia based piracy. This is a plus.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will require a concerted effort to rebuild

Speaker: NA
Text: the shattered national institutions of Somalia

Speaker: NA
Text: if there is to be a long-term solution. Unfor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunately, this hastily cobbled together effort

Speaker: NA
Text: from the government in dealing with this

Speaker: NA
Text: complex problem raises more questions than

Speaker: NA
Text: it answers. The ministerial statement pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vides very little additional information on

Speaker: NA
Text: what this money is going to be spent on,

Speaker: NA
Text: where it is coming from and what the objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives of this assistance actually are. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: told it is going to provide $500,000, as well

Speaker: NA
Text: as skills and expertise, to the joint European

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission and United Nations Office of

Speaker: NA
Text: Drugs and Crime Counter Piracy Program to

Speaker: NA
Text: assist Kenyan authorities in receiving and

Speaker: NA
Text: apprehending piracy suspects. Australia is to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide an official through the Office of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Inspector of Transport Security and the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Federal Police to work with the

Speaker: NA
Text: UNODC in the Nairobi office in Kenya deal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing with piracy in the region. We are not

Speaker: NA
Text: provided with any information as to how this

Speaker: NA
Text: money is going to be spent beyond that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to provide some kind of judicial sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port for Kenyan authorities. The minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: not explained how this money will reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: the threat of piracy. Likewise, we do not

Speaker: NA
Text: know what the Australian government offi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial will do. The government has not even

Speaker: NA
Text: made it clear where the official will come

Speaker: NA
Text: from, whether from the Office of the Inspec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor of Transport Security or from the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian Federal Police. The details are not there.

Speaker: NA
Text: Frankly, this statement has all the hall-

Speaker: NA
Text: marks of another piece of spin supporting the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's ego driven bid for a tempo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rary seat on the United Nations Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Council. We have seen far too much of this

Speaker: NA
Text: extraordinary focus of the Prime Minister on

Speaker: NA
Text: securing this particular seat, a campaign that

Speaker: NA
Text: is consuming the resources of the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: an ment of Foreign Affairs and Trade and dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: the tracting the government from its requirement

Speaker: NA
Text: to advance and protect the interest of Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians overseas. It is not even clear from the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister's statement whether the funding for

Speaker: NA
Text: this announcement is going to come from his

Speaker: NA
Text: own department, the Department of Infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure, Transport, Regional Development

Speaker: NA
Text: and Local Government, or the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign Affairs and Trade, which of course

Speaker: NA
Text: had some significant increases in its budget

Speaker: NA
Text: in the appropriations currently before the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would be concerned, in light of all the

Speaker: NA
Text: cutbacks that have occurred in the depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of regional development under the aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: pices of the current minister, if in fact grants

Speaker: NA
Text: were now going to be provided to Kenya to

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with Somali pirates, rather than to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide assistance to Australian regional com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munities for which this minister and this de-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment should take primary responsibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: It would be a disappointment, at this time

Speaker: NA
Text: when he is cutting back road funding and

Speaker: NA
Text: other expenditure for the regions, if in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: funding were going to be provided towards

Speaker: NA
Text: an anti-piracy program in Somalia. That does

Speaker: NA
Text: not mean that we should not be involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking to combat piracy in Somalia. But,

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly, the funding provided should come

Speaker: NA
Text: from the foreign aid budget or under the ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tivities of Defence, who can play a useful

Speaker: NA
Text: role in helping to protect shipping, Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: and international, in that area. Also, the min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister made some reference to the working

Speaker: NA
Text: group on piracy in the Malacca straits, a very

Speaker: NA
Text: worthwhile initiative initiated and under-

Speaker: NA
Text: taken during the term of the previous gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment. I am pleased that the current minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter is continuing to ensure that Australia de-

Speaker: NA
Text: votes resources to and takes a keen interest

Speaker: NA
Text: in its activities. That area is a particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: important waterway for Australian shipping.

Speaker: NA
Text: A very large proportion of our trade passes

Speaker: NA
Text: through the straits and in dealing with piracy

Speaker: NA
Text: issues we should be concentrating, as a prior-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity, on ensuring that they remain safe.

Speaker: NA
Text: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: (MEDICARE LEVY AND MEDICARE

Speaker: NA
Text: LEVY SURCHARGE) BILL 2009

Speaker: NA
Text: NATION-BUILDING FUNDS

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT BILL 2009

Speaker: NA
Text: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT (VET FEE-HELP AND

Speaker: NA
Text: PROVIDERS) BILL 2009

Speaker: NA
Text: Returned from the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: Message received from the Senate return-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the bills without amendment or request.

Speaker: NA
Text: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: (EXTENDED MEDICARE SAFETY

Speaker: NA
Text: NET) BILL 2009

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed.

Speaker: Mrs HULL
Text: Riverina) (4.24 pm)-In

Speaker: NA
Text: continuing my speech on the Health Insur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance Amendment (Extended Medicare Safety

Speaker: NA
Text: Net) Bill 2009, I would like to bring to the

Speaker: NA
Text: attention of the House many of the issues

Speaker: NA
Text: that come under this bill and the areas that

Speaker: NA
Text: will be capped. Not all of these issues con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cern areas where I believe people are genu-

Speaker: NA
Text: inely putting themselves in a position

Speaker: NA
Text: whereby they are overextending doctors or

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves as to medical issues or are per-

Speaker: NA
Text: haps overextending themselves and they do

Speaker: NA
Text: not require these services.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will look at the issues in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: people who have assisted reproductive tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nology, or ART. In my electoral area cover-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Wagga Wagga and the Riverina, there

Speaker: NA
Text: was an assisted reproductive technology ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice in Wagga Wagga that took place in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Wagga day surgery. Our regional area people

Speaker: NA
Text: came in there to assist with the IVF and

Speaker: NA
Text: many other assisted reproductive skills that

Speaker: NA
Text: were provided by a specialist, who set up in

Speaker: NA
Text: Wagga particularly because the day theatre

Speaker: NA
Text: and the day surgery were there. That enabled

Speaker: NA
Text: her to come in and do obstetrics and also

Speaker: NA
Text: practise her passion for assisted reproductive

Speaker: NA
Text: technology, to benefit many couples who

Speaker: NA
Text: were childless and were assisted by IVF and

Speaker: NA
Text: other procedures.

Speaker: NA
Text: What happened was that when Calvary

Speaker: NA
Text: Hospital, a Catholic-run hospital, took over,

Speaker: NA
Text: having bought out the surgery, the theatres

Speaker: NA
Text: and the day hospital, it no longer allowed

Speaker: NA
Text: that type of activity to take place so now all

Speaker: NA
Text: of those in my region have to travel signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant distances in order to access assisted re-

Speaker: NA
Text: productive technology, IVF and other assis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance to be able to have children. The travel

Speaker: NA
Text: cost to them is absolutely astronomical. Gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: erally, many city people can walk to or get a

Speaker: NA
Text: bus, a train or a ferry or some other form of

Speaker: NA
Text: public transport to a hospital system or to

Speaker: NA
Text: these kinds of facilities and not be personally

Speaker: NA
Text: out of pocket-after paying for bus fares,

Speaker: NA
Text: train fares and other public transport fares-

Speaker: NA
Text: to the degree that my constituents are. When

Speaker: NA
Text: one has got to travel significant distances,

Speaker: NA
Text: you are constantly out of pocket. You might

Speaker: NA
Text: have to stay overnight or to stay two or three

Speaker: NA
Text: nights in order to access these services. If

Speaker: NA
Text: you are staying in a motel it could be ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tremely expensive.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that there is a need to recognise the

Speaker: NA
Text: distance factor and the cost factor for many

Speaker: NA
Text: of those people in rural and regional Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia-and, in my case, in the electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Riverina-who simply have to incur costs

Speaker: NA
Text: those just to physically get themselves to these

Speaker: NA
Text: services let alone use them. So I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned that this does not cover all as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sisted reproductive technology services. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that is simply unfair and quite dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: criminatory, because it does not recognise

Speaker: NA
Text: how much money, including out-of-pocket

Speaker: NA
Text: expenses, regional mums wishing to be

Speaker: NA
Text: mums and families wishing to be families

Speaker: NA
Text: have to spend in trying to access these in the

Speaker: NA
Text: first place.

Speaker: NA
Text: I cannot understand the reasons behind all

Speaker: NA
Text: obstetric services not being covered. I under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand that it has been reported that, between

Speaker: NA
Text: 2003 and 2008, the fees charged by obstetri-

Speaker: NA
Text: cians for in-hospital services reduced by six

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent while the fees charged for out-of-

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital services increased by a quite signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant percentage. But I do wonder about peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple in those areas where you cannot get into

Speaker: NA
Text: a hospital. In particular, I am talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: the Wagga Wagga Base Hospital, which is a

Speaker: NA
Text: referral centre for all of our region and be-

Speaker: NA
Text: yond. It is just so difficult to get into hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: to obtain any of these services. It is simply

Speaker: NA
Text: not possible to access the hospital service for

Speaker: NA
Text: these services. So do you not have the ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice at all or do you try to seek it as an out-

Speaker: NA
Text: of-hospital service? Again, I wonder what

Speaker: NA
Text: considerations have been factored in. I won-

Speaker: NA
Text: der where this is actually coming from. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: specialist has come from a city area or an

Speaker: NA
Text: area that has easy access to hospital services

Speaker: NA
Text: et cetera and those services are not being

Speaker: NA
Text: utilised, then maybe I can understand it, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: do wonder, when we are all lumped into one

Speaker: NA
Text: big melting pot and considered as an aggre-

Speaker: NA
Text: gate or an average, how in such cases we can

Speaker: NA
Text: play a significant part in explaining the is-

Speaker: NA
Text: sues to rural and regional people. I also won-

Speaker: NA
Text: der how much effect this legislation will

Speaker: NA
Text: have in pushing more and more people into

Speaker: NA
Text: the public hospital system where already you

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot access any of those services in rural

Speaker: NA
Text: and regional areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: The one area that concerns me the most-

Speaker: NA
Text: and I spoke about this in the three minutes I

Speaker: NA
Text: had to speak on this bill before question time

Speaker: NA
Text: was called on-is cataract surgery. Only one

Speaker: NA
Text: type of cataract surgery is covered under this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill-and for it to be capped is in itself an

Speaker: NA
Text: issue. It is primarily one of those out-of-

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital services in a day surgery. It may be

Speaker: NA
Text: run on a fly-in fly-out basis or by a person

Speaker: NA
Text: that comes in when there is no ophthalmolo-

Speaker: NA
Text: gist available in the regional areas. It might

Speaker: NA
Text: be somewhere out in the Broken Hill area,

Speaker: NA
Text: somewhere up the back of Bourke or some-

Speaker: NA
Text: where else. Somebody comes in and does a

Speaker: NA
Text: significant caseload because there is no way

Speaker: NA
Text: to get access to an ophthalmologist unless

Speaker: NA
Text: these people come in. Of course it is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: start to blow out when you have people com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in to do significant surgery.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am not saying that there is nobody who

Speaker: NA
Text: will rob or try to rort the safety net system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Anywhere, in anything you do, there will

Speaker: NA
Text: always be somebody who will do something

Speaker: NA
Text: that they should not be doing. I am not say-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing at all that that does not happen. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: hate to think that people would think that I

Speaker: NA
Text: was so naive as to think that there is not

Speaker: NA
Text: somewhere some abuse taking place of the

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net. But this bill is using a steel-

Speaker: NA
Text: capped boot to squash an ant. The fact is that

Speaker: NA
Text: some people might be abusing the system to

Speaker: NA
Text: some small degree but, on the other hand,

Speaker: NA
Text: people in rural and regional Australia are

Speaker: NA
Text: affected in the most significant ways. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: most significant ways they will be the ones

Speaker: NA
Text: that will be affected. Will ophthalmologists

Speaker: NA
Text: think it worth their while to take a day or two

Speaker: NA
Text: or three off work-generally a day and a half

Speaker: NA
Text: or more to travel to many of the outposts in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia; it could be two days of travel each

Speaker: NA
Text: way-and then a day while they are there to

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake that day surgery? With a signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant cap, will these specialist service provid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers consider that it is worth while for them to

Speaker: NA
Text: take all of this time out of their practice in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to go and run these day surgeries? It

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns me greatly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Coupled with this legislation, I understand

Speaker: NA
Text: that there will be further legislation coming

Speaker: NA
Text: into this House on cataract surgery itself. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have not seen this legislation yet, but I am

Speaker: NA
Text: led to believe, from a good source, that fur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ther legislation will be coming into the

Speaker: NA
Text: House severely cutting ophthalmology and

Speaker: NA
Text: cataract surgery. I cannot understand it. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: going to read from an email that I have re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived from one ophthalmologist in my elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate. Ophthalmologists are few and far be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween, let me tell you, and are very hard to

Speaker: NA
Text: come by. It is very hard to attract an oph-

Speaker: NA
Text: thalmologist out into country Australia as it

Speaker: NA
Text: is. With this cap, and with the measures soon

Speaker: NA
Text: to be introduced into the House, it is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: be nigh on impossible for there to be oph-

Speaker: NA
Text: thalmology services for rural and regional

Speaker: NA
Text: people, let alone for those people who live

Speaker: NA
Text: out in the wider expanses of Central Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia, in Broken Hill and other places. This

Speaker: NA
Text: ophthalmologist says that he is writing to

Speaker: NA
Text: make me aware that the government is in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tending to cut the rebate for cataract surgery

Speaker: NA
Text: by 50 per cent. He is not talking about this

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare safety net but, coupled with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare safety net, it is a big hit. He says:

Speaker: NA
Text: Their justification for doing this apparently is

Speaker: NA
Text: because they believe it is too quick and easy to

Speaker: NA
Text: perform and basically, not worth the money.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me tell you, those people who had cata-

Speaker: NA
Text: racts and had to have cataract surgery and are

Speaker: NA
Text: now free of cataracts think it is worth the

Speaker: NA
Text: money. If you lived like that you would soon

Speaker: NA
Text: find out whether it was worth the money. He

Speaker: NA
Text: goes on:

Speaker: NA
Text: Having taken four years of specific eye surgical

Speaker: NA
Text: training to master the procedure on top of a medi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal degree and 3-6 years of hospital residency

Speaker: NA
Text: coupled to the fact that community expectations

Speaker: NA
Text: are for 100% success rates and the stress associ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated with the procedure is somewhat akin to de-

Speaker: NA
Text: fusing a bomb through a microscope, we would

Speaker: NA
Text: beg to differ. One wonders if

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister-

Speaker: NA
Text: Kevin Rudd or-

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Roxon to have their cataract done, whether

Speaker: NA
Text: they will trot down to the local public hospital to

Speaker: NA
Text: sign up to have the junior eye registrar do the

Speaker: NA
Text: procedure or whether they'll seek out the most

Speaker: NA
Text: competent and experienced surgeon in town.

Speaker: NA
Text: He goes on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: The schedule fee for cataract surgery was around

Speaker: NA
Text: $800 in the early 1980s. The Government halved

Speaker: NA
Text: it back then and again cut it by around 30% in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1996. Now they want to cut it in half again. So in

Speaker: NA
Text: late 2009 the fee will be about half what it was

Speaker: NA
Text: over 25 years ago in face dollar terms and allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for inflation, this puts a real dollar value of

Speaker: NA
Text: about an eighth of what it was back then. In all

Speaker: NA
Text: that time our profession has succeeded in making

Speaker: NA
Text: the procedure quicker but also safer and with a

Speaker: NA
Text: faster recovery time and better visual results. We

Speaker: NA
Text: use a lot more high tech equipment now but this

Speaker: NA
Text: makes the procedure more complex, more techni-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally difficult and takes much longer to master, as

Speaker: NA
Text: any training registrar will testify.

Speaker: NA
Text: Basically this ophthalmologist goes on to

Speaker: NA
Text: talk about the public hospital system and

Speaker: NA
Text: why these out-of-hospital cataract operations

Speaker: NA
Text: have expanded. He says it is because you

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot get theatre time in the hospital. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: public hospital system in rural and regional

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia you cannot get theatre time, so of

Speaker: NA
Text: course they are going to be doing more in

Speaker: NA
Text: day surgeries. He says:

Speaker: NA
Text: Up until about six months ago-

Speaker: NA
Text: that is the end of last year-

Speaker: NA
Text: things were going well for our patients. A pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vately insured patient would get done with no out

Speaker: NA
Text: of pocket expense from me as I accepted ‘no-gap'

Speaker: NA
Text: payments from the funds for my surgery. A pa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tient electing to go public would wait about three

Speaker: NA
Text: months to get done at Wagga Base Hospital. If a

Speaker: NA
Text: non-insured patient wanted to go private, the all-

Speaker: NA
Text: up cost would be around $1800 out of pocket,

Speaker: NA
Text: $1100 of which went to the private hospital and

Speaker: NA
Text: the rest split between surgeon and anaesthetist.

Speaker: NA
Text: when it is time for- Since then-

Speaker: NA
Text: and I am talking specifically about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Greater Southern Area Health Service, which

Speaker: NA
Text: has-

Speaker: NA
Text: … cut our theatre lists back to 3 per month and

Speaker: NA
Text: never seem to have a dedicated theatre for emer-

Speaker: NA
Text: gencies, so that the lists we do get are sometimes

Speaker: NA
Text: cancelled for an emergency caesar, trauma case

Speaker: NA
Text: etc. As a result, my public waiting list has now

Speaker: NA
Text: blown out to eleven months and some of my col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leagues have longer waits. The worst thing is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the wait list grows by about two months, every

Speaker: NA
Text: month.

Speaker: NA
Text: So this obviously increases the interest and

Speaker: NA
Text: need for people to get their cataracts done

Speaker: NA
Text: outside the hospital system. I was trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: point to whether there is a recognition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: factors that show why there has been more

Speaker: NA
Text: private surgery and why more of these are

Speaker: NA
Text: being done out of hospital. You can see why

Speaker: NA
Text: when you factor in all of the issues and the

Speaker: NA
Text: challenges we are trying to meet in rural and

Speaker: NA
Text: regional areas. He goes on:

Speaker: NA
Text: This will now cost uninsured patients an extra

Speaker: NA
Text: $312 because of the fee cutback-

Speaker: NA
Text: on top of the increases that the hospitals have

Speaker: NA
Text: now applied and-

Speaker: NA
Text: … hospital charges for uninsured cataract cases

Speaker: NA
Text: are now $1300 for pensioners and a whopping

Speaker: NA
Text: $2075 for non-pensioners.

Speaker: NA
Text: He talks about how much there will be out-

Speaker: NA
Text: of-pocket charges for insured patients et cet-

Speaker: NA
Text: era. The problem we have is, I think, that

Speaker: NA
Text: there has been no thought given to how to

Speaker: NA
Text: address rogue issues. (Time expired)

Speaker: Ms OWENS
Text: Parramatta) (4.40 pm)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: rise to support the Health Insurance Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment (Extended Medicare Safety Net) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2009. It is an extremely important bill for the

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainability of the extended Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net. The purpose of the extended

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare safety net is to protect patients

Speaker: NA
Text: from high out-of-pocket medical costs for

Speaker: NA
Text: out-of-hospital medical services such as GP

Speaker: NA
Text: and specialist services. Relative to the total

Speaker: NA
Text: health budget it is quite a small component

Speaker: NA
Text: but is an incredibly important one.

Speaker: NA
Text: While most people face out-of-pocket

Speaker: NA
Text: costs of less than $50 a year, some members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the community face significant medical

Speaker: NA
Text: bills for out-of-hospital services. In 2007,

Speaker: NA
Text: around seven per cent of individuals had out-

Speaker: NA
Text: of-pocket costs of over $300 per year-add

Speaker: NA
Text: those up for families. And in 2007, 11,000

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians incurred out-of-pocket costs of

Speaker: NA
Text: more than $2,000 each. The number of peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple with these very high out-of-pocket costs

Speaker: NA
Text: initially fell after the Howard government

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced the EMSN in 2004 but rose very

Speaker: NA
Text: quickly again shortly after that and has been

Speaker: NA
Text: rising since.

Speaker: NA
Text: The benefits are highly concentrated in

Speaker: NA
Text: certain types of services. In 2007, over 30

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of all EMSN benefits helped fund

Speaker: NA
Text: obstetric services and 22 per cent went to-

Speaker: NA
Text: wards assisted reproductive services. The

Speaker: NA
Text: EMSN has more than doubled the amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth funding going towards these

Speaker: NA
Text: two professional groups. Only eight per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of the EMSN benefits went towards the

Speaker: NA
Text: funding of general practice consultations.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is also an extremely effective program

Speaker: NA
Text: directing assistance to cancer patients rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive to other patients with high healthcare

Speaker: NA
Text: needs. Given that over 50 per cent of EMSN

Speaker: NA
Text: payments go towards people for obstetric

Speaker: NA
Text: services, assisted reproductive services and

Speaker: NA
Text: chronic illnesses, you can see how incredibly

Speaker: NA
Text: important a program it is. It is incredibly

Speaker: NA
Text: important that it is sustainable over the long

Speaker: NA
Text: term so that we can continue to provide as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sistance to people with the greatest need.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a relatively new program. It was in-

Speaker: NA
Text: troduced by the Howard government in 2004

Speaker: NA
Text: to tackle high out-of-pocket costs for medi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal services. Under the EMSN, patients are

Speaker: NA
Text: reimbursed 80 per cent of their out-of-pocket

Speaker: NA
Text: costs for all out-of-hospital Medicare ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices once annual personal expenditure on

Speaker: NA
Text: these reaches a certain threshold, which was

Speaker: NA
Text: indexed annually. Prior to the introduction of

Speaker: NA
Text: the extended safety net in 2004, there was a

Speaker: NA
Text: limit on the amount of government contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for services. That was done through the

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare schedule fee. In fact, for the first

Speaker: NA
Text: eight or nine years of the Howard govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, contributions to this area were capped

Speaker: NA
Text: by those Medicare schedule fees. But in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2004 that cap was removed and instead 80

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of out-of-pocket costs or out-of-

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital services were paid no matter how

Speaker: NA
Text: much the doctor charged. You would expect

Speaker: NA
Text: that, if you removed the cap in that way,

Speaker: NA
Text: there would be some doctors and specialists

Speaker: NA
Text: who would increase their fees or who would

Speaker: NA
Text: think: ‘Okay, I can increase my fee by 50 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, or 80 per cent or whatever, and it will

Speaker: NA
Text: still be paid by the 80 per cent contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: for out-of-pocket costs.' Some did and costs

Speaker: NA
Text: started to rise, and between 2007 and 2008

Speaker: NA
Text: they rose 30 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: That rise in the spending on EMSN bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fits has not been matched by a drop in pa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tients' out-of-pocket costs. In fact, since its

Speaker: NA
Text: introduction there have been concerns that

Speaker: NA
Text: the EMSN may lead providers to increase

Speaker: NA
Text: fees and thereby dilute the potential benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: to patients. Since the introduction of the

Speaker: NA
Text: EMSN, average fees have increased by

Speaker: NA
Text: around 4.2 per cent per year, excluding gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral practice and pathology, which have been

Speaker: NA
Text: fairly stable. This increase is over and above

Speaker: NA
Text: the rate of inflation and it is estimated that

Speaker: NA
Text: the EMSN is responsible for 70 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the increase. It was directly responsible for

Speaker: NA
Text: 2.9 per cent increase in fees each year. It

Speaker: NA
Text: comes a question of whether the taxpayer

Speaker: NA
Text: should pick up the increase in fees by the

Speaker: NA
Text: specialists.

Speaker: NA
Text: The rise in costs was also of concern to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Howard government. In fact, in 2005,

Speaker: NA
Text: just one year after the scheme was intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced, concerns were such about the charg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of excessive fees by some doctors that

Speaker: NA
Text: the government raised the safety net expen-

Speaker: NA
Text: diture threshold so as to reduce the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of people who would qualify for the EMSN

Speaker: NA
Text: and rein in costs. They did not consider cap-

Speaker: NA
Text: ping again at that stage but they did raise

Speaker: NA
Text: threshold, which meant that people had to

Speaker: NA
Text: spend more of their own money before be-

Speaker: NA
Text: coming eligible. It reduced access to the

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. The original thresholds were set at

Speaker: NA
Text: $300 for concession card holders and FTBA

Speaker: NA
Text: recipients, and $700 for all others. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: were increased to $500 and $1,000 in 2005.

Speaker: NA
Text: After indexation, the thresholds now sit at

Speaker: NA
Text: $555.70 for concession card holders and

Speaker: NA
Text: people who receive family tax benefit part A

Speaker: NA
Text: and $1,111.60 for all other singles and fami-

Speaker: NA
Text: lies. But costs still continue to rise. Consis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tent with the fact that people in affluent areas

Speaker: NA
Text: incur more out-of-pocket costs, it was found

Speaker: NA
Text: that some 55 per cent of EMSN benefits is

Speaker: NA
Text: distributed to the top quintile of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: most socioeconomically advantaged areas,

Speaker: NA
Text: whereas the least advantaged quintile re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceives less than 3.5 per cent. That is, 55 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent for the top quintile and 3.5 per cent for

Speaker: NA
Text: the lowest.

Speaker: NA
Text: In rural areas costs have not increased in

Speaker: NA
Text: the same way. Over time, average out-of-

Speaker: NA
Text: pocket costs increased most in major cities,

Speaker: NA
Text: although the median in the major cities was

Speaker: NA
Text: quite stable, which suggests that the higher

Speaker: NA
Text: out-of-pocket costs in major cities are faced

Speaker: NA
Text: by those at the upper end of the distribution.

Speaker: NA
Text: Interestingly enough, over time the differ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence between the average and the medium is

Speaker: NA
Text: a actually increasing, showing that the differ-

Speaker: NA
Text: beence between the highest-charging specialist

Speaker: NA
Text: and the average-charging specialist has in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased dramatically.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know a lot about the nature of the ris-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing costs because there has been extensive

Speaker: NA
Text: review of the program, with a report coming

Speaker: NA
Text: down in 2009. As required under the Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation Amendment (Medicare) Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 2004, a review was undertaken of the opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, effectiveness and implication of the

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net. That was conducted by the Centre

Speaker: NA
Text: for Health Economics Research and Evalua-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion at the University of Technology in Syd-

Speaker: NA
Text: the ney. The report noted that the safety net has

Speaker: NA
Text: helped patients who have very high costs and

Speaker: NA
Text: has reduced out-of-pocket costs for some

Speaker: NA
Text: patients with cancer, but it clearly showed

Speaker: NA
Text: that there were major concerns in areas such

Speaker: NA
Text: as obstetrics and assisted reproductive tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nology, including IVF. Fifty per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net benefits are paid in those two ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: eas. Medicare benefits have more than dou-

Speaker: NA
Text: bled for both these groups since the safety

Speaker: NA
Text: net was introduced. A significant proportion

Speaker: NA
Text: of the increase in expenditure is because of

Speaker: NA
Text: the increases in fees charged.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is also a substantial difference be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween in-hospital and out-of-hospital fees.

Speaker: NA
Text: Between 2003 and 2008, the fees charged by

Speaker: NA
Text: obstetricians for in-hospital services reduced

Speaker: NA
Text: by six per cent while the fees charged for

Speaker: NA
Text: out-of-hospital services increased by 267 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. That is an extraordinary difference in

Speaker: NA
Text: changes in fees over a relatively short period

Speaker: NA
Text: of five years. Similarly, the fees charged for

Speaker: NA
Text: assisted reproductive technology services fell

Speaker: NA
Text: by nine per cent for in-hospital services and

Speaker: NA
Text: rose by 62 per cent for out-of-hospital ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices. This indicates that some doctors have

Speaker: NA
Text: been taking advantage of the safety net as

Speaker: NA
Text: their fees for out-of-hospital services have

Speaker: NA
Text: increased far in excess of the fees that they

Speaker: NA
Text: are charging in hospitals.

Speaker: NA
Text: The report also showed that, while EMSN

Speaker: NA
Text: payments have provided many with financial

Speaker: NA
Text: relief from significant out-of-pocket medical

Speaker: NA
Text: costs, those in the greatest financial need

Speaker: NA
Text: may be missing out on the benefits. The re-

Speaker: NA
Text: view found that, for every EMSN benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: dollar that is paid to a patient, 78 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: went towards meeting the doctor's higher

Speaker: NA
Text: fees rather than reducing the patient's out-of-

Speaker: NA
Text: pocket costs. Further, those who have bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fited most from affordable services have

Speaker: NA
Text: tended to be in the wealthier areas as they are

Speaker: NA
Text: in a better position to access the more expen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive specialist services in the first place.

Speaker: NA
Text: One would expect that costs would rise

Speaker: NA
Text: over four years, but rises have been extraor-

Speaker: NA
Text: dinary in some areas and quite modest in

Speaker: NA
Text: others. There is also, as I said, the substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: difference between in-hospital and out-of-

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital fees, with extreme variations in fees

Speaker: NA
Text: charged by specialists for the same services.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of this amendment is to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that taxpayers' money goes to reduce the out-

Speaker: NA
Text: of-pocket expenses for the benefit of patients

Speaker: NA
Text: and not to inflate the fees of some specialists

Speaker: NA
Text: in some circumstances. The consequences of

Speaker: NA
Text: fee rises are felt not just by those accessing

Speaker: NA
Text: the extended Medicare safety net but also by

Speaker: NA
Text: people who have not qualified for the safety

Speaker: NA
Text: net and also face those higher costs. This

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment allows the Minister for Health

Speaker: NA
Text: and Ageing to determine the maximum bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fit that would be paid under the safety net

Speaker: NA
Text: through a legislative instrument to allow for

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentary scrutiny. The report identified

Speaker: NA
Text: six areas of particular concern where fees

Speaker: NA
Text: have risen in an irregular way and well

Speaker: NA
Text: above others. Those six specific areas are

Speaker: NA
Text: obstetrics; assisted reproductive technology,

Speaker: NA
Text: including IVF; some cataract operations;

Speaker: NA
Text: some hair transplants; varicose vein treat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment; and several procedures involving the

Speaker: NA
Text: injection of a therapeutic substance into an

Speaker: NA
Text: eye. These areas have more than doubled

Speaker: NA
Text: since the safety net was introduced and, dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: turbingly, this increase is directly accounted

Speaker: NA
Text: for by increases in the fees charged by spe-

Speaker: NA
Text: cialists.

Speaker: NA
Text: In cases such as these, particularly when

Speaker: NA
Text: 50 per cent of the costs associated with this

Speaker: NA
Text: extended Medicare safety net program go to

Speaker: NA
Text: areas such as reproductive health, there was

Speaker: NA
Text: always considerable controversy with any

Speaker: NA
Text: change that was made. We have already

Speaker: NA
Text: heard from the members of the opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: today stories of great pain and grief and joy

Speaker: NA
Text: of people undergoing IVF treatment in recent

Speaker: NA
Text: years under the current laws. We have al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ready heard some of those. We have heard

Speaker: NA
Text: stories of hospitals in regional areas whose

Speaker: NA
Text: departments have shut down or had their

Speaker: NA
Text: funds cut back. That particular issue, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, is not related to this particular bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I would like to cover two particular ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: eas-the cataract area and assisted reproduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive technology-because I know that they

Speaker: NA
Text: are areas where it is very easy to frighten

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are already very fearful about

Speaker: NA
Text: what the future might hold for them.

Speaker: NA
Text: When it comes to cataracts, the changes

Speaker: NA
Text: announced in the budget represent the first

Speaker: NA
Text: time in 13 years that a government has re-

Speaker: NA
Text: viewed the payment for cataract surgery.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the past 13 years there has been signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant advancement in the technology used to

Speaker: NA
Text: carry out cataract operations, which means

Speaker: NA
Text: that operations can now be performed faster,

Speaker: NA
Text: with better results and with greater safety for changes.

Speaker: NA
Text: patients. The changes made by the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment more accurately reflect the time taken

Speaker: NA
Text: to carry out these procedures, which typi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally, these days, is around 20 minutes. For

Speaker: NA
Text: this 20 minutes of work the new standard

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare Benefits Schedule fee will be

Speaker: NA
Text: $419.85. To put this into context, currently

Speaker: NA
Text: the cataract procedure takes around 20 min-

Speaker: NA
Text: utes and has the same fee as the payment

Speaker: NA
Text: made by government for complex skull sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: gery, which takes more time to perform and

Speaker: NA
Text: carries a far greater risk for the patient.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ninety-five per cent of cataract procedures

Speaker: NA
Text: are undertaken in hospital.

Speaker: NA
Text: Assisted reproductive technology is also

Speaker: NA
Text: an area where it is very easy to frighten

Speaker: NA
Text: ple who are already afraid that circumstances

Speaker: NA
Text: for them will be worse than they are now.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the vast majority of people undergoing

Speaker: NA
Text: IVF, this will not be the case. On average,

Speaker: NA
Text: patients are charged around $6,000 per IVF

Speaker: NA
Text: cycle, yet some doctors are charging in ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess of $10,000 per cycle. Patients who see

Speaker: NA
Text: the specialists who charge around that

Speaker: NA
Text: $6,000 or less will not be worse off under

Speaker: NA
Text: these changes. From 1 January the Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: items for ART services will also be restruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tured to better align the items to the phases

Speaker: NA
Text: of treatment involved in the ART cycle. This

Speaker: NA
Text: will help to spread the costs and caps across

Speaker: NA
Text: the treatment cycle to better reflect the costs

Speaker: NA
Text: involved at each stage of the treatment cycle.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the same time the government is also

Speaker: NA
Text: investing $157.6 million in increasing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare rebates for obstetric services, and

Speaker: NA
Text: $120.5 million in maternity services to im-

Speaker: NA
Text: prove options for women and support those

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors that do not charge high fees. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: changes have been particularly welcome in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate. I have met recently with a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of mums who are planning pregnan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies in the next few years and are extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased at the greater range of services that

Speaker: NA
Text: will become available because of those

Speaker: NA
Text: The government remains committed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: extended Medicare safety net. It is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: important part of health services in this coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try and incredibly important for people fac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing quite difficult times in their lives. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 2008, though, expenditure on the safety net

Speaker: NA
Text: was $414 million, 30 per cent more than it

Speaker: NA
Text: was in 2007. Unless we make these changes

Speaker: NA
Text: now and support people in meeting their rea-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonable out-of-pocket costs, this expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: will continue to grow rapidly. As a govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, we cannot continue to see costs rise

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the rise in excessive fees at the

Speaker: NA
Text: upper end of a few small sections of our

Speaker: NA
Text: medical services. This bill creates a mecha-

Speaker: NA
Text: peo- nism by which the government can responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bly manage the safety net, and it is extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: important for supporting the sustainability of

Speaker: NA
Text: the safety net so that singles and families can

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to receive this incredibly important

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance with their out-of-pocket costs.

Speaker: Ms ROXON
Text: Gellibrand-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health and Ageing) (4.57 pm)-in reply-In

Speaker: NA
Text: summing up I would like to thank members

Speaker: NA
Text: for their contributions to the debate on this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill. It gives me great pleasure to follow the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Parramatta, who canvassed so

Speaker: NA
Text: many health issues for her electorate. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: important to many people in the community,

Speaker: NA
Text: so I appreciate that people have taken the

Speaker: NA
Text: time to speak in the debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Health Insurance Amendment (Ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tended Medicare Safety Net) Bill amends the

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Insurance Act 1973 to enable the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Health and Ageing to determine

Speaker: NA
Text: by legislative instrument the maximum bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fit payable under the extended Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net for each Medicare Benefits Sched-

Speaker: NA
Text: ule item. These changes, made by the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment in the budget, ensure that all items

Speaker: NA
Text: currently covered by the safety net remain

Speaker: NA
Text: covered by the safety net and no items will

Speaker: NA
Text: be means tested for eligibility. Importantly,

Speaker: NA
Text: IVF services will remain covered, with no

Speaker: NA
Text: age limits and no limitations on the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of cycles.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members, including the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Cook, who have very personal stories and

Speaker: NA
Text: genuine concern about these changes should

Speaker: NA
Text: be assured that all IVF procedures that are

Speaker: NA
Text: currently covered will continue to be cov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ered. There is still, I think, some remaining

Speaker: NA
Text: concern in the community, some confusion,

Speaker: NA
Text: about the speculation compared to the reality

Speaker: NA
Text: that all items will continue to be covered,

Speaker: NA
Text: with no age limits, no limitation on the num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of cycles and no means-testing. The

Speaker: NA
Text: changes, of course, go to a cap on the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount that can be charged-and I will

Speaker: NA
Text: come to that later-but I think that they

Speaker: NA
Text: should address the concerns, genuine as they

Speaker: NA
Text: are, from people like the member for Cook.

Speaker: NA
Text: Cancer services, as well, will not be affected

Speaker: NA
Text: at all by these changes. The changes that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have made are to restrict taxpayer funds be-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing spent on excessive fees that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: charged by some specialists. We are protect-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the taxpayers, we are protecting the pa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tients, and we are protecting those doctors

Speaker: NA
Text: who are doing the right thing in charging

Speaker: NA
Text: moderate fees.

Speaker: NA
Text: A recent independent review of the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tended Medicare safety net, a report tabled

Speaker: NA
Text: before this debate began, clearly showed that

Speaker: NA
Text: in certain areas, such as obstetrics and IVF,

Speaker: NA
Text: the safety net had been used by specialist

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors to raise their fees knowing that the

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayer would be called on to cover 80 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of the cost of the fee rise. For example,

Speaker: NA
Text: according to this report, between 2003 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 2008 the fees charged by obstetricians for in-

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital services reduced by six per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: while the fees charged for out-of-hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: services increased by a staggering 267 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. The report also showed that the safety

Speaker: NA
Text: net is not making some medical services

Speaker: NA
Text: more affordable for some patients-which,

Speaker: NA
Text: of course, was the purpose for which it was

Speaker: NA
Text: originally intended.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the reasons for this is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of benefit available through the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tended Medicare safety net is unlimited, and

Speaker: NA
Text: some specialists have taken advantage of this

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangement to increase their fees and their

Speaker: NA
Text: incomes, unfortunately with no particular

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit to the patient. The current nature of

Speaker: NA
Text: the safety net means that doctors feel little

Speaker: NA
Text: pressure to moderate their fees. Due to these

Speaker: NA
Text: fee rises for some services some patient out-

Speaker: NA
Text: of-pocket expenses have even increased as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of the extended Medicare safety net.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unless we act now we will not be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: stop this increasingly silly situation and the

Speaker: NA
Text: extended Medicare safety net will become

Speaker: NA
Text: unsustainable.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 2008, expenditure on the extended

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare safety net was $414 million, 30 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent more than the previous year. In some

Speaker: NA
Text: areas the increase is being driven by in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased fees rather than the provision of

Speaker: NA
Text: more services. This bill creates a mechanism

Speaker: NA
Text: for the government to responsibly manage

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure on the extended Medicare safety

Speaker: NA
Text: net. As part of the 2009-10 budget the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment is capping the benefits for some

Speaker: NA
Text: services where there is evidence of large in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creases in the fees charged, services where

Speaker: NA
Text: the majority of the extended Medicare safety

Speaker: NA
Text: net benefit is going to doctors rather than to

Speaker: NA
Text: helping patients. The new caps will apply for

Speaker: NA
Text: the following services: obstetrics, assisted

Speaker: NA
Text: reproductive technology, hair transplantation,

Speaker: NA
Text: the injection of a therapeutic substance into

Speaker: NA
Text: an eye, one type of cataract operation and

Speaker: NA
Text: one type of varicose vein treatment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some members in the debate have ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pressed the concern that this measure will

Speaker: NA
Text: increase the cost of obstetric services but I

Speaker: NA
Text: note that as part of this measure the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will also be investing $156.7 million to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase the Medicare rebates for private

Speaker: NA
Text: obstetric services. This means that the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes will allow all mothers who have

Speaker: NA
Text: their babies delivered by a private doctor to

Speaker: NA
Text: receive a standard Medicare rebate that is 30

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent higher than the current rebate. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government is also investing $120.5 million

Speaker: NA
Text: in a maternity services package. Part of this

Speaker: NA
Text: package will introduce Medicare items for

Speaker: NA
Text: midwifery services and will support greater

Speaker: NA
Text: choice for women-one of the issues

Speaker: NA
Text: touched upon by the member for Parramatta.

Speaker: NA
Text: The cost of IVF should not increase for

Speaker: NA
Text: most patients. On average, patients are

Speaker: NA
Text: charged around $6,000 per IVF cycle, yet

Speaker: NA
Text: there are some doctors charging in excess of

Speaker: NA
Text: $10,000 per cycle. Patients who see special-

Speaker: NA
Text: ists who charge $6,000 or less for a typical

Speaker: NA
Text: IVF cycle will not be worse off under these

Speaker: NA
Text: changes. In relation to the cap on the cataract

Speaker: NA
Text: item, I think that the opposition health

Speaker: NA
Text: spokesperson is confused. The extended

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare safety net only applies to out-of-

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital services. There is, of course, a

Speaker: NA
Text: rate measure which affects cataracts, to

Speaker: NA
Text: which he may have been referring. While I

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge that there is a crossover for a

Speaker: NA
Text: small number of services, 95 per cent of pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate cataract procedures take place as in-

Speaker: NA
Text: patient services so the extended Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net does not apply.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note, also, the closing comments of the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition spokesperson for health, who of-

Speaker: NA
Text: fered to work with the government to iden-

Speaker: NA
Text: tify alternative savings. That was a very kind

Speaker: NA
Text: offer in this debate, but we have not had one

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestion from the opposition for any sav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings in any health related measure, let alone

Speaker: NA
Text: any measure relating to this bill or in this

Speaker: NA
Text: budget debate. We have had no suggestions,

Speaker: NA
Text: no policy proposals-nothing. In fact, all we

Speaker: NA
Text: have had so far is opposition to any of the

Speaker: NA
Text: measures that we have proposed in Health.

Speaker: NA
Text: So I do ask where those suggestions are. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would be happy to see them and consider

Speaker: NA
Text: them but they have not been forthcoming to

Speaker: NA
Text: date and I am not intending to hold my

Speaker: NA
Text: breath while I wait for them. I did wonder if

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposition spokesperson was suggesting

Speaker: NA
Text: that the opposition would now be opposing

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill. Of course, the shadow Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly stated, following the budget:

Speaker: NA
Text: We're not going to block any initiatives other

Speaker: NA
Text: than the private health insurance initiative. So

Speaker: NA
Text: that's our position. We're not changing from it.

Speaker: NA
Text: So I wonder whether the member for Dick-

Speaker: NA
Text: son and the member for North Sydney are

Speaker: NA
Text: not in agreement here, because it seems that

Speaker: NA
Text: the shadow minister is raising some sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: issue that might be walking away from the

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment made by the member for North

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: The important point here is that the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tended Medicare safety net is a patient bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fit. It is not intended to be a mechanism by

Speaker: NA
Text: which doctors can simply increase their in-

Speaker: NA
Text: comes. The changes we have made will re-

Speaker: NA
Text: strict taxpayer funds from being spent on

Speaker: NA
Text: sepaexcessive fees that have been charged by

Speaker: NA
Text: some specialists while protecting those very

Speaker: NA
Text: many doctors who are doing the right thing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Importantly, it will continue to protect pa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tients with high medical costs and protect

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The changes in this bill are necessary to

Speaker: NA
Text: assist us in keeping the safety net sustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: and available to all Australians into the fu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture. These changes will allow Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: families to continue to have access to the

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net for IVF services into the future

Speaker: NA
Text: and they will allow access to the safety net

Speaker: NA
Text: by families of cancer patients, who have very

Speaker: NA
Text: high costs that need to be covered in difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances, and by many other worthy

Speaker: NA
Text: recipients, without this money being unfairly

Speaker: NA
Text: skimmed off by that small number of doctors

Speaker: NA
Text: who are charging excessive fees. The gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment is determined to put the patient first

Speaker: NA
Text: and foremost in all of our considerations, and

Speaker: NA
Text: we believe that this bill does that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: Ms ROXON
Text: Gellibrand-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health and Ageing) (5.06 pm)-by leave-I

Speaker: NA
Text: move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: (TRAINING INCENTIVES) BILL 2009

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Brendan O'Connor:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Text: Boothby) (5.06

Speaker: NA
Text: pm)-I am pleased to speak on the Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Amendment (Training Incentives)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 2009 and indicate that the opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be opposing this legislation. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: worth looking back 18 months because the

Speaker: NA
Text: government have now been in place for a

Speaker: NA
Text: little bit more than 18 months and it is time

Speaker: NA
Text: to deliver a mid-term report card on them.

Speaker: NA
Text: When you look specifically at the area of

Speaker: NA
Text: youth unemployment, you see in only 18

Speaker: NA
Text: months a terrible performance in jobs for

Speaker: NA
Text: teenagers, young Australians. Looking back

Speaker: NA
Text: to November 2007, specifically at 15to 19-

Speaker: NA
Text: year-old Australians, there were 257,000 in

Speaker: NA
Text: full-time jobs, compared with 222,400 now.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are almost 35,000 fewer teenagers in

Speaker: NA
Text: full-time jobs now than when the Rudd gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment was first elected. There are 31,000

Speaker: NA
Text: fewer teenagers in jobs in total. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: now an extra 4,300 teenagers who are unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployed. We have also seen very large falls in

Speaker: NA
Text: the participation rate for teenagers, from 60.4

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent to 57.4 per cent and in the employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment rate for teenagers-that is, the em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment-to-population ratio-from 51 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent to 47.8 per cent. That is a big change in

Speaker: NA
Text: just 18 months.

Speaker: NA
Text: The lesson of previous recessions, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: early 1980s and early 1990s, is that people

Speaker: NA
Text: who are just entering the labour force for the

Speaker: NA
Text: first time are often hit much harder. Youth

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment in Australia generally rises at

Speaker: NA
Text: twice the rate of total unemployment. When

Speaker: NA
Text: we look at 15to 24-year-olds, we see almost

Speaker: NA
Text: 70,000 fewer full-time jobs and 32,500 more

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed. The unemployment rate for

Speaker: NA
Text: those looking for full-time work is up from

Speaker: NA
Text: 9.8 per cent to 12.4 per cent. The overall un-

Speaker: NA
Text: employment rate is up from 9.7 per cent to

Speaker: NA
Text: 11.4 per cent. This is in just 18 months. The

Speaker: NA
Text: participation rate for these young Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: has fallen from 71.2 per cent to 69.4 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, and the employment rate, or employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment-to-population ratio, has fallen almost

Speaker: NA
Text: three per cent, from 64.1 per cent to 61.2 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: When you look at the labour force as a

Speaker: NA
Text: whole, over the last 12 months the economy

Speaker: NA
Text: has lost about 60,000 full-time jobs and there

Speaker: NA
Text: have been about 100,000 part-time jobs cre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated. When you look at the losses that have

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred in the 15to 24-year-old age group,

Speaker: NA
Text: there have been 70,000 full-time jobs lost in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian economy, and that is equiva-

Speaker: NA
Text: lent to the entire loss of full-time jobs in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy over the last 12 months.

Speaker: NA
Text: So this group is definitely bearing the brunt

Speaker: NA
Text: of the global financial crisis, but the Rudd

Speaker: NA
Text: government has introduced some specific

Speaker: NA
Text: policies that will disproportionately affect

Speaker: NA
Text: young Australians and their opportunities to

Speaker: NA
Text: get a start and to get a job.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bungled Job Services Australia will

Speaker: NA
Text: see massive disruption in the area of em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment services, such that 47 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: job seekers will be changing their provider

Speaker: NA
Text: and changing their case worker on 1 July, at

Speaker: NA
Text: a time when unemployment is rising. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have heard from industry groups, from Res-

Speaker: NA
Text: taurant and Catering, from pharmacies and

Speaker: NA
Text: from newsagents that the award modernisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion process will again lead to the loss of

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs, and, typically, a lot of these jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: entry-level jobs for young people. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: heard from a variety of groups that the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's Fair Work Bill will again be job

Speaker: NA
Text: destroying. These are three specific decisions

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government have taken. It is no

Speaker: NA
Text: wonder they are having to pump out billions

Speaker: NA
Text: and billions of dollars without having any

Speaker: NA
Text: idea of how many jobs will be created or

Speaker: NA
Text: supported when they have made specific de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cisions which go to the heart of the opportu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nities that there will be in the labour market.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are two parts to this bill. The first

Speaker: NA
Text: part is for a temporary training supplement

Speaker: NA
Text: of $41.60 per fortnight to eligible job seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: on Newstart or parenting payment who un-

Speaker: NA
Text: dertake approved training. These will be job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers who do not have a year 12 or equiva-

Speaker: NA
Text: lent level qualification, or who have a trade

Speaker: NA
Text: or vocational qualification that can be up-

Speaker: NA
Text: graded to help them find work. The payment

Speaker: NA
Text: will be available from 1 July 2009 to 30 June

Speaker: NA
Text: The opposition are not opposed to train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, but we believe that training is only one

Speaker: NA
Text: limb or one element of getting someone into

Speaker: NA
Text: a job. One of the weaknesses of the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's approach has been a complete failure

Speaker: NA
Text: to create a climate of strong job creation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor have failed to define a clear pathway

Speaker: NA
Text: between training and a job. There is a train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing mantra but not a jobs mantra. It is critical

Speaker: NA
Text: that unemployment is addressed by boosting

Speaker: NA
Text: business confidence and encouraging em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployers to take on new employees. The train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing supplement is something we do not op-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose, but, again, we believe that it is critical

Speaker: NA
Text: to demonstrate how this will lead into em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second part of the bill relates to

Speaker: NA
Text: amending the participation requirements for

Speaker: NA
Text: certain young people, requiring them to ei-

Speaker: NA
Text: ther earn or learn to be eligible for youth

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance. The opposition supports this ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: will be proach. Over the last 12 months we have

Speaker: NA
Text: seen the number of teenagers who are not in

Speaker: NA
Text: full-time education or full-time employment

Speaker: NA
Text: increase from fewer than 200,000-about

Speaker: NA
Text: 195,000-to 242,000. What we know is that

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are not in full-time education

Speaker: NA
Text: and not in full-time employment traditionally

Speaker: NA
Text: will languish and have trouble remaining in

Speaker: NA
Text: the labour force over their lifetimes. As I said

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier, during past economic downturns

Speaker: NA
Text: youth unemployment has increased dispro-

Speaker: NA
Text: portionately. It is critical that we ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: young people do not become disengaged and

Speaker: NA
Text: disenfranchised. One of the concerns about

Speaker: NA
Text: the labour force statistics is that we are see-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing very large falls in the participation rates

Speaker: NA
Text: of young Australians. We have seen in a pe-

Speaker: NA
Text: riod of 18 months very dramatic falls in the

Speaker: NA
Text: participation rates of young Australians. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: critical that we do keep people engaged in

Speaker: NA
Text: the labour market and we do keep people

Speaker: NA
Text: actively looking for work.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said, the opposition does support the

Speaker: NA
Text: tightening-up of youth allowance. But, again,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is only one aspect of improving youth un-

Speaker: NA
Text: employment and providing more opportuni-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties for younger Australians. There are lots of

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects that need to be addressed so that em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployers will take on extra workers so there

Speaker: NA
Text: will be the jobs there for younger Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians. As I said at the start, what we have

Speaker: NA
Text: seen is disappearing jobs for younger Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians-full-time jobs and overall jobs-and

Speaker: NA
Text: big falls in the participation rate and the

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment rate. So, whilst training and educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion can certainly boost employability, train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing is not for everyone and not everyone

Speaker: NA
Text: gains a benefit from training. The experience

Speaker: NA
Text: around the world is that training programs

Speaker: NA
Text: can be very expensive and actually have

Speaker: NA
Text: quite poor employment outcomes. We be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve it is important to tailor approaches to

Speaker: NA
Text: the individual.

Speaker: NA
Text: The opposition will be looking very care-

Speaker: NA
Text: fully at the labour force figures,

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘learn or earn' is not a cynical attempt to dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tort and manipulate the unemployment fig-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures as people who would otherwise be look-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for work are pushed into training in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to claim income support payments. We do

Speaker: NA
Text: not want to see a return to the training

Speaker: NA
Text: treadmill and many of the training programs

Speaker: NA
Text: of Working Nation, which actually had very

Speaker: NA
Text: poor employment outcomes and very low

Speaker: NA
Text: chances of people going from those pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grams into a job. We will be watching the

Speaker: NA
Text: figures on youth unemployment very care-

Speaker: NA
Text: fully. We think that this is a critical area to

Speaker: NA
Text: address for the future because it is very im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant that people do remain engaged, do

Speaker: NA
Text: remain active, so that they have a much

Speaker: NA
Text: stronger connection with the labour force

Speaker: NA
Text: over their lives.

Speaker: Ms HALL
Text: Shortland) (5.18 pm)-I rise

Speaker: NA
Text: to very strongly support the Social Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Training Incentives) Bill 2009

Speaker: NA
Text: before us today. As a person who in a past

Speaker: NA
Text: life worked with young people who were

Speaker: NA
Text: looking for work, and as a person who has

Speaker: NA
Text: had a lot to do with the actual training as-

Speaker: NA
Text: pects of young people and workers generally,

Speaker: NA
Text: I feel that this ‘learn or earn' legislation is

Speaker: NA
Text: very important. At the commencement of my

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution to this debate I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: very strongly emphasise that to let young

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are unemployed languish, with-

Speaker: NA
Text: out any assistance from government, is des-

Speaker: NA
Text: picable. What this legislation will do when it

Speaker: NA
Text: em- is enacted is see that that does not happen.

Speaker: NA
Text: What I also think is despicable is for

Speaker: NA
Text: young people with poor skills, poor literacy

Speaker: NA
Text: and poor numeracy to be penalised and to be

Speaker: NA
Text: thrown on the backburner and totally disre-

Speaker: NA
Text: garded-put into a Work for the Dole pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram, if there is one available, but at no time

Speaker: NA
Text: really having the issues that go to that per-

Speaker: NA
Text: son's employability addressed. I think this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation actually looks at some of those

Speaker: NA
Text: issues and will provide hope and a start for

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring that young people.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the past few years we have had a gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment-not the Rudd government but the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous government-that really squan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dered opportunities and did not train those

Speaker: NA
Text: people for the jobs that were available. We

Speaker: NA
Text: had a chronic skills shortage here in Austra-

Speaker: NA
