Text: lia at a time when our economy was thriving,

Speaker: NA
Text: when there was this great need for people to

Speaker: NA
Text: fill the jobs that were vacant. It would have

Speaker: NA
Text: been an excellent opportunity for the then

Speaker: NA
Text: government to embrace legislation like that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are debating here tonight, legislation that

Speaker: NA
Text: would have ensured that young people were

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared for work and that they were moving

Speaker: NA
Text: forward and being placed in a situation

Speaker: NA
Text: where they could make a tangible contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to our economy, where they had the

Speaker: NA
Text: skills that they needed to enter the workforce

Speaker: NA
Text: and where they could undertake ongoing

Speaker: NA
Text: training.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill will amend the Social Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 1991 to provide for training supplements

Speaker: NA
Text: for eligible recipients of parenting payment

Speaker: NA
Text: and Newstart allowance who have not com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pleted year 12 or equivalent or who seek to

Speaker: NA
Text: upgrade their vocational qualifications and

Speaker: NA
Text: who commence approved training or further

Speaker: NA
Text: education between 1 July 2009 and 30 June

Speaker: NA
Text: 2011. So, here you see the target group:

Speaker: NA
Text: young people who have not completed year

Speaker: NA
Text: 12 or equivalent and who really do not have

Speaker: NA
Text: the education or the skills that they need to

Speaker: NA
Text: enter the workforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: On my way into the chamber I believe I

Speaker: NA
Text: heard the shadow minister for employment

Speaker: NA
Text: participation saying that unemployment has

Speaker: NA
Text: risen. Yes, it has risen, and we acknowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: that on this side of the chamber. We also ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge that the global financial crisis is

Speaker: NA
Text: having an enormous impact on employment

Speaker: NA
Text: but not as big an impact in Australia as it is

Speaker: NA
Text: having elsewhere. We see this as an opportu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity to provide that training for young peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple.

Speaker: NA
Text: The legislation also amends the participa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion requirement for youth allowance, where

Speaker: NA
Text: a person under 20 years of age has not com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pleted year 12 or an equivalent certificate

Speaker: NA
Text: level II to level IV qualification. A youth

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance will be payable to young people

Speaker: NA
Text: without year 12 or equivalent if they study

Speaker: NA
Text: full-time or if they comply with the Youth

Speaker: NA
Text: Allowance Employment Pathway Plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: I need to talk a little bit about the em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment pathway plan. It is absolutely im-

Speaker: NA
Text: perative that a young person with limited

Speaker: NA
Text: training, maybe sometimes a less than per-

Speaker: NA
Text: fect education and very few skills determines

Speaker: NA
Text: a goal and works out how they are going to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve that goal. In working towards that

Speaker: NA
Text: goal they will have a number of strategies. In

Speaker: NA
Text: those strategies they will list the steps that

Speaker: NA
Text: need to be taken for them to gain the qualifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation and gain a job at the end. For instance,

Speaker: NA
Text: an early school leaver may feel that they

Speaker: NA
Text: would make an excellent horticulturalist-

Speaker: NA
Text: they like being outdoors, they like gardening

Speaker: NA
Text: and they do not mind hard work-but they

Speaker: NA
Text: are unaware of what they need to do to ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain a position working in horticulture. For

Speaker: NA
Text: that person an employment pathway plan

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to be developed whereby they will be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to undertake the certificate-level courses

Speaker: NA
Text: that meet the requirements of the job. They

Speaker: NA
Text: will follow it up with some work experience

Speaker: NA
Text: and on-the-job training as well as some for-

Speaker: NA
Text: mal off-the-job training. The pathway plan

Speaker: NA
Text: will require at least 25 hours a week in a

Speaker: NA
Text: combination of part-time study or training

Speaker: NA
Text: and other approved activities, which could be

Speaker: NA
Text: on-the-job training, which I think is impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant because it is all part of helping the

Speaker: NA
Text: young person to develop the skills that they

Speaker: NA
Text: need to enter the workforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some exemptions will apply. We know

Speaker: NA
Text: that training may be reasonably available for

Speaker: NA
Text: a person but the person may not have the

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity to undertake the available training.

Speaker: NA
Text: That could occur in a situation where the

Speaker: NA
Text: young person lives in quite a remote area,

Speaker: NA
Text: where there is only training at a much higher

Speaker: NA
Text: level than the person has the basic skills to

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake or where the person has a disabil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity and needs to undertake a specialised form

Speaker: NA
Text: of training.

Speaker: NA
Text: The training supplement has a financial

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of $83.1 million in additional spend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing over four years, so you can see that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government is making a significant contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to the training of young Australians. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government is prepared to invest at this par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular time in Australia's future. That is what

Speaker: NA
Text: this is; it is investing in training young peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple for Australia's future so that when things

Speaker: NA
Text: improve globally and within the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: economy-when more jobs become avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able-we will have young people with the

Speaker: NA
Text: skills who can walk into those jobs. We will

Speaker: NA
Text: be competitive not only within Australia but

Speaker: NA
Text: globally.

Speaker: NA
Text: The measure also amends the participation

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements for 15to 20-year-olds and has

Speaker: NA
Text: a net financial cost of $14.4 million over four

Speaker: NA
Text: years. The training supplement is an addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional time-limited payment of $41.60 per

Speaker: NA
Text: fortnight. That training allowance is an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: centive to young people to undertake the

Speaker: NA
Text: training. The budget announcement for this

Speaker: NA
Text: measure stated that changes to the participa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion requirement for Youth Allowance will

Speaker: NA
Text: come into effect on 1 July this year and for

Speaker: NA
Text: new claimants without year 12 or equivalent

Speaker: NA
Text: from 1 January 2010. The budget announce-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments also state that the training supplements

Speaker: NA
Text: will commence from 1 July this year. So it is

Speaker: NA
Text: very important that this legislation gets

Speaker: NA
Text: through the parliament in this sitting. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: very important that we are prepared to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide the training that these young people

Speaker: NA
Text: need.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will also assist low-skilled job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers with the costs of participation in

Speaker: NA
Text: training or further education which may as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sist them to obtain employment in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Job seekers will need to participate in ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proved education or training to receive the

Speaker: NA
Text: training supplements. Some people might

Speaker: NA
Text: study full-time; some might study part-time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Partial capacity to work will come into play.

Speaker: NA
Text: People doing courses that go for longer than

Speaker: NA
Text: a 12-month period may be eligible for stu-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent income support payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact that this legislation is targeting

Speaker: NA
Text: low-skilled workers is very important for us

Speaker: NA
Text: here in the parliament to consider. We need

Speaker: NA
Text: to upskill our workforce. As I mentioned at

Speaker: NA
Text: the commencement of my contribution to

Speaker: NA
Text: this debate, one of the big mistakes that the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous government made was failing to

Speaker: NA
Text: skill our workforce and failing to train peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple for the jobs that were available in Austratoring

Speaker: NA
Text: lia. It was such a missed opportunity. At that

Speaker: NA
Text: particular time, we had job vacancies and a

Speaker: NA
Text: very significant youth unemployment rate.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we are doing is addressing the needs of

Speaker: NA
Text: young people and the needs of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will also encourage more young

Speaker: NA
Text: people to gain the education and skills that

Speaker: NA
Text: they need to move into further education. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is not only employment that is important.

Speaker: NA
Text: Success at a lower level course gives young

Speaker: NA
Text: people the confidence to move on to courses

Speaker: NA
Text: that will set them up for a career for their rest

Speaker: NA
Text: of their lives. That career could start with an

Speaker: NA
Text: apprenticeship or otherwise; the employment

Speaker: NA
Text: could be in any job that young people find

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are interested in.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some young job seekers who participate

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Productivity Places Program, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: another aspect of this legislation, will not

Speaker: NA
Text: have to pay for their courses. However, not

Speaker: NA
Text: all courses taken up through the PPP will fit

Speaker: NA
Text: into that category. This is recognition that

Speaker: NA
Text: some people need more help. There is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: member in this House who would deny the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that there are definitely a lot of young

Speaker: NA
Text: people out there who, through no fault of

Speaker: NA
Text: their own, find themselves in quite disadvan-

Speaker: NA
Text: taged situations. The PPP will work well

Speaker: NA
Text: with that particular group of young people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Once again, this legislation is looking after

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly disadvantaged young people.

Speaker: NA
Text: This legislation has been quite well re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived. I note that ACOSS are a little cau-

Speaker: NA
Text: tious but cautiously supportive of the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal. They state that they will be looking

Speaker: NA
Text: closely at the youth allowance conditions so

Speaker: NA
Text: that disadvantaged young Australians are not

Speaker: NA
Text: unfairly penalised, which is what happened

Speaker: NA
Text: under the previous administration. These

Speaker: NA
Text: young Australians were unfairly penalised

Speaker: NA
Text: but not given the training that they needed.

Speaker: NA
Text: ACOSS also said that they acknowledge that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a need for ongoing training and men-

Speaker: NA
Text: that suits the circumstances of young

Speaker: NA
Text: people.

Speaker: NA
Text: The National Union of Students said:

Speaker: NA
Text: It is good to see that the government is expanding

Speaker: NA
Text: the number of tertiary and training places. A re-

Speaker: NA
Text: newed government focus on education will help

Speaker: NA
Text: generations through the recession.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is exactly right. They also said, how-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, that the COAG policies must not be all

Speaker: NA
Text: stick and no carrot. That was a problem un-

Speaker: NA
Text: der the previous government. For anything to

Speaker: NA
Text: be successful, you need to make sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: you have the mixture of carrot and stick

Speaker: NA
Text: right.

Speaker: NA
Text: There will be a significant number of

Speaker: NA
Text: places available as part of the youth compact

Speaker: NA
Text: with the state and territory governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a commitment to immediate action

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure significant school and training

Speaker: NA
Text: places are available for people aged 15 to 19

Speaker: NA
Text: who are entitled to an education or training

Speaker: NA
Text: place. This must be fully implemented by 1

Speaker: NA
Text: July this year. Once again, this is a commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment by government to young people. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that they have a future. The govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is prepared to get behind them and of-

Speaker: NA
Text: fer them the training and the skills that they

Speaker: NA
Text: need to enter the workforce. As I mentioned

Speaker: NA
Text: previously, part of that plan includes on-the-

Speaker: NA
Text: job and off-the-job training. I see that as

Speaker: NA
Text: viding very broad and full training to young

Speaker: NA
Text: people.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, young people aged 20 to 24

Speaker: NA
Text: will have an entitlement to education and

Speaker: NA
Text: training. This commitment will be imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: mented by 1 January 2010. State and terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory governments will work with their educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion authorities and training providers to

Speaker: NA
Text: make arrangements for determining eligibil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity for an entitlement place. It is anticipated

Speaker: NA
Text: that most places will be provided by TAFEs

Speaker: NA
Text: and some registered private training organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sations offering government subsidised

Speaker: NA
Text: qualifications. The Commonwealth, states

Speaker: NA
Text: and territories will work together to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that those young people living in rural and

Speaker: NA
Text: remote areas will also get the access that

Speaker: NA
Text: they not only need but deserve.

Speaker: NA
Text: This legislation provides hope for a future

Speaker: NA
Text: for young people. Changes in this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: support the youth compact and the national

Speaker: NA
Text: youth participation requirements agreed by

Speaker: NA
Text: COAG on 30 April 2009. This measure will

Speaker: NA
Text: also assist in bringing forward the COAG

Speaker: NA
Text: targets of 90 per cent year 12 or equivalent

Speaker: NA
Text: attainment rates for 2015 to 2020. The train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing supplement will be available for two

Speaker: NA
Text: years to provide enhanced incentives for job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers to gain skills and qualifications dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the global recession. This legislation is

Speaker: NA
Text: about government acting. This is about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Rudd government recognising that young

Speaker: NA
Text: people deserve a future, and it is investing in

Speaker: NA
Text: their future by giving them opportunities to

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake training so as to prepare them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves for jobs as they become available.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: O'Connor) (5.37 pm)-In

Speaker: NA
Text: her closing statement, the member for Short-

Speaker: NA
Text: land ran one of the recitation issues that this

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament is now confronted with in terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of ‘a government acting'. There is only way

Speaker: NA
Text: to describe the Social Security Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Training Incentives) Bill 2009, and that is ‘a

Speaker: NA
Text: progovernment reacting'. It is reacting to a very

Speaker: NA
Text: significant fall in employment, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: amongst young people. It is, of course, the

Speaker: NA
Text: outcome of recession, including-as the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister reminded us during her second read-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing speech-the recession that we had to

Speaker: NA
Text: have in the 1990s, when it was again young

Speaker: NA
Text: people in particular who found employment

Speaker: NA
Text: very hard to obtain.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another factor that is making it difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: for young people to get employment is the

Speaker: NA
Text: simple fact that employers are preparing

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves for the introduction of the Fair

Speaker: NA
Text: Work Australia legislation on 1 July. We see

Speaker: NA
Text: daily reports in the media of efforts by the

Speaker: NA
Text: trade union movement to further extend its

Speaker: NA
Text: power and, from its perspective, hopefully its

Speaker: NA
Text: revenues. This is to generate enough money

Speaker: NA
Text: to run another misleading campaign to try to

Speaker: NA
Text: convince the working people of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: that this government should remain in office,

Speaker: NA
Text: knowing full well that we are not part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: trade union appreciation society. We are not

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent upon its funding to win or lose

Speaker: NA
Text: elections. This has been highlighted by the

Speaker: NA
Text: most recent unemployment statistics, which

Speaker: NA
Text: show a fall in the number of people in per-

Speaker: NA
Text: manent employment from 25,000 to 20,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: The unemployment figures were compen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sated by a similar number in casual employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. And, of course, employment is going

Speaker: NA
Text: to go casual because that is the protective

Speaker: NA
Text: mechanism that small business employers

Speaker: NA
Text: will put into their arrangements to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that they do not get caught in the ‘go away'

Speaker: NA
Text: money trap that was significant with the pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vious unfair dismissal exercise. That legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion just became unfair to employers who

Speaker: NA
Text: were silly enough to give people a full-time

Speaker: NA
Text: job and who, for whatever reason, found

Speaker: NA
Text: later that they had to disconnect from those

Speaker: NA
Text: people-and probably for very good reason,

Speaker: NA
Text: as was frequently raised with my office. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, one small business man put on two

Speaker: NA
Text: workers and, at the end of 12 months, the

Speaker: NA
Text: business that he had anticipated had not ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: terialised. He very apologetically put off

Speaker: NA
Text: these two people, paid them in excess of

Speaker: NA
Text: their entitlement and then received claims

Speaker: NA
Text: from each of them for $10,000 for unfair

Speaker: NA
Text: dismissal. He rang his industrial adviser and

Speaker: NA
Text: said, ‘I'll fight these rotten devils to the High

Speaker: NA
Text: Court.' His adviser said, ‘And how much are

Speaker: NA
Text: they asking for?' and he said, ‘$10,000 each.'

Speaker: NA
Text: His adviser said: ‘Pay them. You'll win your

Speaker: NA
Text: case but it'll cost you more than that to do

Speaker: NA
Text: so.' That is coming up. Small business learnt

Speaker: NA
Text: its lesson last time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reverse applied when the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government discontinued unfair dismissal

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation for employers with fewer than

Speaker: NA
Text: 100 workers and, as a result, 50,000 jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: materialised in a month. In both New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales and Victoria-the typical rust bucket

Speaker: NA
Text: states that were not benefiting from the huge

Speaker: NA
Text: growth in resources exports-jobs material-

Speaker: NA
Text: ised not because they were necessarily new

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs but because people had the confidence

Speaker: NA
Text: to employ people on a full-time basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: As history also tells us, there was a time

Speaker: NA
Text: when it was not unusual for young people to

Speaker: NA
Text: leave the workforce after year 10 and enter

Speaker: NA
Text: into on-the-job apprenticeships and other

Speaker: NA
Text: on-the-job training positions. In years gone

Speaker: NA
Text: by, this did not even include TAFE training,

Speaker: NA
Text: which I think is a necessary part of today's

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements. But, again, we wonder why

Speaker: NA
Text: employers are not breaking their necks to

Speaker: NA
Text: take on apprentices and trainees in various

Speaker: NA
Text: categories when they are paid at a rate that

Speaker: NA
Text: does not equate to their productive effort

Speaker: NA
Text: and, more particularly, sees them absent

Speaker: NA
Text: from their workplace one or two days a week

Speaker: NA
Text: for training. No compensation of conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quence is paid to employers for having those

Speaker: NA
Text: people unavailable on those days.

Speaker: NA
Text: These situations have arisen. This legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion proposes that the taxpayer picks up

Speaker: NA
Text: some of that tab, and that may therefore be

Speaker: NA
Text: advantageous, not for people in work but for

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are not in work. It is referred

Speaker: NA
Text: to-and I endorse this principle-as ‘learn or

Speaker: NA
Text: earn'. Whilst I do not disagree with a reason-

Speaker: NA
Text: able safety net, it has unfortunately been

Speaker: NA
Text: found by a lot of young people to be suffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cient to get by on, and they then do not seri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously seek employment. If I were to be given

Speaker: NA
Text: a couple of hours to speak on this issue in

Speaker: NA
Text: this place, I could run through a list of ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: amples where I and members of my extended

Speaker: NA
Text: family, as employers, have had unemployed

Speaker: NA
Text: persons turn up at our places of business for

Speaker: NA
Text: the purpose of doing an interview and, in

Speaker: NA
Text: their opening remarks, say: ‘We don't want

Speaker: NA
Text: this job, you know. We're not going to take

Speaker: NA
Text: it. We'll really be a nuisance to you if you

Speaker: NA
Text: employ us.' They were there to get a signa-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture in their book to say that they had been

Speaker: NA
Text: out actively seeking work. This provision

Speaker: NA
Text: may do something in that regard and that of

Speaker: NA
Text: course will be a positive.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can see that it is a means of assisting. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is going to cost substantial amounts of

Speaker: NA
Text: money-$83.1 million is targeted to date-

Speaker: NA
Text: and, in fact, job seekers meeting these re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quirements will receive an extra $41.60 per

Speaker: NA
Text: fortnight if they undertake an approved train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing or further education course of less than

Speaker: NA
Text: 12 months duration at the certificate II, III

Speaker: NA
Text: IV level. But let me return to the issue as to

Speaker: NA
Text: why it now appears that by year 10 you have

Speaker: NA
Text: not absorbed enough education to take a job

Speaker: NA
Text: in the trades or elsewhere, as was previously

Speaker: NA
Text: the case. One can say, ‘Oh well, it's all com-

Speaker: NA
Text: puterised now.' That is a complexity. That

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to be one of the things that most kids

Speaker: NA
Text: know about and understand before they go to

Speaker: NA
Text: school. I was talking to someone the other

Speaker: NA
Text: day who had to ring their grandchild to help

Speaker: NA
Text: them sort out a software problem they were

Speaker: NA
Text: experiencing with their computer at home.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is wonderful and we read about this all

Speaker: NA
Text: over the place.

Speaker: NA
Text: I once learnt to fly a Chipmunk aeroplane

Speaker: NA
Text: and its only form of navigation was a marine

Speaker: NA
Text: compass. If I were to try to fly a current

Speaker: NA
Text: model of aeroplane today without high levels

Speaker: NA
Text: of computer skills, I would not be able to get

Speaker: NA
Text: it off the ground. Unfortunately, we recently

Speaker: NA
Text: read of a disaster where computers were

Speaker: NA
Text: suddenly interrupted and how difficult it was

Speaker: NA
Text: for a professional pilot to fly a commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: aircraft. A farmer in my electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Connor is now employing equipment

Speaker: NA
Text: which literally drives itself very accurately.

Speaker: NA
Text: So there is a need for that form of training.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the other hand, as reported in the media

Speaker: NA
Text: recently, three young mothers turned up at a

Speaker: NA
Text: picture theatre and, for reasons not stated,

Speaker: NA
Text: could not work out how much was three

Speaker: NA
Text: times the entry fee of $9. That is not an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dictment of those people but an indictment of

Speaker: NA
Text: an education system that has probably turned

Speaker: NA
Text: them out in year 10 with the inability to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that three nines are 27. Why is that? Because,

Speaker: NA
Text: quite foolishly, we walked away from the

Speaker: NA
Text: education structures that made sure every-

Speaker: NA
Text: body knew those basic forms of multiplica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: NA
Text: I ran hotels for about 25 to 30 years and I

Speaker: NA
Text: employed a vast number of staff on about

Speaker: NA
Text: one hour's assessment. The first thing I

Speaker: NA
Text: looked at was whether they walked fast or

Speaker: NA
Text: or slowly, but each and every one of those peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple, particularly the women, had the ability

Speaker: NA
Text: to add up. They could not go to the electronic

Speaker: NA
Text: machine that is now provided and is about

Speaker: NA
Text: the slowest way of dispensing alcohol I have

Speaker: NA
Text: ever seen in my life. I do not know how you

Speaker: NA
Text: can have an alcopops problem. They could

Speaker: NA
Text: add up and they did add up as they put the

Speaker: NA
Text: drinks order together and told the group to

Speaker: NA
Text: which they were supplying the drinks the

Speaker: NA
Text: price. How did they learn that? There were

Speaker: NA
Text: no computers to assist. The cash register was

Speaker: NA
Text: of the push-down variety on which you reg-

Speaker: NA
Text: istered the amount involved; you did not get

Speaker: NA
Text: a message from the register telling you what

Speaker: NA
Text: the change was. You had to work it out your-

Speaker: NA
Text: self. These were young and not-so-young

Speaker: NA
Text: men and women who could add up without

Speaker: NA
Text: any difficulty. From my own recollection,

Speaker: NA
Text: when you walked into a school in the open-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing period you heard kids in every classroom

Speaker: NA
Text: reciting their times tables. They were actu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally taught to read by phonetics. And where

Speaker: NA
Text: are we now? We are back to phonics. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have gone back to having that debate after

Speaker: NA
Text: the elite education establishment undermined

Speaker: NA
Text: all the practical outcomes that equipped a

Speaker: NA
Text: young person to enter employment after year

Speaker: NA
Text: As I have said, there are certain technical

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects to this bill-I read the statistics in the

Speaker: NA
Text: second reading speech of the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Education-but without an adequate basic

Speaker: NA
Text: education another year's training is not going

Speaker: NA
Text: to do much and, if that year's training is

Speaker: NA
Text: needed to repair the incapacity of a young

Speaker: NA
Text: person to read and write, should we be build-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing new assembly halls or, better, should we

Speaker: NA
Text: be organising the teaching profession so that

Speaker: NA
Text: we can turn out young people with the basic

Speaker: NA
Text: three Rs education? I think that is a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: grave concern. All the talk in this parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: about how much money is being spent on

Speaker: NA
Text: education and training is irrelevant unless it

Speaker: NA
Text: delivers outcomes. I smiled today when the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister was explaining that she was going

Speaker: NA
Text: to shift money from a school to which it had

Speaker: NA
Text: been allocated-the school was going to be

Speaker: NA
Text: knocked down-to a school where the other

Speaker: NA
Text: pupils were going to go. That amalgamated

Speaker: NA
Text: school might be brand new, but it is still

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to get the money. I note on one occasion

Speaker: NA
Text: the government obviously woke up to that

Speaker: NA
Text: fact and said, ‘Well, we had better not spend

Speaker: NA
Text: it on paint; we will spend it on computers.' I

Speaker: NA
Text: thought computers were coming free under

Speaker: NA
Text: another program. Are we just recycling

Speaker: NA
Text: money? Is it going to be free computers one

Speaker: NA
Text: day and a coat of paint the next day? As I

Speaker: NA
Text: said in my speech on the appropriations, very

Speaker: NA
Text: few of about the 150 schools in my elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate chose to take the $150,000 on offer. They

Speaker: NA
Text: did not take it because the opinion of the

Speaker: NA
Text: school principal and the parent associations

Speaker: NA
Text: was that they did not need that much. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are now being told to spend up to $3 million

Speaker: NA
Text: or else, yet internally the system is still ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vising us that young people who have not

Speaker: NA
Text: completed year 12 have an inadequate edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation base on which to obtain employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was never the case, and it need not

Speaker: NA
Text: be the case, notwithstanding that there are

Speaker: NA
Text: good reasons for most students to continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: year 12 provided they have a capacity to ab-

Speaker: NA
Text: sorb the education that that system provides.

Speaker: NA
Text: But what if it does not and a student's ten-

Speaker: NA
Text: dency is to be a highly skilled tradesperson?

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a great tragedy of history that some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the most highly skilled tradesmen I have met

Speaker: NA
Text: going back to my childhood have had very

Speaker: NA
Text: little education. But they were highly skilled

Speaker: NA
Text: in their trade, and that has changed some-

Speaker: NA
Text: what because a trade is not so manual. What

Speaker: NA
Text: I am saying is this: these ideas cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: criticised and we hope they work, but they

Speaker: NA
Text: are an indictment of the existing education

Speaker: NA
Text: system because they should not be needed;

Speaker: NA
Text: the training should not be needed.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is another problem that arises from

Speaker: NA
Text: that and, furthermore, I can quote examples.

Speaker: NA
Text: You have got to be very careful as an admin-

Speaker: NA
Text: istrator to see that training does not become

Speaker: NA
Text: an excuse for doing nothing. In recent years I

Speaker: NA
Text: know of people who said, ‘I'm going back to

Speaker: NA
Text: do another course,' and left full-time paid

Speaker: NA
Text: go- employment because a course was easier

Speaker: NA
Text: than turning up for seven hours a day in a

Speaker: NA
Text: job. So that is a problem. You get people

Speaker: NA
Text: who are perennially doing courses, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence of that exists for anyone who wants

Speaker: NA
Text: to check the stats or talk to people who have

Speaker: NA
Text: employed persons who have often come to

Speaker: NA
Text: them as unemployed. I think that is another

Speaker: NA
Text: worthwhile comment to make in this debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the five minutes left available to me, I

Speaker: NA
Text: note that this legislation deals with some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the principles and entry requirements for

Speaker: NA
Text: youth allowance. On the last sitting Thursday

Speaker: NA
Text: I presented to this parliament 6,280-as I

Speaker: NA
Text: think the number was-signatures on a peti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion collected in fewer than 10 days from

Speaker: NA
Text: people protesting about the unfair changes to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Youth Allowance system. It pops up here

Speaker: NA
Text: in a most interesting way when the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: says, to support these initiatives, the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth government committed to mak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing education and training a precondition

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘for young people without year 12, or the

Speaker: NA
Text: equivalent, to obtain youth allowance (other)

Speaker: NA
Text: and family tax benefit part A'. The youth

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance took into account the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: young people, having passed year 12, were

Speaker: NA
Text: typically wishing to enter university and of-

Speaker: NA
Text: ten-as in the case of my electorate-were

Speaker: NA
Text: living an unacceptable travel distance from

Speaker: NA
Text: the place of learning, which required their

Speaker: NA
Text: relocation, and that the rent allowance com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ponent of youth allowance was extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: important to them. They could prove their

Speaker: NA
Text: independence by going to work where work

Speaker: NA
Text: was available.

Speaker: NA
Text: The interesting thing about this is that,

Speaker: NA
Text: while we talk about the new conditions,

Speaker: NA
Text: which have nothing to do with parental in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come and all those sorts of things, they are

Speaker: NA
Text: still a roadblock to participation. Whilst the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister, in her second reading speech, ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: mits that it is very difficult for any young

Speaker: NA
Text: person to get a job at the moment, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: same breath she says, ‘But if you can't find

Speaker: NA
Text: one for 30 hours a week then you can't qual-

Speaker: NA
Text: ify for youth allowance.' In rural areas that

Speaker: NA
Text: does not happen. What students did under the

Speaker: NA
Text: old system was to take the seasonal work,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is now the norm through rural areas,

Speaker: NA
Text: whereby they could work long hours for

Speaker: NA
Text: good rates of pay and accumulate a sum of

Speaker: NA
Text: money-I think it reached about $19,000-

Speaker: NA
Text: and that was then their proven qualification

Speaker: NA
Text: to obtain youth allowance and take them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves off to university, where hopefully

Speaker: NA
Text: some of them might have even studied sci-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence and other scientific disciplines and went

Speaker: NA
Text: back and taught young people. In fact, now

Speaker: NA
Text: we are funding the cost of laboratories and

Speaker: NA
Text: all of these newly equipped facilities in edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation establishments-and hooray for

Speaker: NA
Text: that-but there is nobody with the compe-

Speaker: NA
Text: tence to teach within the repaired or renewed

Speaker: NA
Text: or rebuilt facilities. You would not let most

Speaker: NA
Text: of them loose with a Bunsen burner. So how

Speaker: NA
Text: is that going to work?

Speaker: NA
Text: It is just another indictment of this legislastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. We do not oppose it. We wish it well,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it would not be occurring in this fashion

Speaker: NA
Text: if, when young people came out of education

Speaker: NA
Text: and were not seeking an academic career,

Speaker: NA
Text: they could have the necessary basic skills to

Speaker: NA
Text: be employed and in fact to grow into the

Speaker: NA
Text: highly qualified skills which traditionally

Speaker: NA
Text: they learned in the workplace-and learned

Speaker: NA
Text: them extremely well, as those of us know

Speaker: NA
Text: who still have the opportunity to walk into

Speaker: NA
Text: older style houses and see how they were

Speaker: NA
Text: built with a hammer, nails and handsaws and

Speaker: NA
Text: that sort of equipment no longer used to any

Speaker: NA
Text: great extent. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs D'ATH (Petrie) (5.58 pm)-I rise to

Speaker: NA
Text: speak in support of the Social Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Training Incentives) Bill 2009.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before I go to the key areas of the bill, I will

Speaker: NA
Text: comment on some of the notable statements

Speaker: NA
Text: by the member for O'Connor. Firstly, I sin-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerely disagree with the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Connor's statement that he would not let

Speaker: NA
Text: most teachers loose with Bunsen burners. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that there are some fantastic teachers

Speaker: NA
Text: out there who should be commended for the

Speaker: NA
Text: work that they are doing. We need to make

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that we are supporting those teachers. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am sure that, if the member for O'Connor

Speaker: NA
Text: looked beyond the Building the Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Revolution funding that is being provided by

Speaker: NA
Text: this government and actually looked at this

Speaker: NA
Text: government's overall policy in relation to our

Speaker: NA
Text: education revolution, he and many of the

Speaker: NA
Text: members on the other side of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: would see that this government has commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ted to an overall approach to improving edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation in our schools, both public and pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate, across this country and that that in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cludes working on a national curriculum and

Speaker: NA
Text: a whole range of initiatives. Certainly the

Speaker: NA
Text: schools in my area welcome the debate and

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion on these key areas as much as

Speaker: NA
Text: they welcome the investment in school infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: that they believe is also important.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for O'Connor seems to be

Speaker: NA
Text: arguing that we should make sure that stu-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents are fully equipped for the workforce by

Speaker: NA
Text: grade 10. You would almost be led to be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve, based on the comments just made by

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for O'Connor, that we should

Speaker: NA
Text: get rid of grades 11 and 12 altogether be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause everyone should be suitable for the

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce by grade 10.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Tuckey interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr KJ

Speaker: NA
Text: Thomson)-Order! The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Connor will cease interjecting.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs D'ATH-The member for O'Connor

Speaker: NA
Text: can argue all he wants, but comments were

Speaker: NA
Text: made over and over again during that speech

Speaker: NA
Text: on this bill that we should make sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: students are fully equipped for the workforce

Speaker: NA
Text: by grade 10. That seems to be the bench-

Speaker: NA
Text: mark, not grade 12. The problem is that

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses want more than that nowadays,

Speaker: NA
Text: which the member for O'Connor and other

Speaker: NA
Text: members on the other side of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: would know if they actually went and talked

Speaker: NA
Text: to them. Businesses actually want students to

Speaker: NA
Text: have grade 12 or equivalent qualifications or

Speaker: NA
Text: they want those students to take on further

Speaker: NA
Text: education. It is not acceptable to merely have

Speaker: NA
Text: a grade 10 qualification.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for O'Connor may say,

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘Well, that's because the kids of today aren't

Speaker: NA
Text: taught phonics and aren't taught times ta-

Speaker: NA
Text: bles.' I disagree because my sevenand nine-

Speaker: NA
Text: year-olds are reciting the times tables that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are being taught in a state school and

Speaker: NA
Text: they are also learning to read and write

Speaker: NA
Text: through phonics. That sort of learning is cerin

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly still going on in our schools and we

Speaker: NA
Text: should commend our teachers for still teach-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing those important fundamental aspects of

Speaker: NA
Text: education. But we cannot ignore that com-

Speaker: NA
Text: puters are not just part of our schooling and

Speaker: NA
Text: our businesses but part of our way of life

Speaker: NA
Text: now. We also need to teach our young peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple in primary school and secondary school

Speaker: NA
Text: to adapt with that technology as it evolves

Speaker: NA
Text: over the years.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have no complaint about the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, the taxpayer dollars, picking up this

Speaker: NA
Text: incentive. This government has been com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitted since the day it got into government

Speaker: NA
Text: in 2007 about skills and skills enhancement.

Speaker: NA
Text: For more than the last decade under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government what we saw was a

Speaker: NA
Text: complete reversal when it came to invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in skills. We saw it with money being

Speaker: NA
Text: pulled out of the TAFE system. We saw it

Speaker: NA
Text: with the lack of commitment towards incen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives for trade training. Although we saw a

Speaker: NA
Text: government creating and building Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: technical colleges around the country, spend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing millions and millions of dollars establish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing ATCs, what it did not do was invest in

Speaker: NA
Text: trade training in many other areas, including

Speaker: NA
Text: in our schools. What we saw was a major

Speaker: NA
Text: drain on skills in this country in the trades

Speaker: NA
Text: area. By 2007, employers were absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: screaming out for a government which

Speaker: NA
Text: would take up the need to address skills.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill provides two major incentives.

Speaker: NA
Text: One is a training supplement, eligible to

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are receiving the parent payment

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Newstart allowance. It provides an

Speaker: NA
Text: additional incentive and financial support for

Speaker: NA
Text: those who do not have year 12 qualifications

Speaker: NA
Text: or the equivalent to go back and get further

Speaker: NA
Text: qualifications or a qualification beyond their

Speaker: NA
Text: schooling years. This will ensure that those

Speaker: NA
Text: people can enhance their prospects of em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment by allowing them to acquire skills

Speaker: NA
Text: a trade or a field. It may be different to the

Speaker: NA
Text: VET qualification that some of them may

Speaker: NA
Text: already have. This is very important. A time

Speaker: NA
Text: frame has been set out for this initiative. Be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween 1 July 2009 and 30 June 2011, persons

Speaker: NA
Text: who commence the approved training, who

Speaker: NA
Text: are on the parenting payment or Newstart

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance and who commence a course of 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months or less in an accredited course can

Speaker: NA
Text: access this additional payment of $41.60 per

Speaker: NA
Text: fortnight to assist them-not just to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: them financially while they undertake those

Speaker: NA
Text: studies but, importantly, to assist them in

Speaker: NA
Text: becoming more work ready and more able to

Speaker: NA
Text: compete equitably in the market when it

Speaker: NA
Text: comes to finding employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second initiative is the changes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: participation requirements for the youth al-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowance (other) category. These initiatives

Speaker: NA
Text: are directed particularly at younger people in

Speaker: NA
Text: our communities who may have left school

Speaker: NA
Text: early and who can truly benefit by going

Speaker: NA
Text: back and getting qualifications or additional

Speaker: NA
Text: qualifications in a certificate under the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Qualifications Framework. These are

Speaker: NA
Text: the types of certificate that employers are

Speaker: NA
Text: looking for and the types of skills that em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployers are looking for out there in the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity right now, at a time when the global

Speaker: NA
Text: economic crisis is being felt across this coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try. It is being felt locally in my communities

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate. Incentives like this for

Speaker: NA
Text: ple who have not completed their full educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion at school are significantly beneficial. I

Speaker: NA
Text: had the opportunity to briefly look at the

Speaker: NA
Text: 2006 census data for the electorate of Petrie.

Speaker: NA
Text: Out of the just over 101,000 people who re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponded to the question about their highest

Speaker: NA
Text: level of education, 40 per cent had a highest

Speaker: NA
Text: level of education of grade 10 or its equiva-

Speaker: NA
Text: lent or lower. Although many of those would

Speaker: NA
Text: be older now-and it is true to say that in

Speaker: NA
Text: recent years more young people have been

Speaker: NA
Text: staying at school for longer-we still have

Speaker: NA
Text: too many young people dropping out of

Speaker: NA
Text: school before completing their year 12 or

Speaker: NA
Text: equivalent qualification. In my electorate, I

Speaker: NA
Text: would welcome initiatives like this that will

Speaker: NA
Text: support those people in getting those sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: qualifications.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know from personal experience how

Speaker: NA
Text: hard it can be when you do not finish your

Speaker: NA
Text: schooling. I left school just after grade 10,

Speaker: NA
Text: when I was 15 years old, and it was not until

Speaker: NA
Text: I was in my early 20s that I went back to

Speaker: NA
Text: night school and started doing my senior

Speaker: NA
Text: equivalent. It is true, as was said in the

Speaker: NA
Text: ond reading speech in relation to these incen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives, that those who go back and do further

Speaker: NA
Text: education early in their life are more likely

Speaker: NA
Text: continue that education. Certainly for me,

Speaker: NA
Text: after doing my senior at night school in my

Speaker: NA
Text: early 20s, I then spent the next 14 years

Speaker: NA
Text: studying until I was admitted as a lawyer at

Speaker: NA
Text: the end of the process. If I am any example,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is encouragement so that, once you get

Speaker: NA
Text: back into studying, you are more inclined to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue taking on new skills and enhancing

Speaker: NA
Text: your qualifications. I am not saying that

Speaker: NA
Text: every person who may take up this incentive

Speaker: NA
Text: would necessarily do that; what I am saying

Speaker: NA
Text: is that, by creating these incentives, even if

Speaker: NA
Text: one person takes up this initiative, gains ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditional qualifications and consequently gets

Speaker: NA
Text: a job out of doing so, then these sorts of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: centives are worth doing. I certainly com-

Speaker: NA
Text: peo- mend the Rudd Labor government for put-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting these initiatives in place.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition to the federal government's

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to growing our skills base for

Speaker: NA
Text: this country, I can say that the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: government equally has that approach. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 2007, the Queensland government intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced changes to its schooling system that

Speaker: NA
Text: saw the introduction of the prep year across

Speaker: NA
Text: every school. I was fortunate that my son

Speaker: NA
Text: was in that first prep year and I have seen the

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits come from the introduction of that

Speaker: NA
Text: year. Also the state government introduced at

Speaker: NA
Text: the same time a learn or earn approach to

Speaker: NA
Text: senior students. They said to the senior stu-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents that, if they wanted to leave school

Speaker: NA
Text: before grade 12, then they were expected to

Speaker: NA
Text: be either studying full-time in some other

Speaker: NA
Text: way or going into the workforce and getting

Speaker: NA
Text: a job. I certainly support those initiatives.

Speaker: NA
Text: I understand, as do many youth workers in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate, that this is not always going to

Speaker: NA
Text: be the case and there are going to be young

Speaker: NA
Text: people in every electorate who have difficul-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties for a whole range of reasons. They may

Speaker: NA
Text: sec- be homeless, have substance abuse issues or

Speaker: NA
Text: have mental health issues. There are a whole

Speaker: NA
Text: range of issues that young people may be

Speaker: NA
Text: to facing. That will mean that these people can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not necessarily meet the requirements for the

Speaker: NA
Text: new youth allowance participation. What I

Speaker: NA
Text: am pleased to say is that, as part of this bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is the ability in those circumstances for

Speaker: NA
Text: young people to get a waiver, an exemption

Speaker: NA
Text: and to be considered in that context in rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to their particular circumstances. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased with that because, as I said, it was

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly a concern raised by youth workers

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having said that I believe that those peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple, some of the most vulnerable young peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple in our community, are the ones we should

Speaker: NA
Text: be helping the most to overcome the personal

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances that they are facing, whatever

Speaker: NA
Text: they may be, so that they can earn qualifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions and become someone who has self-

Speaker: NA
Text: esteem, who believes that they can go out

Speaker: NA
Text: and compete in the workforce like any other

Speaker: NA
Text: person and have new skills and the confi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence to get a job, and to have the quality of

Speaker: NA
Text: life that every person in this country deserves

Speaker: NA
Text: to have. For all of those reasons I commend

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr CRAIG THOMSON
Text: Dobell) (6.12

Speaker: NA
Text: pm)-Last week I was able to attend the

Speaker: NA
Text: launch of a very positive initiative put to-

Speaker: NA
Text: gether by group training and registered train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing organisations which operate in my elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate of Dobell on the Central Coast of New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales. This particular initiative was

Speaker: NA
Text: called Adopt an Apprentice program and

Speaker: NA
Text: aims to find new employers willing to take

Speaker: NA
Text: on apprentices who have unfortunately lost

Speaker: NA
Text: their places with other small businesses be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of the economic downturn or through

Speaker: NA
Text: similar circumstances. At the launch of the

Speaker: NA
Text: program the future was looking brighter for

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 job seekers who formed the target number

Speaker: NA
Text: under this program. Out of the 20, five

Speaker: NA
Text: places had already been found as the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram was being launched, so there were al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ready five apprentices with new employers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact that employers are willing to take

Speaker: NA
Text: on young apprentices who have had to be put

Speaker: NA
Text: off elsewhere is largely because these job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers already have some training, experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence and skills. Also the truth is that these

Speaker: NA
Text: young people are ready and willing to work.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have confidence because they have

Speaker: NA
Text: shown up to their workplaces. Their employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers and work mates have supported and en-

Speaker: NA
Text: couraged them. Their confidence came

Speaker: NA
Text: through being backed up by skills learned

Speaker: NA
Text: and training received while on the job. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are ready to try again with a new employer;

Speaker: NA
Text: someone who is willing to take on a keen

Speaker: NA
Text: young person, who, in turn, wants to get

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead with his or her apprenticeship and

Speaker: NA
Text: reach the goal they set out to achieve at the

Speaker: NA
Text: start, and that is to be trade qualified.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the registered trainers at the launch

Speaker: NA
Text: raised concerns about the lack of apprentices

Speaker: NA
Text: generally in the workplace. The man was in

Speaker: NA
Text: his 50s and had worked at Garden Island

Speaker: NA
Text: with over 400 apprentices in various trades

Speaker: NA
Text: working around him when he was a young

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentice. He reminisced about a time when

Speaker: NA
Text: there were many opportunities, and he said

Speaker: NA
Text: that the program that they were launching on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Central Coast was in some small way

Speaker: NA
Text: going to make sure that the apprentices who

Speaker: NA
Text: were in the system could complete the train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing they needed and acquire the skills re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired for the economy that we have on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Central Coast. We need to give our young

Speaker: NA
Text: people job skills for the future. Without this

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of investment we will find ourselves in a

Speaker: NA
Text: hole in a few years time, with a drastic lack

Speaker: NA
Text: of skills.

Speaker: NA
Text: Such neglect for future needs happened

Speaker: NA
Text: under the previous government and we must

Speaker: NA
Text: not let it happen again. We must be in a posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to make sure we continue to train new

Speaker: NA
Text: young people and encourage them to take on

Speaker: NA
Text: further training so that as the economy

Speaker: NA
Text: comes out of the global recession we have

Speaker: NA
Text: the necessary skills to make sure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: economies both locally and on the Central

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast can take advantage of those skills.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the economy recovers we will have in

Speaker: NA
Text: place a better skill base for our young people

Speaker: NA
Text: to help them get ready for the workforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: Setting that up, especially in places such as

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate, is absolutely vital. On the

Speaker: NA
Text: Central Coast, according to the last available

Speaker: NA
Text: figures, youth unemployment reached around

Speaker: NA
Text: 37 per cent. I am speaking about an area

Speaker: NA
Text: where these types of programs are absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: essential. We have always had high youth

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment, but with the global financial

Speaker: NA
Text: crisis we have seen it rise in the last six

Speaker: NA
Text: months from just over 25 per cent to just

Speaker: NA
Text: over 37 per cent. That is why I am support-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Social Security Amendment (Train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Incentives) Bill 2009. It is vital that

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of training be introduced and that these

Speaker: NA
Text: incentives be given so that young people in

Speaker: NA
Text: my area can get a fair shake.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill introduces a new training sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: plement to assist low-skill job seekers re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceiving Newstart allowance or parenting

Speaker: NA
Text: payment to undertake approved training.

Speaker: NA
Text: This will in turn support better employment

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities for those job seekers. The bill

Speaker: NA
Text: will assist low-skill job seekers with the

Speaker: NA
Text: costs of participating in training or further

Speaker: NA
Text: education which may assist them to secure

Speaker: NA
Text: employment in the future. The bill will en-

Speaker: NA
Text: courage more young people to gain the edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation and skills they need to move into fur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ther education or employment, recognising

Speaker: NA
Text: that youth with limited education are particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly vulnerable to becoming unemployed in

Speaker: NA
Text: the long term. The changes will be mirrored

Speaker: NA
Text: in changes to family tax benefit A proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: to commence from January 2010. These

Speaker: NA
Text: changes will proceed separately.

Speaker: NA
Text: Any opportunity for job seekers is vital,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially in regions such as mine, the Cen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tral Coast, where young people have constant

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty in finding work. Not only do we

Speaker: NA
Text: have 37 per cent youth unemployment but 30

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of the workforce commute to Syd-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney every day when they would prefer to

Speaker: NA
Text: work on the Central Coast. This initiative

Speaker: NA
Text: supports the government's commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: improve the educational attainment level of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians by encouraging completion of

Speaker: NA
Text: year 12 or equivalent and a commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed Australians to provide improved

Speaker: NA
Text: access to education and training opportuni-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties through Job Services Australia and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Productivity Places Program.

Speaker: NA
Text: The training supplement will be available

Speaker: NA
Text: to Newstart allowance and parenting pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment recipients who have not completed year

Speaker: NA
Text: 12 or who have a trade or vocational qualifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation that could be upgraded to better equip

Speaker: NA
Text: them to find future employment. Job seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: this meeting these requirements will receive an

Speaker: NA
Text: extra $41.60 per fortnight if they fully meet

Speaker: NA
Text: the activity test or participation requirements

Speaker: NA
Text: by undertaking approved training or further

Speaker: NA
Text: education at the certificate II or certificate III

Speaker: NA
Text: levels. The training supplement will be

Speaker: NA
Text: available for people commencing approved

Speaker: NA
Text: training between 1 July 2009 and 30 June

Speaker: NA
Text: 2011. The training supplement will be avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able under any approved training com-

Speaker: NA
Text: menced in this period when it is completed.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is estimated that over 50,000 low-skill job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers will be assisted over this period.

Speaker: NA
Text: The New South Wales Central Coast, as

Speaker: NA
Text: well as having high youth unemployment,

Speaker: NA
Text: has very low school retention rates, well be-

Speaker: NA
Text: low the benchmarks set at both national and

Speaker: NA
Text: state levels. In fact, less than 50 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: people attending school complete year 12.

Speaker: NA
Text: The object of this bill is to encourage young

Speaker: NA
Text: people to remain in education and training

Speaker: NA
Text: until they have completed year 12 or equiva-

Speaker: NA
Text: lent so they can improve their employment

Speaker: NA
Text: prospects and are equipped to find jobs as

Speaker: NA
Text: the economy improves. These changes sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port the youth compact and the national

Speaker: NA
Text: youth participation requirements agreed by

Speaker: NA
Text: COAG on 30 April 2009. This measure will

Speaker: NA
Text: also assist in bringing forward the COAG

Speaker: NA
Text: target of 90 per cent year 12 or equivalent

Speaker: NA
Text: attainment from 2020 to 2015. As you can

Speaker: NA
Text: see, on the Central Coast we have a long way

Speaker: NA
Text: to go when we have an under 50 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: completion level at the moment and want to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet 90 per cent by 2015. It is only by hav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the government take action in these ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: eas, through bills such as this, that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: some chance of that actually occurring.

Speaker: NA
Text: Youth allowance will be payable to young

Speaker: NA
Text: people without year 12 or an equivalent

Speaker: NA
Text: qualification if they study full time or if they

Speaker: NA
Text: comply with the youth allowance employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment pathway plan, which requires 25 hours

Speaker: NA
Text: a week in a combination of part-time study

Speaker: NA
Text: or training, in combination with other ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proved activities. These requirements will

Speaker: NA
Text: apply until the young person attains year 12

Speaker: NA
Text: or equivalent certificate level II qualification.

Speaker: NA
Text: Exemptions will apply where no training is

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonably available or the person does not

Speaker: NA
Text: have the capacity to undertake the training

Speaker: NA
Text: that is available. These amendments will

Speaker: NA
Text: apply to new applicants for youth allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: from 1 July 2009. The requirements will be

Speaker: NA
Text: progressively implemented for existing

Speaker: NA
Text: youth allowance recipients without year 12

Speaker: NA
Text: or the equivalent between January and July

Speaker: NA
Text: The main points of the bill are the follow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. The training supplement is an additional,

Speaker: NA
Text: time limited, payment of $41.60 per fortnight

Speaker: NA
Text: to help eligible job seekers who participate in

Speaker: NA
Text: approved study or training. It will be avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able for courses commenced between 1 July

Speaker: NA
Text: 2009 and 30 June 2011. The government is

Speaker: NA
Text: introducing this payment to encourage and

Speaker: NA
Text: support low-skilled income support recipi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ents with the costs of undertaking training or

Speaker: NA
Text: further education to assist them to secure

Speaker: NA
Text: employment in the future. The training sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: plement will assist job seekers receiving

Speaker: NA
Text: Newstart allowance or parenting payment

Speaker: NA
Text: who have not completed year 12 or the

Speaker: NA
Text: equivalent or who have a trade or vocational

Speaker: NA
Text: qualification which could be upgraded to

Speaker: NA
Text: better equip them to find future employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Job seekers will need to participate in ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proved education or training to receive the

Speaker: NA
Text: training supplement. For some people this

Speaker: NA
Text: may mean full-time study. Others, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: people with a partial capacity to work, would

Speaker: NA
Text: meet their participation requirements through

Speaker: NA
Text: part-time study. The sorts of approved

Speaker: NA
Text: courses that people will need to do include

Speaker: NA
Text: certificate II to certificate III courses which

Speaker: NA
Text: can be approved. Generally courses would

Speaker: NA
Text: run for at least one semester and can be up to

Speaker: NA
Text: 12 months in duration. People wanting to do

Speaker: NA
Text: a course for longer than 12 months may be

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible for student income support pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. The reason why the training supple-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is time limited is straightforward

Speaker: NA
Text: enough: the training supplement will be

Speaker: NA
Text: available for two years to provide an en-

Speaker: NA
Text: hanced incentive for job seekers to gain

Speaker: NA
Text: skills and qualifications during the global

Speaker: NA
Text: downturn. This makes sure that we do not

Speaker: NA
Text: have a generation that is forgotten because of

Speaker: NA
Text: the global financial crisis.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need to be making sure that not only

Speaker: NA
Text: are we stimulating jobs through the decisive

Speaker: NA
Text: action the government is taking with the

Speaker: NA
Text: stimulus packages but also those young peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple are being equipped with the skills neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary to participate in the economy as it

Speaker: NA
Text: comes out of recession-that they are not

Speaker: NA
Text: being left on the scrap heap, that they are

Speaker: NA
Text: given the opportunity to train and retrain. Job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers who participate in the Productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: Places Program will not have to pay for their

Speaker: NA
Text: course. However, not all courses taken up

Speaker: NA
Text: will be provided through the Productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: Places Program. Some may be through a

Speaker: NA
Text: state or territory subsidised TAFE or RTO

Speaker: NA
Text: place. In such cases, normal course fees will

Speaker: NA
Text: apply. As is currently the case, these course

Speaker: NA
Text: costs are the responsibility of the student. In

Speaker: NA
Text: addition to the assistance provided by the

Speaker: NA
Text: fortnightly training supplement, over the pe-

Speaker: NA
Text: riod 1 January 2009 to 30 June 2010 recipi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ents of Newstart allowance and parenting

Speaker: NA
Text: payment who undertake approved study or

Speaker: NA
Text: training are also eligible for the education

Speaker: NA
Text: entry payment of $208 and the $950 educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion entry payment supplement of the Train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and Learning Bonus.

Speaker: NA
Text: Looking at the training places, the enti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tlement to an education or training place is

Speaker: NA
Text: for any government subsidised qualification.

Speaker: NA
Text: Training places will come from a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: existing sources, including the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: government's Productivity Places Program.

Speaker: NA
Text: This program is providing 711,000 training

Speaker: NA
Text: places over five years to ensure that Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians develop the skills that they and industry

Speaker: NA
Text: need. Of these, 319,000 places, including

Speaker: NA
Text: 20,000 places for workers who may need to

Speaker: NA
Text: be re-skilled, are for job seekers; and

Speaker: NA
Text: 392,000 training places are allocated for ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: isting workers wanting to gain or upgrade

Speaker: NA
Text: their skills.

Speaker: NA
Text: As part of the compact with young Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians, young people under 20 who are work-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing up to 15 hours per week will be eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: for Productivity Places Program training

Speaker: NA
Text: places. For this program to work, some

Speaker: NA
Text: changes will have to be made. From 1 July

Speaker: NA
Text: 2009, young people seeking youth allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: without year 12 or equivalent will be as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sessed against new participation require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. Under these new requirements, to

Speaker: NA
Text: receive youth allowance young people under

Speaker: NA
Text: 21 years of age without year 12 or equivalent

Speaker: NA
Text: will need to: participate in education and

Speaker: NA
Text: training full-time; or participate full-time-

Speaker: NA
Text: that is, generally for at least 25 hours a

Speaker: NA
Text: week-in part-time study or training, in

Speaker: NA
Text: combination with other approved activities,

Speaker: NA
Text: until they gain year 12 or all equivalent cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tificate II qualifications. Young people al-

Speaker: NA
Text: ready receiving youth allowance who do not

Speaker: NA
Text: have year 12 or equivalent qualifications will

Speaker: NA
Text: make the transition to the new requirements

Speaker: NA
Text: between 1 January 2010 and 30 June 2010.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is fair to remind the House why the

Speaker: NA
Text: government is making these changes. Part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the reason is that the changes support the

Speaker: NA
Text: youth compact and national youth participa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion requirements agreed by COAG on 30

Speaker: NA
Text: April 2009. Looking closely at these time

Speaker: NA
Text: frames, the changes will apply to all young

Speaker: NA
Text: people without year 12 or an equivalent

Speaker: NA
Text: qualification claiming youth allowance from

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 January 2009 and to existing youth allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance recipients without year 12 or the

Speaker: NA
Text: equivalent who are not full-time students

Speaker: NA
Text: from 1 January 2010. In order to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: young people already receiving youth allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance time to consider their options, the new

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements will be progressively imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: mented for this group between January 2010

Speaker: NA
Text: and July 2010.

Speaker: NA
Text: Going over the requirements for young

Speaker: NA
Text: people who obtain year 12 or the equivalent

Speaker: NA
Text: qualification, the existing youth allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: participation requirements will continue for

Speaker: NA
Text: 21-year-olds who have received year 12 or

Speaker: NA
Text: the equivalent qualifications. This group of

Speaker: NA
Text: young people is not affected by the measure.

Speaker: NA
Text: The question has been raised that the new

Speaker: NA
Text: participation measures might punish disad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vantaged young people. Past economic

Speaker: NA
Text: downturns have demonstrated that young

Speaker: NA
Text: people with limited education and skills are

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly vulnerable to long-term unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment. They struggle to find employment

Speaker: NA
Text: even when the economy recovers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The arrangements will be flexible for

Speaker: NA
Text: young people with complex needs. For ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ample, young people with multiple barriers

Speaker: NA
Text: such as homelessness or substance abuse

Speaker: NA
Text: issues who would qualify for stream 4 under

Speaker: NA
Text: Job Services Australia arrangements will

Speaker: NA
Text: meet their requirements by participating in

Speaker: NA
Text: this service stream. Similarly, young people

Speaker: NA
Text: with a partial capacity to work will have

Speaker: NA
Text: their hours of participation tailored to their

Speaker: NA
Text: assessed capacity. If eligible, they can also

Speaker: NA
Text: meet their requirements by participating in

Speaker: NA
Text: disability employment services. The range of

Speaker: NA
Text: existing activity test exemptions based on

Speaker: NA
Text: personal circumstances, such as temporary

Speaker: NA
Text: medical incapacity or major personal crisis,

Speaker: NA
Text: will continue to be available. This will en-

Speaker: NA
Text: sure appropriate safeguards are in place to

Speaker: NA
Text: cover periods that young people cannot par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticipate.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is also useful to clear up any concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: about the availability of education or training

Speaker: NA
Text: places. As part of the COAG youth compact,

Speaker: NA
Text: state and territory governments have com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitted to immediate action to ensure suffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cient school and training places are available

Speaker: NA
Text: to young people aged 15 to 19, who will

Speaker: NA
Text: have an entitlement to an education or train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing place for any government subsidised

Speaker: NA
Text: qualification. This commitment will be fully

Speaker: NA
Text: implemented by 1 July 2009. Enrolments

Speaker: NA
Text: will be subject to admission requirements

Speaker: NA
Text: and course availability. In addition, young

Speaker: NA
Text: people aged 20 to 24 will have an entitle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to an education or training place for

Speaker: NA
Text: any government subsidised qualification

Speaker: NA
Text: which would result in the individual attain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a higher qualification. The commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: to 20-to 24-year-olds will be fully imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: mented by 1 January 2010. Enrolment will

Speaker: NA
Text: be subject to admission requirements and

Speaker: NA
Text: course availability.

Speaker: NA
Text: State and territory governments will work

Speaker: NA
Text: with their education authorities and training

Speaker: NA
Text: providers to make arrangements for deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mining eligibility for an entitlement place. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is anticipated that most places will be pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided by TAFEs and some by private regis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tered training organisations offering govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment subsidised qualifications. Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth, state and territory governments will

Speaker: NA
Text: also work with training providers to address

Speaker: NA
Text: issues relating to the provision of places in

Speaker: NA
Text: rural and remote locations. Exemptions will

Speaker: NA
Text: apply in cases where there are no locally ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessible training courses or appropriate dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance education options. Job Services Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia providers will also have the capacity to

Speaker: NA
Text: help young people gain access to education

Speaker: NA
Text: and training programs to improve their skills,

Speaker: NA
Text: including places in the government's Produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tivity Places Program.

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker Adams, you can see

Speaker: NA
Text: through this bill that the government is

Speaker: NA
Text: committed to helping young people, who

Speaker: NA
Text: might not have the best chances of gaining

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term employment, gain the necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: skills to give them a better chance. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: aimed at those young people who have not

Speaker: NA
Text: completed year 12 or the equivalent, or who

Speaker: NA
Text: have a trade or vocational qualification

Speaker: NA
Text: which could be upgraded to better equip

Speaker: NA
Text: them to find future employment. The budget

Speaker: NA
Text: announcement for this measure stated that

Speaker: NA
Text: the changes to participation requirements for

Speaker: NA
Text: youth allowance are to come into effect on 1

Speaker: NA
Text: January 2009 for new claimants without year

Speaker: NA
Text: 12 or the equivalent and from 1 January

Speaker: NA
Text: 2010 for existing recipients without year 12

Speaker: NA
Text: or the equivalent. Budget announcements

Speaker: NA
Text: also stated that the training supplement

Speaker: NA
Text: would commence from 1 July 2009. For

Speaker: NA
Text: young Australians hoping to upgrade their

Speaker: NA
Text: skills-such as from electorates like mine,

Speaker: NA
Text: with 37 per cent youth unemployment and

Speaker: NA
Text: less than 50 per cent of people going on to

Speaker: NA
Text: year 12-the opportunities provided by this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation cannot be overstated. It is vitally

Speaker: NA
Text: important that there are no delays in this leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: islation. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr CLARE
Text: Blaxland-Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary for Employment) (6.30 pm)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: thank all members for their contribution to

Speaker: NA
Text: this debate. The Social Security Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Training Incentives) Bill 2009 is part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's strategy to keep Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: working and set us up for the future. It cre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ates new incentives to train and learn, to help

Speaker: NA
Text: young people now and to make sure we have

Speaker: NA
Text: the skills we need as the global economy

Speaker: NA
Text: recovers. Unemployment is the biggest chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenge we face. It is the biggest challenge

Speaker: NA
Text: governments face all round the world. In

Speaker: NA
Text: America, unemployment has almost doubled

Speaker: NA
Text: in the last 18 months and now stands at 9.4

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent-the highest it has been in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: 25 years. Australia is doing better than most.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unemployment is lower here than in any

Speaker: NA
Text: other major advanced economy bar Japan,

Speaker: NA
Text: but there is a tough road ahead. Unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is projected to rise.

Speaker: NA
Text: When workers lose their job it does not

Speaker: NA
Text: just hurt the individual and their family, it

Speaker: NA
Text: hurts our economy. We lose skills and ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: perience-the skills and experience that we

Speaker: NA
Text: need to come out the other side of the global

Speaker: NA
Text: recession stronger and more competitive than

Speaker: NA
Text: before. We cannot stop the global recession

Speaker: NA
Text: hitting us, but we can reduce its impact. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is why the government is rolling out 35,000

Speaker: NA
Text: job sites across the country over the next 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months, providing tax breaks to small busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness and introducing this legislation, which

Speaker: NA
Text: is part of the jobs and training compact an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced by the Prime Minister in April this

Speaker: NA
Text: year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill before us does two things. First,

Speaker: NA
Text: introduces a temporary training supplement.

Speaker: NA
Text: This payment will be made to people who

Speaker: NA
Text: are amongst the most vulnerable to long-

Speaker: NA
Text: term unemployment: recipients of Newstart

Speaker: NA
Text: and the parenting payment who have not

Speaker: NA
Text: completed year 12 or an equivalent qualifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion or those who have a trade qualification

Speaker: NA
Text: that needs to be upgraded. The training sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: plement of an extra $41.60 a fortnight will be

Speaker: NA
Text: made to Newstart and parenting payment

Speaker: NA
