Text: recipients without a year 12 or an equivalent

Speaker: NA
Text: qualification who start an approved course of

Speaker: NA
Text: study or training between 1 July 2009 and 30

Speaker: NA
Text: June 2011. It is estimated that 50,000 people

Speaker: NA
Text: will benefit from this. Second, the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: changes the participation requirements for

Speaker: NA
Text: youth allowance (other). To obtain youth

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance (other), young people without

Speaker: NA
Text: year 12 or equivalent qualification will now

Speaker: NA
Text: need to participate in education and training.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose is to encourage young people to

Speaker: NA
Text: remain in study or training until they com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plete a basic educational or training qualifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation-to make sure young people are

Speaker: NA
Text: learning or earning.

Speaker: NA
Text: The logic behind these reforms is simple.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unemployment hits some communities and

Speaker: NA
Text: some groups harder than others. Young peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple and workers with low skills are particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly vulnerable. Since September last year

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment amongst young people aged

Speaker: NA
Text: 15 to 24 has grown at a faster rate than it has

Speaker: NA
Text: amongst the rest of the population. The more

Speaker: NA
Text: skills and education people have, the more

Speaker: NA
Text: likely they are to be employed and the more

Speaker: NA
Text: they are likely to be paid. The former Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Employment Participation made this

Speaker: NA
Text: point in his second reading speech:

Speaker: NA
Text: By age 24, only seven out of 10 young people

Speaker: NA
Text: without a year 12 or certificate III or IV qualifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion are in further training or employment. By

Speaker: NA
Text: contrast, nine out of 10 young people with such a

Speaker: NA
Text: qualification are in further training or employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: it In other words, skills count. Qualifications

Speaker: NA
Text: are important. The lesson from the recession

Speaker: NA
Text: of the early nineties is that youth unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment rises quickly and can take a long time

Speaker: NA
Text: to fall. Then, one in three young people who

Speaker: NA
Text: had not completed year 12 were unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployed. They were three times more likely to

Speaker: NA
Text: be unemployed than someone who had com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pleted year 12. These are the facts.

Speaker: NA
Text: The long-term consequence of this is en-

Speaker: NA
Text: trenched disadvantage. Long-term unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment has a devastating impact on indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: viduals and on families. It also has a long-

Speaker: NA
Text: term impact on the productivity and competi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiveness of our economy. That is why this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill is important. It is part of a comprehen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive strategy to reduce the risk of long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment and build the skills that we

Speaker: NA
Text: need to compete in a world beyond the

Speaker: NA
Text: global recession; to keep Australia working. I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Message from the Governor-General rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ommending appropriation announced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: Mr CLARE
Text: Blaxland-Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary for Employment) (6.35 pm)-by

Speaker: NA
Text: leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT (IMPROVED SUPPORT

Speaker: NA
Text: FOR CARERS) (CONSEQUENTIAL

Speaker: NA
Text: AND TRANSITIONAL) BILL 2009

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion

Speaker: NA
Text: by Ms Macklin:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Warringah) (6.35 pm)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not intend to detain the House long at all

Speaker: NA
Text: on this bill because the Social Security Leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: islation Amendment (Improved Support for

Speaker: NA
Text: Carers) (Consequential and Transitional) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2009 is about as uncontroversial as a piece of

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation can be. That does not necessarily

Speaker: NA
Text: mean that there will not be any contention in

Speaker: NA
Text: the House, but I am fairly confident that the

Speaker: NA
Text: contention will be over other aspects of so-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial security policy, not about the particular

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions of this bill. Essentially what this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill does is change the criterion for carers to

Speaker: NA
Text: go on the carer payment from one deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mined by medical classification to one de-

Speaker: NA
Text: termined by the actual level of care provided.

Speaker: NA
Text: As well, it changes the terminology of dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ability to something more appropriate and

Speaker: NA
Text: more sensitive to the modern ear. It is essen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tially housekeeping. It will benefit many

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of people over time, as the cost-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings reflect. The opposition support this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: and we commend it to the House.

Speaker: Ms ANNETTE ELLIS
Text: Canberra) (6.37

Speaker: NA
Text: pm)-It is indeed a pleasure to rise this eve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning to speak in support of the Social Secu-

Speaker: NA
Text: rity Legislation Amendment (Improved Sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port for Carers) (Consequential and Transi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional) Bill 2009. As has probably been said

Speaker: NA
Text: by other members, the earlier bill, the Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Legislation Amendment (Improved

Speaker: NA
Text: Support for Carers) Bill 2009, provides part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the government's response to the report of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Carer Payment (child) Review Taskforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: It gives effect to a number of measures

Speaker: NA
Text: aimed at improving assistance to carers from

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 July this year. The bill we are debating to-

Speaker: NA
Text: night is the companion bill to the improved

Speaker: NA
Text: support for carers bill, which has passed

Speaker: NA
Text: through the House already. This bill now

Speaker: NA
Text: comes in, as the previous speaker said, to put

Speaker: NA
Text: into effect most of the provisions required

Speaker: NA
Text: for carers in this area. I am really very

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to see this happening and to be part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the clarification process in the parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: tonight.

Speaker: NA
Text: As most members will be aware, a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee I chair recently provided a report to

Speaker: NA
Text: the parliament on the role of carers in our

Speaker: NA
Text: society. Through that process we had the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity-and the privilege, I might

Speaker: NA
Text: add-to speak and listen to literally hundreds

Speaker: NA
Text: and hundreds of carers around the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: We had the opportunity to hear precisely

Speaker: NA
Text: what they had to say about their lives, the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of the caring role on their lives and

Speaker: NA
Text: the sorts of things that they saw as important

Speaker: NA
Text: in attempting to lighten the load or to make

Speaker: NA
Text: their journey through their life of caring a

Speaker: NA
Text: little bit more bearable and manageable.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many of the things that are in this bill answer

Speaker: NA
Text: some of those questions and will make things

Speaker: NA
Text: a lot better for many carers. For instance, the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments will include the removal of ref-

Speaker: NA
Text: erences in social security law which, from 1

Speaker: NA
Text: July this year, will be redundant and the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: placement of those references with the new

Speaker: NA
Text: terms necessary for the proper administration

Speaker: NA
Text: of the changes to be introduced.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are a couple of things I would like

Speaker: NA
Text: to mention briefly, if I may, which really will

Speaker: NA
Text: have a great effect on the day-to-day lives of

Speaker: NA
Text: these people. One of them is the 63-day rule.

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendments made by this bill will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: that carers who qualify for the carer payment

Speaker: NA
Text: under the new qualification provisions will

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to take advantage of the existing

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits for carers. For example, under the

Speaker: NA
Text: 63-day rule, carers can temporarily cease to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide constant care but remain qualified

Speaker: NA
Text: for the carer payment. What this new provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion will mean is that, if you are in a caring

Speaker: NA
Text: role and the person for whom you are caring

Speaker: NA
Text: has a period in hospital or a period of respite

Speaker: NA
Text: care for up to 63 days per annum, the carer

Speaker: NA
Text: payment will continue to be made. That

Speaker: NA
Text: makes life a whole heap easier. The cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: caring does not necessarily dissolve into

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing just because the person you are of-

Speaker: NA
Text: fering that care to is not literally in your

Speaker: NA
Text: house or under your care. As I said, they

Speaker: NA
Text: could be in hospital or respite care or a simi-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar type of arrangement. I think this is a

Speaker: NA
Text: really sensible provision and will be very

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome for a number of people out there.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the other provisions is the special

Speaker: NA
Text: backdating for the carer payment. Given that

Speaker: NA
Text: this is a new regime, a new order of things,

Speaker: NA
Text: and knowing the frantic lives that these peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple lead, it may take a little while for some

Speaker: NA
Text: them to access the new forms and the new

Speaker: NA
Text: transitional arrangements. Between 1 July

Speaker: NA
Text: and 1 October this year, if there is evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: in an application from a treating health pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: fessional indicating that the carer would have

Speaker: NA
Text: been qualified for the payment within that

Speaker: NA
Text: period-had they known that they could in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact have made that application or had they

Speaker: NA
Text: had the time to make the application-the

Speaker: NA
Text: application can be backdated, as a transi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional arrangement under the new rules. So

Speaker: NA
Text: between 1 July and 1 October this year there

Speaker: NA
Text: is a little bit of flexibility, given the right

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances, for the carer in question to be

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodated through the application proc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ess, should that be required. Again, that

Speaker: NA
Text: makes it just that bit easier for these people

Speaker: NA
Text: and offers some understanding of the types

Speaker: NA
Text: of situations that they find themselves in and

Speaker: NA
Text: the pressures that we all know they face. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not know how other members feel, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: know that in my own life sometimes I can be

Speaker: NA
Text: very busy. Sometimes paperwork flows

Speaker: NA
Text: through your letterbox and you are not really

Speaker: NA
Text: sure how quickly you will be able to look at

Speaker: NA
Text: it. If you are in a caring role, I tell you, it can

Speaker: NA
Text: be all the more difficult. It is hard enough in

Speaker: NA
Text: normal life, let alone in those sorts of cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am really very pleased to see that we are

Speaker: NA
Text: now progressing. As I said, the original bill

Speaker: NA
Text: has gone through the House, and I believe it

Speaker: NA
Text: is now in the other place. We now have this

Speaker: NA
Text: machinery piece of legislation which will put

Speaker: NA
Text: into place the provisions that were alluded to

Speaker: NA
Text: in the earlier bill. This bill makes them all

Speaker: NA
Text: technically possible. I am very, very happy to

Speaker: NA
Text: think that we are going to see this happen,

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are going to see the progress brought

Speaker: NA
Text: about by these legislative changes. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: only mentioned a couple of them in brief, but

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that for the carers that we have spo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ken to through our inquiry process and the

Speaker: NA
Text: people that we all know in our constituencies

Speaker: NA
Text: of this is really going to make a difference. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is what we are all here for, I believe, as par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liamentarians. In cases like this we can actu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally make a practical difference to the lives

Speaker: NA
Text: of people who really need assistance. So I

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome this bill. As technical as it may be

Speaker: NA
Text: in some cases, it will put into action the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visions of the previous piece of legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Importantly, it builds on the work of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Carer Payment (child) Review Taskforce,

Speaker: NA
Text: which set this in train in the first place. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: proud to be a member of the government that

Speaker: NA
Text: set that up. I am proud that we are now see-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the provisions come in and that the bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fits will flow through to those who have car-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing roles in our community. I welcome this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation into the House.

Speaker: Ms LEY
Text: Farrer) (6.44 pm)-Like the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous two speakers, I welcome the Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Legislation Amendment (Improved

Speaker: NA
Text: Support for Carers) (Consequential and

Speaker: NA
Text: Transitional) Bill 2009. It is insignificant and

Speaker: NA
Text: technical in itself, but it is part of a very im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant range of measures that will make life

Speaker: NA
Text: easier for carers. As our opposition spokes-

Speaker: NA
Text: man said a few moments ago, there would be

Speaker: NA
Text: few less contentious pieces of legislation to

Speaker: NA
Text: go through the House. So, of course, we in

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposition welcome the measures in this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill and the changes that they will help bring

Speaker: NA
Text: to the lives of carers.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was privileged to be part of the Standing

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on Family, Community, Housing

Speaker: NA
Text: and Youth for a short while last year and to

Speaker: NA
Text: commence work on the inquiry that was ta-

Speaker: NA
Text: bled recently. I recognise the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: speaker, the member for Canberra, for her

Speaker: NA
Text: chairmanship of that inquiry. The report was

Speaker: NA
Text: called Who cares…? It really puts so much

Speaker: NA
Text: of what carers feel, believe and passionately

Speaker: NA
Text: want into words. It was a privilege to be part

Speaker: NA
Text: of that committee. As members of parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, every day we hear and see the results

Speaker: NA
Text: of people struggling with the caring role. I

Speaker: NA
Text: just want to touch on a couple of the special

Speaker: NA
Text: moments for me as part of that committee

Speaker: NA
Text: and the moments that encouraged me to

Speaker: NA
Text: work harder for carers. They were the repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentations made by young carers-those who

Speaker: NA
Text: are children struggling with school or in

Speaker: NA
Text: some cases young people at university and

Speaker: NA
Text: who are actually the carers in their family.

Speaker: NA
Text: One particular young lady said:

Speaker: NA
Text: … I have been caring for my father since I was 12

Speaker: NA
Text: years old and he retired. Over those years I did

Speaker: NA
Text: not have any support. It was not until the start

Speaker: NA
Text: this year that I found community options. So for

Speaker: NA
Text: seven years I was doing it on my own and attend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing high school. It was not actually until I started

Speaker: NA
Text: university-and I am doing psychology-that I

Speaker: NA
Text: realised that dad could have a mental illness. I

Speaker: NA
Text: went to his GP and I said, ‘Dad could have de-

Speaker: NA
Text: pression'. I was told that, because I do not have a

Speaker: NA
Text: medical degree, I did not know what I was talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about. So for six months dad went undiagnosed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Subsequently he took himself to hospital with

Speaker: NA
Text: suicidal thoughts. That was a big shock to me

Speaker: NA
Text: personally. For 12 months dad did not have any

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment. I just want to say that, because of that,

Speaker: NA
Text: I would really like GPs to consider that carers are

Speaker: NA
Text: a big part of the lives of the people they look af-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not read that third-party quote to criti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cise GPs at all, but simply to say that the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of carers and those that they look after

Speaker: NA
Text: is a community-wide issue and everybody

Speaker: NA
Text: involved needs to be aware of this. All carers

Speaker: NA
Text: that come to see me in my office without

Speaker: NA
Text: question, apart from being exhausted, talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about their responsibility. They talk about the

Speaker: NA
Text: positives as well; it is not all negative. They

Speaker: NA
Text: have such low expectations and they feel this

Speaker: NA
Text: is a burden that they have to carry very much

Speaker: NA
Text: on their own. If every other chain in the

Speaker: NA
Text: process-including GPs, advocates, work-

Speaker: NA
Text: mates and everybody involved-recognised

Speaker: NA
Text: the enormous load that the caring role places

Speaker: NA
Text: on individuals and offered a bit of support

Speaker: NA
Text: here and there, it would make an enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: difference.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the other things that came out of

Speaker: NA
Text: my work on this committee was a forum we

Speaker: NA
Text: held in my home town of Albury where peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple stood up and for a few minutes gave a

Speaker: NA
Text: snapshot of their lives and the caring role.

Speaker: NA
Text: One member of the committee-I actually

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot remember who it was-said, ‘You all

Speaker: NA
Text: seem so calm,' and one particular woman

Speaker: NA
Text: said, ‘That is because we are all so medi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated.' It really struck me that in order to get

Speaker: NA
Text: through the day a lot of carers are themselves

Speaker: NA
Text: of quite understandably struggling with their

Speaker: NA
Text: own health issues. They really do need sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port.

Speaker: NA
Text: Without making this a political statement,

Speaker: NA
Text: in New South Wales we do certainly notice a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot less support than the government just

Speaker: NA
Text: across the border to the south gives to its

Speaker: NA
Text: carers and their families. With the New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales budget on its way tomorrow, I

Speaker: NA
Text: really do hope that further support for this

Speaker: NA
Text: important area is maintained. It needs to be

Speaker: NA
Text: increased, because along the border-and

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate is on the border-between

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales and Victoria the frank ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice that people are receiving in New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales is to take their family to Victoria

Speaker: NA
Text: where the state government actually does a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot more for their children in school and

Speaker: NA
Text: gives them the respite that they desperately

Speaker: NA
Text: need. Respite is an enormous issue for eve-

Speaker: NA
Text: rybody-and I am sure this is common

Speaker: NA
Text: across the board. For people under 18, there

Speaker: NA
Text: are day programs and places for people to go

Speaker: NA
Text: with their disabilities and have special

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. That is catered for reasonably well.

Speaker: NA
Text: The problem arises for families when their

Speaker: NA
Text: young person turns 18, is no longer entitled

Speaker: NA
Text: to the same level of support or the support

Speaker: NA
Text: changes and-more importantly-the facili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties are not there in the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Just because somebody has a disability

Speaker: NA
Text: does not mean they want to live at home

Speaker: NA
Text: when they turn 18 and become a young

Speaker: NA
Text: adult. They still need to make their own way

Speaker: NA
Text: in the world and they need that level of inde-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendence. There is nowhere which supports

Speaker: NA
Text: them, which allows them their independence,

Speaker: NA
Text: which gives their family that much needed

Speaker: NA
Text: ongoing respite and which keeps them safe

Speaker: NA
Text: and looks after them. I do hope that we as a

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament focus more attention on the needs

Speaker: NA
Text: of carers and that we look at the needs of

Speaker: NA
Text: those young adults. Good things have been

Speaker: NA
Text: done for autism and packages have been put

Speaker: NA
Text: together, and they have made a difference for

Speaker: NA
Text: young people. There is early intervention at

Speaker: NA
Text: school, which is a critical time in a young

Speaker: NA
Text: person's life, but at the moment I am really

Speaker: NA
Text: detecting that some support for young adults

Speaker: NA
Text: with disabilities at the stage of life where

Speaker: NA
Text: they do want to gain some independence is

Speaker: NA
Text: simply not out there. I conclude by thanking

Speaker: NA
Text: those on all sides of the parliament who

Speaker: NA
Text: work hard for those carers in their electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: I encourage each and every one of them to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to support them in whatever way

Speaker: NA
Text: they can.

Speaker: Mr TREVOR
Text: Flynn) (6.50 pm)-I rise

Speaker: NA
Text: to support the Social Security Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Improved Support for Carers)

Speaker: NA
Text: (Consequential and Transitional) Bill 2009.

Speaker: NA
Text: As you will be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker

Speaker: NA
Text: Adams, the measures in this bill are part of a

Speaker: NA
Text: 2008 budget measure of which the legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: component has financial impacts as follows.

Speaker: NA
Text: The total resourcing of all portfolios for the

Speaker: NA
Text: 2008-09 year is $15.5 million; in 2009-10,

Speaker: NA
Text: $72.8 million; in 2010-11, $89.9 million; and

Speaker: NA
Text: treatin 2011-12, $93.3 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pursuant to schedule 1, ‘Amendment of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Social Security Act 1991', from 1 July

Speaker: NA
Text: this year a person will be able to qualify for

Speaker: NA
Text: carer payment if one of the following cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances apply: (a) care is provided to a

Speaker: NA
Text: child with a severe disability or severe medi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal condition; (b) care is provided to two or

Speaker: NA
Text: more children each with a disability or medi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal condition; (c) care is provided to a dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: abled adult and one or more children, each

Speaker: NA
Text: with a disability or medical condition; (d)

Speaker: NA
Text: care is provided to a child who has a terminal

Speaker: NA
Text: condition; (e) the care of two or more chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren each with a severe disability or severe

Speaker: NA
Text: medical condition is exchanged between the

Speaker: NA
Text: separated or divorced parents of the children;

Speaker: NA
Text: (f) care is provided to a child or children on a

Speaker: NA
Text: short-term or episodic basis; (g) care is pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided to a disabled adult or a disabled adult

Speaker: NA
Text: and a dependent child; or (h) care is provided

Speaker: NA
Text: to any of the above while they are in hospi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal.

Speaker: NA
Text: The qualification provisions for carer

Speaker: NA
Text: payment where care is provided to a child

Speaker: NA
Text: with a severe disability or severe medical

Speaker: NA
Text: condition, or care is provided to two or more

Speaker: NA
Text: children each with disability or medical con-

Speaker: NA
Text: dition, or care is provided to a child with a

Speaker: NA
Text: terminal condition, replace the current quali-

Speaker: NA
Text: fication provisions for care provided to a

Speaker: NA
Text: profoundly disabled child or two or more

Speaker: NA
Text: disabled children. Qualification for care pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided to a disabled adult and one or more

Speaker: NA
Text: children each with a disability or medical

Speaker: NA
Text: condition is a new qualification provision

Speaker: NA
Text: that is additional to the current qualification

Speaker: NA
Text: provision for care provided to a disabled

Speaker: NA
Text: adult and a dependent child of the disabled

Speaker: NA
Text: adult.

Speaker: NA
Text: This schedule repeals references to the

Speaker: NA
Text: terms ‘profoundly disabled child' and ‘dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: abled child' where the use of the terms are

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with carer payment from the So-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial Security Act. These terms are replaced

Speaker: NA
Text: with terminology related to the new qualifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation provisions inserted by the improved

Speaker: NA
Text: support for carers bill. The amendments con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained in this schedule ensure that provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: contained in the Social Security Act, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: the care receiver's income and assets tests,

Speaker: NA
Text: will apply to a person who makes a claim for

Speaker: NA
Text: carer payment after the commencement of

Speaker: NA
Text: the improved support for carers bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendments are also made to special

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit provisions to ensure that the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: proved qualification criteria for carer pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is reflected in the relief from the

Speaker: NA
Text: ity test that is applied to people who are not

Speaker: NA
Text: residentially qualified for carer payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: This schedule also makes amendments so

Speaker: NA
Text: that a person who is qualified for carer pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for care provided on a short-term or

Speaker: NA
Text: episodic basis is not qualified for a pensioner

Speaker: NA
Text: concession card but is qualified for a health-

Speaker: NA
Text: care card. Finally, the provisions that relate

Speaker: NA
Text: to who can be the principal beneficiary of a

Speaker: NA
Text: special disability trust are amended in line

Speaker: NA
Text: with the improved qualification criteria for

Speaker: NA
Text: carer payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Rudd Labor government is committed

Speaker: NA
Text: to improving significantly the level of assis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance for carers of children with disability or

Speaker: NA
Text: severe medical conditions. This bill delivers

Speaker: NA
Text: on that commitment. The changes in this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: are the latest in a series of recent support

Speaker: NA
Text: initiatives that have been extended to carers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The 2008 one-off payment legislation deliv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ered $1,000 to carer payment recipients and

Speaker: NA
Text: certain other pensioners with a caring role,

Speaker: NA
Text: and carer allowance recipients were, gener-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally, paid some $600 for each person cared

Speaker: NA
Text: for. Then the Economic Security Strategy

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation of late 2008 provided some

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,400 to carer payment recipients and, gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: erally, $1,000 to carer allowance recipients

Speaker: NA
Text: for each person cared for. These new budget

Speaker: NA
Text: measures are part of an $822 million package

Speaker: NA
Text: from the 2008 budget to support and recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nise carers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments will deliver a new, fairer

Speaker: NA
Text: set of qualification criteria for carer payment

Speaker: NA
Text: paid in respect of a child based on the level

Speaker: NA
Text: of care required rather than the rigid medical

Speaker: NA
Text: criteria currently used to assess qualification

Speaker: NA
Text: for the payment. Estimates are that some

Speaker: NA
Text: 19,000 more carers will have access to carer

Speaker: NA
Text: payment from 1 July 2009.

Speaker: NA
Text: As at January 2009 there were 2,795 carer

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance recipients and 941 carer payment

Speaker: NA
Text: recipients in my electorate of Flynn. The

Speaker: NA
Text: 2006 census recorded for my electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: activFlynn 4,562 people in need of assistance.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the number of people with a profound

Speaker: NA
Text: or severe disability. People with a profound

Speaker: NA
Text: or severe disability are defined as needing

Speaker: NA
Text: help or assistance in one or more of the three

Speaker: NA
Text: core activity areas of self-care, mobility and

Speaker: NA
Text: communication. The 2006 census also re-

Speaker: NA
Text: corded over 9,000 people in my electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Flynn who in the two weeks prior to census

Speaker: NA
Text: night spent time providing unpaid care, help

Speaker: NA
Text: or assistance to family members or others

Speaker: NA
Text: because of a disability, a long-term illness

Speaker: NA
Text: problems relating to old age.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the father of a son with a disability

Speaker: NA
Text: who cannot live without a life-sustaining

Speaker: NA
Text: medication I congratulate these wonderful

Speaker: NA
Text: people for their efforts. I sincerely hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation goes a long way to rewarding

Speaker: NA
Text: them for their efforts. I commend this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: wholeheartedly, from the bottom of my

Speaker: NA
Text: heart, to this House.

Speaker: Mrs MOYLAN
Text: Pearce) (6.58 pm)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Being able to address matters in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Social Security Legislation Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Improved Support for Carers) (Consequen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial and Transitional) Bill 2009 is a great

Speaker: NA
Text: portunity to speak on behalf of all those

Speaker: NA
Text: ple who undertake the important role of car-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing within our community. These changes to

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation will certainly impact on a great

Speaker: NA
Text: number of people who care for others and, in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular, for children who have special care

Speaker: NA
Text: needs.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill proposes to move from focusing

Speaker: NA
Text: on a child's actual medical condition to fo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cusing on care requirements, and this is con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sistent with the application of care require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments for qualification for carer allowance.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new Disability Care Load Assessment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Child) Determination, to be introduced by

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill, is intended to provide an objective

Speaker: NA
Text: tool for assessing the care requirements of

Speaker: NA
Text: care recipients. Assessing care requirements

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to children is complicated by the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that all children need a certain level of

Speaker: NA
Text: care appropriate to their age and level of

Speaker: NA
Text: turity. However, children with severe illness

Speaker: NA
Text: or those recovering from an accident may

Speaker: NA
Text: need considerable extra care.

Speaker: NA
Text: Despite the broadening in 2006 of eligibil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity for carer payments to carers of children

Speaker: NA
Text: with severe intellectual, psychiatric or be-

Speaker: NA
Text: havioural disabilities requiring constant care

Speaker: NA
Text: or supervision, it became apparent that, in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, few families qualified for the carer

Speaker: NA
Text: or payment. Although there were 113,549 car-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers receiving carer allowance to assist them

Speaker: NA
Text: with costs involved in caring for a child with

Speaker: NA
Text: a disability in June 2008, the narrow criteria

Speaker: NA
Text: meant that in practice only 7,000 children

Speaker: NA
Text: were being cared for by people receiving the

Speaker: NA
Text: carer payment, so there has been an obvious

Speaker: NA
Text: disconnect due to the tight eligibility criteria.

Speaker: NA
Text: A recent report following an inquiry by

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives Standing

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on Family, Community, Housing

Speaker: NA
Text: and Youth, of which I am deputy chair, high-

Speaker: NA
Text: lighted the great hardship encountered by

Speaker: NA
Text: many carers, who felt that they were not be-

Speaker: NA
Text: oping adequately supported in the caring role.

Speaker: NA
Text: peo- The Who cares …? report made it clear that

Speaker: NA
Text: there were common concerns amongst carers

Speaker: NA
Text: regardless of what kind of caring role they

Speaker: NA
Text: undertook. They were united by the chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenge they faced, and it became abundantly

Speaker: NA
Text: clear that insufficient attention was being

Speaker: NA
Text: paid to caring for the needs of carers. One of

Speaker: NA
Text: those needs is to simplify the maze of bu-

Speaker: NA
Text: reaucratic red tape and the hoops that carers

Speaker: NA
Text: must jump through to access support. No

Speaker: NA
Text: group could be more worthy of clearing a

Speaker: NA
Text: more certain path than those caring for chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren with a serious illness or disability.

Speaker: NA
Text: The care requirements for carer allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: are far less rigorous than the care require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for carer payment, and the care re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quirements for carer payment for a person

Speaker: NA
Text: caring for an adult are also less rigorous than

Speaker: NA
Text: the care requirements for caring for a child.

Speaker: NA
Text: ma- The differential was explained away by an

Speaker: NA
Text: assumption that all parents of young children

Speaker: NA
Text: engage in the caring role. However, the as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption did not take into account the addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional care responsibilities of those parents

Speaker: NA
Text: who care for children who have a disability

Speaker: NA
Text: or severe medical condition.

Speaker: NA
Text: In an endeavour to rectify this, in 2007 the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government introduced a carer ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: justment payment of up to $10,000. The

Speaker: NA
Text: carer adjustment payment was available

Speaker: NA
Text: where a family had a child aged up to six

Speaker: NA
Text: years who was diagnosed with a major dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ability due to an accidental injury or a severe

Speaker: NA
Text: illness. Carer adjustment payment was an

Speaker: NA
Text: interim payment available while the review

Speaker: NA
Text: of carer payment for carers of children with a

Speaker: NA
Text: medical condition was being conducted. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was to terminate on 30 June 2008, but fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing was provided in the 2008 budget for

Speaker: NA
Text: carer adjustment payment to continue to be

Speaker: NA
Text: available past that date.

Speaker: NA
Text: A review task force headed by Anthony

Speaker: NA
Text: Blunn was established in March 2007 to ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: amine the effectiveness of carer payment as a

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net for carers of children with pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: found disabilities or severe medical condi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. The terms of reference recognised that

Speaker: NA
Text: a carer payment is an income support pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for carers who, because of the demands

Speaker: NA
Text: of their caring role, are unable to support

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves through substantial participation

Speaker: NA
Text: in the workforce. The report of the review,

Speaker: NA
Text: released in early 2008, concluded that carer

Speaker: NA
Text: payment did not provide the intended safety

Speaker: NA
Text: net and recommended changes that are now

Speaker: NA
Text: the subject of this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of the 32 recommendations in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Blunn review were changes to eligibility re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quirements and a new assessment process to

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise the level of care required by the

Speaker: NA
Text: care receiver and provided by the carer; bet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter support for carers through improved ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice delivery, including case coordination

Speaker: NA
Text: and more accessible information about pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments; increased support for carers to par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticipate in the workforce through improved

Speaker: NA
Text: access to the Job Network, help with child-

Speaker: NA
Text: care arrangements and assistance for em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployers; and increased recognition for carers

Speaker: NA
Text: through carer recognition legislation and a

Speaker: NA
Text: national action plan for carers. It is interestability,

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to note that there have been many inquir-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies into and reviews of this issue over the

Speaker: NA
Text: years, and in every case they have come up

Speaker: NA
Text: with very similar conclusions.

Speaker: NA
Text: More recently, the bill was referred to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate Standing Committee on Community

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs. A submission was made to that

Speaker: NA
Text: committee by the Disability Services Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission of Western Australia, which was

Speaker: NA
Text: very positive about the benefits of the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes that we are discussing tonight and

Speaker: NA
Text: the way in which they would make for better

Speaker: NA
Text: support for carers. The Director-General of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Disability Services Commission of West-

Speaker: NA
Text: ern Australia, Dr Ron Chalmers, commented

Speaker: NA
Text: specifically on the bill's ability to ease the

Speaker: NA
Text: financial hardship for carers.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said earlier, few people are eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: for the carer payment in its current form. The

Speaker: NA
Text: changes outlined in this bill will ensure that a

Speaker: NA
Text: further 19,000 carers of children will now

Speaker: NA
Text: qualify for a carer payment. This is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome change indeed. The bill changes the

Speaker: NA
Text: way eligibility is assessed for carer payment

Speaker: NA
Text: for those caring for a child. Currently eligi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility is based, as I said, on a child's disabil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity or medical condition. The new methodol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ogy for assessing eligibility will be through

Speaker: NA
Text: the disallowable legislative instrument re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred to previously, called the Disability

Speaker: NA
Text: Care Load Assessment (Child) Determina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Instead of focusing solely on a child's

Speaker: NA
Text: medical condition, this takes into account the

Speaker: NA
Text: care needs and is consistent with the way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which applications are assessed for carer

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance. It is also pleasing to see for the

Speaker: NA
Text: first time access to carer payment for a carer

Speaker: NA
Text: caring for a child up to the age of 16 who has

Speaker: NA
Text: a short-term or episodic illness. This may

Speaker: NA
Text: include mental illness conditions or medical

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions such as cancer and the many other

Speaker: NA
Text: illnesses that often beset children. This new

Speaker: NA
Text: instrument for determining eligibility will

Speaker: NA
Text: provide a test for assessing the functional

Speaker: NA
Text: behaviour and special care needs of a

Speaker: NA
Text: child. That includes a section to be com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pleted by a treating health professional, a

Speaker: NA
Text: method of rating the child's care needs and

Speaker: NA
Text: method of providing a qualifying rating for

Speaker: NA
Text: the carer that takes account of the care

Speaker: NA
Text: vided by the carer and the assessment, again,

Speaker: NA
Text: of the health professional.

Speaker: NA
Text: Item 10 of this bill inserts new sections

Speaker: NA
Text: along with changes to existing sections. It

Speaker: NA
Text: sets out the criteria for qualification for a

Speaker: NA
Text: carer payment, and it includes some new

Speaker: NA
Text: items. Some of these are: a child with a se-

Speaker: NA
Text: vere disability or medical condition; two or

Speaker: NA
Text: more children, each with a disability or

Speaker: NA
Text: medical condition; a disabled adult and one

Speaker: NA
Text: or more children, each with a disability or

Speaker: NA
Text: medical condition; a child who has a termi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nal condition; exchange care of children;

Speaker: NA
Text: short-term, episodic care of children; extenderstand

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of short-term or episodic care of chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren; disabled adult or disabled adult and

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent child; hospitalisation; and some

Speaker: NA
Text: short-term circumstances. In order to qualify

Speaker: NA
Text: for these payments, the carer must provide

Speaker: NA
Text: constant care to a care receiver who has high

Speaker: NA
Text: care needs, provide that care in the home of

Speaker: NA
Text: the care receiver and be an Australian resi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent. This section has not changed. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: there are new sections that take into account

Speaker: NA
Text: the impact of caring on a person's ability

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake training, education, unpaid volun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary work or paid employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Limitations are currently in place on the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of hours a carer can work before

Speaker: NA
Text: they cease to provide constant care for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of receiving carer payment. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the toughest hurdles for carers is

Speaker: NA
Text: need to make a choice between continuing to

Speaker: NA
Text: work in the paid workforce and the need to

Speaker: NA
Text: give full-time care. So often, the care

Speaker: NA
Text: are such that continuing to work in the paid

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce, even on a part-time basis, is

Speaker: NA
Text: ply not a choice at all. And the limited op-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions for carers to participate in the paid

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce are further exacerbated by the

Speaker: NA
Text: severe shortage of places in day-care facilithen

Speaker: NA
Text: ties or carers who can come into the home to

Speaker: NA
Text: a relieve the principal carer. These are issues

Speaker: NA
Text: that I think need further airing and further

Speaker: NA
Text: procommunity discussion. Financial hardship is

Speaker: NA
Text: a major ongoing concern for many carers and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Who cares …? report actually recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mends a significant increase in the base rate

Speaker: NA
Text: of carer payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have also asked that the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: consider easing the tax burden on carers. The

Speaker: NA
Text: financial support received by carers can be

Speaker: NA
Text: quickly consumed by specialist medical ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices, medication and/or equipment required

Speaker: NA
Text: by those they care for-for example, buying

Speaker: NA
Text: a wheelchair, adapting a house and the myr-

Speaker: NA
Text: iad other additional costs that carers must

Speaker: NA
Text: fund. They soon add up, and it is easy to un-

Speaker: NA
Text: how rapidly financial stress can

Speaker: NA
Text: build up in families who find themselves in

Speaker: NA
Text: these circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: Financial isolation of carers is further ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: acerbated by employment limitations. Cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rently, there are significant disincentives for

Speaker: NA
Text: carers to earn supplementary income because

Speaker: NA
Text: any additional income reduces quite sharply

Speaker: NA
Text: the amount of income support they receive.

Speaker: NA
Text: Carers should be able to look to the future

Speaker: NA
Text: with at least some degree of certainty and

Speaker: NA
Text: to maintain a reasonable standard of living, and

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill does go one step closer to providing

Speaker: NA
Text: greater certainty and better support.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, the changes outlined in this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill will be very welcome to those caring for

Speaker: NA
Text: children with a disability or severe illness.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, the whole issue of how we sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: the port, value and treat our carers will need

Speaker: NA
Text: much more attention in the future. Many of

Speaker: NA
Text: the issues raised in the 2007 task force report

Speaker: NA
Text: needs commissioned by the Howard government

Speaker: NA
Text: are again canvassed in the latest report, Who

Speaker: NA
Text: simcares …? As I said in my speech to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House during the tabling of that report, if we

Speaker: NA
Text: are to answer, ‘We care'-that is, those of us

Speaker: NA
Text: in this place responsible for the legislation-

Speaker: NA
Text: we need to confront the issues facing

Speaker: NA
Text: carers head on and match the rhetoric with

Speaker: NA
Text: reality. It will need all the political will we

Speaker: NA
Text: can muster to ensure a better future for carers

Speaker: NA
Text: and those they care for, just as this legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion will assist many in the community who

Speaker: NA
Text: provide extra care to children. I welcome the

Speaker: NA
Text: measures that are outlined in this bill. The

Speaker: NA
Text: changes recommended in the task force re-

Speaker: NA
Text: port will make a difference to the lives of

Speaker: NA
Text: carers now and into the future; in the mean-

Speaker: NA
Text: time, these incremental changes are very

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome.

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Text: Jagajaga-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Families, Housing, Community Services and

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous Affairs) (7.11 pm)-in reply-

Speaker: NA
Text: First of all, I thank all the members for their

Speaker: NA
Text: contributions to this important debate. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security Legislation Amendment (Im-

Speaker: NA
Text: proved Support for Carers) Bill 2009 pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vides part of the government's response to

Speaker: NA
Text: the report of the Carer Payment (child) Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: view Taskforce, and gives effect to a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of measures aimed at improving assistance to

Speaker: NA
Text: carers from 1 July 2009. The improved sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port for carers bill will extend qualification

Speaker: NA
Text: for carer payment to around 19,000 more

Speaker: NA
Text: carers from 1 July 2009 by delivering a new,

Speaker: NA
Text: fairer set of qualification criteria for carer

Speaker: NA
Text: payment paid in respect of a child, based on

Speaker: NA
Text: the level of care required rather than the

Speaker: NA
Text: medical criteria currently used to assess

Speaker: NA
Text: qualification for the payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill, the Social Security Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Improved Support for Carers)

Speaker: NA
Text: (Consequential and Transitional) Bill 2009,

Speaker: NA
Text: makes amendments as a consequence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: measures contained in the improved support

Speaker: NA
Text: for carers bill. This companion bill makes

Speaker: NA
Text: minor amendments of a consequential and

Speaker: NA
Text: transitional nature. The amendments made

Speaker: NA
Text: by this bill include removal of references in

Speaker: NA
Text: the social security law that from 1 July 2009

Speaker: NA
Text: will be redundant, and replaces those refer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ences with new terms and references neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary for the proper administration of the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes introduced in the improved support

Speaker: NA
Text: for carers bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendments made by this bill will pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide that carers who qualify for carer pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment under the new qualification provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: will be able to take advantage of the 63 days,

Speaker: NA
Text: or the pro rata equivalent, for carers qualified

Speaker: NA
Text: on a short-term or episodic basis on which

Speaker: NA
Text: carers can temporarily cease to provide con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stant care and remain qualified for carer

Speaker: NA
Text: payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill provides that nominated visa

Speaker: NA
Text: holders who cannot qualify for carer pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment as they do not meet the residency re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quirement can be granted an exemption from

Speaker: NA
Text: the activity test in relation to special benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: if they are providing care to a child or chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren who meet the criteria contained in the

Speaker: NA
Text: new qualification provisions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill also amends the provisions that

Speaker: NA
Text: relate to the nomination of the principal

Speaker: NA
Text: beneficiary of a special disability trust under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Social Security Act 1991 or the Veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: Entitlements Act 1986 to reflect the changes

Speaker: NA
Text: made by the introduction of the improved

Speaker: NA
Text: qualification criteria for carer payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Lastly, the bill also provides for the back-

Speaker: NA
Text: dating of carer payment for people who qual-

Speaker: NA
Text: rigid ify for carer payment under one of the new

Speaker: NA
Text: qualification provisions. A person who

Speaker: NA
Text: makes an application before 1 October 2009

Speaker: NA
Text: will be able to have their carer payment

Speaker: NA
Text: backdated to the date they became qualified

Speaker: NA
Text: for carer payment. The earliest date at which

Speaker: NA
Text: they can become qualified is the date of im-

Speaker: NA
Text: plementation of the new qualification provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion, which is 1 July 2009. We look forward

Speaker: NA
Text: to these provisions becoming law to support

Speaker: NA
Text: carers doing a very important job in our

Speaker: NA
Text: community, caring for children who have

Speaker: NA
Text: very serious illnesses.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Message from the Governor-General rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ommending appropriation announced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Text: Jagajaga-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Families, Housing, Community Services and

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous Affairs) (7.15 pm)-by leave-I

Speaker: NA
Text: move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: SOCIAL SECURITY AND OTHER

Speaker: NA
Text: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: (AUSTRALIAN APPRENTICES)

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion

Speaker: NA
Text: by Ms Gillard:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Text: Boothby) (7.16

Speaker: NA
Text: pm)-I will not detain the House long in

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking to the Social Security and Other

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation Amendment (Australian Appren-

Speaker: NA
Text: tices) Bill 2009. This bill seeks to exempt

Speaker: NA
Text: incentives paid to apprentices from treatment

Speaker: NA
Text: as assessable income for taxation, social se-

Speaker: NA
Text: curity and veterans affairs purposes. These

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments will ensure that apprentices

Speaker: NA
Text: retain the entire amount of the financial in-

Speaker: NA
Text: centives paid to them. This will bring these

Speaker: NA
Text: new payments into line with the tax treat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment afforded to previous incentives. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: sensible measure that the opposition support.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first of these payments is the Skills

Speaker: NA
Text: for Sustainability for Australian Apprentices.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a pilot program aimed at encouraging

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices to undertake sustainability re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lated training, by granting a payment of

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,000 on completion of a required level of

Speaker: NA
Text: training. Discussions about sustainability

Speaker: NA
Text: related training have been around in this

Speaker: NA
Text: space for some time. We welcome this pilot

Speaker: NA
Text: program and we will be interested to see how

Speaker: NA
Text: it develops.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second payment is a rebadged pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment called the Tools for Your Trade incen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive. In fact, it is not even rebadged, because

Speaker: NA
Text: the old incentive was also called Tools for

Speaker: NA
Text: Your Trade. This measure will combine three

Speaker: NA
Text: existing incentives into one. Whilst the op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position will be supporting the bill, we do

Speaker: NA
Text: have a couple of issues here. First of all, the

Speaker: NA
Text: new incentive is not set to be payable until 1

Speaker: NA
Text: January 2010, and there is an issue for ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: prentices and trainees who commence be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween 12 May 2009-that is, budget day-

Speaker: NA
Text: and 1 January 2010. There is a real question

Speaker: NA
Text: as to whether those people will be eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: BILL 2009 for the Tools for Your Trade incentive or

Speaker: NA
Text: whether they will fall through the gap in the

Speaker: NA
Text: merging of these three programs. So we do

Speaker: NA
Text: have an issue in that, in moving from the old

Speaker: NA
Text: Tools for Your Trade to a newer, simplified

Speaker: NA
Text: incentive, a cohort of apprentices will miss

Speaker: NA
Text: out.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second issue is that a detailed exami-

Speaker: NA
Text: nation of the budget papers reveals a pea and

Speaker: NA
Text: thimble trick in the incentives being paid to

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices. Incredibly, at a time when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy needs to support em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployers, apprentices and people staying in

Speaker: NA
Text: their apprenticeships, the Rudd government

Speaker: NA
Text: is taking a net $197 million out of the pock-

Speaker: NA
Text: ets of apprentices. This is classic sleight of

Speaker: NA
Text: hand: a number of things are going. The big-

Speaker: NA
Text: gest one is the apprenticeship training fee

Speaker: NA
Text: voucher. Labor had a policy to fund $800 for

Speaker: NA
Text: out-of-pocket payments, which they an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced in December 2006. They have not

Speaker: NA
Text: stuck by that, and in fact they have abolished

Speaker: NA
Text: the apprenticeship training fee voucher,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was introduced in the 2007 budget. In

Speaker: NA
Text: their 2007 election policy document Skilling

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia for the future the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: promised that all subsidies and payments to

Speaker: NA
Text: employers and apprentices would be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained. When you look at the fine print in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget, you can see that this is not extra

Speaker: NA
Text: money for apprentices. In the middle of what

Speaker: NA
Text: is leading to $188 billion in net debt and

Speaker: NA
Text: $315 billion in gross debt you can see that

Speaker: NA
Text: they have taken $197 million out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: pockets of apprentices.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we have a look at the latest figures

Speaker: NA
Text: from the NCVER on apprenticeships and

Speaker: NA
Text: trainees-and bear in mind that these figures

Speaker: NA
Text: are six months behind-we see that between

Speaker: NA
Text: the March 2008 quarter and the December

Speaker: NA
Text: 2008 quarter apprenticeship commencements

Speaker: NA
Text: in traditional trades fell by 10 per cent. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is really before a lot of the impact came from

Speaker: NA
Text: the slowdown in the economy. As we have

Speaker: NA
Text: heard, at the same time that we are seeing

Speaker: NA
Text: commencements falling the Rudd Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government has abolished the apprenticeship

Speaker: NA
Text: training fee vouchers, which provided up to

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,000 to apprentices to help pay for their

Speaker: NA
Text: training. As I said, apprentices who com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mence after 12 May 2009 will not have ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess to the Tools for Your Trade funding be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause this has been put on hold until 1 Janu-

Speaker: NA
Text: The opposition have been vocal in their

Speaker: NA
Text: support for small business and apprentices

Speaker: NA
Text: during this economic downturn. As one ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ample of this, during the leader of the oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition's budget reply, we put up a proposal to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring forward the incentives for employers

Speaker: NA
Text: for traditional trades into the first two years

Speaker: NA
Text: of the apprenticeship. As the OECD noted in

Speaker: NA
Text: its review of vocational education and train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in Australia and policy relating to it, most

Speaker: NA
Text: of the incentives for employers are actually

Speaker: NA
Text: back-ended towards the end of an appren-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticeship. We believe that it makes sense to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring them forward to a time in those first

Speaker: NA
Text: couple of years when the apprentice is not as

Speaker: NA
Text: productive and when the cost of hiring them

Speaker: NA
Text: is something that all businesses will take into

Speaker: NA
Text: account. Bringing forward those incentives

Speaker: NA
Text: for employers will also help to boost cash

Speaker: NA
Text: flows at a time when employers need this

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance most. The bill is a modest pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal designed to help employers retain their

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices and take on new apprentices,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially apprentices whose employment is

Speaker: NA
Text: in jeopardy. It provides a very good example

Speaker: NA
Text: of how a modest, targeted proposal can be

Speaker: NA
Text: more effective than massive waves of ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: travagant cash splash-the $22 billion in

Speaker: NA
Text: cash splash, the $42 billion in economic

Speaker: NA
Text: stimulus and other examples.

Speaker: NA
Text: The opposition will be supporting this leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: islation. We are disappointed that the Rudd

Speaker: NA
Text: government have taken $197 million from

Speaker: NA
Text: the pockets of apprentices. We are also dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed that they were not able to time it a

Speaker: NA
Text: bit better. It seems that apprentices who

Speaker: NA
Text: commence between 12 May 2009 and 1

Speaker: NA
Text: January 2010 will miss out on the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's Tools for Your Trade incentive, but

Speaker: NA
Text: we do support exempting these new incen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives as assessable income for taxation.

Speaker: Mr HAYES
Text: Werriwa) (7.24 pm)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: government is unapologetic when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: investing in nation building and investing in

Speaker: NA
Text: education and training. An investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: nation building through what we are doing in

Speaker: NA
Text: the development of infrastructure is just as

Speaker: NA
Text: important as what we are doing not only in

Speaker: NA
Text: the development of our skills now but also in

Speaker: NA
Text: our requirements for the future. Therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Social Security and Other Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Australian Apprentices) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2009 takes certain very positive steps in rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to apprentices, particularly incentives

Speaker: NA
Text: for apprentices to remain in their apprentice-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships through to completion with a view to

Speaker: NA
Text: plying their trade productively and compre-

Speaker: NA
Text: hensively in our communities into the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: We on this side of the House are commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ted to supporting jobs. No-one could chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenge us on that, despite the fact that people

Speaker: NA
Text: on the other side of the House want to make

Speaker: NA
Text: mild protestations when it comes to our

Speaker: NA
Text: spending on targeting jobs. But, when it

Speaker: NA
Text: came down to it, I also saw the rush of peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple from the other side who wanted to get

Speaker: NA
Text: their faces on the camera in association with

Speaker: NA
Text: our investment in schools or what we are

Speaker: NA
Text: doing with social housing. The Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Housing, Ms Plibersek, who is at the table at

Speaker: NA
Text: the moment, accompanied me in my own

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate, where we are doing significant

Speaker: NA
Text: things with housing. As a matter of fact, in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate, which has a very high propor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of social housing, over $16 million has

Speaker: NA
Text: been allocated not to the construction of new

Speaker: NA
Text: premises but to the refurbishment of existing

Speaker: NA
Text: stock.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the really decent things occurring

Speaker: NA
Text: out there at this stage is the partnerships

Speaker: NA
Text: are emerging. In a recent program targeted at

Speaker: NA
Text: Macquarie Fields, one of the contractors that

Speaker: NA
Text: won social housing contracts is involved in a

Speaker: NA
Text: partnership to train people. Around $154,000

Speaker: NA
Text: is going to go towards helping kids from

Speaker: NA
Text: challenged backgrounds to become involved

Speaker: NA
Text: with working in the construction industry

Speaker: NA
Text: and to ascertain whether they want to stay

Speaker: NA
Text: there, with a view to leading them into trade

Speaker: NA
Text: apprenticeships in the building and construc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion area. That is a wonderful thing to do. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is targeted at a group that may be at risk of

Speaker: NA
Text: falling through the cracks. This is something

Speaker: NA
Text: that this government are doing. Whilst we

Speaker: NA
Text: are investing in creating jobs, we are not tak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing our eye off the ball when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: looking into the future and looking at the

Speaker: NA
Text: skills that we can develop in all these kids

Speaker: NA
Text: into the future. That is why this bill is importraining

Speaker: NA
Text: tant. As I said at the outset, this is about

Speaker: NA
Text: taining young people primarily when they

Speaker: NA
Text: embark on an apprenticeship. Far too often,

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunately, people start these things and

Speaker: NA
Text: then let them go. There are many reasons for

Speaker: NA
Text: that, I guess, but one of the things that this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill addresses is to put the incentive in there

Speaker: NA
Text: for targeted young people to complete their

Speaker: NA
Text: training and to fulfil the terms of their ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: prenticeships.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government are investing in a range

Speaker: NA
Text: of things. We are certainly investing heavily

Speaker: NA
Text: in roads in my electorate. I know that others

Speaker: NA
Text: are heavily committed to ports and rail, but

Speaker: NA
Text: what we are doing through the school mod-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernisation project, what we are doing in our

Speaker: NA
Text: local hospital and what we are doing in so-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial housing are very major investments. In

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaking these investments, we are also

Speaker: NA
Text: investing in the skills development of our

Speaker: NA
Text: people. From the opposition's perspective,

Speaker: NA
Text: after their 12 years in government it all got a

Speaker: NA
Text: bit hard to some extent for them. Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, you might recall that when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government came to power they

Speaker: NA
Text: that took money out of the education system. We

Speaker: NA
Text: found ourselves, after having about a billion

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars stripped out of education and while it

Speaker: NA
Text: was raining bars of gold, as the saying goes,

Speaker: NA
Text: in a position where we did not have the

Speaker: NA
Text: tradespeople to work in our mines, to move

Speaker: NA
Text: our coal and to export our iron ore.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a matter of fact, one of my young sons

Speaker: NA
Text: found himself working for a period of time

Speaker: NA
Text: in Blackwater and then in Port Hedland-

Speaker: NA
Text: making significant amounts of money I

Speaker: NA
Text: might add, in the process. But one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: problems there was that people were re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired to come in on short-term overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: visas to provide the skills necessary for the

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity of the industries. That is an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dictment of the planning that took place. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: an indictment of those responsible, who al-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowed this to occur by not overseeing the

Speaker: NA
Text: of our young people to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: rewe had an adequate supply of apprentices

Speaker: NA
Text: moving through the system and therefore we

Speaker: NA
Text: had the tradespeople with the necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: skills necessary for the productivity those

Speaker: NA
Text: industries provide which contribute to the

Speaker: NA
Text: growth of this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: To that end, the Deputy Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: has only recently indicated that in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: the tendering processes for the federal gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment and its infrastructure projects, pref-

Speaker: NA
Text: erence is being given to businesses that can

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrate a commitment to training and

Speaker: NA
Text: employment of apprentices and trainees. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated a little while earlier in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: social housing, that is precisely what the

Speaker: NA
Text: principal contractor is doing for those pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: jects in my electorate of Werriwa, particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly in areas of Claymore, Minto and Mac-

Speaker: NA
Text: quarie Fields. Young people are being trained

Speaker: NA
Text: in those areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a matter of fact, it was very heartening

Speaker: NA
Text: the other day for me to be with the head of

Speaker: NA
Text: the South West Sydney Institute of TAFE,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Barry Peddle, who came to see me about

Speaker: NA
Text: the $10 million that the federal government

Speaker: NA
Text: has now allocated for a new building skills

Speaker: NA
Text: centre in Ingleburn. This new centre will be

Speaker: NA
Text: used for training young people in building

Speaker: NA
Text: and construction. Part of the reason for my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate being the recipient of that fund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing-hopefully it had something to do with

Speaker: NA
Text: some fruitful lobbying-was that where I

Speaker: NA
Text: live is the growth centre for Sydney. The

Speaker: NA
Text: south-west is where the next wave of devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opment will occur.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the things that follow from that

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a boom in housing and construction

Speaker: NA
Text: to facilitate the development. At the moment

Speaker: NA
Text: we do not have the number of tradespeople

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary to facilitate that. That is what this

Speaker: NA
Text: investment of $10 million is designed to do.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is to help provide those apprentices in the

Speaker: NA
Text: industries necessary to accommodate the

Speaker: NA
Text: south-west growth centre of Sydney. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: something that we, in my neck of the woods,

Speaker: NA
Text: have a vested interest in. It will certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: give young people the opportunity to pursue

Speaker: NA
Text: their desires, talents and skills in that

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: NA
Text: To some extent I will continue my speech

Speaker: NA
Text: with my personal involvement in apprentice-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships. Whilst my daughter went on to univer-

Speaker: NA
Text: sity and became a high school teacher, both

Speaker: NA
Text: my sons decided that university was not for

Speaker: NA
Text: them. One of the boys became a builder-

Speaker: NA
Text: carpenter and the other boy-after an ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: prenticeship through the National Electrical

Speaker: NA
Text: the Contractors Association, a group training

Speaker: NA
Text: body-became an electrician. That has

Speaker: NA
Text: opened up a whole range of opportunities for

Speaker: NA
Text: them over the years. To some extent one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the boys has moved in and out of his calling,

Speaker: NA
Text: but because he successfully completed an

Speaker: NA
Text: apprenticeship he always had something to

Speaker: NA
Text: fall back on. As the boys describe it, they go

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘back on tools'. That is pretty helpful.

Speaker: NA
Text: My other son, the electrician, has been

Speaker: NA
Text: around. He is the fella who has been to Port

Speaker: NA
Text: Hedland and Blackwater and worked in the

Speaker: NA
Text: mines and done all those things. He has

Speaker: NA
Text: come back and, because of the stimulus

Speaker: NA
Text: package, he is now doing work locally for

Speaker: NA
Text: the first time ever, as he has put it to me. He

Speaker: NA
Text: is working locally refurbishing Housing

Speaker: NA
Text: NSW stock in our local area. He set up his

Speaker: NA
Text: own little private company and he is out

Speaker: NA
Text: there subbing and doing all those sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: things. So, good luck to them!

Speaker: NA
Text: But it is not just my boys-I am talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about my direct experience-I know their

Speaker: NA
Text: friends are out there doing similar things. As

Speaker: NA
Text: a matter of fact, about nine weeks ago I held

Speaker: NA
Text: a forum in my electorate. I invited all the

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses, through the chambers of com-

Speaker: NA
Text: merce et cetera to find those who had an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terest in picking up work that could possibly

Speaker: NA
Text: flow from the stimulus package targeted at

Speaker: NA
Text: education-the schools projects-and social

Speaker: NA
Text: housing. In my electorate, which is in outer-

Speaker: NA
Text: metropolitan Sydney, I can report to you that

Speaker: NA
Text: we had 220 people turn up from local busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: direcnesses, wanting to know how they could ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: press their interest in being involved in these

Speaker: NA
Text: matters. One of the key things I discovered

Speaker: NA
Text: when listening to a number of the people

Speaker: NA
Text: there was that they wanted some indication

Speaker: NA
Text: of how the tendering process would operate.

Speaker: NA
Text: They wanted to know what skills they would

Speaker: NA
Text: need. A few of them wanted to know how

Speaker: NA
Text: many apprentices they would need to put on.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another one wanted to know where the ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: prentices would undertake that training, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause they wanted the apprentices working at

Speaker: NA
Text: the moment. They were pretty heartened to

Speaker: NA
Text: hear about the establishment of the new

Speaker: NA
Text: TAFE facility in Ingleburn. It will target,

Speaker: NA
Text: ostensibly, the building and construction

Speaker: NA
Text: trades. That is certainly going to help the

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers of young people coming into this

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. It was important for those people

Speaker: NA
Text: who attended my forum to learn, with some

Speaker: NA
Text: surety, about the numbers of jobs that are

Speaker: NA
Text: likely to be created.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that an electorate office out there

Speaker: NA
Text: should not become an employment facility

Speaker: NA
Text: but my office has been inundated with peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple ringing up and wanting to know how to

Speaker: NA
Text: get their names on the list and how to ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: press an interest in jobs. We refer them to

Speaker: NA
Text: Housing NSW and to the New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Education and Training.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is now an endless stream of people

Speaker: NA
Text: who are trying to get involved-from estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished companies through to people such as

Speaker: NA
Text: my young fella who wants to set up his own

Speaker: NA
Text: business so that he can participate in the jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: created by this round of stimulus package

Speaker: NA
Text: activity. And that sort of thing is occurring,

Speaker: NA
Text: would say, in every electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another of our very successful businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: in Ingleburn is Broens engineering. I knew

Speaker: NA
Text: Carlos Broens when he started this company

Speaker: NA
Text: as a toolmaker. He and his brother were the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole business. It now employs around 300

Speaker: NA
Text: people. In outer metropolitan Sydney, that is

Speaker: NA
Text: a large employer. Last year, he took on 34

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices. He actually has a TAFE facility

Speaker: NA
Text: on his site now so that young apprentices can

Speaker: NA
Text: be trained with the equipment the business

Speaker: NA
Text: uses. He has been preselected, I understand,

Speaker: NA
Text: for contracts for Boeing, and he is doing

Speaker: NA
Text: work for BMW, GMH and Mercedes. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: a success story of our area. From the back

Speaker: NA
Text: blocks of Sydney, he is now exporting to

Speaker: NA
Text: world markets. His site certainly has signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant engineering credibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: What Carlos always maintains, and what

Speaker: NA
Text: distinguishes his approach, is his commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to training. He spearheaded Austool, a

Speaker: NA
Text: body which attracted some government

Speaker: NA
Text: funds, with a view to targeting skills devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opment in the toolmaking sector. Unfortu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nately, that scheme did not go all that well,

Speaker: NA
Text: and he became discouraged with the process.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was when he started TAFE visiting his

Speaker: NA
Text: premises-they are now working from his

Speaker: NA
Text: premises. He has been instrumental in TAFE

Speaker: NA
Text: reinjecting itself in Ingleburn-which is a

Speaker: NA
Text: growing industrial estate of the south-west of

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney-with a view to targeting young ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: prentices there and providing opportunities

Speaker: NA
Text: for employers. Young people are able to be

Speaker: NA
Text: trained locally as opposed to having to be

Speaker: NA
Text: carted off to the various TAFE colleges de-

Speaker: NA
Text: pending on their specialties. We are now see-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing opportunities for companies to work in

Speaker: NA
Text: conjunction, hand in hand, with some of

Speaker: NA
Text: these skills providers. The use that is now

Speaker: NA
Text: being made of TAFE, and TAFE facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: working in partnership with the individual to

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver these trade developments, is now

Speaker: NA
Text: paying significant dividends throughout the

Speaker: NA
Text: I industrial areas of my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill will do a number of things which

Speaker: NA
Text: will support young people in their trades. It

Speaker: NA
Text: will certainly support retention of appren-

Speaker: NA
Text: tices. The bill will amend the Income Tax

Speaker: NA
Text: Assessment Act 1997, the Social Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1986 to exempt the value of payments made

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Skills for Sustainability for Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian Apprentices and Tools For Your Trade,

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Australian Apprenticeships Incen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives Program, from treatment as assessable

Speaker: NA
Text: income for income tax purposes and from the

Speaker: NA
Text: income test for benefits under social security

Speaker: NA
Text: and veterans' affairs legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Skills for Sustainability for Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Apprentices is a pilot program within the

Speaker: NA
Text: Skills for the Carbon Challenge initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: This initiative came out of the 2020 Summit

Speaker: NA
Text: and aims to accelerate the response to cli-

Speaker: NA
Text: mate change by industry and the tertiary

Speaker: NA
Text: education sector. To encourage apprentice-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships to undertake sustainability related

Speaker: NA
Text: training, the payment of $1,000 will be pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided to eligible apprentices who have suc-
