Speaker: NA
Text: cessfully completed the required level of

Speaker: NA
Text: training to provide them with skills in sus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainability and environmentally sustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: work practices.

Speaker: NA
Text: The enhanced Tools For Your Trade pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment combines and extends three existing

Speaker: NA
Text: support initiatives-the Tools For Your Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: voucher, the apprenticeship wage top-up and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth trade learning scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship-in the one new Tools For Your Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: payment under the Australian Apprentice-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships Incentives Program. The new payment

Speaker: NA
Text: comprises five separate cash payments total-

Speaker: NA
Text: ling $3,800 paid over the life of the appren-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticeship to apprentices in selected trade oc-

Speaker: NA
Text: cupations, agricultural occupations and, if in

Speaker: NA
Text: rural and regional locations, horticultural

Speaker: NA
Text: occupations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new arrangements, importantly, re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce the administrative burden for employers

Speaker: NA
Text: of apprentices, broaden eligibility criteria,

Speaker: NA
Text: benefiting more apprentices, and ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices in skills shortage trades are

Speaker: NA
Text: gible for the same level of government sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port regardless of age and employer size. The

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments in the bill will ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: ble apprentices receive the full benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: payments made under the two new programs

Speaker: NA
Text: and are consistent with the tax treatment of

Speaker: NA
Text: previous programs that have paid personal

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits to apprentices.

Speaker: NA
Text: I welcome these measures as they apply

Speaker: NA
Text: through my electorate. I will always play a

Speaker: NA
Text: role in advocating proper and sustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: trade based training. It is something that we

Speaker: NA
Text: as a nation have prided ourselves on in the

Speaker: NA
Text: past and it is something that over the past 10

Speaker: NA
Text: or 12 years we have allowed to escape. If we

Speaker: NA
Text: are serious about building our economy for

Speaker: NA
Text: the future, this is something we need to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: our eye on. I welcome this. I think it is good

Speaker: NA
Text: for young people. It is a great measure to

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage the retention of apprentices and it

Speaker: NA
Text: is very good for businesses such as Broens

Speaker: NA
Text: engineering.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is what we can do as a nation. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: important that we give suitable attention to

Speaker: NA
Text: trade based training and trade development.

Speaker: NA
Text: It worked very effectively for my young fel-

Speaker: NA
Text: las. As I said, they have all been able to go

Speaker: NA
Text: on and do a range of different jobs, but at

Speaker: NA
Text: some stage when it suits them they return the

Speaker: NA
Text: tools. These are skills that they will maintain

Speaker: NA
Text: for life. Their skills passport will enable

Speaker: NA
Text: them to participate in building our economy

Speaker: NA
Text: in the future.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: O'Connor) (7.44 pm)-

Speaker: NA
Text: On the face of it, the Social Security and

Speaker: NA
Text: Other Legislation Amendment (Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Apprentices) Bill 2009 is of a fairly minor

Speaker: NA
Text: nature but is of an administrative type and

Speaker: NA
Text: consequently brings together certain pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. As frequently occurs over time, gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernments make a variety of initiatives and it

Speaker: NA
Text: becomes obvious that they should be amal-

Speaker: NA
Text: gamated into a single grant or whatever. It

Speaker: NA
Text: eli- also, I am pleased to say, makes sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: such grants as are given in these circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances are not subject to the income tax that

Speaker: NA
Text: eligi- would otherwise apply to the income of

Speaker: NA
Text: of the young people, apprentices and others. I

Speaker: NA
Text: should not use the words ‘young people'. An

Speaker: NA
Text: apprenticeship now is not only a project for

Speaker: NA
Text: the young; it is a project for mature persons

Speaker: NA
Text: who seek to improve themselves from hav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing basic employment skills in areas of de-

Speaker: NA
Text: clining employment. I think all congratula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions are due to those who do make that

Speaker: NA
Text: choice, because it is quite difficult.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nevertheless, whilst it is just a trial pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram, the Skills for Sustainability for Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian Apprentices is of great interest to me. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think it is a great idea. I think it is a pity

Speaker: NA
Text: in the second reading speech, the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: did not bother to tell us where these sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities might exist in the future. What

Speaker: NA
Text: you have to be to participate in the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's program of carbon pollution reduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is of course a screen jockey. You have to

Speaker: NA
Text: be an employee of a hedge fund or a bank, or

Speaker: NA
Text: someone else who is going to try and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: establish your respectability, having de-

Speaker: NA
Text: stroyed the world economy on your last at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tempt. And you are going to be given the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to gamble on certificates to pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lute. I thought that was a pretty bad place to

Speaker: NA
Text: start in addressing a problem that appears to

Speaker: NA
Text: be universal, throughout the globe, where

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia could be a contributor in providing

Speaker: NA
Text: the world with the technology that might

Speaker: NA
Text: work. The technology that the world has

Speaker: NA
Text: provided to date will not work in any signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant fashion, be it wind generation, solar

Speaker: NA
Text: power or any of those things, simply because

Speaker: NA
Text: they lack the substance or, if you like, the

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity to work.

Speaker: NA
Text: But there are opportunities within the pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent technology, and one might wonder if the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister, in coming up with this particular

Speaker: NA
Text: program, might have thought it a good idea

Speaker: NA
Text: to have a special class in the management of

Speaker: NA
Text: high-voltage DC transmission systems.

Speaker: NA
Text: HVDC, as we know it, is most notable, but

Speaker: NA
Text: not recognised by many, as the means of

Speaker: NA
Text: transmitting electricity across Bass Strait. It

Speaker: NA
Text: had to be chosen on that occasion simply

Speaker: NA
Text: because you could not have a series of posts

Speaker: NA
Text: along the way with a transformer, which is a

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary energy-consuming component of

Speaker: NA
Text: high-voltage AC transmission, on which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian system relies with only a couple

Speaker: NA
Text: of exceptions. And the great advantage of

Speaker: NA
Text: high-voltage DC transmission is that you can

Speaker: NA
Text: shift electrical energy over huge distances.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Chinese are presently building a

Speaker: NA
Text: 2,000-kilometre transmission line-being

Speaker: NA
Text: constructed, I might add, by people with

Speaker: NA
Text: that, whom I have significant contact in this arena

Speaker: NA
Text: because I believe I have to learn, as other

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentarians in this place do not. The

Speaker: NA
Text: fact is that ABB, as it is now known-it was

Speaker: NA
Text: once Asea Brown Boveri-is building that

Speaker: NA
Text: line for the Chinese. The Europeans are flat

Speaker: NA
Text: out utilising this technology because it saves

Speaker: NA
Text: emissions just by being in existence. It does

Speaker: NA
Text: not require a great deal of inventiveness. It

Speaker: NA
Text: does not require hundreds of billions of dol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lars, as might be required in proving up car-

Speaker: NA
Text: bon capture and sequestration, which I have

Speaker: NA
Text: never seen as a logical response to the prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem because it just says, ‘We'll make the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem go away'.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the utilisation of high-voltage DC

Speaker: NA
Text: transmission, however, you reduce the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of energy lost, particularly over long

Speaker: NA
Text: distances. And it can compete with gas pipe-

Speaker: NA
Text: lines. Gas pipelines are very energy ineffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cient. The one that delivers gas from the Pil-

Speaker: NA
Text: bara to the City of Perth uses in its compres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sors the power equivalent to one of the coal-

Speaker: NA
Text: fired power stations that service the state-

Speaker: NA
Text: 250 megawatts. Yet, if the electricity that is

Speaker: NA
Text: generated from that pipeline when it gets to

Speaker: NA
Text: Perth was in fact generated at the well-head

Speaker: NA
Text: end-on the beach, if you like, in the case of

Speaker: NA
Text: offshore gas reserves-and sent down on

Speaker: NA
Text: HVDC, you would lose significantly less

Speaker: NA
Text: energy and you would have consequent im-

Speaker: NA
Text: provement in emissions.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wonder how many apprentices are doing

Speaker: NA
Text: their time in that technology. It is a pity that

Speaker: NA
Text: there was not some sort of list in the explana-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory memorandum or somewhere else which

Speaker: NA
Text: tells us where this smart alec idea is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: work. There are huge opportunities in the

Speaker: NA
Text: reform of energy generation-and the evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence is all there. It is not new technology;

Speaker: NA
Text: we do not have to invent it, although we

Speaker: NA
Text: could leverage off, from a technological ba-

Speaker: NA
Text: sis, some of the generating opportunities that

Speaker: NA
Text: would follow an adequate HVDC system,

Speaker: NA
Text: which in my mind ought to be now under

Speaker: NA
Text: construction as the appropriate stimulus

Speaker: NA
Text: package instead of wasting money as is be-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing done at the moment on school facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: that are unnecessary in many cases, in build-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing passenger railways that will lose money

Speaker: NA
Text: forever and-I will get the minister at the

Speaker: NA
Text: table, the Minister for Housing, to put her

Speaker: NA
Text: head up when I say this-in public housing

Speaker: NA
Text: that will cost money for ever and ever there-

Speaker: NA
Text: after. I noted the other day that the Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian parliament has had to budget $8

Speaker: NA
Text: million simply to fix up the houses that have

Speaker: NA
Text: been trashed under their responsibility at the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the reality is that, if apprentices are

Speaker: NA
Text: going to be given $1,000, as this act pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vides, for the purpose of gaining skills in

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainability, I think it would be a good idea

Speaker: NA
Text: if the parliament gave it some privileges.

Speaker: NA
Text: But, as I said, this government has stepped

Speaker: NA
Text: out to build public housing, passenger rail-

Speaker: NA
Text: ways and of course spread a mere $24 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: in cash around, but if it had chosen to invest

Speaker: NA
Text: that sort of money in sustainable energy ini-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiatives that are available and would easily fit

Speaker: NA
Text: within those costs, they would not have this

Speaker: NA
Text: procession of industry groups coming along

Speaker: NA
Text: and saying, ‘Please don't drive us out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: country with an emissions trading scheme,'

Speaker: NA
Text: which at the end will give no guarantee of

Speaker: NA
Text: reducing emissions. It is in fact a process of

Speaker: NA
Text: selling certificates to pollute. The question

Speaker: NA
Text: to how much your business or your consum-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers can bear of that cost will decide what

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions might follow.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are talking about a good idea here,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is to get apprentices dealing in new

Speaker: NA
Text: technology. That might be hydrogen fuel cell

Speaker: NA
Text: technology, which would be a great opportu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity for young people. It is a technology that

Speaker: NA
Text: will happen, as will the plug-in electric car

Speaker: NA
Text: and the technology associated with lithium

Speaker: NA
Text: ion batteries and all other things that will be

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with that process. The reality is

Speaker: NA
Text: that what the government is doing, notwith-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing the offering of the minister for re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sources today-I had to watch him on televi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion because you are not allowed to make

Speaker: NA
Text: jokes in this place any more!-when he

Speaker: NA
Text: talked about this massive investment in sus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainability, is peanuts. The government can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not make a major contribution of less than

Speaker: NA
Text: $10 billion. An investment of that amount

Speaker: NA
Text: would be a starting point and it could deliver

Speaker: NA
Text: a 10 or 15 per cent long-term, permanent

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction in emissions without sending alu-

Speaker: NA
Text: minium smelters et cetera to the wall. Other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries, and particularly China, are taking

Speaker: NA
Text: this option. Their centralised bureaucratic

Speaker: NA
Text: structure will not lead to the sort of market

Speaker: NA
Text: solution that the Rudd government believes

Speaker: NA
Text: will drive Australian business to save the

Speaker: NA
Text: world. They are investing in renewables or

Speaker: NA
Text: non-emitting technology such as nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: power. They have 25 such projects on the

Speaker: NA
Text: drawing board or under construction as we

Speaker: NA
Text: speak. Even the Iranians, for whatever rea-

Speaker: NA
Text: son, are building a nuclear power station,

Speaker: NA
Text: presumably so that they can sell more oil!

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, with its tidal energy resource,

Speaker: NA
Text: has one of the biggest renewable energy re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sources in the world, according to the World

Speaker: NA
Text: Energy Council. A body associated with Ox-

Speaker: NA
Text: ford University can come out here and tell us

Speaker: NA
Text: what we have on a world table and you never

Speaker: NA
Text: hear a bleep from this government, which

Speaker: NA
Text: as says that it wants to go to Copenhagen and

Speaker: NA
Text: lead the world in a response to the issues of

Speaker: NA
Text: carbon emissions and climate change.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have two choices as a nation. I can tell

Speaker: NA
Text: you that we will be giving apprentices

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,000 to get sustainability skills, but if in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact the whole system is going to be driven

Speaker: NA
Text: by screen jockeys-apparently they will all

Speaker: NA
Text: live in Sydney, because New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: government ministers are salivating over the

Speaker: NA
Text: profits that will accrue to Sydney arising

Speaker: NA
Text: from an emissions trading scheme. If some-

Speaker: NA
Text: one takes a profit out of the trading concept,

Speaker: NA
Text: that is an extra cost that somebody else has

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay. Yet we are talking here today of what

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices might do. We will not have elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tric cars or hydrogen fuel cell cars, which in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact still require an electricity input to elecdifferent

Speaker: NA
Text: trolyse the water to produce hydrogen, unless

Speaker: NA
Text: we produce more electricity. So apprentices

Speaker: NA
Text: need to learn how better to produce renew-

Speaker: NA
Text: able electricity at the gigawatt level, as could

Speaker: NA
Text: occur in the Kimberleys. The technology

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with the conversions for high-

Speaker: NA
Text: voltage DC transmission-and these things

Speaker: NA
Text: only cost $250 million a pop-is the sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity that the minister should have

Speaker: NA
Text: talked about in his second reading speech.

Speaker: NA
Text: The speech should have referred to directing

Speaker: NA
Text: young people to these opportunities and giv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing them the opportunity to earn $1,000 or

Speaker: NA
Text: more.

Speaker: NA
Text: But of course those projects are not on the

Speaker: NA
Text: drawing board. There is no opportunity for

Speaker: NA
Text: young apprentices to learn about that be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause this government does not believe in it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government's ETS provides more oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunities for repairers of desktop computers,

Speaker: NA
Text: because that is what the scheme is all about.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not about creating opportunities in tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nology. And the lousy few hundred million

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars that the minister boasted about today

Speaker: NA
Text: will simply not deliver anything like that

Speaker: NA
Text: needed from government. If the money that

Speaker: NA
Text: was put into public housing was put into an

Speaker: NA
Text: initiative like that a lot of people would not

Speaker: NA
Text: need public housing because their jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: would not be at risk, as is patently obvious

Speaker: NA
Text: they will be when you start to jack up the

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive costs of local industries such as

Speaker: NA
Text: iron, steel and aluminium, where the work-

Speaker: NA
Text: force is often filled with loyal Labor votes-

Speaker: NA
Text: but that does not seem to worry this govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Maybe the intelligentsia will re-elect

Speaker: NA
Text: them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Concerning sustainability for apprentices

Speaker: NA
Text: learning, while there are no projects and

Speaker: NA
Text: while projects are not necessarily going to

Speaker: NA
Text: come from industry because they have been

Speaker: NA
Text: taxed to a point where they have no money

Speaker: NA
Text: left-and that is the theory behind ETS; you

Speaker: NA
Text: make things so costly that people will make

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure choices. They will have

Speaker: NA
Text: no money and, as things stand, they will in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact be competing with the government to

Speaker: NA
Text: borrow money. We touched on this in ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion time today but I did not think the Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer had much of an idea of what he was

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about and nor did the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: when quoting the interest rate spreads-you

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot borrow the money in Australia, so

Speaker: NA
Text: what is the point. Anyway, coming back to

Speaker: NA
Text: the issue, the Skills for Sustainability Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian apprentices grant is a sensible initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Outside some technical adjustments, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Skills for Sustainability Australian appren-

Speaker: NA
Text: tices grant is the thing that should be point-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the way for young people in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity but it is lacking in that it does

Speaker: NA
Text: not tell the kids what it happens to be.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said, at the moment the only proposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion before this parliament is a screen

Speaker: NA
Text: jockey's opportunity because that is what an

Speaker: NA
Text: ETS is. An ETS is a process of licensing

Speaker: NA
Text: people to pollute and trying to drive them

Speaker: NA
Text: into some sort of reduced emissions position

Speaker: NA
Text: by making it too expensive to stay where

Speaker: NA
Text: they are. But it ignores the option of leaving

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia completely or passing the cost on

Speaker: NA
Text: downstream, as can occur in electricity gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration where there is a captive consumer

Speaker: NA
Text: market. So what are the kids going to learn

Speaker: NA
Text: there? You should say to them, ‘Here are the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities.' One of the reasons for the

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of opportunities is that the government

Speaker: NA
Text: are not investing in saws or planing units or

Speaker: NA
Text: anything like that. Instead, they have taken

Speaker: NA
Text: all the basic investments of sustainability-

Speaker: NA
Text: none of them have a technological peak-

Speaker: NA
Text: when that same money could have been put

Speaker: NA
Text: into achieving up to a 40 per cent reduction

Speaker: NA
Text: in emissions trading for Australia and would

Speaker: NA
Text: have led the way for apprentices to have

Speaker: NA
Text: genuine sustainability skills.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: commend the former speaker for his contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bution to the debate. I too rise in support of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Social Security and Other Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Australian Apprentices) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2009. This bill is about a very minor

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment to various acts but it will make a

Speaker: NA
Text: huge difference for thousands of apprentices

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the country. Being an apprentice

Speaker: NA
Text: is not something that I have experienced in

Speaker: NA
Text: my varied careers. But I remember that,

Speaker: NA
Text: when I was in year 7, I basically decided that

Speaker: NA
Text: I wanted to become an apprentice butcher

Speaker: NA
Text: and leave school. That was not so much

Speaker: NA
Text: about a love of the butchering industry but

Speaker: NA
Text: more because the nun who taught me at the

Speaker: NA
Text: time terrified me. I thought that the best

Speaker: NA
Text: tion was to join my family's profession,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is the meat trade. My grandfather was

Speaker: NA
Text: a butcher and so were my father, my uncle

Speaker: NA
Text: and two of my brothers, so I thought that that

Speaker: NA
Text: was the way to go. As it turned out, I did not

Speaker: NA
Text: go that way. I know that there are a couple of

Speaker: NA
Text: meatworkers in the parliament and they

Speaker: NA
Text: make a contribution. I did not go down the

Speaker: NA
Text: route of an apprenticeship and instead ended

Speaker: NA
Text: up being a teacher and the like.

Speaker: NA
Text: Apprentices are a very important section

Speaker: NA
Text: of the community and one that we definitely

Speaker: NA
Text: need to look after as much as possible. The

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation before the House amends the In-

Speaker: NA
Text: come Tax Assessment Act 1997, the Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments Act 1986 to ensure that the Skills for

Speaker: NA
Text: Sustainability and Tools for Your Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: payments made to apprentices are not as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sessable income for tax purposes. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: quite significant legislation for apprentices.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is quite significant in the current economic

Speaker: NA
Text: climate that it got past Treasurer Swan as

Speaker: NA
Text: well, I guess. But he understands the benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: of looking after these skills and making sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are nurtured and developed, espe-

Speaker: NA
Text: cially in tough economic times. These legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lative changes will ensure that the appren-

Speaker: NA
Text: tices and the community get the full benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: of these two programs by them not being

Speaker: NA
Text: assessable income for tax purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are about 400,000 apprentices in

Speaker: NA
Text: training around the country. I will declare a

Speaker: NA
Text: possible conflict of interest here. My

Speaker: NA
Text: nephew, Joel Perrett, is an apprentice and

Speaker: NA
Text: possibly might benefit from this enhance-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I will not declare every single member

Speaker: NA
Text: of my family who has been an apprentice in

Speaker: NA
Text: the past, but for the sake of clarity and in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to be honest and respectable I will de-

Speaker: NA
Text: clare that possible conflict of interest-and

Speaker: NA
Text: so that Joel has the thrill of being named in

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament. He works in the building indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try, with cranes in particular. One of my

Speaker: NA
Text: op- other brothers works in the crane industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Obviously, they are particularly sensitive to

Speaker: NA
Text: the swings and roundabouts of the economic

Speaker: NA
Text: climate. They are based down on the Gold

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast and they are probably doing work in

Speaker: NA
Text: the electorate of the good member for Mon-

Speaker: NA
Text: crieff, where a lot of high-rise construction is

Speaker: NA
Text: taking place. So I declare that possible con-

Speaker: NA
Text: flict of interest.

Speaker: NA
Text: These apprentices, these men and

Speaker: NA
Text: women-and I was going to say young men

Speaker: NA
Text: and women, but I know that that is not nec-

Speaker: NA
Text: essarily the case anymore; people are going

Speaker: NA
Text: back as mature age apprentices nowadays-

Speaker: NA
Text: are learning the skills and know-how through

Speaker: NA
Text: on-the-job experience to ensure that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: the skills that we need to carry Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: forward into the future. It is particularly im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant that we do this when times are tough

Speaker: NA
Text: so that we are ready to come out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: trough. We must be ready for that. People

Speaker: NA
Text: batten down the hatches and markets tighten

Speaker: NA
Text: up when economic circumstances deterio-

Speaker: NA
Text: rate, so it is important that the government

Speaker: NA
Text: does what it can to make sure that people are

Speaker: NA
Text: primed, ready and trained-retrained if nec-

Speaker: NA
Text: essary-so as to go into overdrive when the

Speaker: NA
Text: market turns around. I am sure that all those

Speaker: NA
Text: in the House would take heart from the eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic outlook figures that we have seen over

Speaker: NA
Text: the last few weeks. There would not be any-

Speaker: NA
Text: one partaking of dole queue schadenfreude

Speaker: NA
Text: and hoping for things to go bad. Instead, I

Speaker: NA
Text: am sure that we all want the best for Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Skills for Sustainability program for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian apprentices is a great initiative to

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage apprentices to complete the sus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainability related training. They receive

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,000 once they have successfully com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pleted the required level of training. Obvi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously, $1,000 is not as much today as it was

Speaker: NA
Text: when I was contemplating going into the

Speaker: NA
Text: butchering trade in 1977, but $1,000 is still

Speaker: NA
Text: quite significant and a great incentive.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian workplaces are crying out for

Speaker: NA
Text: people with training in environmentally sus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainable work practices, and the Skills for

Speaker: NA
Text: Sustainability payment will provide an added

Speaker: NA
Text: incentive to apprentices who complete their

Speaker: NA
Text: training in this area. It will also give them a

Speaker: NA
Text: head start when it comes time to find a job.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those who are equipped to meet the sustain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ability challenges that they might face on the

Speaker: NA
Text: job will obviously be ahead of the pack. This

Speaker: NA
Text: skill will become much more of a factor for

Speaker: NA
Text: employers when they determine who will

Speaker: NA
Text: become their employees. As Australia transi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions slowly but surely and inevitably to a

Speaker: NA
Text: low carbon economy-I say this irrespective

Speaker: NA
Text: of what goes on in the red chamber-

Speaker: NA
Text: consumers will increasingly want outcomes

Speaker: NA
Text: that are good for the environment. The ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: prentices who benefit from these programs

Speaker: NA
Text: will be well equipped and ready to deliver.

Speaker: NA
Text: Incidentally, the idea of the Skills for

Speaker: NA
Text: tainability program came out of the Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: 2020 Summit convened by the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter in April 2008 and held in this building.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is further evidence that politicians do

Speaker: NA
Text: not have all the bright ideas and it also shows

Speaker: NA
Text: that this government is prepared to listen to

Speaker: NA
Text: good ideas no matter where they come from.

Speaker: NA
Text: Obviously, there are many people who feel

Speaker: NA
Text: that, if we just listen to taxi drivers, we could

Speaker: NA
Text: solve all of the world's problems pretty

Speaker: NA
Text: quickly. But the 2020 Summit went beyond

Speaker: NA
Text: just taxi drivers; it engaged lots of different

Speaker: NA
Text: people from lots of different sections within

Speaker: NA
Text: our community and some great ideas flowed

Speaker: NA
Text: from that.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the weeks leading up to the national

Speaker: NA
Text: 2020 Summit, I held a community forum in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate in conjunction with Griffith

Speaker: NA
Text: University and, in particular, the Nathan

Speaker: NA
Text: campus. More than 400 people filled the

Speaker: NA
Text: auditorium at Griffith University. We shared

Speaker: NA
Text: a few hours of robust debate and information

Speaker: NA
Text: sharing. There are certainly some very pas-

Speaker: NA
Text: sionate people with some very firmly held

Speaker: NA
Text: beliefs. It was a fantastic experience and it

Speaker: NA
Text: was important for me as the new local mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber to be informed about the range of views

Speaker: NA
Text: in my community-although, there were

Speaker: NA
Text: times when I wished that the range of views

Speaker: NA
Text: had not been quite as broad as was presented.

Speaker: NA
Text: But, nevertheless, it was great for the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity to be heard, and that is why I, in

Speaker: NA
Text: partnership with Griffith university, will be

Speaker: NA
Text: holding a Southside summit on 22 August

Speaker: NA
Text: this year. If the member for Moncrieff wants

Speaker: NA
Text: to put that date in his diary, he is more than

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome to attend. I would be more than

Speaker: NA
Text: happy to have him address a particular sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the community. A range of topics

Speaker: NA
Text: will be up for discussion, and I am sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: we will hear more great ideas like the Skills

Speaker: NA
Text: for Sustainability program.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I mentioned earlier, the other payment

Speaker: NA
Text: Susproposed in this legislation is Tools For Your

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade. This new payment combines and ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tends three programs previously offered to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian apprentices to support them in

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaking apprenticeships in areas of na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional skills shortage. The Tools For Your

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade payment includes five separate cash

Speaker: NA
Text: payments, totalling $3,800 over the life of an

Speaker: NA
Text: apprenticeship. They are not insignificant

Speaker: NA
Text: amounts of cash, especially for an appren-

Speaker: NA
Text: tice. This new payment will help more ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: prentices make life easier for employers and

Speaker: NA
Text: it will also ensure that Australian apprentices

Speaker: NA
Text: in areas of skills shortage are eligible for the

Speaker: NA
Text: same level of support. Importantly, this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: ensures that payments made to apprentices

Speaker: NA
Text: under these programs will be tax exempt. I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand this is in line with the tax treat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of other programs that have made simi-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar payments to apprentices.

Speaker: NA
Text: The two programs are worth about $700

Speaker: NA
Text: million over four years. So we are not talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about just a few dollars or a token gesture;

Speaker: NA
Text: this is significant cash on the table to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that our apprentices, be they young, old or

Speaker: NA
Text: mature, are able to complete their training

Speaker: NA
Text: with as much support as possible from the

Speaker: NA
Text: government. I am sure that everyone can see

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefits of the programs in encouraging

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices to undertake training in areas of

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce shortage and sustainability. Any

Speaker: NA
Text: investment that we can pump into meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: skills shortages and equipping people for the

Speaker: NA
Text: climate change jobs of the future is money

Speaker: NA
Text: well spent as far as I am concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: On a related note, earlier this year I was

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to meet 10 young people working on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Green Corps project to improve water

Speaker: NA
Text: quality and protect the local flora and fauna

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Rocky Water Holes Creek area of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Oxley Creek catchment in my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, the Rocky Water Holes Creek

Speaker: NA
Text: area floods fairly regularly, and that has a

Speaker: NA
Text: significant impact on the suburbs of Rocklea

Speaker: NA
Text: and Salisbury. It was great to go along and

Speaker: NA
Text: meet the guys who were working on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Green Corps project. They were cleaning up

Speaker: NA
Text: the river bank around the construction train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing centre and attempting to move rubbish

Speaker: NA
Text: from lantana. It was amazing to see the filth

Speaker: NA
Text: and rubbish that had accumulated there over

Speaker: NA
Text: the last 20, 30, 40 or 50 years. I took some

Speaker: NA
Text: photographs of these young people and have

Speaker: NA
Text: included them in a newsletter.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Gray interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: ple tomorrow.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Gray-I would appreciate that.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: people had not necessarily been the most

Speaker: NA
Text: successful at school. A couple of them had

Speaker: NA
Text: made a decision to go into an environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: job because that is what they had always

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted to do. Some were being trained up so

Speaker: NA
Text: that they could spend a year backpacking

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas and perhaps use their green skills in

Speaker: NA
Text: other parts of the world that may be a little

Speaker: NA
Text: more embracing of legislation like the Car-

Speaker: NA
Text: bon Pollution Reduction Scheme. It was a

Speaker: NA
Text: great opportunity to meet these young guys

Speaker: NA
Text: working on the Green Corps, and they

Speaker: NA
Text: seemed to be picking up a lot of skills. Obvi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously, things have changed a bit in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: the knowledge that they need. They now

Speaker: NA
Text: have to know how to use personal protective

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment and different types of machines

Speaker: NA
Text: such as brush-cutters and the like, which

Speaker: NA
Text: seemed incredibly dangerous. These young

Speaker: NA
Text: people said that they would not let me touch

Speaker: NA
Text: any of the brush-cutters, which was probably

Speaker: NA
Text: a wise decision. This is a great training op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunity and experience for young job seek-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers, and these young people are doing a great

Speaker: NA
Text: job in helping to regenerate local native plant

Speaker: NA
Text: species through weeding, planting and water

Speaker: NA
Text: quality monitoring.

Speaker: NA
Text: These programs that are before the House

Speaker: NA
Text: will help ease the financial burden for ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: prentices and encourage more into training

Speaker: NA
Text: areas of sustainability and skill shortages.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why are we doing this? We are doing this

Speaker: NA
Text: because the government understands that a

Speaker: NA
Text: carbon restrained economy is all but upon us.

Speaker: NA
Text: If you doorknock any household in my elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate of Moreton, I am sure two out of three

Speaker: NA
Text: would say they understand that something

Speaker: NA
Text: has to be done about climate change. You

Speaker: NA
Text: occasionally get the ill-informed people who

Speaker: NA
Text: think that the world's global warming prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems were changed last year when the Kyoto

Speaker: NA
Text: protocol was signed, but most understand

Speaker: NA
Text: that more has to be done. Carbon belts have

Speaker: NA
Text: to be tightened in every household. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: great to see these 15-, 16-, 17and 18-year-

Speaker: NA
Text: old guys and girls who have done it a bit

Speaker: NA
Text: tough being given the opportunity to train

Speaker: NA
Text: and do their bit to save the planet.

Speaker: NA
Text: That view is not necessarily shared by

Speaker: NA
Text: everyone in the House or in the Senate; there

Speaker: NA
Text: are people who still do not quite get it. I

Speaker: NA
Text: know that all the forward-thinking members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Liberal Party would certainly be in

Speaker: NA
Text: favour of getting some legislation in as soon

Speaker: NA
Text: as possible-legislation that would be ahead

Speaker: NA
Text: of the curve, as they say, in what the world

Speaker: NA
Text: needs. However, it is not a bad thing for Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia to take a leadership position when it

Speaker: NA
Text: comes to climate change. As I indicated ear-

Speaker: NA
Text: lier in my speech, there will be job opportu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nities and opportunities to export our tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nologies and knowledge around the world if

Speaker: NA
Text: we can steal a march on those other countries

Speaker: NA
Text: that are still filled with sceptics. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: to think that in this parliament in 2009, after

Speaker: NA
Text: all the debates in the House and in the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: about climate change, people will find out

Speaker: NA
Text: that this was the group of people that be-

Speaker: NA
Text: trayed the later generations, that this was the

Speaker: NA
Text: group of people who did not read the writing

Speaker: NA
Text: writ large on the wall. Still there are sceptics.

Speaker: NA
Text: Still there are people who go overseas, talk

Speaker: NA
Text: to a couple of scientists-possibly not main-

Speaker: NA
Text: stream scientists; I do not know-and then

Speaker: NA
Text: say, ‘Oh no, I spoke to someone who had a

Speaker: NA
Text: different view; therefore, we need to revise

Speaker: NA
Text: our whole understanding.' I am hoping that

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite will take the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: inform their caucus and that we will have

Speaker: NA
Text: some movement on this legislation so that

Speaker: NA
Text: those young people whom I met during my

Speaker: NA
Text: visits to the Green Corps can take heart from

Speaker: NA
Text: the politicians in this House. I commend the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill to the House.

Speaker: Ms HALL
Text: Shortland) (8.18 pm)-It

Speaker: NA
Text: gives me great pleasure to speak on the So-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial Security and Other Legislation Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment (Australian Apprentices) Bill 2009 in

Speaker: NA
Text: the House tonight. This bill will amend the

Speaker: NA
Text: Income Tax Assessment Act 1997, the Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments Act 1986 to allow Australian appren-

Speaker: NA
Text: tices to receive the full value, without deduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, of payments made under Skills for Sus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainability for Australian Apprentices and

Speaker: NA
Text: Tools For Your Trade within the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Apprenticeship Incentives Program. In addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, it will make the taxation treatment of

Speaker: NA
Text: payments under the two new programs con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sistent with the treatment of previous pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grams that deliver payments to Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no more important role that a

Speaker: NA
Text: government can play than to ensure that Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia has appropriately trained tradespeople.

Speaker: NA
Text: How do you get appropriately trained trades-

Speaker: NA
Text: people? People need to undertake appren-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticeships. Unfortunately, under the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: hate government a chronic skills shortage was

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed to develop in many of the trades.

Speaker: NA
Text: Coming from the Hunter, in which my elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate of Shortland is situated, it was very

Speaker: NA
Text: apparent that employers were unable to ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain suitably qualified tradespeople. Unfortu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nately for Australia, the Howard government

Speaker: NA
Text: chose to do absolutely nothing. They allowed

Speaker: NA
Text: this chronic skills shortage to get worse and

Speaker: NA
Text: worse. That meant that we had fewer and

Speaker: NA
Text: fewer qualified tradespeople. The Rudd gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's approach is totally different to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government's approach. We know

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australia is part of a global market. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are part of the global economy. For Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: to benefit from being part of that global mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ket and global economy, we must have ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: propriately trained tradespeople, tradespeo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple who have completed apprenticeships and

Speaker: NA
Text: tradespeople who are highly skilled. The

Speaker: NA
Text: only way we will get these tradespeople is

Speaker: NA
Text: for them to undertake apprenticeships. The

Speaker: NA
Text: financial impact of the Skills for Sustainabil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity for Australian Apprentices is estimated to

Speaker: NA
Text: cost about $20 million over four years. The

Speaker: NA
Text: other program, Tools For Your Trade within

Speaker: NA
Text: the broader Australian Apprenticeship Incen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives Program, is estimated to cost about

Speaker: NA
Text: $670.1 million over four years. Every cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: that is worthwhile spending, because it will

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage more young people to undertake

Speaker: NA
Text: apprenticeships.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that when the previous govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment was in power there was a lot of rhetoric

Speaker: NA
Text: about supporting apprentices, about training

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices, about how undertaking an occu-

Speaker: NA
Text: pation as a tradesperson was a noble aspira-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. We know that and we are making it

Speaker: NA
Text: possible by putting in place programs like

Speaker: NA
Text: these two that are included in this legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I have already indicated, the bill exempts

Speaker: NA
Text: the value of payments made under Skills for

Speaker: NA
Text: Sustainability for Australian Apprentices and

Speaker: NA
Text: Tools For Your Trade from treatment as as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sessable income for income tax purposes and

Speaker: NA
Text: from the income tax test for benefits under

Speaker: NA
Text: social security and veterans affairs legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. This is a major incentive for young

Speaker: NA
Text: people to undertake training as apprentices.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments ensure that Australian ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: prentices receive the full benefit of the pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments made under the two new programs.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are consistent with the taxation treat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of previous programs that have paid

Speaker: NA
Text: personal benefits to Australian apprentices.

Speaker: NA
Text: While we are talking about apprentices

Speaker: NA
Text: and apprenticeship programs, I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: share with the House details of the launch of

Speaker: NA
Text: a program that took place in the Hunter last

Speaker: NA
Text: Wednesday, 10 June. It was a rather cold

Speaker: NA
Text: morning and 60 bold and brave souls turned

Speaker: NA
Text: out early for the launch of the Adopt an Ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: prentice program. The campaign was

Speaker: NA
Text: launched by nine group training schools

Speaker: NA
Text: working in Newcastle, Lake Macquarie, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunter Valley and the Central Coast. I might

Speaker: NA
Text: add that the Shortland electorate also takes in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Central Coast. The campaign is to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices working during the current

Speaker: NA
Text: downturn. It is really important to emphasise

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have had a skills shortage in the eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic good times and what we need to do

Speaker: NA
Text: now is train our young people so they will be

Speaker: NA
Text: ready once the downturn is over. The group

Speaker: NA
Text: training organisations have set aside their

Speaker: NA
Text: own interests and identities as entities and set

Speaker: NA
Text: out to work together. That is a really impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant point. They are joining together in a

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign aimed at assisting employers and

Speaker: NA
Text: also apprentices whose training positions are

Speaker: NA
Text: under threat. I congratulate all those who are

Speaker: NA
Text: involved, especially the group training com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany NovaSkill, who have provided the

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership on this initiative. To anyone who

Speaker: NA
Text: may be listening in the Hunter-Central Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: area, I have considerable information on this

Speaker: NA
Text: program that can be obtained from my elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate office.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Adopt an Apprentice program will as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sist apprentices to continue their trade train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and the completion of their trade qualifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation at a time when their jobs under threat.

Speaker: NA
Text: Employers will have maintained a pool of

Speaker: NA
Text: skilled labour to meet future demands as the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy recovers. Potential employers

Speaker: NA
Text: should go to the website and have a look at

Speaker: NA
Text: the availability of apprentices and then regis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter their interest with the responsible group

Speaker: NA
Text: training program. The Adopt an Apprentice

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign is a call to arms, which is the way

Speaker: NA
Text: the group apprenticeship organisations have

Speaker: NA
Text: put it. It is a call to arms, and employers are

Speaker: NA
Text: working together to keep young apprentices

Speaker: NA
Text: in work in these uncertain times. The cam-

Speaker: NA
Text: paign highlights that young apprentices,

Speaker: NA
Text: through no fault of their own, are affected

Speaker: NA
Text: and still need to complete their training. Ini-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiatives like this really show what can be

Speaker: NA
Text: done. If people are interested in checking it

Speaker: NA
Text: out, the website for the Adopt an Apprentice

Speaker: NA
Text: program is:

Speaker: NA
Text: www.apprenticeships.det.nsw.ed.au.

Speaker: NA
Text: They can obtain the information that they

Speaker: NA
Text: need from that website.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reason I have brought this program to

Speaker: NA
Text: the attention of the House is that it recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nises how important tradespeople are to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. This program recognises that govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments should do everything in their power to

Speaker: NA
Text: help young people complete their apprentice-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships. Skills for Sustainability for Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Apprentices is one such program. It is a pilot

Speaker: NA
Text: program within the Skills for the Carbon

Speaker: NA
Text: Challenge initiative. This initiative is an out-

Speaker: NA
Text: come of Australia's 2020 Summit which

Speaker: NA
Text: aims to accelerate industries' and tertiary

Speaker: NA
Text: education's response to climate change. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: an innovative program aimed at training ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: prentices and giving them the kinds of skills

Speaker: NA
Text: that they will need for the future. To encour-

Speaker: NA
Text: age Australian apprentices to undertake sus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainability related training, the payment of

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,000 will be provided to eligible Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices who have successfully com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pleted the required level of training which

Speaker: NA
Text: teaches skills as to sustainable and environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentally sustainable work practices, all very

Speaker: NA
Text: important at this time. It was only last week

Speaker: NA
Text: that we debated the CPRS legislation in this

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament and now we are encouraging

Speaker: NA
Text: young people to obtain trade qualifications in

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental areas, which is very impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is also the Tools For Your Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: payment initiative within the broader Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian Apprenticeships Incentives Program.

Speaker: NA
Text: That combines and extends three administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively complex programs previously avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to Australian apprentices. So it is good

Speaker: NA
Text: for employers and it is good for apprentices.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new payment initiative comprises five

Speaker: NA
Text: separate cash payments totalling $3,800, paid

Speaker: NA
Text: over the life of the Australian apprenticeship.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new arrangement reduces the adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: trative burden on employers of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices, broadening eligibility criteria.

Speaker: NA
Text: By doing that it is benefiting more Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices and it is also, as I have men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned, benefiting employers. It will ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australian apprentices in areas of skill

Speaker: NA
Text: shortages become trained. These apprentices

Speaker: NA
Text: are eligible for the same level of government

Speaker: NA
Text: support regardless of their age and of their

Speaker: NA
Text: employer's size. These two new programs

Speaker: NA
Text: represent significant measures and encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian apprentices to develop skills in

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainability in order to participate in the

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is important legislation. The issue of

Speaker: NA
Text: training apprentices was brought up at the

Speaker: NA
Text: 2020 Summit. Payments under Skills for

Speaker: NA
Text: Sustainability for Australian Apprentices is a

Speaker: NA
Text: very important measure, as are all the meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures in this legislation. The legislation that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have before us today should be supported

Speaker: NA
Text: by all in the House. By supporting this legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation we are ensuring that we have suitably

Speaker: NA
Text: trained tradespeople for the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate interrupted.

Speaker: NA
Text: PETITIONS

Speaker: NA
Text: Responses

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs Irwin-On behalf of the Standing

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on Petitions, and in accordance

Speaker: NA
Text: with standing order 209, I present the follow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing ministerial responses to petitions that

Speaker: NA
Text: have been received:

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Farzad Kamangar

Speaker: NA
Text: Dear Mrs Irwin

Speaker: NA
Text: Thank you for your letter dated 8 May 2009 on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions,

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning a petition against the death penalty in

Speaker: NA
Text: Iran and the possible execution of a Kurdish Ira-

Speaker: NA
Text: nian teacher, Mr Farzad Kamangar.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government is committed to promoting in-

Speaker: NA
Text: ternational human rights standards in Iran, includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing equal treatment for all Iran's citizens. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Government is deeply concerned by

Speaker: NA
Text: reports of persecution of political and social ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tivists and the ongoing suppression of freedom of

Speaker: NA
Text: expression.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian officials, in Canberra and Tehran, have

Speaker: NA
Text: made clear repeatedly to the Iranian authorities

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's strong concerns about human rights in

Speaker: NA
Text: Iran. In addition, Australia has joined with the

Speaker: NA
Text: European Union in representations to the Iranian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, calling on Iran to fulfil its interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional human rights obligations, including with

Speaker: NA
Text: respect to Mr Kamangar's Kurdish community.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the specific case of Mr Kamangar, we joined

Speaker: NA
Text: with the European Union in 2008 in expressing

Speaker: NA
Text: our concerns to the Government of Iran. As far as

Speaker: NA
Text: we are aware, Mr Kamangar's sentence of execu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion has not been carried out. Our Embassy in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tehran will continue to monitor his case.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government also has a policy of global op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position to the death penalty, and is working with

Speaker: NA
Text: the international community to achieve its univer-

Speaker: NA
Text: sal abolition. Australia was an original co-sponsor

Speaker: NA
Text: of this year's United Nations General Assembly's

Speaker: NA
Text: resolution on the moratorium on the use of the

Speaker: NA
Text: death penalty, and is working actively with like-

Speaker: NA
Text: minded countries in New York to ensure that this

Speaker: NA
Text: issue remains on the General Assembly's agenda.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Government will continue to raise

Speaker: NA
Text: its concerns about human rights in Iran with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Iranian authorities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thank you for referring this petition to me.

Speaker: NA
Text: From the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Stephen Smith.

Speaker: NA
Text: Education Funding

Speaker: NA
Text: Dear Mrs Irwin

Speaker: NA
Text: Thank you for your letter dated 8 May 2009 about

Speaker: NA
Text: the petition submitted for the Committee's con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration on the proposal to relocate the East

Speaker: NA
Text: Gippsland TAFE and to develop a multi-sports

Speaker: NA
Text: complex for the Gippsland region. An application

Speaker: NA
Text: for these activities was recently submitted by

Speaker: NA
Text: Wellington Shire Council under the Regional and

Speaker: NA
Text: Local Community Infrastructure Program-

Speaker: NA
Text: Strategic Projects (RLCIP-SP).

Speaker: NA
Text: I am pleased to inform you that the application

Speaker: NA
Text: submitted to the RLCIP-SP by the Council for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Gippsland Regional Sports Complex - Sale has

Speaker: NA
Text: been approved for funding of $3,250,000. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Rudd Government is delivering record funding of

Speaker: NA
Text: $800 million to local governments under the

Speaker: NA
Text: RLCIP to build and improve community infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure, support local jobs, and stimulate local

Speaker: NA
Text: economies during the global economic recession.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thank you for raising this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: From the Minister for Infrastructure,

Speaker: NA
Text: Transport, Regional Development and

Speaker: NA
Text: Local Government, Mr Albanese.

Speaker: NA
Text: Statements

Speaker: Mrs IRWIN
Text: Fowler) (8.31 pm)-In re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cent weeks during my statements to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House I have focused on the value that has

Speaker: NA
Text: been gained from public hearings held by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Committee on Petitions. The com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee has been very pleased with the level

Speaker: NA
Text: of engagement from petitioners and with the

Speaker: NA
Text: support it has received from ministers and

Speaker: NA
Text: departments. This evening, I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: refer to two other aspects of the committee's

Speaker: NA
Text: work, and to some of the benefits that we can

Speaker: NA
Text: hope to gain. The first aspect relates to ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess to information about petitions and the

Speaker: NA
Text: second aspect relates to the cooperation and

Speaker: NA
Text: goodwill that is shown to the committee by

Speaker: NA
Text: other parliaments as they share information

Speaker: NA
Text: about their petitions processes.

Speaker: NA
Text: As you know, Madam Deputy Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: the petitions committee was first established

Speaker: NA
Text: in this the 42nd Parliament. To some extent it

Speaker: NA
Text: is carving out new territory, although, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, I acknowledge the long tradition of

Speaker: NA
Text: petitions to the United Kingdom parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: and the inheritance in Australia of the right

Speaker: NA
Text: to petition our parliament. Australians have

Speaker: NA
Text: long been exercising that right. Something

Speaker: NA
Text: that is new to our petitions process, I believe,

Speaker: NA
Text: is the high degree of responsiveness by the

Speaker: NA
Text: executive to issues that are raised in peti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. In this way, I would argue that peti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions can be seen to have a greater impact

Speaker: NA
Text: and petitioners may feel they are having in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased success in getting their message

Speaker: NA
Text: across.

Speaker: NA
Text: Something else that is new to the House,

Speaker: NA
Text: and which may be contributing to the effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiveness of petitioning, is the petitions com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee's centralised collection and publica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion on its website of information about peti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. That information includes details on

Speaker: NA
Text: the process of petitioning the House, the

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of petitions, statements made by mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers when presenting those petitions, evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence given to the committee by petitioners

Speaker: NA
Text: and public servants and the written responses

Speaker: NA
Text: made by ministers when the committee re-

Speaker: NA
Text: fers petitions to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Anyone who is interested is able to see on

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee's website not only the terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of petitions that have been presented to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House-collected under headings that relate

Speaker: NA
Text: to the portfolio area covering the subject of

Speaker: NA
Text: the petition-but also other petitions that

Speaker: NA
Text: relate to the same subject areas. They can

Speaker: NA
Text: also see very clearly the ways that the issues

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been raised in the petitions have

Speaker: NA
Text: been dealt with by members, the House and

Speaker: NA
Text: the government. Enabling easy public access

Speaker: NA
Text: to this information is a significant aspect of

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee's work.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the House or Representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Committee on Procedure presented

Speaker: NA
Text: its 2007 report on petitioning the House, it

Speaker: NA
Text: began a process that culminated in the

Speaker: NA
Text: changing of arrangements for petitions and

Speaker: NA
Text: the establishment of the petitions committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Procedure Committee considered itself

Speaker: NA
Text: bound by six principles of petitioning. I will

Speaker: NA
Text: outline those principles, and what I think the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee intended by them. The principles

Speaker: NA
Text: were that, first, petitions belong to the pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic. Behind this is the belief that the ability

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the public to communicate di-

Speaker: NA
Text: rectly with the House is important to our

Speaker: NA
Text: democracy. Secondly, petitions sent to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House should be addressed by the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Procedure Committee considered that

Speaker: NA
Text: the establishment of a petitions committee

Speaker: NA
Text: was the most effective way for the House to

Speaker: NA
Text: act in relation to petitions. Thirdly, govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments should respond. The Procedure Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee wanted to encourage ministers and

Speaker: NA
Text: their departments to respond in a timely way

Speaker: NA
Text: to the issues raised in petitions. Fourthly,

Speaker: NA
Text: members' involvement should be enhanced

Speaker: NA
Text: and streamlined. By this, the Procedure

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee meant that members had an im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant role to play in raising and debating

Speaker: NA
Text: the issues addressed in petitions. Fifthly,

Speaker: NA
Text: rules should be relevant and fair. The com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee sought to encourage a process, includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the process of preparing petitions, which

Speaker: NA
Text: was easier for petitioners. Sixthly, informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion technologies should be used more effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively. The traditional right of people to ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dress their grievances directly to the King

Speaker: NA
Text: now needs to be aligned with modern tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nology. In particular, the Procedure Commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee stated that the House could not ignore the

Speaker: NA
Text: possibilities raised by electronic petitions. I

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that these principles have, to one

Speaker: NA
Text: degree or another, been applied.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to expand on the final princi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple, the effective use of information technol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ogy, and some unexpected benefits that have

Speaker: NA
Text: been obtained. In June last year, the Petitions

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee decided to inquire into the intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of an electronic petitioning system

Speaker: NA
Text: for the House of Representatives. In particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar, the committee wanted to consider the

Speaker: NA
Text: different models of electronic petitioning that

Speaker: NA
Text: might be introduced, changes that might be

Speaker: NA
Text: required to House practices and procedures

Speaker: NA
Text: in order to implement e-petitions, the role of

Speaker: NA
Text: members, privacy and security concerns,

Speaker: NA
Text: resource implications and the experience of

Speaker: NA
Text: of other relevant jurisdictions. This is a signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant inquiry for the committee and the House

Speaker: NA
Text: and it will be completed later this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee was grateful to hear from

Speaker: NA
Text: other parliaments about their innovations in

Speaker: NA
Text: petitions. It has received submissions from

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Assembly and the Legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: Council in Tasmania and the Scottish Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament Public Petitions Committee. The

Speaker: NA
Text: committee has held a videoconference with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Scottish committee, enabling a very con-

Speaker: NA
Text: structive discussion and establishing a rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionship that continues to this day. The Scot-

Speaker: NA
Text: tish committee is about to report on its in-

Speaker: NA
Text: quiry into the public petitions process, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the report will be read with interest. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland parliament, like the Scottish Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament Public Petitions Committee, is gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: erous in sharing information and views on

Speaker: NA
Text: the issues raised by e-petitions. The issues

Speaker: NA
Text: raised by petitions in modern parliaments are

Speaker: NA
Text: many and varied and the experience gained

Speaker: NA
Text: by other parliaments is valuable to us. In

Speaker: NA
Text: closing, I would like to acknowledge the co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operative attitude of committees and parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in other jurisdictions and the profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sional relationships being developed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: petitions committee. I think what we have in

Speaker: NA
Text: common is a definite commitment to facili-

Speaker: NA
Text: tating direct engagement by members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: public with our parliaments.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMITTEES

Speaker: NA
Text: Intelligence and Security Committee

Speaker: Mr BEVIS
Text: Brisbane) (8.37 pm)-On

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: on Intelligence and Security, I present the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee's report entitled Review of the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: listing of Ansar al-Islam, AAA, IAA, IMU,

Speaker: NA
Text: JeM and LeJ as terrorist organisations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the report be made a parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary paper.

Speaker: Mr BEVIS
Text: This report has departed

Speaker: NA
Text: from the usual format of terrorist proscrip-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion reports. In this report the committee has

Speaker: NA
Text: sought some improvements with respect to

Speaker: NA
Text: the statement of reasons process. The com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee recommends that in future the Attor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney-General provide the committee with a

Speaker: NA
Text: statement of reasons where a decision is

Speaker: NA
Text: taken not to re-list an organisation, similar

Speaker: NA
Text: that now supplied when an organisation is

Speaker: NA
Text: listed.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no requirement for the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General to provide the committee with de-

Speaker: NA
Text: tailed reasons when he decides not to re-list

Speaker: NA
Text: an organisation. However, it would be useful

Speaker: NA
Text: if, where the Attorney-General has decided

Speaker: NA
Text: he will not be re-listing an organisation as a

Speaker: NA
Text: terrorist organisation under the Criminal

Speaker: NA
Text: Code, a statement of reasons explaining his

Speaker: NA
Text: decision is provided to the committee and

Speaker: NA
Text: that there also be a publicly released state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of reasons.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee was advised that the At-

Speaker: NA
Text: torney-General recently considered advice

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Director-General of Security with

Speaker: NA
Text: respect to the Egyptian Islamic Jihad (EIJ).

Speaker: NA
Text: Based on that advice he stated he would not

Speaker: NA
Text: be re-listing EIJ as a terrorist organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Criminal Code after the current

Speaker: NA
Text: listing expired on 30 March 2009. The com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee's recommendations would enhance

Speaker: NA
Text: transparency and public confidence in this

Speaker: NA
Text: important process.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee in this parliament and ear-

Speaker: NA
Text: Report lier parliaments has taken the view that the

Speaker: NA
Text: non-statutory guidelines used by ASIO are a

Speaker: NA
Text: useful tool in evaluating the evidence sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: porting a listing or re-listing. The committee

Speaker: NA
Text: believes it would be helpful in its role if the

Speaker: NA
Text: statement of reasons were written in part in a

Speaker: NA
Text: way that directly links the evidence with the

Speaker: NA
Text: ASIO guidelines.

Speaker: NA
Text: This approach would also better inform

Speaker: NA
Text: public understanding of the listing process

Speaker: NA
Text: and outcomes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee has also requested that fu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture statements of reasons be drafted, in part,

Speaker: NA
Text: in such a way that the information is directly

Speaker: NA
Text: referrable to the statutory criteria for listing

Speaker: NA
Text: contained within the Criminal Code.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn to the current regulations. They

Speaker: NA
Text: to were signed by the Governor-General on 13

Speaker: NA
Text: March 2009. They were then tabled in the

Speaker: NA
Text: House and the Senate on 17 March 2009.

Speaker: NA
Text: The disallowance period of 15 sitting days

Speaker: NA
Text: for the committee's review of the listing be-

Speaker: NA
Text: gan from the date of the tabling. Therefore

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee has conducted its affairs in

Speaker: NA
Text: order for it to report to the parliament by

Speaker: NA
Text: today, Monday 15 June 2009.

Speaker: NA
Text: Notice of the inquiry was placed on the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee's website and in the national daily

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper. One submission was received

Speaker: NA
Text: from a public organisation. Representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Federation of Community Legal Cen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tres (Vic.) Inc., the Attorney-General's De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment and ASIO attended a private hear-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing on the listings.

Speaker: NA
Text: I now quickly turn to other organisations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ansar al-Islam

Speaker: NA
Text: Ansar al-Islam has immediate objectives

Speaker: NA
Text: to overthrow the Iraqi government, expel

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition forces from the country and estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lish a Sunni Islamic state administered under

Speaker: NA
Text: Shariah law.

Speaker: NA
Text: The last confirmed terrorist act Ansar al-

Speaker: NA
Text: Islam was involved in was an attack on a

Speaker: NA
Text: Peshmerga barracks, reportedly killing 19

Speaker: NA
Text: people and destroying two vehicles on 13

Speaker: NA
Text: August 2008.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee does not recommend disal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowance of the regulation in relation to Ansar

Speaker: NA
Text: al-Islam.

Speaker: NA
Text: Asbat al-Ansar (AAA)

Speaker: NA
Text: Asbat al Ansar, AAA, has objectives to es-

Speaker: NA
Text: tablish a Sunni Islamic state in Lebanon by

Speaker: NA
Text: overthrowing the Lebanese government,

Speaker: NA
Text: eliminating Israel and impeding anti-Islamic

Speaker: NA
Text: and pro-Western influences in Lebanon. The

Speaker: NA
Text: group believes its struggle justifies violence

Speaker: NA
Text: against civilians. Its strategies in seeking its

Speaker: NA
Text: objectives include the use of terrorist tactics.

Speaker: NA
Text: AAA remains focused on supporting jihad

Speaker: NA
Text: in Iraq and planning attacks against Leba-

Speaker: NA
Text: nese security forces, and Western interests.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee does not recommend disal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowance of the regulation in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: AAA.

Speaker: NA
Text: Islamic Army of Aden (IAA)

Speaker: NA
Text: The Islamic Army of Aden, IAA, is a

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunni Islamic extremist group that first came

Speaker: NA
Text: to public prominence in 1998, when it issued

Speaker: NA
Text: statements detailing its intention to over-

Speaker: NA
Text: throw the Yemeni government and imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Shariah law; and called for operations

Speaker: NA
Text: against Western interests in Yemen.

Speaker: NA
Text: In March-April members of the group

Speaker: NA
Text: suspected of planning to travel to Iraq to

Speaker: NA
Text: fight foreign forces were arrested.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee does not recommend disal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowance of the regulation in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: IAA.

Speaker: NA
Text: Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan

Speaker: NA
Text: The IMU is now fighting in support of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Taliban.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee does not recommend disal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowance of the regulation in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: IMU.

Speaker: NA
Text: Jaish-e-Mohammad (JeM)

Speaker: NA
Text: The JeM is a Sunni Islamic organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: also based in Pakistan.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee does not recommend disal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowance of the regulation in relation to JeM.

Speaker: NA
Text: Lashkar-e Jhangvi (LeJ)

Speaker: NA
Text: The LeJ is a Sunni Islamic group involved

Speaker: NA
Text: in terrorist activities including attacks in La-

Speaker: NA
Text: hore.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee does not recommend disal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowance of the regulation in relation to LeJ.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, as I have done on other oc-

Speaker: NA
Text: casions, I note the cooperation of members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the committee and thank them for their

Speaker: NA
Text: involvement and also thank the secretariat.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: Berowra) (8.43 pm)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: intend to speak in support of the report and

Speaker: NA
Text: the remarks of the chair in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: continued proscription of these six organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. They were organisations initially listed

Speaker: NA
Text: as terrorist organisations in 2003, and each of

Speaker: NA
Text: them had been listed on the United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: list of terrorist organisations. They came up

Speaker: NA
Text: for review under the new legislative ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements passed by parliament in 2004,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the committee therefore reviewed the

Speaker: NA
Text: first re-listing of these organisations in 2005.

Speaker: NA
Text: Following this, the committee again re-

Speaker: NA
Text: viewed these re-listings in June 2007. So this

Speaker: NA
Text: is the third review of re-listing of these six

Speaker: NA
Text: terrorist organisations. The chair has been

Speaker: NA
Text: through a brief outline of the circumstances

Speaker: NA
Text: which lead us to a view that the Attorney has

Speaker: NA
Text: properly listed these organisations.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the report is some useful information to

Speaker: NA
Text: help guide those who are interested in under-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing the sorts of criteria that apply in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to listing organisations. ASIO's

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines, as they were outlined to us in

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence in 2005, include factors such as

Speaker: NA
Text: engagement in terrorism, ideology and links

Speaker: NA
Text: to other terrorist groups or networks, links to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, the threat to Australian interests,

Speaker: NA
Text: proscription by the United Nations or like-

Speaker: NA
Text: minded countries, and engagement in peace

Speaker: NA
Text: and mediation processes. The committee

Speaker: NA
Text: noted that these guidelines are indicators

Speaker: NA
Text: only and not formally set out in the act but

Speaker: NA
Text: has found them a useful tool in its delibera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. The committee continues to use these

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines to assist it in relation to its re-

Speaker: NA
Text: views.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Federation of Community Legal Cen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tres made the point to us that, in the case of

Speaker: NA
Text: six organisations, the statements of reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: did not identify that any of the organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: in question have links to Australia. I note that

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee's view is that it is a misunder-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing of the statutory scheme to suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that listing of an organisation with no identi-

Speaker: NA
Text: fiable links to Australia exceeds the scope of

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislative intent or is a misuse of power.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee takes the view that, while

Speaker: NA
Text: direct links to Australia are not a statutory

Speaker: NA
Text: prerequisite, links are appropriate considera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions in the selection of organisations for

Speaker: NA
Text: proscription. I think it is important because

Speaker: NA
Text: in the context of threats to Australia's inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ests they can be posed to our citizens abroad

Speaker: NA
Text: as well as our interests that extend beyond

Speaker: NA
Text: the territorial boundaries of Australia. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are matters that were relevant to the commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee in its deliberations in relation to these

Speaker: NA
Text: particular organisations.

Speaker: NA
Text: I continue to be impressed with the quality

Speaker: NA
Text: of the deliberations of my colleagues on

Speaker: NA
Text: these matters. I have seen the other side of

Speaker: NA
Text: the wicket, as it were, and believe that they

Speaker: NA
Text: bring a very mature deliberation to this task.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it is one of the most important tasks

Speaker: NA
Text: that parliamentary committees can be en-

Speaker: NA
Text: gaged in. The committee is assisted by a very

Speaker: NA
Text: able secretary. I see Robert Little in the ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: visers' box; he is the inquiry secretary. I say

Speaker: NA
Text: to him and his colleagues that we very much

Speaker: NA
Text: value your collective efforts and the work

Speaker: NA
Text: that you undertake to ensure that in relation

Speaker: NA
