Text: to these very important deliberations we are

Speaker: NA
Text: well informed and able to fulfil our responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend the report of the committee to

Speaker: NA
Text: the House and assure honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: that these matters are important. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: important for securing the safety of the

Speaker: NA
Text: broader Australian community based here

Speaker: NA
Text: and abroad. I am delighted to be associated

Speaker: NA
Text: with this particular report.

Speaker: NA
Text: Treaties Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Report

Speaker: Mr KELVIN THOMSON
Text: Wills) (8.48

Speaker: NA
Text: pm)-On behalf of the Joint Standing Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee on Treaties, I present the committee's

Speaker: NA
Text: report entitled Report 101: Treaties tabled on

Speaker: NA
Text: 3 February 2009

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the report be made a parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary paper.

Speaker: Mr KELVIN THOMSON
Text: In present-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Report 101 of the Joint Standing Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee on Treaties, I note that this report

Speaker: NA
Text: views two treaty actions: firstly, the Conven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion on the Protection and Promotion of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Diversity of Cultural Expressions and, sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ondly, the Agreement between Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: the European Community on Trade in Wine.

Speaker: NA
Text: In each case the treaties committee has sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: ported the proposed treaties and has recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mended that binding treaty action be taken.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Convention on the Protection and

Speaker: NA
Text: Promotion of the Diversity of Cultural Ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pressions identifies the expression of culture

Speaker: NA
Text: by an individual or group as a tangible entity.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of the convention is to protect

Speaker: NA
Text: and promote the diverse range of these cul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tural expressions in an increasingly global-

Speaker: NA
Text: ised world. The convention requires nations

Speaker: NA
Text: to undertake to assist the creation of cultural

Speaker: NA
Text: expressions both domestically and abroad

Speaker: NA
Text: through regulatory, legislative, financial and

Speaker: NA
Text: technical assistance and to report to the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations on these measures. The con-

Speaker: NA
Text: vention is particularly concerned with secur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing cultural expressions that are under im-

Speaker: NA
Text: mediate threat and securing the cultural ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pressions of developing nations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The treaties committee is of the view that

Speaker: NA
Text: the convention will help to develop and

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain Australia's cultural industries

Speaker: NA
Text: protect Australia's valuable cultural expres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions. The committee considers that acces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion to the convention will demonstrate to

Speaker: NA
Text: the international community Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to cultural diversity and that it

Speaker: NA
Text: will expand Australia's active engagement

Speaker: NA
Text: with UNESCO.

Speaker: NA
Text: The treaties committee also considered the

Speaker: NA
Text: Agreement between Australia and the Euro-

Speaker: NA
Text: pean Community on Trade in Wine. Under

Speaker: NA
Text: this agreement Australia and the European

Speaker: NA
Text: Community are required to accept a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: wine labelling restrictions based on the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction and geographical origin of the wine

Speaker: NA
Text: and to recognise 16 previously unauthorised

Speaker: NA
Text: rewinemaking techniques. Significantly, Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian fortified winemakers will be required

Speaker: NA
Text: to phase out the use of the terms ‘port' and

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘sherry' within 12 months of the entry into

Speaker: NA
Text: force of the agreement and the term ‘tokay'

Speaker: NA
Text: will have to be phased out within 10 years of

Speaker: NA
Text: the agreement's entry into force.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Wine and Brandy Corpora-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion assured the committee that, whilst there

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a cost to the industry in ceasing the

Speaker: NA
Text: use of these wine names, the agreement will

Speaker: NA
Text: secure the use of terms which are valuable to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's fortified wine industry, including

Speaker: NA
Text: ‘ruby', ‘tawny', ‘vintage' and ‘cream'. Fur-

Speaker: NA
Text: thermore, the government has provided fi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nancial assistance which will assist in the

Speaker: NA
Text: rebadging of wines. This project will see the

Speaker: NA
Text: term ‘sherry' replaced with the term ‘apera'

Speaker: NA
Text: within 12 months and the term ‘tokay' re-

Speaker: NA
Text: placed with ‘topaque' within 10 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: In exchange for Australia's acceptance of

Speaker: NA
Text: these labelling restrictions, the European

Speaker: NA
Text: Community will be required to permit the

Speaker: NA
Text: import and marketing of Australian wines

Speaker: NA
Text: produced using 16 winemaking techniques

Speaker: NA
Text: which previously lacked authorisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, Australian winemakers stand to

Speaker: NA
Text: gain greater access to European wine mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: and to kets under the agreement.

Speaker: NA
Text: The treaties committee considers that ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cession to the agreement will strengthen

Speaker: NA
Text: trade between Australia and the European

Speaker: NA
Text: Community and is of the view that the

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement will provide Australian winemak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers with greater and more secure access to

Speaker: NA
Text: European wine markets. I thank the numer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous agencies, individuals and organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: who assisted in the treaties committee's in-

Speaker: NA
Text: quiries, and I thank the treaties committee

Speaker: NA
Text: secretariat for its assistance in preparing this

Speaker: NA
Text: report. I commend the report to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Legal and Constitutional Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Report

Speaker: Mr DREYFUS
Text: Isaacs) (8.53 pm)-On

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of the Standing Committee on Legal

Speaker: NA
Text: and Constitutional Affairs, I present the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee's report entitled Access all areas:

Speaker: NA
Text: Report of the inquiry into Draft Disability

Speaker: NA
Text: (Access to Premise-Buildings) Standards,

Speaker: NA
Text: together with the minutes of proceedings and

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence received by the committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the report be made a parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary paper.

Speaker: Mr DREYFUS
Text: It is my pleasure to pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent the report Access all areas: Report of

Speaker: NA
Text: the inquiry into Draft Disability (Access to

Speaker: NA
Text: Premise-Buildings) Standards, which is the

Speaker: NA
Text: third report of the committee for this parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. There are approximately four million

Speaker: NA
Text: people with a disability in Australia, a num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber which is expected to increase as the

Speaker: NA
Text: population ages. Every day people with a

Speaker: NA
Text: disability face physical barriers in the

Speaker: NA
Text: munity, from a doorway too narrow for a

Speaker: NA
Text: wheelchair, to not being able to visit their

Speaker: NA
Text: member of parliament because his or her

Speaker: NA
Text: office is located at the top of a flight of

Speaker: NA
Text: stairs. These physical barriers to the built

Speaker: NA
Text: environment have broader consequences for

Speaker: NA
Text: people with a disability, in restricting their

Speaker: NA
Text: access to the economic and social environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of our community.

Speaker: NA
Text: The draft Premises Standards are designed

Speaker: NA
Text: to make buildings more accessible for people

Speaker: NA
Text: with mobility, vision and hearing impair-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. If introduced, the Premises Standards

Speaker: NA
Text: will have a widespread impact, changing

Speaker: NA
Text: buildings regulations for new buildings and

Speaker: NA
Text: existing buildings undergoing significant

Speaker: NA
Text: upgrades.

Speaker: NA
Text: As well as providing improved access, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Premises Standards would also provide cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainty to building certifiers, developers and

Speaker: NA
Text: managers that they are complying with their

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations under the Commonwealth Dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ability Discrimination Act. In conducting the

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry, the committee received evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: from disability advocacy groups, the prop-

Speaker: NA
Text: erty and building sectors and many con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned individuals. The level of interest in

Speaker: NA
Text: the inquiry clearly demonstrates how impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant these issues are to people with a disabil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity.

Speaker: NA
Text: The report reflects the unanimous view of

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee that the Premises Standards

Speaker: NA
Text: should be finalised and introduced without

Speaker: NA
Text: delay. However, there are a number of areas

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Premises Standards which should be

Speaker: NA
Text: amended prior to their introduction. The

Speaker: NA
Text: committee has recommended that access be

Speaker: NA
Text: provided to the common areas of class 2

Speaker: NA
Text: buildings, such as residential apartment

Speaker: NA
Text: buildings. It is clear that the market has not

Speaker: NA
Text: responded to the needs of people with a dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ability or to the requirements of the Disabil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity Discrimination Act, even where class 2

Speaker: NA
Text: buildings are primarily used for short-term

Speaker: NA
Text: com- accommodation. As a result, people with a

Speaker: NA
Text: disability are excluded from an affordable

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation option in serviced apart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments which might otherwise be well suited

Speaker: NA
Text: for their needs. The committee's recommen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dation to include class 2 buildings within the

Speaker: NA
Text: scope of the Premises Standards reflects the

Speaker: NA
Text: overwhelming majority of evidence received.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee also recommended that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Premises Standards distinguish between new

Speaker: NA
Text: and existing class 1b buildings. These are

Speaker: NA
Text: bed and breakfast, eco-lodges and similar

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation. The committee found that

Speaker: NA
Text: the proportional cost increases imposed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Premises Standards are substantial in

Speaker: NA
Text: existing class 1b buildings. The committee

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore considers that the current threshold

Speaker: NA
Text: of four bedrooms or dwellings for accessibil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity in existing buildings is appropriate. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, the increases in costs flowing from ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessibility requirements in new class 1b

Speaker: NA
Text: buildings are much more modest. The com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee has therefore recommended that ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessibility requirements should be imposed

Speaker: NA
Text: on all new and purpose-built class 1b build-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings, regardless of the number of rooms or

Speaker: NA
Text: dwellings they provide.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given the long and protracted history of

Speaker: NA
Text: the development of the Premises Standards,

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee has recommended that they be

Speaker: NA
Text: finalised and introduced without delay.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, there are a number of areas where

Speaker: NA
Text: more research is required and other areas

Speaker: NA
Text: which are the result of previous negotiation

Speaker: NA
Text: and compromise. It is important to assess

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the standards, and certain provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: in the standards, are working to achieve their

Speaker: NA
Text: object and purpose. As a result, the commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee has made a detailed recommendation re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lating to the review of the Premises Stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dards after some years of operation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to thank the other members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee and the skilled and dedicated

Speaker: NA
Text: staff of the secretariat who worked on this

Speaker: NA
Text: important inquiry: Anna Dacre, Serica Mac-

Speaker: NA
Text: kay, Stephen Still and Sharon Bryant, some

Speaker: NA
Text: of whom are with us in the advisers box. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would also like to acknowledge the contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of all those who shared their time, ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pertise and experience with the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: during this inquiry. I have spoken of the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee's key recommendations for the

Speaker: NA
Text: draft Premises Standards. There are other

Speaker: NA
Text: relatively minor changes discussed in the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee's report.

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Text: Fisher) (8.58 pm)-I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to join the chairman of the commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee in supporting the report which has been

Speaker: NA
Text: tabled by the committee. Once again, it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: unanimous report of the House of Represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tatives Standing Committee on Legal and

Speaker: NA
Text: Constitutional Affairs. We covered a very

Speaker: NA
Text: important area in relation to disability. This

Speaker: NA
Text: committee seems to work very well together.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is obviously a cross-party committee, but

Speaker: NA
Text: we put our politics aside when we consider

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of reference referred to us by responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble ministers.

Speaker: NA
Text: With respect to the report being tabled to-

Speaker: NA
Text: day, the committee was asked by the Attor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney-General to consider and report on the

Speaker: NA
Text: draft Disability (Access to Premises-

Speaker: NA
Text: Buildings) Standards covering a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: areas including:

Speaker: NA
Text: the appropriateness and effectiveness of the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed Premises Standards in achieving their ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: jects;

Speaker: NA
Text: the interaction between the Premises Standards

Speaker: NA
Text: and existing regulatory schemes operating in state

Speaker: NA
Text: and territory jurisdictions, including the appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ateness and effectiveness of the proposed Model

Speaker: NA
Text: Process to Administer Building Access for People

Speaker: NA
Text: with Disability;

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the Premises Standards will have an un-

Speaker: NA
Text: justifiable impact on any particular sector or

Speaker: NA
Text: group within a sector; and

Speaker: NA
Text: any related matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee received a substantial number

Speaker: NA
Text: of recommendations from across the country

Speaker: NA
Text: when we advertised for views, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted to consult widely. In fact, we re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived 146 submissions. We held six public

Speaker: NA
Text: hearings and one roundtable hearing. The

Speaker: NA
Text: whole idea of following this process was to

Speaker: NA
Text: try to discern what the Australian community

Speaker: NA
Text: was telling the committee and the parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a result, following our deliberations

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee made 19 recommendations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee chairman outlined some of

Speaker: NA
Text: those recommendations but the first recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendation of the report is that Premises

Speaker: NA
Text: Standards should be introduced without de-

Speaker: NA
Text: lay. The Premises Standards has a protracted

Speaker: NA
Text: history and the committee considered that

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefits it will provide, such as certainty

Speaker: NA
Text: and accessibility, should not be delayed any

Speaker: NA
Text: further. That was particularly important.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the key recommendations relates

Speaker: NA
Text: to class 2 buildings, which are residential

Speaker: NA
Text: apartment buildings. At the moment the

Speaker: NA
Text: Premises Standards does not require these

Speaker: NA
Text: buildings to be accessible. The committee

Speaker: NA
Text: has recommended that the common areas of

Speaker: NA
Text: class 2 buildings should be within the scope

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Premises Standards-that is, they

Speaker: NA
Text: should be made accessible. There were a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of reasons for that and it was obvi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous to the committee that those reasons have

Speaker: NA
Text: veracity and that the recommendations ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to be implemented.

Speaker: NA
Text: Class 1b buildings were also the subject of move:

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation by the committee. Class 1b

Speaker: NA
Text: buildings include eco-lodges, bed and break-

Speaker: NA
Text: fasts and holiday cottages. At present, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Premises Standards only applies to class 1b

Speaker: NA
Text: buildings containing four or more bedrooms.

Speaker: NA
Text: This means that the accessibility require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments of the Premises Standards would not

Speaker: NA
Text: apply to these types of buildings that have

Speaker: NA
Text: fewer than four bedrooms. The committee

Speaker: NA
Text: recognises that many class 1b buildings are

Speaker: NA
Text: run by small businesses with limited re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sources. One of the things about disability

Speaker: NA
Text: and disability regulation is that there has to

Speaker: NA
Text: be a balance. On the one hand we have to

Speaker: NA
Text: give people access and we have to treat peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple with disability as being equal to other

Speaker: NA
Text: people in the community. On the other hand

Speaker: NA
Text: we are not really serving the interests of

Speaker: NA
Text: people with disability if we send small busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness to the wall in the process.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee found that it was clear that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is much less expensive to provide access

Speaker: NA
Text: when building a new bed and breakfast or

Speaker: NA
Text: holiday cottage. That is why the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: has recommended that the requirements for

Speaker: NA
Text: accessibility should be imposed on all new

Speaker: NA
Text: and purpose built class 1b buildings regard-

Speaker: NA
Text: less of the number of bedrooms they contain

Speaker: NA
Text: but that the proposed four-bedroom threshold

Speaker: NA
Text: should be maintained for existing buildings.

Speaker: NA
Text: There were a whole range of other matters

Speaker: NA
Text: in the report, and time will not allow me to

Speaker: NA
Text: cover them, but they include areas such as

Speaker: NA
Text: dignity, fit-out, and review. We also pointed

Speaker: NA
Text: out that lessons could be learnt from the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: view of the transport standards for which,

Speaker: NA
Text: seven years on, a final report has still not

Speaker: NA
Text: been released. (Time expired)

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Ms JA Saf-

Speaker: NA
Text: fin)-Does the member for Isaacs wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: move a motion in connection with the report

Speaker: NA
Text: to enable it to be debated on a later occasion?

Speaker: Mr DREYFUS
Text: Isaacs) (9.03 pm)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House take note of the report.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: In accor-

Speaker: NA
Text: dance with standing order 39 the debate is

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned. The resumption of the debate will

Speaker: NA
Text: be made an order of the day for the next sit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting.

Speaker: NA
Text: Legal and Constitutional Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Report: Referral to Main Committee

Speaker: Mr DREYFUS
Text: Isaacs) (9.04 pm)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the order of the day be referred to the Main

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee for debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: PRIVATE MEMBERS' BUSINESS

Speaker: NA
Text: Urban Planning

Speaker: Ms RISHWORTH
Text: Kingston) (9.04

Speaker: NA
Text: pm)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) recognises the importance of sound urban

Speaker: NA
Text: planning for the long-term future of our

Speaker: NA
Text: towns and cities;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) acknowledges that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) planning new communities and regener-

Speaker: NA
Text: ating older communities must maximise

Speaker: NA
Text: the ‘liveability' of these communities;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) local planning should ensure that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (i) local employment is available close

Speaker: NA
Text: to the local communities;

Speaker: NA
Text: (ii) transport options are well con-

Speaker: NA
Text: nected and integrated, including

Speaker: NA
Text: availability of public transport

Speaker: NA
Text: bike paths to reduce car depend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ency and promote healthy alterna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives such as walking and cycling;

Speaker: NA
Text: (iii) housing and local infrastructure are

Speaker: NA
Text: designed to minimise the environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental footprint, including options

Speaker: NA
Text: to promote water and energy con-

Speaker: NA
Text: servation;

Speaker: NA
Text: (iv) community services are available;

Speaker: NA
Text: and

Speaker: NA
Text: (v) local infrastructure facilitates a

Speaker: NA
Text: sense of community and place; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) urban planing of our communities must

Speaker: NA
Text: maximise the social, economic and envi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ronmental outcomes for local residents;

Speaker: NA
Text: and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) urges all levels of government, industry, as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sociated professions and the community to

Speaker: NA
Text: work together to ensure that we have healthy,

Speaker: NA
Text: happy, safe and sustainable communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: In moving this motion, I hope that the par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament will join me in recognising the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portance that sound urban planning has for

Speaker: NA
Text: the future health and wellbeing of our cities,

Speaker: NA
Text: local communities and us as individuals.

Speaker: NA
Text: With the population of our cities growing

Speaker: NA
Text: and with the increasing demand for housing,

Speaker: NA
Text: our communities are faced with a challenge

Speaker: NA
Text: of how we best manage this need. The solu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is much more complex than just allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing urban sprawl to continue. Rather, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: motion states, we must take the opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: to develop communities that maximise the

Speaker: NA
Text: social, economic and environmental out-

Speaker: NA
Text: comes for local residents. This reflects the

Speaker: NA
Text: Planning Institute of Australia's principles on

Speaker: NA
Text: urban growth management, which begin by

Speaker: NA
Text: declaring:

Speaker: NA
Text: Any pattern of urban growth has social, economic

Speaker: NA
Text: and environmental implications that need to be

Speaker: NA
Text: considered and balanced in deciding the most

Speaker: NA
Text: desirable urban growth solution.

Speaker: NA
Text: This means, as the motion states, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: the planning of our new communities should

Speaker: NA
Text: and consider the availability of local employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, allowing for people to spend less time

Speaker: NA
Text: travelling to and from work and more time

Speaker: NA
Text: with their families. The motion also makes

Speaker: NA
Text: clear that considerations regarding the health

Speaker: NA
Text: of residents are essential. If we look at the

Speaker: NA
Text: ABS statistics in 2007-08 we find that they

Speaker: NA
Text: show that 68 per cent of all Australian men

Speaker: NA
Text: and 55 per cent of all Australian women are

Speaker: NA
Text: overweight or obese. This is an increase of

Speaker: NA
Text: five per cent since 1995. We need to think

Speaker: NA
Text: about how our town planning may affect

Speaker: NA
Text: every policy area, including health, and how

Speaker: NA
Text: we might address this issue of obesity in our

Speaker: NA
Text: society. People can be healthier and have a

Speaker: NA
Text: more enjoyable life with the best opportuni-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties if they are at the forefront of planners'

Speaker: NA
Text: minds and considerations. This means ensur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing that transport options connect people to

Speaker: NA
Text: their places of employment and their places

Speaker: NA
Text: of leisure.

Speaker: NA
Text: Transport options should include clean

Speaker: NA
Text: and green modes such as bike paths and pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic transport. They also mean making it eas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ier for residents to go to local shops and ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices on foot. A well-designed community

Speaker: NA
Text: reduces its carbon footprint by reducing the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of kilometres driven by each of its

Speaker: NA
Text: residents, in turn allowing residents to spend

Speaker: NA
Text: more time enjoying the things they like to do

Speaker: NA
Text: around their local community. On top of this,

Speaker: NA
Text: if people are not driving they are more likely

Speaker: NA
Text: to be walking or riding their bikes, which, as

Speaker: NA
Text: I said earlier, is far better for their health and

Speaker: NA
Text: the environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: As our suburbs keep expanding, as they

Speaker: NA
Text: are likely to do in Kingston, it is vitally im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant that we think about what we would

Speaker: NA
Text: like our new suburbs to look like. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: that the RMIT University is currently under-

Speaker: NA
Text: taking a 10-year research program titled ‘Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: imagining the Australian suburb' and I look

Speaker: NA
Text: forward to reading more of their work, but

Speaker: NA
Text: we already know a number of key things.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our future suburbs need to be designed so

Speaker: NA
Text: that houses and communities minimise water

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption and to allow for the re-use of

Speaker: NA
Text: greywater and stormwater run-off. They need

Speaker: NA
Text: to be planned to minimise energy consump-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in terms of lighting and other energy

Speaker: NA
Text: use. There are many local communities who

Speaker: NA
Text: are already choosing to take the lead on this.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my electorate of Kingston, residents of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Aldinga eco-village have prided themselves

Speaker: NA
Text: on their houses and their common commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity areas being both water and energy effi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cient.

Speaker: NA
Text: To make sure that we promote the wellbe-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of our communities, we must plan to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide for community spaces, spaces for

Speaker: NA
Text: young and old sports teams to compete and

Speaker: NA
Text: places for families to enjoy and share activi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties with one another. Urban planning as an

Speaker: NA
Text: idea has a very short history, but if we do

Speaker: NA
Text: realise the ramifications of bad town plan-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning then our communities will not sustain

Speaker: NA
Text: us into the future. I commend the motion to

Speaker: NA
Text: the House. (Time expired)

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Ms JA Saf-

Speaker: NA
Text: fin)-Is the motion seconded?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Dreyfus-I second the motion and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: serve my right to speak.

Speaker: Mr BRIGGS
Text: Mayo) (9.09 pm)-I rise to

Speaker: NA
Text: join with the member for Kingston on this

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of town planning and support her mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I understand she comes from an area

Speaker: NA
Text: which has significant planning issues. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Onkaparinga council-the city of Onkapar-

Speaker: NA
Text: inga inches into my electorate-struggles

Speaker: NA
Text: with issues of planning in the southern sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: urbs of Adelaide.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are two issues I wish to deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: tonight with regard to planning. They relate

Speaker: NA
Text: to my electorate, Mount Barker and sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rounds, Littlehampton and Nairne in particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar. Some years ago, in 2000, the Heysen

Speaker: NA
Text: Tunnels opened in the Adelaide Hills on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Eastern Freeway, which opened up the

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide Hills significantly. That was the

Speaker: NA
Text: former member for Mayo's greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: achievement as the member for Mayo, he

Speaker: NA
Text: proudly boasts, and it certainly has created

Speaker: NA
Text: significant economic development in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide Hills, opened them up and changed

Speaker: NA
Text: the dynamic.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, it also brought an up-tick in

Speaker: NA
Text: growth-in Mount Barker, Nairne and Lit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tlehampton in particular-which has brought

Speaker: NA
Text: with it considerable difficulties, with lagging

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure, roads, services and water. Wa-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, of course, is a huge issue in my elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate. This has been a major concern for my

Speaker: NA
Text: constituents. It has a major impact on our

Speaker: NA
Text: ability to grow our own food. The Adelaide

Speaker: NA
Text: Hills produces not only some of the best

Speaker: NA
Text: wine in the country but also some of the best

Speaker: NA
Text: food. It is an important area for agriculture

Speaker: NA
Text: not and an area we must protect. With this fast

Speaker: NA
Text: expansion there has been a real impact on

Speaker: NA
Text: people's ability to continue to grow their

Speaker: NA
Text: own food. We have seen farmers tempted by

Speaker: NA
Text: offers from developers-as retirement pack-

Speaker: NA
Text: ages, I guess-for their land. This has cre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated an interesting dynamic, where there is

Speaker: NA
Text: now quite an anti-development feeling in

Speaker: NA
Text: Mount Barker and surrounding communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second issue I want to deal with is

Speaker: NA
Text: that of future growth in my area. It is an is-

Speaker: NA
Text: sue which the state member for Kavel, Mark

Speaker: NA
Text: Goldsworthy, has been following. I com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mend Mark for the work he has done. He

Speaker: NA
Text: recently surveyed the towns concerned, ask-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing people's opinions on this issue, and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived quite an extraordinary reaction, with

Speaker: NA
Text: about 1,500 survey respondents all very

Speaker: NA
Text: strongly raising concerns about the pace of

Speaker: NA
Text: development and the actions of the state

Speaker: NA
Text: government in relation to development. The

Speaker: NA
Text: state planning minister, Mr Holloway-who

Speaker: NA
Text: I think is an upper house member in the state

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament-said in our local newspaper, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Mount Barker Courier, which has also been

Speaker: NA
Text: pursuing this issue with some vigour, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: state government will have the final say

Speaker: NA
Text: about continuing development in the region.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is fair to say that that has enraged locals.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rather than locals and the council being con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered and their views taken into account,

Speaker: NA
Text: the state government is just going to bulldoze

Speaker: NA
Text: its way through ordinary people and their

Speaker: NA
Text: views. That has caused an enormous amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of concern in my electorate. Development is

Speaker: NA
Text: a very contentious issue, particularly as it

Speaker: NA
Text: impacts on agricultural land, services,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether we have enough police, hospitals,

Speaker: NA
Text: health care and whether the roads are up to

Speaker: NA
Text: standard. Mount Barker is a country town

Speaker: NA
Text: that is now being turned into a dormitory

Speaker: NA
Text: suburb.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a big issue, and I was disappointed

Speaker: NA
Text: with the action of the state government. I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that they will reconsider the part of

Speaker: NA
Text: their plan-I think it is a 20-year plan-

Speaker: NA
Text: where they plan for Mount Barker, Little-

Speaker: NA
Text: hampton and Nairne to grow significantly.

Speaker: NA
Text: They should reconsider that. The people in

Speaker: NA
Text: my area want them to do so. What the state

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor minister said and did has been very

Speaker: NA
Text: unpopular. I think people accept that bull-

Speaker: NA
Text: dozers are needed for development but they

Speaker: NA
Text: will not accept their opinion being bulldozed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the state Labor government. They need to

Speaker: NA
Text: reconsider this quickly. I know it is not an

Speaker: NA
Text: area that state Labor has traditionally put

Speaker: NA
Text: much emphasis on, up around Mount Barker,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it should not be treated as a second rate

Speaker: NA
Text: area because politically it is not important; it

Speaker: NA
Text: is very important to the Adelaide Hills and to

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia. The Adelaide Hills retains a

Speaker: NA
Text: beauty and it should not just be turned into

Speaker: NA
Text: an outer dormitory suburb. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr DREYFUS
Text: Isaacs) (9.15 pm)-As

Speaker: NA
Text: someone who is deeply interested in the fu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture of our cities, and who believes that the

Speaker: NA
Text: forms of our cities play a critical role in the

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of lives we are able to lead, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to support this motion. The forms

Speaker: NA
Text: our cities take are important. They have a

Speaker: NA
Text: profound influence on our economic prosper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity, on the impact we have on our unique

Speaker: NA
Text: environment, on the level of social exclusion

Speaker: NA
Text: and inequality experienced in our communi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties and on the quality of life Australians and

Speaker: NA
Text: their families are able to enjoy. Well-thought-

Speaker: NA
Text: out urban planning fosters the free flow of

Speaker: NA
Text: people and goods through major areas of

Speaker: NA
Text: economic activity and service delivery. Good

Speaker: NA
Text: urban planning connects communities with

Speaker: NA
Text: the labour markets, educational institutions

Speaker: NA
Text: and community networks needed in order for

Speaker: NA
Text: them to flourish.

Speaker: NA
Text: The great majority of Australians live in

Speaker: NA
Text: our major cities. You need only look to

Speaker: NA
Text: greater Melbourne or south-east Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: to see the rapid expansion of our urban pe-

Speaker: NA
Text: riphery. Our local community in my elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate of Isaacs, in Melbourne's south-east

Speaker: NA
Text: growth corridor, is part of that expansion. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have young families looking for affordable

Speaker: NA
Text: low-density housing in new estates in Keys-

Speaker: NA
Text: borough, Sandhurst, Carrum Downs and

Speaker: NA
Text: Skye. We have retirees moving from family

Speaker: NA
Text: homes to smaller properties in newer, denser

Speaker: NA
Text: developments by the beach in Chelsea, Car-

Speaker: NA
Text: rum and Mentone. We have the growing in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustrial areas in Dandenong South and Brae-

Speaker: NA
Text: side. And in the middle of my electorate we

Speaker: NA
Text: have a large green wedge. Previous far-

Speaker: NA
Text: sighted planning has preserved this green

Speaker: NA
Text: wedge, which provides our community with

Speaker: NA
Text: a semirural area close to home.

Speaker: NA
Text: Urban policy in growth areas like my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate demands careful planning for the

Speaker: NA
Text: needs of a community which is as diverse in

Speaker: NA
Text: age and occupation as it is in income and

Speaker: NA
Text: cultural heritage. Urban policy permeates

Speaker: NA
Text: every level of government involvement in

Speaker: NA
Text: public life. More than most other areas of

Speaker: NA
Text: policy, urban planning calls for an active role

Speaker: NA
Text: from government because we have a collec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive interest in the form of our cities. All

Speaker: NA
Text: governments have legitimate policy objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives in areas like economic prosperity,

Speaker: NA
Text: justice and environmental stability. These

Speaker: NA
Text: objectives can be facilitated by the structure

Speaker: NA
Text: of our cities or they can be ignored. Deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions about industry and innovation, migra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, public transport, housing and infrastrucfederal

Speaker: NA
Text: ture all affect the form and function of our

Speaker: NA
Text: cities. To act as if urban planning is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: federal issue does not lessen its federal im-

Speaker: NA
Text: plications; it simply results in poor policy

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes. Government must be involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: and must lead the planning of our cities. This

Speaker: NA
Text: extends to the federal government as well as

Speaker: NA
Text: to state and local governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Infrastructure, Transport,

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional Development and Local Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has created a major cities unit in his

Speaker: NA
Text: department. This major cities unit enables

Speaker: NA
Text: cities and agencies responsible for urban is-

Speaker: NA
Text: sues to have a single point of contact within

Speaker: NA
Text: the federal government. It is appalling that,

Speaker: NA
Text: for almost 12 years under the previous gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment, Australia had no Minister for Hous-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and no major cities strategy. We need to

Speaker: NA
Text: remember that the Labor government that

Speaker: NA
Text: left office in 1996 had created a Better Cities

Speaker: NA
Text: program and a Better Cities strategy, the ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: jective of which was to address a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: challenges facing Australian cities. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: included rapid growth and a demand for in-

Speaker: NA
Text: frastructure investment on the fringes of ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: jor cities, loss of population and under-use

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities and services in established urban

Speaker: NA
Text: areas and the increasing social, environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental and economic cost of poorly planned

Speaker: NA
Text: and managed cities. After the 12 years of

Speaker: NA
Text: inaction of the Howard government these are

Speaker: NA
Text: still among the challenges of urban planning

Speaker: NA
Text: that face Australia today.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Rudd government is responding to

Speaker: NA
Text: these challenges through the major cities unit

Speaker: NA
Text: and a coordinated whole-of-government ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach to urban planning. Given the signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cance of urban planning to our economic

Speaker: NA
Text: prosperity and social structure, the future of

Speaker: NA
Text: social our cities demands national leadership,

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Rudd government is providing. I

Speaker: NA
Text: look forward, in the coming years, to seeing

Speaker: NA
Text: more being done at a federal level in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to the urban fabric of our cities, because the

Speaker: NA
Text: government is in the position of be-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing able to provide the leadership which is

Speaker: NA
Text: needed, the leadership that was sorely lack-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing during the whole of the period of the

Speaker: NA
Text: former Howard government.

Speaker: Mr BILSON
Text: Dunkley) (9.20 pm)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: rise to support the motion and the sentiment

Speaker: NA
Text: that has been put forward by the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingston and acknowledge her interest in

Speaker: NA
Text: this area. I do say, though, that sentiment is

Speaker: NA
Text: no substitute for hard work and that words

Speaker: NA
Text: are no substitute for even harder work. And

Speaker: NA
Text: this area of public policy requires not only a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot of hard work but very extensive collabo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ration, because so many of the influences on

Speaker: NA
Text: successful cities are dispersed right across

Speaker: NA
Text: multiple levels of government-and, more

Speaker: NA
Text: importantly, across all the consumers, home

Speaker: NA
Text: purchasers, developers and investors, all

Speaker: NA
Text: looking at their interests as we in this na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional parliament look at the national interest.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is not something new, though. This

Speaker: NA
Text: issue has been with us for some time. The

Speaker: NA
Text: previous government certainly did more than

Speaker: NA
Text: apprise itself of these concerns. It set about

Speaker: NA
Text: doing something about them. In fact, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: of 2003-04 budget there was an urban environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment initiative around sustainable cities. It

Speaker: NA
Text: touched on a number of issues concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: water quality, the information available

Speaker: NA
Text: within the community, air quality, renewable

Speaker: NA
Text: energy, waste management, the Year of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Built Environment, green buildings, a green

Speaker: NA
Text: car rating scheme, cycling facilities, air qual-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity research, photovoltaic rebate schemes,

Speaker: NA
Text: chemical monitoring database, the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Pollutant Inventory-just to name a few. So

Speaker: NA
Text: this is not something that is particularly new.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it went further. I was pleased to chair

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives Standing

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on Environment and Heritage

Speaker: NA
Text: and undertake what was then viewed as a

Speaker: NA
Text: very seminal piece of research and a piece of

Speaker: NA
Text: important national leadership with the sus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainable cities inquiry. This committee report

Speaker: NA
Text: was born out of my conviction, and that of

Speaker: NA
Text: the coalition government's side of the par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament, that the cities that we have may not

Speaker: NA
Text: be directly a consequence of federal gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment policy but, when they do not work

Speaker: NA
Text: well, it lands on the federal government to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide the remedies. The social hardship,

Speaker: NA
Text: the economic dislocation, the enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: commuter times, the cost in terms of envi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ronment and in terms of family pressure, the

Speaker: NA
Text: economic concerns and the vulnerability of

Speaker: NA
Text: people to movement in petrol prices and the

Speaker: NA
Text: like all come home to the federal govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: With that in mind we thought, ‘What can

Speaker: NA
Text: we do now to outline a template for more

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainable cities into the future,' and this

Speaker: NA
Text: report did that. We led that debate and it

Speaker: NA
Text: welcomed unanimously right across the

Speaker: NA
Text: community and in a bipartisan sense. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: promoted into the ministry and did not have

Speaker: NA
Text: the privilege of finishing the final few paraplanning

Speaker: NA
Text: graphs-my friend and colleague Dr Mal

Speaker: NA
Text: Washer had that honour and distinction-but

Speaker: NA
Text: the report is still very much true to the work

Speaker: NA
Text: that we undertook. It talked about the key

Speaker: NA
Text: things that we need to look at in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainability: to recognise that more than

Speaker: NA
Text: three-quarters of GDP-the economic activ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity in Australia-happens in our cities; that

Speaker: NA
Text: the vast proportion of the population lives

Speaker: NA
Text: our cites; and to recognise the pressure on

Speaker: NA
Text: our environment, our consumption of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sources and our future living standards. All

Speaker: NA
Text: these are interwoven in our cities.

Speaker: NA
Text: The report identified a range of areas of

Speaker: NA
Text: action about urban development and the role

Speaker: NA
Text: that the federal government could play in

Speaker: NA
Text: urban policy in trying to make sure that all

Speaker: NA
Text: decision making and funding was aligned to

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainability and better city objectives. It

Speaker: NA
Text: also looked at settlement patterns: what was

Speaker: NA
Text: happening in terms of dwelling sizes; the

Speaker: NA
Text: size of households; and the different models

Speaker: NA
Text: that were developing around the place and

Speaker: NA
Text: how they could be handled in a development

Speaker: NA
Text: assessment process that did not seek to tell

Speaker: NA
Text: people how and where they should live-

Speaker: NA
Text: because that would be destined to fail-but

Speaker: NA
Text: would at least make it easier and more con-

Speaker: NA
Text: venient for people to live with amenity and

Speaker: NA
Text: lifestyle and with ready access to those im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant elements of their lives that they

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted to be near to, and if they were not

Speaker: NA
Text: they would commute.

Speaker: NA
Text: A long time ago I drove a Mazda 808 su-

Speaker: NA
Text: per deluxe coupe, burnt orange-a great ve-

Speaker: NA
Text: hicle for its time-and at around 19 I

Speaker: NA
Text: stopped driving for pleasure and for the fun

Speaker: NA
Text: of it and started driving because I had to

Speaker: NA
Text: travel somewhere. I had a transport task. The

Speaker: NA
Text: mobility requirement was to move from

Speaker: NA
Text: was where I lived, to where I worked, to where I

Speaker: NA
Text: studied, to where I played sport and to where

Speaker: NA
Text: I undertook leisure activities. The key about

Speaker: NA
Text: more sustainable cities is not just better

Speaker: NA
Text: and better urban land use but it is

Speaker: NA
Text: also about integrating all of those areas of

Speaker: NA
Text: policy so that those key elements of people's

Speaker: NA
Text: lives are more within reach. We outlined an

Speaker: NA
Text: agenda for that in the sustainability report,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I do not have the time to go through that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was pleased that our leader, Malcolm

Speaker: NA
Text: Turnbull, was a part of that committee in its

Speaker: NA
Text: later incarnations and continues to highlight

Speaker: NA
Text: in the importance of these issues. But I am

Speaker: NA
Text: drawn to something that Victorian senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Kim Carr said. He said that if you do not

Speaker: NA
Text: have a minister for cities and a minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: urban development you are not for real. La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor does not have a minister for cities and it

Speaker: NA
Text: does not have a minister for urban develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. The opposition has a shadow minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for sustainable development and cities and,

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Kim Carr benchmark, the opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: is far more serious about taking the impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant action, not just recognising the problems

Speaker: NA
Text: and the challenges but putting in place the

Speaker: NA
Text: sound public policy. I fear that this will

Speaker: NA
Text: be an area where Labor quickly identifies

Speaker: NA
Text: and secures the political opportunities and

Speaker: NA
Text: the sound bytes and leaves the sound public

Speaker: NA
Text: policy and hard work to others. The coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: is up to that task; we have the policies and

Speaker: NA
Text: they will be revealed-(Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ZAPPIA
Text: Makin) (9.25 pm)-I begin

Speaker: NA
Text: by commending the member for Kingston

Speaker: NA
Text: for bringing this matter to the attention of

Speaker: NA
Text: House. I certainly will not use up the few

Speaker: NA
Text: minutes that I have responding to everything

Speaker: NA
Text: that was said by members opposite, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: noticed the member for Dunkley talked

Speaker: NA
Text: about the record of this government when it

Speaker: NA
Text: comes urban planning and I think it is like

Speaker: NA
Text: chalk and cheese when you compare it with

Speaker: NA
Text: the previous government. I want to specifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally respond to something the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Mayo said when he made some references to

Speaker: NA
Text: the state planning minister in South Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia, the Hon. Paul Holloway. Paul Holloway

Speaker: NA
Text: is in fact a very highly regarded and very

Speaker: NA
Text: competent planning minister and one who is

Speaker: NA
Text: held in the utmost respect by most of the

Speaker: NA
Text: developers and the people involved in plan-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning in South Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I should also say that when it comes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hills Face area of South Australia, which is a

Speaker: NA
Text: very unique area and one that is of concern

Speaker: NA
Text: to a lot of South Australians, it was in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: Jay Wetherill, the planning minister prior to

Speaker: NA
Text: Paul Holloway, who implemented a freeze

Speaker: NA
Text: on planning and development in the Hills

Speaker: NA
Text: Face zone until a comprehensive community

Speaker: NA
Text: plan was developed for all of the Hills Face

Speaker: NA
Text: area. So, again, when it came to protecting

Speaker: NA
Text: our very valuable Hills Face area, it took a

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor government in South Australia to do

Speaker: NA
Text: that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to make a number of observa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions with respect to this resolution. The first

Speaker: NA
Text: is that good planning is often taken for

Speaker: NA
Text: granted and sufficient recognition is not

Speaker: NA
Text: given to the importance that it plays in the

Speaker: NA
Text: again lives of people. Planning can have a very

Speaker: NA
Text: profound effect on the quality of the lives of

Speaker: NA
Text: people who live in any community, because

Speaker: NA
Text: that is where they spend their lives, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: where they interact with others and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: where their children attend school, sport and

Speaker: NA
Text: other activities. As a consequence, a person's

Speaker: NA
Text: life is very much influenced by the people

Speaker: NA
Text: they associate with. Local communities ef-

Speaker: NA
Text: the fectively become an extension of one's own

Speaker: NA
Text: home. You can often become very attached

Speaker: NA
Text: to your local community, as we see fre-

Speaker: NA
Text: quently from the fact that people will live in

Speaker: NA
Text: the same area for pretty much all of their

Speaker: NA
Text: lives. And if you look at the statistics you

Speaker: NA
Text: will see that of those people who do move

Speaker: NA
Text: the majority do not move very far away from

Speaker: NA
Text: the original suburban area or community

Speaker: NA
Text: they grew up in. So it is a fact of life that the

Speaker: NA
Text: local community and the planning that goes

Speaker: NA
Text: into it can truly affect the quality of a per-

Speaker: NA
Text: son's life and the opportunities that are pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented to them. Sometimes, regrettably, as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of poor planning rather than a lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities, a person will find themselves

Speaker: NA
Text: in a situation where they are confronted by

Speaker: NA
Text: some very negative forces. Time will not

Speaker: NA
Text: permit me to elaborate on that but perhaps on

Speaker: NA
Text: another occasion I will.

Speaker: NA
Text: So good local area planning does make a

Speaker: NA
Text: drastic difference to the individual lives of

Speaker: NA
Text: people, to the environment, which we have

Speaker: NA
Text: heard other speakers talk about, and to the

Speaker: NA
Text: economic opportunities presented both to the

Speaker: NA
Text: individual and to the community as a whole.

Speaker: NA
Text: Critically, the areas of health and education

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes can very much become reliant on

Speaker: NA
Text: good planning and good development. In

Speaker: NA
Text: recent times the term ‘sustainable communi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties' has often been used; it is an expression

Speaker: NA
Text: you hear quite frequently when you talk to

Speaker: NA
Text: planners. Conversely, governments around

Speaker: NA
Text: the world are now expending large sums of

Speaker: NA
Text: money rectifying and rebuilding poorly

Speaker: NA
Text: planned communities of earlier years. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have some good examples of that in South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, where the state government today

Speaker: NA
Text: is having to expend hundred of millions of

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars in order to rectify and rebuild com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munities that were built some 50 years ago

Speaker: NA
Text: and not properly planned out.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the sad things that I hear too often

Speaker: NA
Text: is that there ought to be more land released

Speaker: NA
Text: for the purpose of building new homes. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: a view promoted by a number of housing

Speaker: NA
Text: developers. The problem with that is that

Speaker: NA
Text: housing developers may be very good at

Speaker: NA
Text: building houses but they are not necessarily

Speaker: NA
Text: so good at building communities, and there

Speaker: NA
Text: is a difference. Having a nice house without

Speaker: NA
Text: access to schools, shops, hospitals, sports

Speaker: NA
Text: clubs, parks, community hubs, universities,

Speaker: NA
Text: workplaces and so on can very much add to

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost of living and can lead to a much

Speaker: NA
Text: poorer quality of life for those people who

Speaker: NA
Text: live there. It is true that not all services

Speaker: NA
Text: ever be available in every community. But

Speaker: NA
Text: that is why transport systems have to be de-

Speaker: NA
Text: signed from the very outset. However, I ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cept that long-term area planning can never

Speaker: NA
Text: be perfect. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! It being 9.30

Speaker: NA
Text: pm, I propose the question:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rural Fire Service Awards

Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Text: Paterson) (9.30 pm)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Tonight I rise to inform this House that on

Speaker: NA
Text: Saturday, 30 May, I attended a very special

Speaker: NA
Text: ceremony at the Bulahdelah Golf Club rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ognising the outstanding achievement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Great Lakes District bri-

Speaker: NA
Text: gades of the Rural Fire Service. I joined with

Speaker: NA
Text: former commissioner the Hon. Phil Koper-

Speaker: NA
Text: berg; current Rural Fire Service Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner Shane Fitzsimmons; Chief Superin-

Speaker: NA
Text: tendent Steve Yorke; Superintendent Kam

Speaker: NA
Text: Baker; Inspector Cecil Miller; and many

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the local brigades and their

Speaker: NA
Text: families to recognise these local heroes. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Lakes District is made up of 23 bri-

Speaker: NA
Text: gades comprising 687 members, with 46 fire-

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting vehicles and two support vehicles.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Great Lakes District brigades attended

Speaker: NA
Text: 283 incidents in 2008 and 121 incidents to

Speaker: NA
Text: date in 2009, with significant out of area as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sistance in the recent tragic bushfires in Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of the event was to present

Speaker: NA
Text: nine National Medals, two First Clasp

Speaker: NA
Text: Awards, two Second Clasp Awards, one

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Clasp Award, 13 15-year long-service

Speaker: NA
Text: medals and 16 long-service awards to mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the Great Lakes District Rural Fire

Speaker: NA
Text: Service. The national medal is presented to

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the rural fire service in recogni-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of their years of diligent service that

Speaker: NA
Text: have gone above and beyond what is ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pected of active members within their bri-

Speaker: NA
Text: can gade. Long-service awards are presented to

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Rural Fire Service in recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nition of their years of active service.

Speaker: NA
Text: The recipients were Arthur Skinner, cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rently a member of the Tuncurry Catering

Speaker: NA
Text: Brigade, who received the National Medal

Speaker: NA
Text: and the First, Second and Third Clasp

Speaker: NA
Text: Awards for 59 years service; Norman Cun-

Speaker: NA
Text: ningham, currently a member of the Minim-

Speaker: NA
Text: bah Brigade, who received the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Medal and the Second Clasp Award for 46

Speaker: NA
Text: years service; Neal Cook, who received the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Medal for 25 years service as a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the North Arm Cove Brigade;

Speaker: NA
Text: Kevin Johnson, who received the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Medal and the 15-year long-service award

Speaker: NA
Text: for 23 years service as a member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minimbah Brigade; Glyn Davies, who re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived the National Medal for 19 years ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice as a member of the Pacific Palms and

Speaker: NA
Text: Bungwahl Brigades; Brent Williams, who

Speaker: NA
Text: received the National Medal, the First Clasp

Speaker: NA
Text: Award and the 15-year long-service award

Speaker: NA
Text: for 18 years service as a member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minimbah Brigade; Dennis Webb, who re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived the National Medal and 15-year long-

Speaker: NA
Text: service award for 17 years service as

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of the Minimbah Brigade; Gladys Pearce,

Speaker: NA
Text: currently a member of the Great Lakes

Speaker: NA
Text: Communications Brigade, who received the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Medal for 17 years service; Phil

Speaker: NA
Text: MCAsey, who received the National Medal

Speaker: NA
Text: and 15-year long-service award for 16 years

Speaker: NA
Text: service as a member of the Green Point Bri-

Speaker: NA
Text: gade; Phil Hughes, who received the 15-year

Speaker: NA
Text: long-service award for 25 years service as a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the North Arm Cove Point Bri-

Speaker: NA
Text: gade; Athol Blanch, who received the 15-

Speaker: NA
Text: year long-service award for 21 years service

Speaker: NA
Text: as a member of the Limeburners Creek Bri-

Speaker: NA
Text: gade; Max Mehan, who received the 15-year

Speaker: NA
Text: long-service award for 21 years service as a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Limeburners Creek Brigade;

Speaker: NA
Text: Mark Rimmer, who received the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Medal and 15-year long-service award for 20

Speaker: NA
Text: years service as a member of the Minimbah

Speaker: NA
Text: Brigade; Paul Murrell, who received the 15-

Speaker: NA
Text: year long-service award for 20 years services

Speaker: NA
Text: as a member of the Green Point Brigade;

Speaker: NA
Text: Robert MCMaster, who received the 15-year

Speaker: NA
Text: long-service award for 18 years service as a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Minimbah Brigade; Kim

Speaker: NA
Text: MCDermott, who received the 15-year long-

Speaker: NA
Text: service award for 17 years service as a mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of the Monkerai Brigade; Joe Karsen-

Speaker: NA
Text: barg, who received 15-year long-service

Speaker: NA
Text: award for 17 years service as a member of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minimbah Brigade; Dennis Webb, who

Speaker: NA
Text: received the 15-year long-service award for

Speaker: NA
Text: 17 years service as a member of the Minim-

Speaker: NA
Text: bah Brigade; Mark Johnson, who received

Speaker: NA
Text: the 15-year long-service award for 15 years

Speaker: NA
Text: service as a member of the Minimbah Bri-

Speaker: NA
Text: gade; John Murray, who received the 25-year

Speaker: NA
Text: long-service award for 31 years service as a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Limeburners Creek Brigade;

Speaker: NA
Text: Alan Witt, who received the 25-year long-

Speaker: NA
Text: service award for 31 years service as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Limeburners Creek Brigade; and Lowell

Speaker: NA
Text: Reardon, who received the 25-year long-

Speaker: NA
Text: service award for 27 years service as a mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: a mem- ber of the Green Point Brigade.

Speaker: NA
Text: These fine Australians and their fellow

Speaker: NA
Text: brigade members are our heroes. At a mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's notice, they regularly put their lives

Speaker: NA
Text: on the line to help people who they may not

Speaker: NA
Text: know to defend and save property that they

Speaker: NA
Text: do not own for a common bond that is

Speaker: NA
Text: uniquely Australian. This has been borne out

Speaker: NA
Text: in fighting fires not just across the region and

Speaker: NA
Text: not just across the state of New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: but indeed across all of Australia. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: not paid for their personal sacrifices, but they

Speaker: NA
Text: are truly respected and admired for them. To

Speaker: NA
Text: them and their families I, on behalf of this

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament, say thank you on a job well

Speaker: NA
Text: done. You serve your community and you

Speaker: NA
Text: serve your nation very well indeed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Delegation to Dharamsala

Speaker: Mr DANBY
Text: Melbourne Ports) (9.34

Speaker: NA
Text: pm)-At the end of next week when the

Speaker: NA
Text: House rises for the winter break, I will have

Speaker: NA
Text: the great privilege of leading the first Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian parliamentary delegation to Dharamsala,

Speaker: NA
Text: in India. This is the seat of the Tibetan gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment in exile, headed by His Holiness the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dalai Lama, who will be celebrating his 74th

Speaker: NA
Text: birthday. The delegation will consist of me,

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Fremantle, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Fisher, Senator Lud-

Speaker: NA
Text: lam, Senator Hanson-Young and Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Xenophon. I must stress at the outset that this

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be an official parliamentary delega-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. We will not be representing the parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, the government, the opposition or even

Speaker: NA
Text: our political parties. The all party parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary group for Tibet, which I chair, is not

Speaker: NA
Text: even an official parliamentary group. In a

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentary sense, we will be representing

Speaker: NA
Text: only ourselves. But we will also be repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: senting a very large number of Australians of

Speaker: NA
Text: all political persuasions who care about the

Speaker: NA
Text: freedom and human rights of oppressed na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionalities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ever since the Chinese invasion of 1950,

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of Tibet have been denied not

Speaker: NA
Text: only their national independence but also the

Speaker: NA
Text: freedom to practise their culture and relig-

Speaker: NA
Text: ion-although I acknowledge that the situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion has improved somewhat since the dark

Speaker: NA
Text: days of the Cultural Revolution in China.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet, as we saw during the extensive distur-

Speaker: NA
Text: bances in Tibet last year, the people of that

Speaker: NA
Text: country-particularly the younger genera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion-have not lost their desire for national

Speaker: NA
Text: and personal freedom. It is estimated that

Speaker: NA
Text: there are up to 500,000 Chinese troops in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tibet, a region with a Tibetan population of

Speaker: NA
Text: only two million people-although there are

Speaker: NA
Text: five million Tibetans who live in wider areas

Speaker: NA
Text: of the People's Republic of China. There has

Speaker: NA
Text: been a systematic effort to settle Tibet with

Speaker: NA
Text: Han Chinese migrants in the hope of swamp-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Tibetans and extinguishing their cul-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Dharamsala, we will be meeting with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Dalai Lama, who is recognised by all

Speaker: NA
Text: Tibetans, inside and outside Tibet, as their

Speaker: NA
Text: national and spiritual leader. We will also

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting Professor Samdong Rinpoche, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister of the Tibetan government in

Speaker: NA
Text: exile, who was elected by the world commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity of Tibetans in exile.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that the Chinese Embassy in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia told the Age last week that they had

Speaker: NA
Text: opposed our delegation's visit to Dharamsala

Speaker: NA
Text: as it would be an interference in Chinese

Speaker: NA
Text: sovereignty because we are supporting Ti-

Speaker: NA
Text: betan independence. Let me say to this

Speaker: NA
Text: House, as I have said to successive Chinese

Speaker: NA
Text: ambassadors: I am not anti China. This dele-

Speaker: NA
Text: gation's visit to India is in no way an act

Speaker: NA
Text: hostility towards China. I wish nothing but

Speaker: NA
Text: happiness and prosperity for the great Chi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nese people. But, just as the Chinese people

Speaker: NA
Text: fought for many decades to free their country

Speaker: NA
Text: of foreign invaders and to re-establish their

Speaker: NA
Text: sovereignty, I hope our Chinese friends

Speaker: NA
Text: would understand that the people of Tibet

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to do the same for their country. There

Speaker: NA
Text: are 1.2 billion people in China. I find it hard

Speaker: NA
Text: to understand why they feel it necessary to

Speaker: NA
Text: deny self-government to a minority popula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of only five million in a remote area of

Speaker: NA
Text: their vast country. Many Chinese feel that

Speaker: NA
Text: they liberated Tibet from feudalism and they

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot understand why the Tibetans are not

Speaker: NA
Text: grateful for that. I am not here to defend the

Speaker: NA
Text: system that operated before 1950, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: Chinese themselves do not welcome changes

Speaker: NA
Text: brought to China by foreigners, even if those

Speaker: NA
Text: foreigners are well intentioned.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I was at university, I studied Marx-

Speaker: NA
Text: ism under a great professor, Dr Frank

Speaker: NA
Text: Knopfelmacher, who insisted that we read

Speaker: NA
Text: Das Kapital and the even more turgid Die

Speaker: NA
Text: Grundrisse. In those studies I learnt that one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the basic tenets of Marxism-Leninism is

Speaker: NA
Text: atheism, which is the official state ideology

Speaker: NA
Text: of China. It is very odd that a country with

Speaker: NA
Text: such an ideology would insist on appointing

Speaker: NA
Text: the spiritual second-in-command of the Dalai

Speaker: NA
Text: be Lama's religion. The Panchen Lama-the

Speaker: NA
Text: authentic one-was ‘disappeared' by agents

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Beijing regime when he was five years

Speaker: NA
Text: old. That is now many years ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Dalai Lama has said that he accepts

Speaker: NA
Text: the Chinese assertion that China has histori-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally exercised sovereignty over Tibet-

Speaker: NA
Text: although I note in passing that many histori-

Speaker: NA
Text: ans in Tibet dispute this-and that he is will-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to accept the same autonomous status

Speaker: NA
Text: that China has accepted for Hong Kong and

Speaker: NA
Text: Macau. I have to say that this seems a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: markably moderate position, given the sad

Speaker: NA
Text: of history of oppression in Tibet since 1950. I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that the Chinese leadership will eventu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally have the wisdom to accept the Dalai

Speaker: NA
Text: Lama's proposal, although I do not expect it

Speaker: NA
Text: to happen soon.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some people say to me that Tibet is a lost

Speaker: NA
Text: cause. My reply is that I am old enough to

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen the fall of the Berlin Wall, the end

Speaker: NA
Text: of apartheid, the demise of fascism in Spain

Speaker: NA
Text: and Communism in the Soviet Union and the

Speaker: NA
Text: establishment of independence in East

Speaker: NA
Text: Timor. I do not believe that any just cause is

Speaker: NA
Text: truly lost. The cause of the people of Tibet is

Speaker: NA
Text: a just case and one that I am proud to sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hinkler Electorate: Hervey Bay

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Text: Hinkler) (9.39 pm)-

Speaker: NA
Text: During the 2007 election, I campaigned on a

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to secure $1.5 million to help

Speaker: NA
Text: build the much needed community centre for

Speaker: NA
Text: the fast growing city of Hervey Bay in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate. If ever there was a project that

Speaker: NA
Text: cried out to heaven for completion, it is this

Speaker: NA
Text: one. It is hard to believe that a city

Speaker: NA
Text: people does not already have a centre, but

Speaker: NA
Text: new infrastructure is actually the biggest so-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial challenge that Hervey Bay faces at the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment. It has grown like topsy and contin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ues to grow. Assistance from state and fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral governments with infrastructure is criti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal. Unfortunately, Labor failed to match my

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to the project, and it seems that

Speaker: NA
Text: the government has followed through by re-

Speaker: NA
Text: jecting a regional community and local infra-

Speaker: NA
Text: structure program funding application for

Speaker: NA
Text: this project. In fact, my opponent at the last

Speaker: NA
Text: federal election would not even commit to it.

Speaker: NA
Text: On Friday, 22 May, I heard from the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ponents, who were absolutely devastated that

Speaker: NA
Text: their high-quality application had been

Speaker: NA
Text: knocked back by the federal government.

Speaker: NA
Text: This project has a considerable history. Prior

Speaker: NA
Text: to the local government amalgamations in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland, Hervey Bay City Council com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitted $1 million and land to the project-a

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment later reaffirmed by the newly

Speaker: NA
Text: amalgamated Fraser Coast Regional Council.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Queensland government also made $1.5

Speaker: NA
Text: million available to the project, and many

Speaker: NA
Text: service clubs in town have been actively

Speaker: NA
Text: fundraising for it. All that was missing was

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth contribution under the

Speaker: NA
Text: RLCIP criteria. The project fitted that criteria

Speaker: NA
Text: beautifully. The community centre would

Speaker: NA
Text: have been a hub for a number of social ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices for children and youth, as well as coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: selling, mentoring and referral services and

Speaker: NA
Text: other information outlets. These would be

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered by semi-government organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: and NGOs. The proponents had already de-

Speaker: NA
Text: veloped a plan for construction, costs were

Speaker: NA
Text: completed and two weeks ago the building

Speaker: NA
Text: permit was lodged. This is a shovel-ready

Speaker: NA
Text: project. It is an environmentally keen project

Speaker: NA
Text: with a six-star rating. This would have

Speaker: NA
Text: helped to create jobs in Hervey Bay while

Speaker: NA
Text: also providing much needed civic infrastruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture. It has now been left high and dry due to

Speaker: NA
Text: of 50,000 some bureaucratic decision.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we talk about vibrant regional

Speaker: NA
Text: communities, of course a robust local com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity is important. But what is also impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant in towns and cities are good places for

Speaker: NA
Text: people to live, where residents can enjoy

Speaker: NA
Text: quality of life and, if they fall into difficul-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties, be referred to proper services. One thing

Speaker: NA
Text: that is desperately needed in Hervey Bay is a

Speaker: NA
Text: community centre-a place where people

Speaker: NA
Text: can come together for assistance, support and

Speaker: NA
Text: guidance. I have spoken to a number of peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple about the funding knock-back and have

Speaker: NA
Text: given them an assurance that I will seek fur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ther information from the minister and the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentary secretary and that I will con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue to fight to get Commonwealth funding.

Speaker: NA
Text: I put on the record the position that the

Speaker: NA
Text: community finds itself in, thanks to this de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cision. These words are direct quotes from a

Speaker: NA
Text: local resident-they are not mine. They

Speaker: NA
Text: state:

Speaker: NA
Text: Presently, services in our community are deliv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ered in a hodge-podge of inaccessible facilities,

Speaker: NA
Text: some of which are of asbestos laden.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some people have access to emergency relief and

Speaker: NA
Text: others confidential services in parking lots, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause they cannot fiscally get into a facility.

Speaker: NA
Text: services are forced to pay commercial scale rents,

Speaker: NA
Text: directly impacting on the level of service avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to the homeless, the aged, challenged fami-

Speaker: NA
Text: lies and other targeted consumers.

Speaker: NA
Text: In a community that has almost nothing; where

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs are few and far between at the best of times,

Speaker: NA
Text: we stand to lose in excess of $2.5 million funding

Speaker: NA
Text: and a valuable community asset because the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth would not partner with us on this

Speaker: NA
Text: project.

Speaker: NA
Text: As news of this poor decision becomes publicly

Speaker: NA
Text: known, people in our community will be justifia-

Speaker: NA
Text: bly outraged.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bearing these words in mind, I urge the min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister and the parliamentary secretary, who I

Speaker: NA
Text: might say have been very good to me to this

Speaker: NA
Text: point, to support this project and do the right

Speaker: NA
Text: thing for the people of Hervey Bay.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition: Coral Sea Heritage Park

Speaker: Mr TURNOUR
Text: Leichhardt) (9.44 pm)-

Speaker: NA
Text: I rise tonight to present a petition approved

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Standing Committee on Petitions. The

Speaker: NA
Text: petition has been organised by Mr Wayne

Speaker: NA
Text: Bayne, Mr Robert Erskine and other con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned citizens, who have since established

Speaker: NA
Text: the Coral Sea Access Alliance Group to

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign against the establishment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Coral Sea Heritage Park as proposed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pew Environment Group. The Pew Envi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ronment Group's proposal would effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: ban fishing and a range of other uses in more

Speaker: NA
Text: than one million square kilometres of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Coral Sea. There have been 2,053 signatures

Speaker: NA
Text: collected in support of this petition. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: not in a format that allows them to be tabled

Speaker: NA
Text: tonight but I do have them here in my hand.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nine hundred signatures were collected in

Speaker: NA
Text: one night at a meeting I attended in Cairns,

Speaker: NA
Text: organised by Mr Bayne and local fishers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Pew Coral Sea Heritage Park would

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively ban fishing in an area bordered by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and our

Speaker: NA
Text: maritime border with PNG, the Solomon Is-

Speaker: NA
Text: lands and New Caledonia. This, as I said, is

Speaker: NA
Text: Other an area of more than one million square kilo-

Speaker: NA
Text: metres of sea. The petition raises concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: about government actions ‘that will result in

Speaker: NA
Text: any usage restrictions, access or additional

Speaker: NA
Text: controls over the area known as the Coral

Speaker: NA
Text: Sea beyond those that exist under current

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation'.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have discussed the Pew proposal with a

Speaker: NA
Text: broad cross-section of the community and

Speaker: NA
Text: representative groups, including recreational

Speaker: NA
Text: and professional fishers, tourism representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives, the Super Yacht Group and environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental groups. This is a large and broad

Speaker: NA
Text: cross-section of local stakeholders and inter-

Speaker: NA
