Text: est groups, as well as many members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: local community. The vast majority of peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple see the Pew proposal as extreme and an

Speaker: NA
Text: ambit claim to lock up the Coral Sea. I share

Speaker: NA
Text: this view and have discussed this with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for the Environment, Heritage and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Arts, the Hon. Peter Garrett. Sadly, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pew proposal has divided the community

Speaker: NA
Text: and has sought to pre-empt a bioregional

Speaker: NA
Text: planning process being undertaken by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since the petition was established, the en-

Speaker: NA
Text: vironment minister has released the biore-

Speaker: NA
Text: gional plan for the area and established a

Speaker: NA
Text: conservation zone covering the Coral Sea. I

Speaker: NA
Text: sought to ensure that any conservation zon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing while the bioregional planning is pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceeding would not impact on fishers in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Coral Sea. I am pleased that the minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: ensured that this has happened. The Pew

Speaker: NA
Text: group have not got their no-take zone and I

Speaker: NA
Text: will continue to fight any such proposal. Ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: isting tourism operators and other commer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial users of the area will have to obtain free

Speaker: NA
Text: permits to continue operating. Concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: about this permit process have been raised

Speaker: NA
Text: with me by the Coral Sea Access Alliance

Speaker: NA
Text: and I will be raising these with the minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yes, the government is moving forward

Speaker: NA
Text: with its bioregional planning process, includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing consultations on whether there needs to

Speaker: NA
Text: be increased protection in the area, but no

Speaker: NA
Text: final decision has been made. People do rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ognise that this is a valuable and important

Speaker: NA
Text: area and that there are areas that need to be

Speaker: NA
Text: protected, but we need to work through a

Speaker: NA
Text: proper process, which is what the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: government is doing. I will continue working

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that fishing and other interests are

Speaker: NA
Text: considered in this process, as I did prior to

Speaker: NA
Text: the announcement of the conservation zone.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are consultation meetings in Cairns

Speaker: NA
Text: today and tomorrow as part of the biore-

Speaker: NA
Text: gional planning process. This petition high-

Speaker: NA
Text: lights concerns about government consulta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion processes when it comes to environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental issues and seeks to ensure that any

Speaker: NA
Text: consultations be ‘conducted transparently

Speaker: NA
Text: and not purely for the purpose of fulfilling a

Speaker: NA
Text: bureaucratic requirement'. In many ways

Speaker: NA
Text: people seem cynical about consultations, but

Speaker: NA
Text: it is very important that we do engage prop-

Speaker: NA
Text: erly with the community about this process. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am committed to that. I can assure petition-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers that I will be following with considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: interest these consultations and will continue

Speaker: NA
Text: to raise any issues and concerns with the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, the petition raises concerns about

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign based groups-in this case, Pew-

Speaker: NA
Text: instigating Australian environmental policy. I

Speaker: NA
Text: can assure petitioners that the Pew Environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Group, funded out of the United States,

Speaker: NA
Text: is not in control of environmental planning in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. The bioregional planning process

Speaker: NA
Text: was instigated and begun under the former

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government, following the estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lishment of the Environment Protection and

Speaker: NA
Text: Biodiversity Conservation Act. The Rudd

Speaker: NA
Text: government is moving forward with this bio-

Speaker: NA
Text: regional planning and I would encourage all

Speaker: NA
Text: those with an interest in the Coral Sea to en-

Speaker: NA
Text: gage in the consultation processes construc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively. I congratulate Mr Bayne, Mr Erskine

Speaker: NA
Text: and all of the 2,053 people who have signed

Speaker: NA
Text: these petitions in support for actively partici-

Speaker: NA
Text: pating in our Australian democracy. I look

Speaker: NA
Text: forward to the parliament's response to this

Speaker: NA
Text: petition.

Speaker: NA
Text: The petition read as follows-

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: This petition of the citizens of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Draws to the attention of the House:

Speaker: NA
Text: Our concern over any possible actions by any

Speaker: NA
Text: government departments, ministers or govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment authorities that will result in any usage re-

Speaker: NA
Text: strictions, access, or additional controls over the

Speaker: NA
Text: area known as The Coral Sea beyond those that

Speaker: NA
Text: exist under current legislation. We express con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderable concern over several aspects of the

Speaker: NA
Text: PEW Foundation's proposal to establish the Coral

Speaker: NA
Text: Sea Heritage Park and demand that this proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: be dismissed immediately in its entirety. Public

Speaker: NA
Text: consultations on previous environmental issues

Speaker: NA
Text: have been extremely poorly advertised with little

Speaker: NA
Text: concern for the public opinions expressed.

Speaker: NA
Text: We therefore ask the House to:

Speaker: NA
Text: That any proposed environmental policies in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia be instigated by Australian organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: and that Australian environmental policy be under

Speaker: NA
Text: the control of a duly elected Australian Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. In future we demand that the public consul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation process be conducted transparently and not

Speaker: NA
Text: purely for the purpose of fulfilling a bureaucratic

Speaker: NA
Text: requirement.

Speaker: NA
Text: from 1 citizen

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Coral Sea Heritage Park

Speaker: NA
Text: Herbert Electorate

Speaker: Mr LINDSAY
Text: Herbert) (9.49 pm)-I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased that the member for Leichhardt has

Speaker: NA
Text: raised this issue tonight and I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: add my contribution in relation to it. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: long been on the public record calling for the

Speaker: NA
Text: expansion of the Great Barrier Reef Marine

Speaker: NA
Text: Park to cover further coral reefs in that area.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been particularly concerned about the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact on the shark fishery in that area. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is where there have been some very signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant adverse effects from unscrupulous fish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers, and the shark population should be better

Speaker: NA
Text: protected. I am hoping that will be an out-

Speaker: NA
Text: come of the current government's process in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the Coral Sea.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tonight I want to raise the issue of how

Speaker: NA
Text: Townsville people have been done in the eye

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Rudd government and I will give sev-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral examples. The member for Blair will

Speaker: NA
Text: know that I have Australia's largest defence

Speaker: NA
Text: base in my electorate, and we have had this

Speaker: NA
Text: conversation previously. I may bring 9 FSB

Speaker: NA
Text: up to Townsville, sir, so watch out!

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing at Lavarack Barracks on 12 No-

Speaker: NA
Text: vember 2007, the current Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: promised to increase defence spending by at

Speaker: NA
Text: least three per cent real annually to 2016. He

Speaker: NA
Text: said:

Speaker: NA
Text: We believe that those in uniform, our men

Speaker: NA
Text: women in uniform who serve our country with

Speaker: NA
Text: distinction deserve that level of certainty …

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet the heart of Labor's Pappas review into

Speaker: NA
Text: defence was to slash spending. In the 2009-

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 budget, Defence has been required to

Speaker: NA
Text: make $20 billion worth of savings over 10

Speaker: NA
Text: years. It is a case of the Rudd government

Speaker: NA
Text: giving with one hand and then taking back

Speaker: NA
Text: with the other.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then there is the other broken promise,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was particularly felt in my electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: of Herbert, where the Prime Minister and the

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow minister for defence at the time indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated that the first of the new family medical

Speaker: NA
Text: centres that Labor were promising would be

Speaker: NA
Text: opened in both Townsville and Darwin. Well,

Speaker: NA
Text: neither Townsville nor Darwin has received a

Speaker: NA
Text: family medical centre but other centres have.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a clear broken promise in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Defence Force.

Speaker: NA
Text: Look at the promise of the national broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: band network. In March 2001 Mr Rudd said:

Speaker: NA
Text: We're proposing to invest up to $4.7 billion in

Speaker: NA
Text: this proposal …

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Rudd also promised that it would be

Speaker: NA
Text: commenced in late 2008. Now there is a new

Speaker: NA
Text: plan, and the new plan will not cost $4.7 bil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lion but $43 billion. The promise was that

Speaker: NA
Text: construction would commence by late

Speaker: NA
Text: 2008-yet another broken promise. There

Speaker: NA
Text: has been no construction commenced and we

Speaker: NA
Text: will not likely see any construction for some

Speaker: NA
Text: time. My community of Magnetic Island,

Speaker: NA
Text: near Townsville, is not even going to be cov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ered by the national broadband network.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is quite extraordinary for a community

Speaker: NA
Text: like Magnetic Island.

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to roads, the Douglas arterial

Speaker: NA
Text: received $55 million to become four lanes in

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget before last. Do you know how

Speaker: NA
Text: much work has been done on that four-laning

Speaker: NA
Text: project? None. We do not even know when it

Speaker: NA
Text: might start. The ring road is finished but the

Speaker: NA
Text: and four-laning of the Douglas arterial, which

Speaker: NA
Text: was to take the extra volume of traffic gener-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated by the ring road, does not even have a

Speaker: NA
Text: commencement date at this stage, yet it is

Speaker: NA
Text: supposed to be and is touted as being a na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion-building project. How can it be a nation-

Speaker: NA
Text: building project if it is not being built?

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to private health insurance, in a

Speaker: NA
Text: letter to the Australian Health Insurance As-

Speaker: NA
Text: sociation on 20 November 2007, Kevin Rudd

Speaker: NA
Text: said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Labor is committed to retaining the exist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing private health insurance rebates.

Speaker: NA
Text: Never was an election promise given so em-

Speaker: NA
Text: phatically and then broken so brazenly. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: had such a terrible flow-on into the public

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital system and the private hospital sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem in Townsville, but that is another story

Speaker: NA
Text: for another day. On ABC TV on Wednesday

Speaker: NA
Text: night the Prime Minister, under pressure

Speaker: NA
Text: from unions wanting the abolition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Building and Construction Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner, was very quick to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: We will be adhering to our pre-election commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I take absolutely seriously my commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Australian people prior to the last

Speaker: NA
Text: I just wish he would ‘take absolutely seri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously' all of his other commitments. Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: keep election promises when it suits them

Speaker: NA
Text: and break them when it does not. The Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian people cannot ever again trust what

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Labor Party tells them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Herbert Morton Olm

Speaker: Mr NEUMANN
Text: Blair) (9.54 pm)-I am

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking tonight about a remarkable individ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ual. His name is Herbert Morton Olm. He

Speaker: NA
Text: was born at Ropeley in the Lockyer Valley

Speaker: NA
Text: on 7 August 1908. He is still with us. He is a

Speaker: NA
Text: much loved and respected and popular figure

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Laidley Tabeel aged-care home. Until

Speaker: NA
Text: recently he lived on the family farm at Rope-

Speaker: NA
Text: ley with the support of his family. His grand-

Speaker: NA
Text: son Joshua works for me as an electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: officer and is the treasurer of my branch of

Speaker: NA
Text: the ALP, the Raceview Flinders branch in

Speaker: NA
Text: Ipswich.

Speaker: NA
Text: Herb is an interesting character. Herb

Speaker: NA
Text: joined the Labor Party in 1930. He would

Speaker: NA
Text: have joined earlier but in Queensland at that

Speaker: NA
Text: stage you had to wait until you were 21 to

Speaker: NA
Text: join the Labor Party. In Queensland now you

Speaker: NA
Text: can join the Labor Party at 15 years of age.

Speaker: NA
Text: He was made a life member of the party in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1978. In 1936 he married the love of his life,

Speaker: NA
Text: Maud, and they were blessed with eight chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren and many grandchildren and great-

Speaker: NA
Text: grandchildren. He was appointed a Justice of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Peace in 1934, one of only three in Gat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ton at the time, and he is Queensland's long-

Speaker: NA
Text: est serving JP. The most remarkable thing

Speaker: NA
Text: about his life is this: he lived all his life in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Lockyer Valley, which has always been a

Speaker: NA
Text: fairly conservative area. It is part of my elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate but traditionally it has voted conserva-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive. He has been involved in many coopera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive and society activities in the Lockyer Val-

Speaker: NA
Text: ley and is a Lockyer legend. In fact, the for-

Speaker: NA
Text: mer conservative state member for Lockyer

Speaker: NA
Text: described him as a one of the 10 most impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: election. tant people in the Lockyer Valley.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the most interesting things about

Speaker: NA
Text: Herb is that in 1960 he managed to convince

Speaker: NA
Text: a very young police officer called Bill Hay-

Speaker: NA
Text: den that he should run for the seat of Oxley.

Speaker: NA
Text: Oxley was created in 1949 and held by the

Speaker: NA
Text: then health minister, Don Cameron. Oxley

Speaker: NA
Text: had existed before, but it had been renamed

Speaker: NA
Text: Griffith in 1934. But it had never been held

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Labor Party. Bill won it with a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: markable swing of 9.4 per cent. Herb took

Speaker: NA
Text: nine months off from the family farm to go

Speaker: NA
Text: full-time campaigning with Bill Hayden.

Speaker: NA
Text: Herb wrote many speeches. Bill was a young

Speaker: NA
Text: fellow and he had Dallas with him in an old

Speaker: NA
Text: car and they drove around all over the place.

Speaker: NA
Text: Herb introduced Bill to many farmers, cat-

Speaker: NA
Text: tlemen and people involved in all kinds of

Speaker: NA
Text: activities in the Lockyer Valley.

Speaker: NA
Text: On Herb's 100th birthday, Bill Hayden

Speaker: NA
Text: spoke movingly and brilliantly at the Gatton

Speaker: NA
Text: Shire Hall. Many people were there, includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Minister for Ageing, Justine Elliot.

Speaker: NA
Text: There were messages from all and sundry,

Speaker: NA
Text: from political leaders and one from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queen. The mayor of the Lockyer Valley

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional Council was there, and I was hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: oured to be there among the 160 people. Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: attributed much of the swing that he got in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1961 to Herb. He spoke almost tearfully

Speaker: NA
Text: about what Herb had done for him: the men-

Speaker: NA
Text: toring, the advice, the counselling, the people

Speaker: NA
Text: Herb had introduced him to. His sage help

Speaker: NA
Text: was invaluable in Bill winning in 1961. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have Bill's old seat and it is very much as it

Speaker: NA
Text: was in 1961, except I have got Boonah in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stead of Esk.

Speaker: NA
Text: People like Herb who have lived all their

Speaker: NA
Text: lives campaigning and being involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: community activities like Blue Care and

Speaker: NA
Text: many other voluntary things should be hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: oured. We should cherish them. People like

Speaker: NA
Text: Herb are not just an institution and a legend

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Lockyer Valley; they are to be admired

Speaker: NA
Text: and respected. His generation is a great gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration. His contribution to political life and

Speaker: NA
Text: community life in the Lockyer Valley cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: be underestimated. I want to pay tribute to

Speaker: NA
Text: Herb and thank him for his generational con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tribution: now his grandson is helping me

Speaker: NA
Text: and his family has been involved in helping

Speaker: NA
Text: run Labor Party campaigns and helping the

Speaker: NA
Text: cause of the labour movement for genera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. Thank you, Herb, for the life you have

Speaker: NA
Text: lived. Thank you for what you have done for

Speaker: NA
Text: me, Bill Hayden and all those people who

Speaker: NA
Text: hold the principles of the Labor Party and the

Speaker: NA
Text: labour movement so dear. Well done, Herb.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: House adjourned at 9.59 pm
